HEADLINE: Essay; 
Arik And George

BYLINE:  By WILLIAM SAFIRE 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON 

 BODY:
President Bush recalled the helicopter tour of the West Bank given him by Ariel Sharon three years ago. The Israeli prime minister, who knows every ridge and wadi of Judea and Samaria, smiled ruefully and said that such a low-flying tour was not possible these days because the chopper would be vulnerable to Palestinian fire.
 The way to suppress such guerrilla gunfire was clear in the White House visitor's mind: Begin negotiations only when Yasir Arafat realizes that violence no longer pays. When the Palestinian leader publicly and privately takes action to turn off terror, Israel's economic retaliation will end, allowing an interim state of nonbelligerency to be negotiated. 
 Apparently Bush understands Sharon's requirement for "quiet" before talks begin. It would be foolish to transfer tax revenues to Palestinian buyers of rockets and mortar shells. In early April, the U.S. president will welcome Egypt's Hosni Mubarak and Jordan's King Abdullah to the White House, showing he is open to ideas from peaceful Arabs, but he has pointedly not invited Arafat.
That's because nobody should be allowed to shoot his way into the White House. An invitation should be an incentive. After Arafat decides to order his well-armed Force 17 to cease firing on Israelis, and after he re-jails Hamas bombers and publicly calls on his followers to stop the war, that will be the time for a visit. 
Another incentive for stopping the violence would be to show Arafat that a policy of killing has consequences. Bush told reporters, "During the campaign I said we'll begin the process of moving our embassy to Jerusalem." (His words last May were, "As soon as I take office, I will begin the process of moving the U.S. ambassador to the city Israel has chosen as its capital.") Secretary of State Powell reiterated that to Congress two weeks ago: "President Bush is committed to moving our embassy to Jerusalem. The process is ongoing. We have not started any actions yet." 
So? Bush has taken office; when does the "ongoing" process go on? The message would be unmistakable: The U.S. recognizes that Israel's capital is Jerusalem. If Israel one day negotiates away a portion of the city to be a Palestinian capital, the U.S. will build an embassy there, too. In the meantime, the insult to Israel's sovereign right to choose its capital should end.
Sharon did not press this point. Nor did he come to Washington with what Golda Meir used to call a shopping basket, seeking aid. On the contrary, the most significant discussions that took place were those least publicly discussed: strategic military cooperation on missile defense.
Israeli technicians with U.S. financing have for years been developing the Arrow antimissile missile. It is a generation beyond the gulf war's souped-up Patriots. At nine times the speed of sound, the Arrow is designed to seek an incoming missile in mid-course phase, which can be over 100,000 feet. I'm told it has had some successful tests in the past two years on dummy missiles. 
Without the most sophisticated guidance system, its results would be hit-or-miss. But Israel's Arrow may one day be coupled with our Aegis phased-array radar missile-tracking systems aboard U.S. naval vessels in the eastern Mediterranean. An Arrow-Aegis system jointly operated by the U.S. and Israel could counter the threat from weapons of mass destruction now being built in Iraq and Iran with aid from Russia and North Korea.
Neither Sharon nor Bush is fixated on the Palestinian problem to the exclusion of other fronts in the Middle East. When Foreign Minister Hubert Vedrine of France arrives here next week, Bush should send this message to President Jacques Chirac in newly Socialist Paris: How about reasserting France's traditional interest in Lebanon?
Syria now occupies that once-independent nation, hosting Iran's Hezbollah terrorists. Five years ago, Chirac told Beirut, "The Lebanese Army and internal security forces must, following total Israeli withdrawal, be the only guarantors of the State's authority," enabling Syrian forces to withdraw.
Israel is out; why isn't Chirac's France enlisting European allies to enforce U.N. Resolution 425, freeing Lebanon from Syrian occupation? That would strike a blow against regional terror.
With new leaders, Israel and the U.S. have disenthralled themselves. Time to think anew and act anew.

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: STOCKS & BONDS; 
Shares Slide Further as Dow Nears Bear Market Territory

BYLINE:  By MICHAEL BRICK 

 BODY:
Stocks fell sharply yesterday, with losses spreading to sectors that often thrive alongside a reviving economy, taking the Dow Jones industrial average to its lowest point in more than two years.
 The stock market's latest stumble came after a sharp and broad decline on Tuesday, when the Federal Reserve acted less aggressively in its effort to resuscitate the economy than some investors had hoped. The central bank lowered short-term interest rates by half a percentage point, leading to selling by investors who had bid up technology stocks in hopes of a three-quarter-point cut. 
 Cyclical stocks, which are usually among the first to rise when the Fed stimulates borrowing and spending, took heavy losses yesterday. But so did food and drug stocks, which investors often add to their portfolios to weather an economic storm. 
"The market is still trying to come to grips with, short term at least, what they wanted Greenspan to do," said John C. Forelli, an institutional money manager for Independence Investment Associates, referring to Alan Greenspan, the Fed chairman.
The Dow industrials fell 233.76, or 2.4 percent, to 9,487.00, its lowest close since March 4, 1999. The Dow is now 19.1 percent below its closing high of 11,722.98 on Jan. 14, 2000, and is just 108.62 points shy of joining the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index and the Nasdaq composite index in bear market territory.
In general, technology stocks fell by a smaller percentage, but the day's trading was volatile. The technology-weighted Nasdaq fell 27.21 points, or 1.5 percent, to 1,830.23. Losses by technology stocks weighed on the S.& P. 500, which fell 20.48, or 1.8 percent, to 1,122.14.
New evidence appeared yesterday that investors were disenchanted by the markets or were unwilling to commit themselves to stocks. Mutual fund investors removed $11.4 billion from equity funds in February, transferring the bulk to money market accounts, according to Lipper Inc., a mutual fund industry research firm. It was the first net decrease in stock fund assets that the firm has recorded since August 1998, but it came after an increase of $140 billion in January.
The investors who remained in stocks, meanwhile, were becoming increasingly concerned about the prospects for corporate earnings as the economy cools.
"I think everybody is just confused," said Ned Collins, head trader at Daiwa Securities America. "I do believe that earnings are going to be the key factor."
Investors who had once hoped slumping earnings would be confined to the technology sector now seem less assured. Caterpillar fell $1.69, to $42.18; International Paper dropped $1.83, to $35.53; and Alcoa fell $1.64, to $34.64. Pharmaceutical and food stocks, often bought as a shelter from an economic storm, also declined. Coca-Cola fell $2.18, to $45.25, and Johnson & Johnson fell $3.57, to $87.23.
Biotechnology stocks helped lead the decline in the technology sector. Amgen fell $5.88, to $55.44; Idec Pharmaceuticals lost $7.06, to $42.06, and Biogen dropped $3.44, to $56.88.
Based on price-to-earnings ratios, however, many technology stocks are becoming fairly valued on a historical basis for the first time in three years, in Mr. Forelli's view.
"The question is if you can believe the earnings," he said. It was a question investors seemed to be asking themselves about many other sectors as well.
 --------------------

Treasury Prices Fall
 (By Reuters) -- Bond prices fell yesterday along with stocks after the Federal Reserve cut interest rates less than investors hoped on Tuesday.
John Canavan, an analyst at Stone & McCarthy Research Associates in Princeton, N.J., said investors continued to hold interest-rate-sensitive short-term securities rather than long-term issues after the Fed suggested in its post-meeting statement that it was poised to cut interest rates before its next scheduled meeting on May 15, if necessary.
The price of the 10-year Treasury note fell 5/32, to 101 26/32. The yield, which moves in the opposite direction from the price, rose to 4.77 percent from 4.75 percent on Tuesday.
The 30-year bond fell 6/32, to 101 16/32. Its yield rose to 5.27 percent from 5.26 percent on Tuesday.

CORRECTION-DATE: March 24, 2001

 CORRECTION:
An article in Business Day on Thursday about trading in the stock market on Wednesday carried an incorrect figure from the mutual fund research company Lipper Inc. for the money that investors withdrew from stock funds in February. It was $2.4 billion, not $11.4 billion.

HEADLINE: Giuliani, Citing Economy, Seeks Cuts in Agency Budgets 

BYLINE:  By ERIC LIPTON 

 BODY:
Citing the slowdown in the national economy, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani announced yesterday that he had instructed city agencies to prepare to cut spending over the next 15 months by as much as $500 million, a belt-tightening he said might prove unnecessary but was prudent given Wall Street's recent troubles.
 The budget cut requests -- generally 2 percent in the current fiscal year and 6 percent for the 2002 fiscal year, which starts July 1 -- have been sent out to all city agencies, the mayor said. But the reductions, if they went into effect, would not be across the board, the mayor said, hinting already that his traditionally well-treated Police Department, among other agencies, might be largely spared. 
 "The art of governing is making choices," Mr. Giuliani said. "Public safety may be more important than something else." 
The mayor said he was confident the city could handle any cuts without significantly curtailing services. But the announcement -- the letter requesting the cuts actually went out a month ago -- drew an immediate rebuke yesterday from City Council officials, who said it might be little more than an effort by the mayor to increase pressure on unions to settle contract talks for less money.
"Political huffing and puffing has begun," Council Speaker Peter F. Vallone said through a spokesman.
To date, despite the plunge in the financial markets and the wave of layoffs nationwide, the most recent available data suggest that the city economy continues to grow, with 17,100 private jobs reportedly added in January and an unemployment rate of 4.9 percent, the lowest since 1988. City tax revenues through February were $127 million ahead of the mayor's latest projection, Comptroller Alan G. Hevesi said yesterday.
But about a sixth of city tax revenues are generated by Wall Street firms and other financial institutions, many of which are off to a bad year. Mr. Giuliani cautioned yesterday that there was no reason for alarm. The city now projects to reach the end of this fiscal year, June 30, with a $2.3 billion surplus in its $39.67 billion budget. The administration, he said, is just trying to anticipate any major downturn.
"You always prepare for the worst and hope for the best, and I think probably that is the way it is going to work out," the mayor said.
Mayor Giuliani has already proposed a $39.32 billion budget for the 2002 fiscal year, which includes many cuts to agencies that manage city parks, libraries and programs for the elderly and to city museums, among other areas. When he released this plan in January, the mayor said that these cuts -- many of which he proposes each year -- were little more than bargaining chips to discourage the City Council from trying to expand spending. 
If that first round of cuts were combined with the new reductions he has requested, the impact could be severe. For the Brooklyn Public Library, for example, $8.2 million was slated to be cut as part of Mr. Giuliani's January budget plan; if an additional 6 percent reduction is to be found, the library will lose $3.6 million more, meaning a total reduction of 17 percent in its $68.6 million city appropriation. Brooklyn library officials said that total cut would force 59 of its branches to reduce their schedules from mostly six days a week to four. 
"The Council will ensure that vital city services will be protected," Mr. Vallone said.
Council officials said they expected that before any major service reductions were considered, the mayor would trim back the $401 million in tax cuts he had proposed in the 2002 budget, including the elimination of the city's sales tax on clothing, costing $181 million.
The mayor said he had no plans for now to modify his tax cut plan. But negotiations with the Council over the 2002 budget will not formally begin until April, after the mayor releases a more final spending plan.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani said the city should prepare for the worst. (Ruby Washington/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Court Says Employers Can Require Arbitration of Disputes 

BYLINE:  By LINDA GREENHOUSE 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 21 

 BODY:
The Supreme Court handed employers a major victory today by ruling that companies can insist that workplace disputes go to arbitration rather than to court.
 The 5-to-4 decision resolved a disagreement among the lower federal courts about the scope of the Federal Arbitration Act, a 76-year-old law that makes arbitration agreements enforceable in federal court. 
 While the law indisputably applied to a wide variety of commercial disputes, the disagreement, based on an awkwardly worded exemption for at least certain workers, was over whether it covered employment contracts.
Reading the exemption narrowly, the majority said today that Congress intended to exempt only transportation workers from the law's reach. Justice Anthony M. Kennedy wrote the majority opinion, which was joined by Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist and by Justices Sandra Day O'Connor, Antonin Scalia and Clarence Thomas. 
Encouraged by earlier Supreme Court decisions treating arbitration favorably, employers are increasingly requiring workers to agree in advance to take any employment-related dispute to binding arbitration as a way of avoiding costly and prolonged litigation.
But while siding with a majority of the lower courts on the overall scope of the arbitration law, the court left unresolved some important questions about what rights workers might retain under other federal laws, like the major antidiscrimination laws that guarantee the right to punitive damages and legal fees. Many arbitration agreements cap damages at lower levels and do not guarantee that employees who prevail can recover their costs. It is also unclear whether arbitration agreements can preclude class actions.
Quoting language from an earlier arbitration case, Justice Kennedy said that under arbitration, a party gives up a judicial forum but "does not forgo the substantive rights afforded by the statute." 
One arbitration specialist, David Gibbs, a lawyer in Boston who advises corporate clients on setting up alternative dispute resolution systems, said today that there were dozens of cases in the lower courts addressing the elements that make up a fair arbitration program. The trend in the lower courts has been to ensure that workers receive the remedies available under federal law.
The case today began in 1997 as a discrimination suit under California law by a salesman for Circuit City Stores. Circuit City tried to enforce its standard arbitration agreement, which the salesman, St. Clair Adams, signed when he was hired two years earlier. The agreement made all "disputes or controversies" relating to employment at Circuit City subject to final, binding arbitration.
On the basis of that agreement, the Federal District Court in San Francisco barred Mr. Adams's lawsuit. But the United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit, also in San Francisco, ruled that the agreement was not enforceable because the Federal Arbitration Act did not apply to employment contracts. With the Ninth Circuit being the biggest of the federal circuits, covering nine Western states, the decision alarmed the business community. Every other appeals court to have considered the question had found the arbitration act to apply to employment.
The linguistic difficulty with the law came from an exemption clause providing that the statute did not apply "to contracts of employment of seamen, railroad employees, or any other class of workers engaged in foreign or interstate commerce." What categories of employees was Congress excluding from federally enforced mandatory arbitration?
To the judges of the Ninth Circuit, the most natural reading was that Congress meant to exclude all employment contracts, particularly in light of the legislative history that showed that Congress was interested in making commercial contracts subject to arbitration as quickly as possible by assuaging the concerns of organized labor over bringing any employment contracts under the new law.
Under the Supreme Court's precedents at the time, Congress's jurisdiction over the economy was extremely narrow, so the exclusion referred only to those categories of employment over which Congress indisputably had jurisdiction.
The other federal appeals courts, however, had read the exclusion narrowly to apply, today as in 1925, only to workers in the transportation industries. That was the correct interpretation, Justice Kennedy said today, because to give a more elastic meaning to the phrase "engaged in foreign or interstate commerce" would be to "bring instability to statutory interpretation." Consequently, the exemption applies only to "contracts of employment of transportation workers," Justice Kennedy said.
That conclusion in itself opened new questions for resolution in future cases. How should courts define transportation workers -- for example, a ticket agent for an airline? A delivery truck driver for Circuit City?
In a dissenting opinion, Justice David H. Souter said the court was "imputing something very odd to the working of the Congressional brain" by concluding that Congress excluded coverage of "the class of employment contracts it most obviously had authority to legislate about in 1925" while extending the law to a much larger category of employees over whom federal jurisdiction was then highly uncertain.
"It would seem to have made more sense either to cover all coverable employment contracts or to exclude them all," Justice Souter said, noting that Congress might well have made the policy judgment that "arbitration could prove expensive or unfavorable to employees, many of whom lack the bargaining power to resist an arbitration clause if their prospective employers insist on one."
Justice John Paul Stevens wrote a more sharply worded dissent. By its "refusal to look beyond the raw statutory text," he said, the court "misuses its authority." Justice Stevens added: "A method of statutory interpretation that is deliberately uninformed, and hence unconstrained, may produce a result that is consistent with a court's own views of how things should be, but it may also defeat the very purpose for which a provision was enacted."
The other two dissenting justices, Ruth Bader Ginsburg and Stephen Breyer, signed both of the dissenting opinions.
Among the questions left open by the decision, Circuit City Stores v. Adams, No. 99-1379, was what role remains for federal administrative agencies, like the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission, in pursuing enforcement actions on behalf of employees who are covered by arbitration agreements.
The court will decide shortly whether to hear an appeal by the E.E.O.C. from a decision by the federal appeals court in Richmond, Va., that it could not seek relief like backpay, damages or reinstatement on behalf of workers covered by arbitration agreements. The agency is arguing in that case, E.E.O.C. v. Waffle House Inc., No. 99-1823, that it was not a party to the agreement and that in seeking relief on the part of individuals, it is vindicating important public rights.
In a second labor decision today, the court ruled 7 to 2 that a federal law, the Employee Retirement Income Security Act of 1974, pre-empts state law on the designation of beneficiaries of Erisa-covered pension plans. In this case, Egelhoff v. Egelhoff, No. 99-1529, a man who was recently divorced died without a will and without removing his wife's name as the beneficiary of his pension. Under Washington State law, the benefits would have gone to his children by an earlier marriage, but the court ruled today that the Erisa designation should prevail.

HEADLINE: BOLDFACE NAMES 

BYLINE:  By James Barron 

 BODY:
That's Pleather, With a P
 ROSIE O'DONNELL has agreed to say it isn't so. People for the Ethical Treatment of Animals went to court demanding a retraction when she said that the Gap was selling leather that the animal-rights group approved of. Not so, said the group's president, INGRID E. NEWKIRK -- there is no such thing as "PETA-approved leather." 
 Ms. O'Donnell's comment came after the Gap chain promised to stop selling leather from India and China. That promise came, in turn, after Ms. Newkirk and the rock singer CHRISSIE HYNDE were arrested during a protest at a Gap store in Manhattan.
Yesterday, Ms. Newkirk said that PETA's $350,000 lawsuit against Ms. O'Donnell had been settled and that Ms. O'Donnell would read a 111-word clarification on her syndicated talk show. Ms. Newkirk said Ms. O'Donnell had been in on the writing. "She added a part in which she added she wears pleather pants on occasion," Ms. Newkirk said. Pleather is, after all, synthetic.

Off Camera, but in Surgery
On camera, LORRAINE BRACCO shoulders the burden of being Tony's psychotherapist on the HBO mob opera "The Sopranos." Off camera, her shoulder has been giving her trouble, and yesterday DR. STUART HERSHON, the team physician of the New York Yankees, operated on it at Beth Israel Medical Center's Singer Division, on the Upper East Side. Ms. Bracco went home by midafternoon and was doing fine, an HBO spokeswoman said. The operation will not keep Ms. Bracco away from the show: the last few scenes for this season's episodes were filmed last month.

Gore and Greenspan, in Tandem
Once again, AL GORE'S Wednesday class at Columbia University featured the kind of question-and-answer session that nonstudent reporters would have loved to be in on. The answerer was ALAN GREENSPAN, chairman of the Federal Reserve, which cut interest rates half a percentage point when many investors had hoped for more.
Mr. Gore pre-empted Mr. Greenspan's answer to one question, according to a student quoted by Dow Jones. The question had to do with whether one could predict the turnaround speed of a recession-bound economy, and Mr. Gore gave the answer: if plotted on a fever chart, a recovery "could be a U, or it could be an L, like a hockey stick, or a V and, if the wrong choices are made, it could be a W."
Another student said that when Mr. Gore finished his by-the-letter explanation, he and Mr. Greenspan high-fived each other.

Watch the Screen, and Wince
There were two Kates (the actress KATE HUDSON, top right, and the magazine editor KATE BETTS) and a Stuart at a party for Ms. Hudson's new film, "About Adam." The Stuart -- STUART TOWNSEND, who plays Adam, a Lothario from Dublin -- hedged on whether he was a real-life Lothario from Dublin. He said something about how acting was about "getting to do something a little further removed from who you are." He said he wished he had been a little further removed from the pre-party screening of "About Adam." "Normally I go to the pub, but this time I decided to watch it," he said. "Bad news. I should have gone to the pub." Why? "I thought it was depressing. You always go, 'What was I doing? Sleepwalking?' "
So what will he say if he watches the film he just finished, "Queen of the Damned," the sequel to "Interview With a Vampire"? Playing the vampire Tom Cruise made famous, Mr. Townsend discovered his inner rock 'n' roller. "I did a gig for 3,000 people in the desert in Australia," he said, "and I realized that acting really wasn't half as much fun as getting on stage and prancing around."
But enough with these movies. Mr. Townsend recently co-starred in a London production of "Orpheus Descending" and wants to do more theater. "It's where you learn," he said. "All the rest is just money and chauffeurs."

HEADLINE: Iraqis Now Daring to Talk of Life After Hussein 

BYLINE:  By JOHN F. BURNS 

DATELINE: BAGHDAD, Iraq, March 15 

 BODY:
On the eve of the gulf war 10 years ago, a Westerner visiting Baghdad could be sure of one constant in any conversation with an Iraqi -- obsequious praise of Saddam Hussein, Iraq's often merciless ruler.
 Usually, the phrases about "the Iraqi people's great leader, His Excellency Saddam Hussein," and the "glorious era" of his rule would have an edge of urgency, as if only an excessive display of loyalty could ward off the retribution Mr. Hussein has been known to exact for dissent, including summary executions of whole families. 
 But a visit to Iraq shows that even if little has altered in the way Mr. Hussein maintains control, something else has changed. 
Where once the verbal genuflecting would pour forth unprompted, it is now possible for a visitor to go days without anyone but the government "minder" who accompanies every visiting foreigner mentioning Mr. Hussein. More than that, growing numbers of Iraqis, seizing moments when the minders are distracted, are ready to take the risk of whispering their fear of the Iraqi ruler and the deep-seated hatred that they say he has engendered among this country's 23 million people.
Even more remarkable, officials at senior levels have begun to speak of a time when Mr. Hussein will no longer be the country's ruler, and even, in two interviews in the past 15 days, to allude to his eventual death.
Altogether, the changes could suggest that at 63 Mr. Hussein is seriously ill. A decade ago, for a foreigner even to hint that Mr. Hussein might be mortal was to court expulsion, and for an Iraqi official to do so was unknown. 
The first of the two senior officials to broach the subject of Mr. Hussein in interviews was Abdul-Karim al-Hashemi, a former higher education minister with a doctorate in geochemistry from Boston University who heads the Organization of Friendship, Peace and Solidarity, an agency that is a prominent part of Baghdad's machinery for greeting foreigners. At the start of the interview, he was asked what he thought Americans should know about the state of affairs in Iraq.
Almost immediately, he began a discourse about the durability of the Baghdad regime and how it was not solely reliant on its current leader.
"To this day, people in America and Britain do not know that Saddam Hussein is not heading a one-man show," he said. "They don't know that the system Saddam Hussein has put in place is operating, not deteriorating, and not only operating, but developing."
Ten days later, a more senior official, Human Abdul Khaliq al-Ghaffour, inquired about the reporter's personal experiences as a lymphoma patient, a decade ago, and asked whether his visitor's lymphoma, a form of cancer, had spread to his bone marrow, and whether he had undergone a bone marrow transplant. 
After arguing briefly that the United States should open a "dialogue" with Iraq, Mr. Khaliq then turned unprompted to the issue of Mr. Hussein's mortality. "We are proud of Saddam Hussein, of course, but we are realists," he said. "Even after years of his long life, and I hope that he will stay forever, we are human beings, we know that there is an end to life. But we have thousands of Saddam Husseins now, so we have nothing to fear, this is the reality."
Mr. Khaliq is regarded by Western intelligence as one of perhaps two dozen men who form an inner circle around Mr. Hussein. He has been information minister since 1997; before that, for 10 years until 1992, he was chairman of Iraq's Atomic Energy Commission and thus, according to Western intelligence reports, was deeply involved in Iraq's efforts to build nuclear weapons. Mr. Khaliq, 54, holds a doctorate in nuclear physics from London University.
Later, when Mr. Khaliq's remarks were passed along to other Iraqis, during moments of unmonitored conversation, several reacted with something approaching nonchalance, as if they had known that Mr. Hussein was not well. One man said his family had ties with the Iraqi leader going back nearly 20 years but that nobody in the family had seen him lately. He added: "But of course, he's sick. He's very sick. We know that."
Another man, a physician, said it was known that Mr. Hussein was ill, and that many Iraqis were commenting privately about the Iraqi ruler's seeming pallor and weight loss during recent appearances on television. But added, "If we talk of that, it's KALABOSH" -- an Arab word meaning handcuffs.
Rumors like these have surfaced before only to recede as the Iraqi ruler vigorously carried on. After talk five years ago that he had Hodgkin's disease, a form of lymphoma, Mr. Hussein appeared on television to boast that he was fit enough to swim the Tigris. Politically, too, he has seemed in many ways stronger than ever. 
In the face of the harsh economic sanctions against Iraq over the past decade, he has defied the Western world over his secret weapons arsenal, and Iraqis say, exiles assert, enriched himself, his family and his cronies from black market dealings while millions of his countrymen have fallen into destitution.
While blaming the West for Iraq's deepening poverty, he has continued building vast marble palaces in Baghdad and other cities.
More specific rumors circulating now mostly come from Arab-language newspapers published outside Iraq that rely heavily on exiled Iraqi opposition groups. Some say one of his palaces has been turned into a clinic, some say the younger of his two sons, Qusai, stands ready to take control. Earlier this month, the Washington Times carried a report that Mr. Hussein had informed his family and senior aides in December that he was dying, and said that that Secretary of State Colin L. Powell "is reputed to give this intelligence assessment credibility."
This welter of rumor has provoked widespread doubts. At Western embassies in the region, officials familiar with the most recent intelligence reports remain skeptical that the Iraqi leader is ill, telling reporters that they have no evidence to indicate that, and cautioning that the Iraqis may be spreading the rumors as part of a "disinformation campaign" to weaken support for the economic sanctions.
"If there was some reason to believe that Saddam might be removed from the scene within weeks or months, then there might be less receptivity to a hard-line position on sanctions," one Western diplomat commented.
The Central Intelligence Agency, for its part, has been dismissive of such rumors. "I wouldn't attach credibility to rumors that Saddam is seriously ill," said one American intelligence official.
This time, Mr. Hussein has offered no public denial that he is ill. But he has responded in a way, by keeping up a vigorous schedule of official duties; Iraqi newspapers and broadcasts detail his every meeting with a foreign dignitary, or with his cabinet
At one of those appearances, a military parade in Baghdad four months ago, remained in the bitter cold for 13 hours, repeatedly firing a hunting rifle with one hand to salute the battalions marching past, and impressing diplomats with his stamina. At one point, hearing some of the guests complaining about the cold, he ordered an aide to fetch them warm clothing.
Some diplomats who were present, having heard the rumors of cancer, wondered if they were looking at a double. But an ambassador from a neighboring country, who greeted Mr. Hussein and shook his hand, said he had no doubt it was Mr. Hussein.
"Looking at him out there in the cold, firing that rifle, you couldn't imagine any guy stronger than him," he said. "And when he ordered warm clothes -- well, the way his assistants reacted, snapping to attention, it could only have been the real Saddam."

HEADLINE: Republicans Consider Increasing Tax Cut at Low End 

BYLINE:  By DAVID E. ROSENBAUM and RICHARD W. STEVENSON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 21 

 BODY:
Facing criticism that President Bush's tax plan is too generous to the wealthy and not responsive to the faltering economy, Republicans in Congress moved today to make tax cuts more favorable to low-income taxpayers and to get money into people's pockets quicker.
 The chairman of the House Ways and Means Committee, Representative Bill Thomas of California, announced that he had rewritten two of the main aspects of the Bush plan to give more benefits to the less affluent. The committee is scheduled to vote on Mr. Thomas's proposals on Thursday. 
 In the Senate, Republican leaders have been meeting to find ways to make a tax cut applicable right away. Among the possibilities under consideration, a staff assistant said, was a temporary suspension of part of workers' Social Security and Medicare withholding taxes and an increase in the amount of income subject to the lowest tax rate.
In the House, the Budget Committee approved, on a party-line vote, a budget outline that would set aside $1.62 trillion for tax relief over the next 10 years. The committee approved the plan 23-19 after rejecting a series of Democratic amendments.
Two weeks ago, the House approved the central element of the president's tax plan, an across-the-board reduction in income-tax rates that would save taxpayers nearly $1 trillion over the next decade.
Today, Mr. Thomas addressed two other parts of the president's plan: lower taxes for married couples and an expanded tax credit for families with children. In both instances, Mr. Thomas expanded the benefits for taxpayers with low and moderate incomes, a step that is likely to attract at least some Democratic votes.
Mr. Thomas's proposals would increase the 10-year cost of these two elements of the president's plan by about a third, to about $400 billion from about $300 billion.
The full House could vote on these proposals as early as next week.
The budget resolution adopted tonight by the House Budget Committee provides for tax cuts of at least the size sought by Mr. Bush, and would allow them to be phased in on a slightly more accelerated schedule than originally sought by the White House.
The Budget Committee plan would also hold overall spending increases to lower levels than in recent years, but it left open the option of providing more money later in the year for two areas with powerful constituencies, the military and agriculture.
The budget resolution is a nonbinding blueprint intended to guide the tax and appropriations committees as they do their work. It generally tracked the budget sent to Congress this month by Mr. Bush, but altered it in a few respects. 
The House plan would place more restrictions than the White House version on use of temporary surpluses being generated by Medicare, allowing them to be used only for reducing the national debt or to expand the system of health insurance for the elderly and the disabled.
The House budget would also provide more money than the administration next year in several areas, including veterans' benefits. 
The House budget provided for total spending for the fiscal year starting Oct. 1 of $1.977 trillion, an increase of 3.7 percent from the current fiscal year. Discretionary spending on most government programs outside Social Security and Medicare would rise 4 percent next year, to $660 billion.
The budget resolution would permit the tax cut to grow if new budget surplus projections this summer showed that the government would have even more excess revenue than expected.
Despite growing pressure from some members of both parties to address the faltering economy by passing a tax cut that would put tens of billions of dollars in the pockets of consumers this year, the committee limited the tax cut for this year to the amount in the income tax bill passed by the House earlier this month, about $5.6 billion.
The resolution would allow the tax cut to increase next year to $64 billion, more than twice what Mr. Bush originally sought. Most of the tax cut would not take effect until the middle of the decade.
Mr. Thomas said he intended to keep all tax cuts within the $1.6 trillion framework proposed by Mr. Bush, but he has not indicated how he intended to do this. When asked, he talked about fitting "a pound and a half of sugar into a one-pound bag."
The Senate is moving on taxes at a much slower pace than the House and is not likely to vote on the matter until May. Then, it is likely to approve a measure far different from what the House passes. It will be up to a House-Senate conference committee to resolve the differences.
No one who follows Congress doubts that a large tax cut will be enacted before the year is out, but the various components of the measure are still very much in question.
For married couples, Mr. Thomas's proposal has four parts:
*He would double the standard deduction for couples filing joint returns to make it twice the standard deduction for single taxpayers.
*For those who itemize deductions, he would gradually raise the amount of income covered by the 15 percent tax bracket.
*For low-income earners, he would increase the amount of income on which they would be entitled to the earned-income tax credit.
*He would adjust the alternative minimum tax, a special tax on those with unusually large deductions, so that couples would not be treated less favorably than single people.
The goal of the last point was to provide relief from what is known as the marriage penalty, the quirk in the tax law that leads to some couples owing more in taxes than they would if they were unmarried and filed separate returns. 
Mr. Thomas's plan, however, would give a tax reduction to almost all couples, whether or not they faced a penalty. It is almost identical to a measure that Congress approved last year and that was vetoed by President Bill Clinton.
These measures would be more generous to low-income taxpayers than the president's plan. The president would allow couples to take a 10 percent deduction on the first $30,000 earned by the lower-earning spouse, a measure that would not help the large majority of taxpayers at lower income levels who use the standard deduction.
The other part of the Thomas plan would double the child tax credit to $1,000 per child from $500, and $100 of the increase would be retroactive and applicable to 2001 income taxes. Workers with one or two children who do not owe enough in income taxes to be entitled to the full credit would be entitled to a rebate up to the amount they paid in Social Security and Medicare taxes. Under existing law, only taxpayers with three or more children are entitled to the refund.
President Bush proposed doubling the credit, but his plan would not expand the refund.

HEADLINE: German Confidence Is at Lowest Point Since July '99 

BYLINE:  By EDMUND L. ANDREWS 

DATELINE: FRANKFURT, March 21 

 BODY:
German industry fired off a powerful warning today that all is not well in Europe's biggest economy, when an important barometer of business confidence dived sharply, unnerving investors across Europe.
 In its monthly survey of sentiment among business executives, the IFO economic research institute, based in Munich, said confidence last month suffered its biggest plunge in more than a year, reaching a level not seen since July 1999 when Europe was being hit hard by the Asian financial crisis. The index fell twice as far as most economists had predicted. 
 Because the index is considered a reliable guide to future economic growth, the news compounded disappointment over the limited scale of the Federal Reserve's reduction in short-term interest rates on Tuesday. Stock markets declined across Europe, and the value of the euro slipped below 90 cents for the second time in two weeks. 
Adding to the bad news, the European Commission's statistical arm reported today that industrial production fell 1.9 percent in January, more than economists had expected.
No one doubts that Europe is slowing down, but there is much less agreement about how serious and widespread the trend will be.
In the last month, most private economists have trimmed their forecasts for European growth to 2.5 percent from about 3 percent. But that is still well above current predictions for the United States.
"It is too early to pull down the shutters," said Klaus Friedrich, chief economist at Dresdner Bank in Frankfurt. "If we get another two months of this and the numbers stay at this level, then there would be reason to worry."
The picture in Europe is far from homogenous. Signs of a slowdown are most acute in Germany, which is heavily dependent on exports outside Europe and which has been slow to liberalize its labor markets. But France, the next largest economy in Europe, remains fairly buoyant, and smaller countries like the Netherlands, Spain and Ireland are still growing quickly. Ireland, in fact, has drawn an official rebuke from the European Union over tax cuts that may overheat its economy.
Even in Germany, many manufacturers are still doing well, especially those that export mainly to Europe rather than to the United States. "We have the biggest backlog of orders right now that we have ever had," said Wieland Schmitz, a spokesman for MAN A.G., which makes trucks, buses, printing systems and other heavy equipment.
MAN's situation contrasts sharply with Freightliner, the American truck-making subsidiary of DaimlerChrysler, which is struggling with a sharp slowdown in the American market. In part because only 10 percent of MAN's exports go to the United States, it still foresees solid growth this year and next.
Nevertheless, anxiety is on the rise, once again putting the European Central Bank in a tight spot. So far, the bank has resisted following the Federal Reserve with interest rate cuts of its own because it worries more about inflation. 
But few economists believe the bank's forecast that Europe can still grow 3 percent this year, and unemployment across Europe remains at an uncomfortably high level of nearly 9 percent even after last year's economic growth.
As for inflation, it is already above the central bank's self-imposed ceiling of 2 percent annually, and the euro is again sputtering. A move to perk up growth with easier money could aggravate both trends.
"They cannot follow the Fed, and they shouldn't," said Alfred Boss, an economist at the Kiel Institute for World Economics in Germany.
Without changes like lower taxes and more flexible rules on hiring and firing, Mr. Boss said, it is "highly improbable" that Germany can grow any faster than 2.1 percent in 2001 and 2.5 percent thereafter, even with a cut in interest rates. 
In Britain, which did not adopt the euro, confidence among both consumers and businesses remains high, the main reason the Bank of England decided not to cut interest rates last month.
"The most striking feature of the U.K. economy was the strength of demand and confidence despite the world outlook," the Bank of England said today in a summary of discussions from its most recent meeting. "The U.S. slowdown could affect the confidence of businesses and consumers in the U.K., but it had not done so yet."
Thomas Mayer, senior European economist at Goldman, Sachs in Frankfurt, said Germany's abrupt loss of confidence might stem in part from frustration over economic reform, not the broader European economic picture. "The message of this survey is that this is mostly a German problem, rather than a European problem," Mr. Mayer said, referring to the German business sentiment data.
By contrast, executives at Alcatel, the French telephone equipment maker, remain fairly optimistic. Jean-Pierre Halbron, Alcatel's chief financial officer, said that because Europe never went on quite the same technology spending spree as the United States did, it is suffering less.
"If you take the last two to three years, telecommunication investment in Europe has been 50 percent of what it has been in the United States, and the economies are the same size," Mr. Halbron said.
Mr. Mayer added that the IFO survey found German pessimism directed at domestic conditions, not exports. And it coincided with a government decision to reinforce rules that give workers a say in corporate decision making, which Mr. Mayer said "put German industry in a very, very sour mood."
Romano Prodi, president of the European Commission, vented his own frustration today about slow progress in parts of Europe. "We have to speed things up," he told reporters in Brussels today, where a special meeting on economic reform is set for the weekend.

HEADLINE: CRITIC'S NOTEBOOK; 
Message in a Coca-Cola Can

BYLINE:  By A. O. SCOTT 

 BODY:
THERE is a scene in David O. Russell's "Three Kings" that has haunted me since the first time I saw it. Not the notorious tour of Mark Wahlberg's internal organs, but the moment when Mr. Wahlberg's character, separated from his comrades and pursued by Iraqi Republican Guards, bursts into an Iraqi bunker full of cell phones and calls his wife at home in the suburbs of Detroit.
 For some reason this scene reminds me of one in Pawel Pawlikowski's "Last Resort." The protagonist, a young Russian woman stranded at a holding center for refugees on the coast of Britain, hooks up with an Internet pornographer. As she goes through the motions for his camera, her would-be boyfriend comes to her rescue. After he beats up the pornographer, the camera lingers on a computer screen that displays the reactions of cybervoyeurs around the world who think they've witnessed the coolest live Webcast ever. 
 And this moment, in turn, recalls a sequence in Jasmin Dizdar's "Beautiful People," in which a young British soccer hooligan is unwittingly airlifted into the killing fields of Bosnia during the siege of Srebrenica. An unexpected act of heroism -- involving the young man's heroin stash -- is captured on television and beamed via satellite to his parents back in London. And then I think of a silly advertising jingle for a company that has since changed its name and its logo: "We're all connected." Yes, but only because we were disconnected first.
Are these scenes images of globalization? The word conjures images of -- what, exactly? In common usage, globalization has an abstract, ideological ring; it belongs to the idiom of punditry, high-level policy debates and political sloganeering. Depending on whom you believe, globalization either holds out the promise of open markets, free-flowing information and political liberalization or hastens the erosion of cultural identities and consolidates power in the hands of big, unaccountable corporations.
But as difficult as it is to find a safe analytical perch from which to assess the large-scale consequences of globalization -- which can be defined, for the sake of argument, as the increasingly rapid and dramatic movement of goods, capital, information and people across ever more permeable geographical, cultural and political boundaries -- it may be even trickier to understand its effects on daily life or to glimpse its human face.
A few years back, you could hardly turn on American network television without seeing pictures -- brought to you courtesy of advertising agencies employed by various computer companies, long-distance carriers and freight haulers -- of Masai herdsmen, Central Asian shepherds, Japanese schoolchildren and Scotsmen in kilts. Their motley, smiling countenances were selling not so much a series of products and services as a single, reassuring idea: whatever our differences of language, custom and costume, we're all the same.
Of course this anodyne, unexceptionable message had a specific subtext: we're the same because we want the same things -- fast Internet connections, overnight delivery and half-decaf skim lattes (as well as, presumably, peace, shelter and clean drinking water). Through these ads, the American television-watcher could practice a kind of cost-free mental tourism, experiencing at once the frisson of exoticism and the balm of complacency: not only are they just like us, but what they want is also what we already have. 
Advertising, of course, is a medium devoted to fantasy, an unabashedly utopian art form that dresses the banalities of ordinary commerce in the raiments of universalism, projecting a perfect world into the hectic humdrum of buying and selling. Movies are different -- or at least have the potential to be. They are able, sometimes, to brush the finer grain of reality, and catch sight -- often sidelong or by accident -- of the hard material substrata underneath the fantasy: the gravel on the roads of the global village.

Jokes and Jingles
A handful of recent films -- from different corners of the world, divergent in style and scope -- address globalization not as an idea, or even as a theme, but rather as a half-invisible context, a source of jokes, stories and serendipitous metaphors.
The most recognizable and widespread of these may also be the humblest: the Coca-Cola can, whose red and white lettering forms a universally legible ideogram for the worldwide consumer economy. "I'd like to buy the world a Coke, and keep it company," goes an old advertising jingle, which seems charmingly dated only because it has proved so deliberately prophetic. Without the benefit of paid product placement, the Coke logo always manages to find its way into camera range.
In Khyentse Norbu's "Cup," released last year, the opening scenes show a group of young Tibetan Buddhist monks using the familiar soda can as a ball in an impromptu soccer game. After being confiscated by their monastery's no-nonsense abbot, the adaptable object finds its way into a shrine, where it serves as a holder for votary candles. 
Superficially, this part of "The Cup" looks like a variation on a theme introduced more than 20 years ago in the South African comedy "The Gods Must Be Crazy," in which a Coke bottle falls from the heavens into the midst of an insular African tribe, which treats it as a sacred object -- a fetish, in anthropological parlance.
But unlike "The Gods Must Be Crazy," which was sufficiently popular in Europe and the United States to spawn a sequel, "The Cup" is more than a primitivist fairy tale about the collision between archaic tradition and encroaching modernity. (Nor, conversely, is it about the corruption of a vulnerable ancient culture by the predatory West.)
The film, made in Bhutan (with Japanese and European financing) by a prominent lama who became interested in directing during the filming of Martin Scorsese's "Kundun," takes a wry, humanistic look at cultural conflict.
The novices are obsessed, like most of the rest of the world, with soccer, and Mr. Norbu follows their efforts to bring the World Cup, and therefore television, to their cloistered corner of the world. 
When it arrives, the results are neither revolutionary nor catastrophic, but just what you might expect: a room full of excited young men cheering for their team, which happens to be Brazil.
Coke -- and the ambiguous power of television -- also figures in the Chinese director Zhang Yimou's "Not One Less," which examines the lives of children on the margins of the high-tech worldwide economy in a more somber light.
The film takes place in an impoverished village in rural China, where there is a perpetual shortage of school supplies (and teachers), and where children are sent away to the city to work off their parents' debts. When this happens to one of her pupils, the film's heroine, a stubborn and unworldly 13-year-old substitute teacher, resolves to bring him back.

A Persistent Inequality
To earn money for her bus ticket, she and her class spend a day working in a brickyard. She calculates (mistakenly, as it turns out) that they will have enough money left over for two cans of room-temperature Coke from the village store: 24 ounces to be shared among 27 thirsty mouths. 
There is something heartbreaking in seeing all these children delicately -- one might almost say reverently -- sipping warm brown sugar water from flimsy aluminum containers. Part of the pathos arises from the intensity of their appreciation of something that is elsewhere taken entirely for granted. The scene is a reminder of the terrible inequality that persists -- and deepens -- in the new market-dominated world even as it also acknowledges a profound and curiously innocent desire to belong to that world. 
The guilty, uncontrollable desire for coke -- the illegal variety, that is -- is at the center of "Traffic." Most of the discussion of Steven Soderbergh's film has focused on its relevance to American drug policy. But in trying to tell a story about the drug trade, Mr. Soderbergh and Stephen Gaghan, the screenwriter, have told a story about trade, regulated and unregulated markets, the law of supply and demand, and the unintended consequence of Nafta. (That they have done so is acknowledged in a speech delivered by Miguel Ferrer's character, a low-level importer who has turned on his bosses, to the Drug Enforcement Administration agents played by Don Cheadle and Luis Guzman. While Mr. Cheadle's character has a witty retort -- "What, are we on Larry King?" -- he doesn't have a persuasive counterargument.)
"Traffic" moves back and forth between the United States and Mexico, between a North overwhelmed by its appetites and a South corrupted by the business of feeding them. This map has some basis in reality, but it also projects a world turned upside down: replace illegal coke with the legal kind -- or, for that matter, with pharmaceuticals, fast food or movies -- and the multinational North becomes the supplier, pushing its product on the rest of the world. Or, more benignly, inventing new ways to give people what they want. 

Spartan Pleasures
But every desire eventually finds its opposite. Robert Zemeckis's "Cast Away" is a film that might seem in every way antithetical to "Not One Less" (whose cast, for one thing, consists entirely of nonprofessional actors). When we first encounter its hero, Chuck Noland, he might be starring in a promotional film for his employer, Federal Express. He is in Moscow, preaching the corporate gospel of speed and efficiency to a work force still fighting off the long socialist hangover. He's an exemplary -- and, since he's played by Tom Hanks, a heroically ordinary -- modern man, married to his work, living in constant motion, surrounded by gadgets and luxury objects and able to squeeze only fleeting moments of intimacy into his busy schedule. 
By now you know what happens next: Chuck's plane crashes in the South Pacific. His four-year sojourn on a deserted island, which occupies one of the most extraordinary hours of screen time in recent film history, is a long nightmare of solitude and desperation. But even nightmares hold an element of wish fulfillment. I doubt I'm the only moviegoer who watched with envy as well as pity Chuck's struggle to survive and stay sane. 
"The world is too much with us, late and soon," Wordsworth wrote. "Getting and spending we lay waste our powers." Or, to put it in the brand-conscious poetry of our own era, "The World on Time" may turn out to be an ambiguous gift. In the middle hour of "Cast Away," we watch someone, freed from the world as we know it, recover the elemental powers that his restless, clock-driven existence had shorn away. (It's hardly surprising that the movie did so well during the winter holidays, when the desire to flee from the entanglements of family and the pressures of shopping become especially acute.)
The FedEx packages from the plane wreck do arrive, of course, washing up in the tide with their familiar purple and orange markings. And they turn out to contain not only useful objects (thank goodness someone thought to ship a pair of ice skates across the southern tropics), but metaphors. Is there a more potent image of the desperate longing that lies beneath our easygoing commodity fetishism than Wilson, the volleyball whose brand becomes a name (it could have been Voit or Spalding), and whose blank surface becomes, when imprinted with Chuck's blood, a human face?
The things we surround ourselves with become the uncanny repositories of our alienated humanity, and the object of our stymied capacity to love. The loss of the volleyball, and Chuck's reaction to it, is both absurd -- Wilson is only a thing, after all -- and authentically tragic: Wilson is his best friend. 
Another of the packages that reach Chuck on his island -- and help to save his life -- contains Chinese videotapes, which he uses as lashing on his makeshift raft. In my own daydream, the unwatched tapes are a VHS transfer of Edward Yang's sublime "Yi Yi (a One and a Two)," a movie that like "Cast Away" finds drift and disconnection amid affluence and busyness.

Anomie the World Over
If "Cast Away" is a brilliant parable of the present human condition, "Yi Yi" examines that same condition with the sensitive precision of a great novel. NJ Jian, the sad-eyed, reluctant patriarch of a middle-class Taipei family, lives in the Eastern zone of Chuck Noland's world. He runs a small software company in search of venture capital, and he and his family live in a sleek urban environment that could be Manhattan or Frankfurt. NJ's teenage daughter hangs out at New York Bagels, his young son prefers McDonald's to traditional Chinese banquet food and a plastic bottle of Head and Shoulders sits on the side of the family's bathtub.
None of the details seem inserted to make a point: their function is descriptive. Just as Balzac in cataloguing the furnishings of a Paris apartment house could uncover the deep logic of 19th-century bourgeois society -- its class antagonisms, its sexual politics, its unacknowledged prejudices and intimate secrets -- so has Mr. Yang, in dwelling on the details of domestic and business life in a late-20th-century metropolis, discovered an essential structure of feeling.
A name for this feeling might be anomie, the sense of dislocation that accompanies the radical expansion of horizons. This is not to say that globalization makes us all unhappy, but rather that in redefining the pursuit of happiness and, at least arguably, freeing more people to pursue it, the present stage of capitalism also creates new forms of misery, not only material but also psychic. And it is striking how many recent movies regard the world with a sorrowful, worried expression, finding moments of comfort in an atmosphere of disconnection.
If "Traffic," for example, is explicitly about drugs, it is implicitly about the failure of communication and the fracture of intimate bonds by market forces. The brokenness that is the film's true subject is symbolized by its narrative structure: the links between the three stories are plain to the viewers but invisible to the characters. The world is too big for them to understand, and refuge from its remorseless logic is possible only in small measures and fleeting moments.
The New Yorker film critic David Denby has beautifully described "Yi Yi" as "a kind of melancholy globalist poem, an anxious tremor of the downturn." Like "Cast Away" and the other movies, "Yi Yi" was completed before the Nasdaq slide and the foot-and-mouth epidemic brought intimations of apocalypse to the public mood. The sense of somber uncertainty that pervades these movies is not a response to current events, but rather the underside of the giddy self-confidence that supposedly dominated the late 1990's.
The anxiety arises not from the fear of collapsing markets, but from the worry that, as goods proliferate and information circulates, meaning and human connections may be in danger of collapse. Like any other art, movies are powerless to restore what is broken, but they can provide images of what the rushing world conspires to obscure -- the anxious, melancholy human face.

Something in Common: The Wide World

HEADLINE: The Free Fall of the Australian Dollar Remains a Mystery 

BYLINE:  By BECKY GAYLORD 

DATELINE: SYDNEY, Australia, March 22 

 BODY:
The Australian dollar has analysts baffled. It probably should be weak, they say -- but not this weak.
 The Aussie, as it is called here, slipped to an all-time low of just under 50 United States cents late last week, and it seems likely to stay down -- or even dip further -- in the near term, whether analysts can make sense of it or not. 
 The slump is a particular problem for Australian businesses that rely on imports or want to expand internationally. And though it is also making Australian assets cheaper than ever for many foreign investors, few seem interested in buying. 
The currency does not have much going for it at the moment. At home, consumers are glum, unemployment is rising and business investment has sagged. In the fourth quarter of last year, the economy shrank for the first time in almost a decade. And internationally, weak global growth is weighing on the Aussie.
"You can pin it to lots of different factors," Ivan Colhoun, chief economist at Deutsche Bank in Sydney, said of the currency's tumble. "It's all very negative."
Still, analysts are hard pressed to explain just why the Australian dollar has fallen so far -- more than 24 percent against the United States dollar since January 2000, and more than 10 percent against the United States dollar just this year -- making it the second-worst performing major currency in the world, beating only the Turkish lira. Yesterday, it settled at 49.51 cents.
What is clear is that sentiment surrounding the Aussie is sour. "Investors have been burned so many times in the past two and a half years," said Greg McKenna, currency strategist at the National Australia Bank, that when the Aussie falls now, "it's like, 'Oh God, not again.' "
Overseas investors have been turning away from Australia since the late 1990's. Foreign holdings of the national government's bonds, for example, which peaked at 40 percent of the total outstanding in 1997, have dropped to just one quarter of the total. Even as Australia maintained steady economic growth and low inflation in recent years, the country failed to lure back the bulk of international investors and hedge fund managers who abandoned Australian assets during the Asian economic crisis of the late 1990's.
Now, as a global slowdown threatens, Australia's association with regional trouble spots like Japan, which buys one-fifth of the country's exports, are dragging the Aussie down again. Shipments abroad are bound to suffer if an economic meltdown spreads. Almost two-thirds of Australia's exports are commodities, including wool, wheat, gold and zinc; the country is the world's largest exporter of coal. And because the local currency is considered commodity-based, its performance typically suffers when global economic growth -- and demand -- crumple.
The lower currency is not all bad. It makes exports much cheaper, for one thing, and export strength is helping to cushion the country's economic slowdown. It is in part because of this -- and in part because the slide has been long and slow and has not pushed up inflation -- that the central bank has taken only minimal action to support the Aussie.
Still, Prime Minister John Howard protested recently that the country's economic fundamentals, while weaker than late last year, do not justify the Aussie's current level.
Most strategists and economists agree that it is undervalued -- some say significantly so. "Fundamentally, it seems ridiculously cheap," said Rory Robertson, a New York-based strategist at Macquarie Equities.
Intangible concerns, like business and consumer confidence, are holding great sway, analysts said. And a relatively small economy like Australia's, which accounts for just 1 percent of total global gross domestic product, can be tossed around more by the tides of capital flows.
Given the current conditions, analysts say, the Aussie is likely to continue to struggle. Some say the currency should be close to a bottom, but none are confidently predicting when it will recover. "Presumably, eventually, investors will notice," Mr. Robertson said. "Australia's having a half-price sale."

HEADLINE: Economic Jitters Send Latin American Stocks Reeling; 
In Argentina, Official Seeks A Free Hand

BYLINE:  By CLIFFORD KRAUSS 

DATELINE: BUENOS AIRES, March 22 

 BODY:
Two tumultuous days into his new tenure as Argentina's economy minister and designated savior, Domingo Cavallo outlined his plans late Wednesday and asked Congress for extraordinary powers to revive the stalled economy.
 Mr. Cavallo promised to make Argentina more competitive without devaluing the peso or ending the decade-old currency board system that pegs its value to the United States dollar. He called for tax cuts, tariff changes and rapid easing of business and labor regulations. 
 But hopes that the plan would immediately bolster investor confidence seemed dim. The benchmark Merval stock index plunged 6.6 percent today, driven in part by a similar retreat in neighboring Brazil and by worries that the currency peg may be broken despite government assurances, as has happened in countries like Turkey. 
Late in the day, the market rout was aggravated by rumors, immediately denied, that Argentina's president, Fernando de la Rua, would resign.
In the two days since Mr. de la Rua brought Mr. Cavallo in as the country's third economy minister in three weeks, Mr. Cavallo has engaged in a frenetic pace of economic planning and politicking. It appeared to be as much an effort to dispel the impression that the government was adrift as to kickstart an economy that has contracted for two years.
"Soon Argentines will see us in action," Mr. Cavallo said, "and the country will be different."
He offered few details of his plan, instead calling on Congress to grant him almost unlimited powers to privatize state agencies, slash state payrolls, revamp pension laws to cut business costs, give companies more freedom to hire and fire and scrap other regulations.
The plan included several departures from past policies. Mr. Cavallo called for eliminating the current 14 percent import tariff on capital goods to encourage investment. At the same time, he called for average import duties on consumer goods from countries outside the Mercosur trade bloc to rise to 20 percent from 18 percent, to protect domestic producers. Mercosur also includes Brazil, Paraguay and Uruguay.
Such unilateral tariff changes are bound to rankle Brazil, Mercosur's leader, which prefers that trade policies be coordinated among members. Mr. Cavallo and the foreign minister, Adalberto Rodriguez Giavarini, were expected to fly to Brazil to talk with concerned officials. 
Mr. Cavallo's plan included a few tax increases, but mainly it aimed to raise more revenue by fighting tax evasion and corruption. He called for a new rule requiring all financial transactions over $1,000 to be completed by check rather than in cash. He also proposed a small tax on financial transactions that would be deductible from income and value-added taxes.
All told, the program was intended to shave $3 billion from the expanding government deficit this year. With $150 billion in foreign debt, Argentina was expected to miss the goal set by the International Monetary Fund for reducing its deficit in the first quarter; the monetary fund organized a bailout package of nearly $40 billion late last year.
Mr. Cavallo appeared to have a fight on his hands in Congress, where members of the Radical Party of President De la Rua have expressed reservations about giving him the power he wants, especially with regard to pension and labor laws. Mr. Cavallo, who leads a small conservative party, ran for president against the ruling Alianza coalition in 1999. 
Members of the opposition Justicialist Party, which was in power when Mr. Cavallo served as economy minister under former President Carlos Saul Menem, reacted more positively. 
"We understand the country is in bad shape," said Governor Jose Manuel de la Sota of Cordoba province, who praised Mr. Cavallo's plans to cut taxes and streamline regulations. "We will be a constructive opposition."
But labor leaders were skeptical. Hugo Moyano, who led a damaging 24-hour nationwide strike on Wednesday, said he was not about to stop the protests. 
"I don't believe Cavallo's policies will remove the country from its crisis," Mr. Moyano said. "They always postpone the social needs of the people."

HEADLINE: What Turkey Should Do 

 BODY:
To the Editor:
 Re "Bush Team Getting Initiation on Turkey's Ailing Economy" (news article, March 18): 
 A stable, democratic Turkey is in everyone's interest, but there are some things that only Turkey can do to bring this about. If we are to continue providing Turkey with billions of dollars, it should be in the context of its cleaning up corruption; ending the occupation of Cyprus, which costs millions a year; and finding a peaceful solution to the Kurdish problem, which the capture of the Kurdish guerrilla commander Abdullah Ocalan has made possible. 

ANNE M. RICE
Great Falls, Va., March 19, 2001

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: Economic Jitters Send Latin American Stocks Reeling; 
Brazil Frets Over Rate Rise And the Turmoil Next Door

BYLINE:  By JENNIFER L. RICH 

DATELINE: SAO PAULO, Brazil, March 22 

 BODY:
Brazil's stock markets plummeted today on the heels of a surprise half-point increase in interest rates by the Brazilian central bank Wednesday night, and they were rattled further by developments in neighboring Argentina. Sao Paulo's benchmark Bovespa index fell 5.34 percent, closing at 14,046.19.
 Meant to stabilize the falling value of Brazil's currency, the real, and to keep inflation from igniting, the interest rate move wound up worsening the growing concern over the Brazilian economy's prospects, economists said. 
 "It introduced a little uncertainty in the market," said Andre Loes, chief economist at Banco Santander. "They could have insisted a little more with the foreign-exchange markets."
After the Brazilian government's sales of dollar-indexed notes earlier this week failed to relieve mounting pressure on the real, the central bank's policy committee said it raised rates to ensure that the country would not exceed its inflation target of 4 percent this year. The Brazilian government instituted a system of inflation targets two years ago after a sharp devaluation of the currency threatened the stability of the local economy. 
Concerns over increasing instability in Argentina, the apparent slowing of the American economy, and disappointment over Brazil's yawning current account deficit have pushed the real down in value 5.3 percent this month, to 2.161 to the dollar, a two-year low.
Some economists said, though, that the central bank's move was justified. They said the market needed a signal that the central bank was willing to take tough, politically unpopular measures to guard against inflation, which scourged the country in the 1980's.
"This change in the rate was very important, because it made it very clear that if necessary the central bank would increase the rate," said Jose Carlos de Faria, an economist at Deutsche Bank in Sao Paulo. "Before this, the market had the perception that the central bank would not take such a strong move."
Over the last 11 months, the central bank's policy committee has been lowering rates. The benchmark short-term rate, known as Selic, which the bank briefly pushed up to 45 percent to head off a run on the real, has been falling steadily from 19.50 percent in the aftermath of the 1999 devaluation. It dropped to 15.25 percent before Wednesday, but the bank's surprise increase pushed it back up to 15.75 percent.
Business leaders and politicians continue to demand a significant reduction in interest rates, arguing that Brazilian industry needs lower borrowing costs to increase the competitiveness of Brazilian products in world markets. 
In that climate, Mr. Loes of Banco Santander called the half-point rate innocuous and wondered whether it would have much effect on inflation.
Economists say that while the fundamentals of the Brazilian economy remain strong, a growing financial crisis and political turmoil in Argentina have made investors in Brazil increasingly nervous.
Doubts remain whether the newly appointed Argentine economy minister, Domingo Cavallo, will be able to push through an emergency economic package and pull the country out of a long recession. There was also some concern that his plan to unilaterally alter tariffs would be disruptive to Mercosur, the four-nation trade bloc led by Brazil that also includes Uruguay and Paraguay.
Until there is some clarification of the Argentine situation, analysts said, markets in both countries will remain rocky and prone to sharp reactions to developments on either side of the border.

HEADLINE: Key Forecasting Gauge Declined in February 

BYLINE:  Reuters 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 22 

 BODY:
A key forecasting gauge for the economy fell in February after a significant gain in January, but it indicated that growth should pick up in the next few months, a private research group said today.
 The group, the Conference Board, reported that the index of leading economic indicators dropped 0.2 percent in February after a revised 0.5 percent gain in January. The drop matched Wall Street expectations. 
 The board corrected the leading index from a 0.3 percent decline reported earlier in the day and attributed the revision to an error in compiling consumer expectations data. The mistake occurred because the board used midmonth consumer sentiment figures instead of the usual end-of-month numbers, which were higher. Overall consumer expectations were therefore corrected to a 0.12 percent decline from a previously reported 0.19 percent fall.
The board's economist, Ken Goldstein, said the data suggested that inflation was still not in sight and explained that although the leading index declined steadily in the last quarter of 2000, it did not meet the 3.5 percent annualized loss over six months that would signal a recession.
Instead, Mr. Goldstein predicted another quarter of slow growth before the economy would pick up again in the summer.
He said that the half-point cut in interest rates by the Federal Reserve this week would stimulate spending and consumption and inject "adrenaline" into the economy.
He recognized, however, that declining exports in the last quarter of 2000 played a role in slowing the economy. "There's a problem in demand, but it's not investment and it's not consumption," he said. "It's in exports." The United States export market remained "dried up" in the context of global economic weakness, he said.
A separate report released today showed that jobless claims rose, as measured on a four-week average, offering further evidence the economy is slowing. While claims fell to 379,000 in the March 17 week from a revised 380,000 in the prior week, the four-week average rose to 377,000 from a revised 365,500.
Diane Swonk, chief economist at Bank One in Chicago, agreed that despite slower growth rates the the nation had "a weak economy that's still in expansion territory" and concurred that the next few months carried stronger growth prospects.
Neither Mr. Goldstein nor Ms. Swonk appeared concerned that the recent fluctuations in the stock market would generate obstacles to investment or economic growth in the months to come.
The Conference Board said the coincident index, a barometer of current economic trends, rose 0.1 percent in February after remaining unchanged in January and increasing 0.1 percent in December.
