HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING; 
And the Oscar for the network willing to hold out the longest to sell costly spots goes to . . . ABC.

BYLINE:  By Stuart Elliott 

 BODY:
IN another sign of the effect of the struggling economy on Madison Avenue, ABC has become the reluctant star of a Hollywood cliffhanger called "Crouching Network, Hidden Sponsors," completing the sale of commercial time during the 73rd annual Academy Awards a scant three days before showtime.
 One reason for the lag compared with better times, when ABC normally sold out the broadcast a month or two beforehand rather than the Thursday before the Sunday, was that the network held firm to higher prices set last year as the American economy was emulating the best picture of 1952, "The Greatest Show on Earth," rather than the best picture of 1997, "Titanic." 
 ABC, part of the Walt Disney Company, has finished selling the spots for an estimated average of just less than $1.4 million for each 30 seconds, compared with $1.2 million in 2000. That underscores an advertising truism: demand for prestigious, so-called event programming generally holds up in a weakened economy as marketers, like investors, make a flight to perceived quality.
The higher prices, however, along with the souring economic outlook, led some longtime Oscar sponsors to reduce the amount of commercial time they bought. One stalwart, Revlon, withdrew altogether after paring its buy last year, a disappearance related to its own financial problems rather than the economic slowdown. 
To fill the commercial time, ABC recruited newcomers to the program like Anheuser-Busch, Kinko's and Yahoo to join returnees like American Express, Eastman Kodak, General Motors, the Pepsi-Cola unit of PepsiCo and Charles Schwab & Company. The result is a show with an ad lineup that will resemble the Super Bowl's, with a far longer advertiser roster than typical.
"Obviously, it was a little more challenging," said Mike Shaw, president for sales and marketing at the ABC Television Network division of ABC, who spoke in a telephone interview from Los Angeles as he was helping sell the final 60 seconds of commercial time left.
"It would have been a lot easier to make a price adjustment a month ago and put it to bed," he added, "but this is a franchise we're interested in holding, and one year's softness is not going to impact that."
The Academy Awards, which ABC has rights to broadcast through 2008, is usually the second-highest-rated program each year, behind only the Super Bowl. Last year, the show drew an average audience of 46.3 million, and an estimated 79 million people watched at least some of it.
"Our strategy is to sponsor the highest-rated television events to reach our consumer in the most entertaining programs," said Peter McLoughlin, vice president for corporate media at Anheuser-Busch in St. Louis. "We've been the exclusive beer sponsor for 13 years in the Super Bowl, so it was natural for us to become the exclusive beer sponsor in the Academy Awards."
The Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences, which administers the Oscars, has long restricted the types of products that can run commercials during the show, and this is the first year for beer. Mr. McLoughlin and Mr. Shaw said the change of heart was unrelated to the softness in commercial sales but took place after Anheuser-Busch approached ABC last year about becoming a sponsor in 2001.
"ABC took a reel of our commercials to the academy and what was presented was well received," Mr. McLoughlin said. "They opened the door, and we appreciate it."
Anheuser-Busch will run two humorous, though tasteful, commercials during the show, both created by the Chicago office of DDB Worldwide, part of the Omnicom Group. One, about drinking responsibly, features the boy band 'N Sync and ran during the Super Bowl in January. The other, about a Clydesdale and a mouse, was to have run during the Super Bowl but was held.
"We know consumers watching big events and tuning in to 'appointment TV' like the Academy Awards are interested, involved viewers," said Laura Kurzu, vice president for marketing at Kinko's in Ventura, Calif. "They're less likely to migrate away during commercial breaks."
That is why Kinko's and its agency, the Playa del Rey, Calif., office of TBWA/Chiat/Day, part of the TBWA Worldwide unit of Omnicom, chose the show as the place to introduce a campaign featuring the comedian Ryan Stiles and carrying the theme "We're doing more."
"And because the market did free up somewhat," Ms. Kurzu said, referring to the ability of the newcomers to join in, "we expanded the commercial from 30 to 60 seconds."
"We're even 'doing more' with media time," she added, laughing.
Several other advertisers are also running spots longer than the conventional 30 seconds, including Pepsi-Cola, with two 90-second commercials featuring the singer Britney Spears. "With three minutes, we really stand out," said Dawn Hudson, senior vice president for strategy and marketing at Pepsi in Purchase, N.Y., which also bought three minutes last year. "It makes us look like a more dominant sponsor."
The Super Bowl-like ad lineup "could be a very good thing," she added, "because it offers more opportunities for 'talk value' for all the different advertisers on the show" compared with previous years when there were fewer marketers.
One Oscars mainstay, Kodak, is also buying the same amount of commercial time this year as last, 90 seconds, running three spots by Ogilvy & Mather Worldwide in New York, part of the WPP Group, that introduce a campaign carrying the theme "Share moments, share life."
"We're happy to be joined by these prominent companies," said Kent McNeley, chief marketing officer for consumer imaging at Kodak in Rochester, as "they see some of the value of advertising on the Academy Awards as we have."
Kodak is taking its sponsorship further, to paraphrase a recent ad slogan, signing a 20-year contract to name a new Academy site for the awards show the Kodak Theater.
General Motors is also using its sponsorship to introduce new commercials. Some are for Chevrolet by Campbell-Ewald in Warren, Mich., part of the Interpublic Group of Companies. And one, by the Troy, Mich., office of D'Arcy Masius Benton & Bowles, part of the Bcom3 Group, is the centerpiece of an aggressive new campaign for Cadillac, evoking the era when "every American had a dream of driving a Cadillac" and asserting, "It's time to start dreaming again."
"This is a big statement for Cadillac, so it's important to kick it off on a premier property," said Kim Kosak, director for advertising and promotions at Cadillac in Detroit.
"We call it the 'special occasion spot,' " she added, "because it will run only on programs like the Academy Awards."
The Cadillac spot offers a whirlwind ride from the past, as conjured up with vintage footage of a 1953 Cadillac LeMans, Muhammad Ali and American astronauts, to the future, symbolized by Cadillacs due in 2002 and beyond. One Pepsi spot also combines the past and future, showing Ms. Spears performing by an old-fashioned neon Pepsi sign.
One advertiser, though, is resolutely remaining in the present, addressing the faltering economy.
"We're breaking a spot with Chuck talking to investors about what he thinks about today's market," said Jack Calhoun, senior vice president for advertising and brand management at Schwab in San Francisco, referring to the founder, Mr. Schwab.
Mr. Calhoun summarized the message of the commercial, by the New York office of BBDO Worldwide, part of Omnicom, as "Everybody just take a deep breath and relax."
That goes for you Oscar nominees, too.

HEADLINE: Fed Minutes Show Concern Over Falling Economy 

BYLINE:  Reuters 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 22 

 BODY:
Federal Reserve policy makers decided to cut interest rates aggressively for a second time in January because the economy was losing steam surprisingly swiftly, minutes of their meeting showed today.
 "The speed and extent of the slowdown were much more pronounced than they had anticipated," according to minutes from the meeting of the Federal Open Market Committee on Jan 30 and Jan. 31. 
 The committee voted 10 to 0 at the meeting to lower interest rates by one-half of a percentage point, matching a half-point reduction on Jan. 3 in between regular meetings and bringing the Fed's target rate on overnight loans between banks to. 5.5 percent. 
The Fed policy makers also agreed to emphasize that the main risk the economy faced was excessive weakness, signaling they were leaning toward more rate reductions.
Indeed, the Fed reduced interest rates another half-point on Tuesday, reducing the federal funds rate to 5 percent, its lowest level since mid-1999.
The minutes from January's meeting showed policy makers were not entirely sure what to make of the current loss of vigor in the economy.
"The eventual degree and duration of the softening in economic conditions were difficult to predict," the minutes said.
"In particular, it was unclear whether the pause in the economic expansion would be largely limited to a relatively short inventory correction or would involve a more extensive cyclical adjustment," they added.
The committee members felt that they were doing the right thing to revive the flagging economy and that the rate cuts they were making would bolster consumer and business confidence.
In particular, the minutes said "the most critical element" was rapid growth in productivity, a measure of how much workers produce in any given hour, which the committee felt would bolster incomes and keep inflation in check.
"The members saw substantial underlying strength and resilience in the economy and they remained optimistic about its prospects beyond the near term in light of the monetary stimulus that was being implemented and the persistence of rapid advances in productivity," the minutes said.
The next scheduled committee meeting is on May 15, but there is nothing to prevent policy makers from lowering rates between meetings.

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: STOCKS & BONDS; 
Stocks Get Late Bounce as Buyers Move In

BYLINE:  By ALEX BERENSON 

 BODY:
A late-afternoon rally saved investors from steep losses yesterday, as stocks gained strongly in the last hour of trading. Technology stocks ended the day sharply higher, while the Dow Jones industrial average swung from a decline of more than 380 points at 2:40 p.m. to a decline of less than 98 points at the close. 
 After dismal trading on Tuesday and Wednesday and then Thursday morning, the sudden surge of buying came seemingly out of nowhere. The late-day gains were not related to fundamental changes in the outlook for the economy or for corporate profits, traders and analysts said. 
 Instead, the rally appeared to be driven mainly by traders who had sold stocks and stock indexes "short," betting that prices would decline. For most of the day, the short-sellers were right, but just before 3 p.m., a wave of buying from big investors stopped the decline.
As traders in New York and at options pits in Chicago saw that prices were not dropping any further, they hastened to buy shares to cover their short sales, one trader said. That buying pushed prices higher, and the short-covering fed on itself for the next hour.
"All it takes is a little bit of a run-up to get it going, and if it doesn't fall back, the locals in the pits start covering their shorts," the trader said. 
For the day, the Dow lost 97.52 points, or 1.03 percent, closing at 9,389.48. The technology-heavy Nasdaq rose 67.47 points, or 3.69 percent, closing at 1,897.70, while the broader Standard & Poor's 500-stock index ended almost even, down 4.56 points, or 0.41 percent, at 1,117.58.
Despite its afternoon rally, the Dow has dropped almost 600 points since the Federal Reserve cut short-term interest rates a half-point three days ago. The Dow is fewer than a dozen points from officially entering a bear market, a milestone it will reach if it closes below 9,378. Wall Street defines a bear market as a fall of 20 percent or more in a broad index; the Dow hit its record high of 11,722.98 on Jan. 14, 2000.
Because the Nasdaq and the S.& P. 500, which contain many more stocks than the Dow, have already fallen more than 20 percent, a slide by the Dow into bear territory would be largely symbolic, putting a coda on the great bull market that began in 1982. More important, a continued fall in the Dow would show that investors were nervous that corporate stalwarts like General Electric might not be immune to the earnings and sales shortfalls that have already rocked information technology companies like Cisco Systems.
Losers today included G.E., which fell $1.30, to $37.70, and manufacturers like Boeing, which skidded $1.85, to $52, and Minnesota Mining and Manufacturing, off $1.82 at $101.81. But drug makers and technology companies gained. Merck rose $1.75, to $69.71, while Hewlett-Packard jumped $1.66, to $30.89.
"What's going to turn the market around is when earnings estimates stop coming down," said Michelle Clayman, chief investment officer at New Amsterdam Partners, which manages about $1 billion. "Maybe we're talking about the late third quarter, early fourth quarter before things look better."
Even so, two Wall Street strategists saw signs of hope in yesterday's trading action. Abby Joseph Cohen, chief United States strategist for Goldman, Sachs, noted that many top technology companies had actually risen since Tuesday. Intel, which fell to a 52-week low of $24.50 on Tuesday, closed yesterday at $28.69, while Dell Computer rose to $26.25 from $24.44 on Tuesday.
Investors are recognizing that some technology stocks are now trading at reasonable levels and that the worst disappointments in technology profits may have already occurred, Ms. Cohen said. "There's a collective realization that stocks have sold off notably," she said. "We think that this preannouncement period for corporate profits is going to mark the worst period."
Jeff Applegate, the chief investment strategist at Lehman Brothers and a stalwart bull whose optimism proved misguided last year, said he thought stocks could bottom within days or weeks. Mr. Applegate said he was disappointed that the Federal Reserve had not cut interest rates more than 0.5 percent on Tuesday to try to stimulate the economy. But he said he expected that the Fed would continue to cut rates and that the cuts it had already made would soon begin to help the economy.
Stocks usually hit bottom about three months after the Fed lowers rates, and the Fed initially cut rates on Jan. 3, so a rally may be imminent, Mr. Applegate said. Yesterday, "you got to some levels where you saw some real buyers coming in," he said. --------------------

Treasury Prices Rise
By Bloomberg News
Treasury bond prices rose yesterday on expectations that the Federal Reserve will cut interest rates before the central bank meets again on May 15.
Government debt is reacting "to a very horrific experience in the stock market, and there are those who say that this will be the recession of 1991 all over again," said Todd Finkelstein, who manages $1.3 billion at Boston Advisors Inc.
The 10-year Treasury note rose 8/32, to a price of 102 2/32. The note's yield, which moves in the opposite direction from the price, fell to 4.74 percent from 4.77 percent on Wednesday.
The price of the 30-year Treasury bond rose 5/32, to 101 21/32. The bond's yield fell to 5.26 percent from 5.27 percent on Wednesday.

HEADLINE: A Glut of Cable TV in India; 
A 'Wild West' Market That Overshadows China's

BYLINE:  By MARK LANDLER 

DATELINE: BOMBAY, March 18 

 BODY:
Hailing a taxi in this chaotic city can be a gamble in the best of times. When Cyrus Broacha is at the wheel, all bets are off. 
 Mr. Broacha, the manic host of a daytime show on MTV India, often masquerades as a blind cabdriver, using a hidden camera to record the reactions of passengers. Other times, he shows up in the corner barbershop, brandishing a pair of garden shears at unsuspecting patrons. 
 Such antics have made Mr. Broacha's show, "Bakra," one of the top programs on MTV India. And it has helped MTV India, an offshoot of the American MTV, keep its head above water in a television market with no fewer than six music-video channels. 
"I can't understand why people keep starting music channels," said Alex Kuruvilla, managing director of MTV India. "I think rich people must say, 'It's my daughter's birthday, I'll give her a music channel.' "
Nor is the bewildering choice limited to music video channels. Movies, sports, news, general entertainment, children's and regional programs can all be found on cable. Often, three or more channels compete in the same category. In a country that has too little of most things, India has created one of the most plentiful television markets in the world.
The pell-mell growth of cable here is in striking contrast to the other great Asian market, China. Despite much greater foreign investment in China and breathless predictions by Rupert Murdoch and other Western media moguls eager to tap that market, China remains a place where CNN can be watched mainly in hotel rooms and diplomatic compounds.
"Everybody wants to get into China," said Kunal Dasgupta, chief executive of Sony Entertainment Television. "But it's clear to us that India is a much more near-term opportunity, and almost as big."
Peter Mukerjea, chief executive of Star TV India, said: "There used to be a sense that India was full of problems. Now it's like the Wild West of media. There's no other place like it."
Except, perhaps, the United States. India feels a lot like the American market in the early 1980's, when cable television, then unregulated, was growing at a torrid rate. Ever since satellite-delivered cable came to India in 1991, after the gulf war had turned CNN into an overnight sensation, the government has stood aside as the industry bloomed.
To be sure, television is still far from ubiquitous in this country of more than a billion people. Fewer than half of Indian households, or about 70 million homes, have TV's. Of those, an estimated 28.5 million have cable, according to a report by HSBC Securities. That makes India the third-largest cable market, behind the United States and China.
While most Chinese receive only a handful of channels, because of restrictions on foreign broadcasters by the Chinese government, Indians receive up to 85 channels for a monthly rate of 150 rupees, or $3.26.
The downside of all this freedom is a TV market as teeming as the streets of Bombay. 
India has 30,000 to 50,000 cable operators, mostly mom-and-pop operations, stringing cable from trees to houses. With slowing advertising revenue and new channels squeezing in every month, the rivalry between big players like Star and Sony has become crippling.
"We've had a tough couple of years," Mr. Kuruvilla of MTV said. "We've got a small pie, and millions of people are fighting for a piece."
The proliferation of sexually charged television images is also stirring a debate in this traditional country. India's information and broadcasting minister, Sushma Swaraj, recently criticized a fashion channel from France that featured scantily clad models.
The channel, FTV, defused the controversy by agreeing to beam a separate signal, with more demure models, to India. But as television spreads into India's rural heartland, and as channels fight more fiercely for viewers, questions of taste are likely to come up again.
"Farmers in the Punjab are getting 'Baywatch,' " said Ramesh Vangal, chairman of an Internet portal, AtIndia.com. "One can argue about what kind of effect it is having. But it is transforming India."
The transformation is most obvious in Bombay, the media capital of India, where billboards promoting TV shows like "Suddenly Susan" and "Ally McBeal" have elbowed aside posters for Indian movies. Executives here say the rise of nationally popular TV programs has alarmed Bombay's huge film industry.
A case in point is the Indian version of "Who Wants to Be a Millionaire," which made its debut in July on Star TV and riveted the nation for weeks. The show, known in Hindi as "Kaun Banega Crorepati," shattered ratings records and spawned several copycat game shows.
"It completely overturned the myth that only Bollywood works in this market," said Mr. Kuruvilla, using the nickname for India's film industry.
Bollywood movies tend to be overripe melodramas, better on action than character development. But they are reliably popular, feeding several all-movie cable channels and spinning off dubbed soundtracks, known as playbacks, that make up 70 percent of MTV's Hindi-language schedule.
But the game show was a home-grown hit, and it catapulted Star TV, owned by Mr. Murdoch's News Corporation, from an also-ran to the No. 1 cable service in India. Star has built on the show's success by producing a popular Hindi-language family drama that runs after it.
"Millionaire" was a holy grail of sorts for American broadcasters here -- a non-Indian programming concept tailored to Indian tastes. Sony and another cable channel, Zee, have produced game shows and are trying to exploit other American genres, like reality-based shows.
Sony, which operates an entertainment and movie channel as well as distributing CNBC India, is producing a series that will feature a princess trapped on an island. Fifteen contestants will face a series of hurdles, natural and man-made, to free the princess and claim a prize.
Mr. Dasgupta said Sony Entertainment planned to invest $250 million in India over the next three years, developing two new channels and getting into film production and distribution. The Sony Corporation owns 61 percent of the company, while Indian investors and Bollywood celebrities own the rest.
"In China, we're still clawing our way back from 'Seven Years in Tibet,' " said Mr. Dasgupta, referring to the Brad Pitt film about the Dalai Lama that angered Beijing because of its depiction of Chinese repression in Tibet. 
"This market has emerged," he said, "as more conducive to major U.S. studios."
Still, other executives said the success of "Millionaire" does not mean that every popular American or British concept can be turned into a hit with a bit of tweaking. Mr. Mukerjea is skeptical about replicating shows like "Survivor," which put contestants into trying circumstances.
"For the average Indian citizen, day-to-day existence is hard enough," he said. "He has to wait in a mile-long queue for a bus and then run after it because there are people hanging off the back. Here, if you go 40 kilometers out of Bombay, you're on the set of 'Survivor.' "
A former ad salesman whose pukka accent attests to his years in Britain, Mr. Mukerjea has become the most-watched TV executive in India. As Star soars in the ratings, the company is expanding into distribution: it recently bought 26 percent of India's third-largest cable system, Hathaway Cable, for $70 million.
Mr. Mukerjea, 45, plans to upgrade Hathaway's network to provide broadband service to its 2.5 million subscribers, most of whom are in Bombay. He is also exploring direct-to-home satellite transmission and FM radio, which -- given Bombay's legendary traffic jams -- is a natural business.
Star has made such inroads in India that it has shifted the center of gravity of the company. Mr. Murdoch's younger son, James, still runs Star from its headquarters in Hong Kong. But he visits India every two months. And other Star executives are increasingly involved in India.
"China is more close at hand from Hong Kong," Mr. Mukerjea said, "but this is an unbelievable opportunity. It's the tip of the iceberg."
The trouble is, everybody feels the same way. More than 30 channels started in the last year, at a time when advertising has slowed to an annual increase of 15 percent, down from 25 percent. Advertisers also have been rattled by the slowdown in the global economy and the recent earthquake here.
Despite all the new choices, Indians are not watching more television. They average about one hour and 20 minutes a day, a figure that has not changed in recent years. With few families owning more than one set, the popularity of one show usually comes at the expense of another. "Millionaire," for example, eclipsed the ratings of an Indian passion, cricket games.
Given these realities, Indian television is due for a shakeout. Well-financed companies like Star and Sony, with multiple channels, are likely to survive, while stand-alone channels fall by the wayside. In its category, Mr. Kuruvilla said, MTV is "the only financially viable channel of the lot."
Lest anyone confuse MTV with its video-playing brethren, Cyrus Broacha, the fake cabdriver, is loose on the streets of Bombay, looking for people to trick in the name of successful television.

HEADLINE: Kofi Annan Seems Good Bet for Re-election, and U.S. Is Pleased 

BYLINE:  By BARBARA CROSSETTE 

DATELINE: UNITED NATIONS, March 22 

 BODY:
Kofi Annan, the first leader of the United Nations to rise from within its ranks, said today that he would accept a second five-year term as secretary general. With no other strong candidates in the field at this point, he is likely to be re-elected later this year, well in advance of the end of his first term, Dec. 31. 
 In Washington, a State Department spokesman welcomed Mr. Annan's decision. "His performance as secretary general has been outstanding," said Philip Reeker, the deputy spokesman. Five years ago, the United States vetoed a second term for Mr. Annan's predecessor, Boutros Boutros-Ghali, and promoted Mr. Annan for the job. 
 Mr. Annan will visit Washington on Friday for a meeting with President Bush, Secretary of State Colin L. Powell and the national security adviser, Condoleezza Rice. At a news conference today the secretary general said he expected to discuss a range of issues with American leaders, including the Middle East, Iraq and the Balkans. 
He said he would also raise the question of American dues to the organization. Although a deal with other countries was reached in December that allowed the United States to reduce the size of its United Nations assessment -- and the pact was approved by Jesse Helms, the chairman of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee as well as a powerful critic of the United Nations -- more than $580 million in past dues is still held up in the House of Representatives. William H. Luers, president and chairman of the United Nations Association of the United States, the largest American citizens' support group, welcomed Mr. Annan's announcement and said that the secretary general had brought "a new level of integrity" to the office and the organization, and had done much to open it up to outsiders.
Richard C. Holbrooke, the former American ambassador to the United Nations, today called Mr. Annan "the best secretary general since the organization was founded." 
Mr. Annan, a Ghanaian who will be 63 next month, is popular within the organization and has become a celebrity figure outside the United States, where the United Nations is generally held in higher regard and has a higher visibility. He has earned praise from industrial countries for his determination to reform the organization's archaic and politicized management system, a task being carried out largely by the deputy secretary general, Louise Frechette of Canada. He published trenchant reports of peacekeeping failures, often under his watch as head of that department, and ordered a study of how to improve its efficiency. 
Mr. Annan has provoked concern among some developing nations' governments wary of his overtures to international corporations to join in mitigating the effects of a globalizing economy through a program called the "global compact," and of his calls for intervention in countries where leaders abuse their citizens. 
Mr. Annan, a softspoken man with a calm, elegant demeanor and a sense of humor that has pulled his colleagues through difficult periods, said today that he had agonized over seeking a second term. Diplomats said that ultimately the decision was a joint one. They say that Mr. Annan's wife, Nane, a Swedish lawyer and artist, was known to be concerned about the toll the job was taking on her husband and the time they could spend together.
Asked today what his wife thought of his decision to seek a second term, Mr. Annan replied: "She said that she would support me. I shouldn't say more than that."

HEADLINE: Critics Say U.S. Energy Agency Is Weak in Oversight of Utilities 

BYLINE:  By JEFF GERTH and JOSEPH KAHN 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 22 

 BODY:
The pressure was intense when federal regulators met privately last month to debate remedies for soaring electricity prices in California.
 Officials of the Federal Energy Regulatory Commission, the agency whose mandate is to ensure "just and reasonable" electricity rates nationwide, had evidence that a few companies had been selling electricity to California at prices far above the cost of generating it. The agency faced an imminent deadline to challenge those prices or let the companies possibly pocket hundreds of millions of dollars in unfair profits. 
 An internal memorandum laid out two choices. The agency could audit and punish "bad actors," the companies that were exploiting the market. Or it could identify "bad hours," when electricity shortages were most acute and spiking prices were arguably nobody's fault, and order refunds for only the most exorbitant prices. 
"It may be easier to identify bad hours than bad actors," the memorandum said.
The commission took the easier way. It decided not to investigate reports of abuses by companies, but issued an order that could require them to refund to the state utilities up to $124 million collected during a relatively few "bad hours" in January and February. That is hundreds of millions of dollars less than California might have claimed, since the most potential overcharging occurred during "good hours," when power was more plentiful but prices were often just as extreme. The order ignored those hours.
Today, in a criticism of the agency's lack of aggressiveness, California regulators estimated that generators had charged $6.2 billion above competitive levels over 10 months. They urged the agency to dig deeper, hoping it would demand more refunds or other stiff remedies. But the agency's track record -- one of complacency in the eyes of state officials -- leaves California regulators skeptical that Washington will confront the big power producers.
The small, obscure agency, tucked behind the rail yard of Union Station here, has largely soft-pedaled its role as the electricity industry's top cop, even though it has wide authority to keep power companies in line. To keep rates reasonable, it can impose price caps, strip companies of the right to charge market rates, force them to return excessive profits and even suspend deregulation altogether.
Instead, the agency has largely left it to private companies to pry open the $250 billion electricity industry, which has historically been controlled by monopoly utilities and state officials. The agency's defenders, including its chairman, Curt Hebert Jr., a fierce advocate of unfettered markets, say that its largely hands-off approach reflects the delicate balancing of competing interests -- a commitment to protect consumers while not stifling market forces.
But politicians, utility executives, energy economists and local regulators say California's rolling blackouts and skyrocketing electricity prices are the signs of a market running amok. They accuse the agency of standing aside as companies manipulate their way to windfall profits. The agency's critics, who include one of its own commissioners and numerous staff members, say that its enforcement mission has been blunted by free-market passions and the influence of industry insiders in its ranks.
When the agency began its first national investigation of high electricity prices last year, it named a newly recruited industry insider, Scott Miller, to lead the effort. Mr. Miller and his colleagues said in their report that there was "insufficient data" in California to prove any profiteering by generating companies. Yet his own former employer, PG&E Energy Trading, was at the time a subject of a civil antitrust investigation by the Justice Department that focused on electricity market abuses in New England.
The agency has given state regulators a lead role in monitoring local power markets. Yet even as these regulators have urged the agency to be more aggressive in investigating suspicions that companies have abused their power in California, New England, the Midwest and the mid-Atlantic, they have frequently been ignored or rebuffed.
Critics say that the agency began deregulation before it was ready or willing to make sure the markets worked effectively. They accuse it of showing favoritism to industry -- allowing companies, for example, to ignore requirements to file detailed reports of market transactions that are critical to proving accusations of market abuses.
"We need to wake up to the fact that this is a dysfunctional market that is being gamed and manipulated by those who participate in it," said William Massey, a commissioner of the agency who has become one of its leading critics. 
The agency's inaction, the critics say, leads to "gaming" -- jockeying for profits that does not necessarily involve illegality -- and outright market manipulation. Consumers and utilities are the victims, paying billions of dollars more for electricity than if the markets were truly competitive.
Agency officials acknowledge that enforcement of market rules to curb gaming and manipulation had not been a high priority in previous years. But they defended their recent California order as proof that they intend to keep markets free of abuse. They add that the agency is also pressuring two generators to refund almost $11 million for possibly manipulating the California market last spring.
Agency officials and some outside analysts say that poorly conceived deregulation plans by states, a shortage of power plants, rising natural gas prices, and even the weather have had more impact on electricity prices than abuses by companies or any failings by the agency. They say the agency must balance the competing interests of generators, local regulators and utility companies if it is to keep deregulation on track.
"We're trying to craft a system that gives breathing room to develop a market, but not so much room that undue market power punishes consumers," Mr. Hebert said.

Fight Over Deregulation
Today's debate traces back to the 1930's, when President Franklin D. Roosevelt backed legislation to break up utility monopolies. The Federal Power Act of 1935 gave the Federal Power Commission a mandate to ensure "just and reasonable" electricity rates. The Federal Power Commission was abolished in 1977 and replaced by the Federal Energy Regulatory Commission, an independent agency with 1,200 employees that also oversees oil pipelines and the natural gas market. The president appoints the chairman and four commissioners -- two Democrats and two Republicans with staggered terms of five years. Two Republican seats are currently unfilled.
The deregulation of the electricity markets began in the late 1980's, after the agency had begun opening the gas markets. By 1996, the commissioners issued a landmark order that forced utility companies to open their transmission lines to other utilities and electricity wholesalers. The commission and many private economists expected that by prying open protected markets, electricity prices would immediately fall.
That possibility set off a deregulation frenzy, most prominently in California, New York, New England and the mid-Atlantic states. Generating companies rushed to expand in the new, borderless market.
But the agency's balancing act has grown more difficult as electricity deregulation has spread nationwide. Congress has forced it to trim its staff in recent years. Officials complain that investigating abuses in electricity markets strains their resources.
And as the California crisis has worsened, the commissioners have begun sparring publicly among themselves about what to do. This week, Mr. Massey, a Democratic commissioner, and Mr. Hebert (pronounced AY-bear), a Republican, sat side by side before a House panel and argued diametrically opposed positions. Mr. Hebert said high prices in California "were sending the right signals to get supply there." Mr. Massey called the prices that generators were charging "unlawful" and said that his agency, by not reining them in, "is simply not doing its job."
The agency's leadership has been in flux for months. Congressional and industry officials in Washington say President Bush is considering replacing Mr. Hebert, whom he named to the top post less than two months ago, with Pat Wood, who runs the Texas public utility commission. A White House spokeswoman had no comment on the reports. 
Though Mr. Hebert's positions are not far from those of the Bush administration, his relations with California leaders may have made his position tenuous. Mr. Hebert, a Mississippian who is a close ally of the Senate majority leader, Trent Lott, has warred with California politicians who have proposed new solutions to the crisis there.
Mr. Hebert, who has served as a commissioner since 1997, has often taken the most ideologically free-market position of any commissioner. He flatly rejects the idea of price caps on electricity as hopelessly ineffective and contrary to market forces. When Gov. Gray Davis outlined a plan to have the state buy transmission lines to relieve utility companies' debt, Mr. Hebert's response was dismissive. "It's not in the interest of the American public," he pronounced.
Even as new electricity markets opened in the summer of 1999, they started producing nasty shocks. The mid-Atlantic region experienced some early volatility.
As the turmoil grew, economists began raising the alarm about a phenomenon called "market power," the ability of energy traders in the new national market to sustain prices above the competitive level. Proving such abuses is difficult, because it requires comparing tens of thousands of separate electricity transactions with the costs of the generators that initiated them.
Joseph Bowring, who heads the market monitoring unit of the nonprofit entity that operates the mid-Atlantic transmission system, said that power companies there had exercised some market power. But only the Federal Energy Regulatory Commission, not local regulators, had the authority to collect the data to determine how much market power had been exercised and whether it had been abusive or not, he said.
Mr. Bowring said he talked to agency officials about doing so. In the end, Mr. Bowring and several agency officials said, the agency chose not to investigate.
The decision roiled some agency officials.
Ron Rattey, a veteran agency economist, wrote a memorandum last June describing the staff as "impotent in our ability to monitor, foster, and ensure competitive electric power markets." The staff, the memorandum said, did not even enforce a requirement that power companies file detailed quarterly reports listing essentially every sale they make. Such data would have been useful to Mr. Bowring.

Local-Federal Clash
Local regulators who want to ensure competitive prices often have to act on their own. Monitors in New England have intervened about 600 times since 1999 to correct prices they determined had been caused, at least in part, by market manipulation.
The federal agency has sometimes chastised them for interfering too much.
The industry, not surprisingly, shares that view. One vocal critic was Mr. Miller. Before the agency recruited him last July to head its division of energy markets, he was director of policy coordination for the national energy-trading unit of PG&E Corporation, the California holding company whose assets also include Pacific Gas and Electric, the California utility.
Although the utility has lost billions of dollars during California's crisis, Mr. Miller's former unit has become one of the most profitable new energy traders nationwide. PG&E Energy Trading, by several estimates, is now the second-largest seller of electricity in New England.
The company has had a rocky relationship with regulators. They intervened several times in 1999 and 2000 to retroactively cancel auctions they said produced excessive profits for PG&E and other companies. Mr. Miller denounced the practice, though he acknowledged in public testimony that his company sometimes charged "very high" prices when it could.
"One person's predatory pricing is another person's competitive advantage," Mr. Miller said at a public hearing on deregulation in Texas in 1999. New England regulators too often acted as "judge, jury and executioner" when overseeing the market, he said.
One year later, Mr. Miller and his new colleagues at the federal agency got a chance to examine New England's problems from the regulators' perspective. Their Nov. 1 report attributed New England's frequent price gyrations to technical and regulatory flaws.
As Mr. Miller's team was preparing its report, the Justice Department, whose threshold for stepping into possible industry wrongdoing is far higher than the agency's, began looking into whether price spikes in New England pointed to unlawful monopoly power or collusion, people contacted by the department during that inquiry said.
One subject of the civil inquiry is possible price manipulation in one of New England's ancillary services markets, people contacted by the department said. They said the department was examining whether PG&E and two other companies tried to corner that market for several months early last year. PG&E confirmed that the Justice Department had contacted it, but denies wrongdoing and says it has cooperated with the department's requests.
Mr. Miller has declined to comment on his role at PG&E or at the agency. His supervisors defended his work and said they had detected no conflict of interest between his work at PG&E and his duties at the agency.
Those duties brought Mr. Miller to California last August. With electricity prices there soaring, he and his colleagues sat down with several utility executives at the agency's San Francisco office.
One executive, Gary Stern, director of market monitoring for Southern California Edison, wanted the agency to stop what he suspected were market abuses by power generators. He provided a road map to help investigators figure out how power companies traded power contracts -- and whether they had manipulated the markets.
But when Mr. Miller and his team approached 11 generators and marketers -- including his old employer -- a few weeks later, they did it their way. They asked eight questions, many of them imprecise, like: "Describe your strategy for bidding generation resources into market."
This question, Mr. Stern said in a recent interview, "was equivalent to asking a suspected burglar how he spent his day."
Some agency officials also thought the team should probe deeper. Mr. Rattey recommended that Mr. Miller seek the quarterly pricing reports that marketers were supposed to file. But his suggestion was not adopted, agency records show.
Daniel Larcamp, Mr. Miller's supervisor, said "there might have been more information that could have been obtained" in the California inquiry. But he said the commission gave the staff only three months to finish, making it impossible to collect and analyze the reams of data involved. 
For Mr. Miller, agency documents show, the investigation was so time-consuming that he had no time to fill out the financial disclosure form required of new federal employees. Mr. Miller submitted his form in late January, after a reporter requested it. Agency lawyers approved the form, but only after he provided additional information about his job and compensation from PG&E. The lawyers said Mr. Miller's participation had been permissible because PG&E was not the subject of the investigation.
When the staff report was issued on Nov. 1, it found high prices and problems in the design of the California market. But while the companies "had the potential to exercise market power," the commission said, there was "insufficient data" to prove that they did.
Some marketers saw the report as an exoneration.
"This has been looked at several times, most notably by the FERC and nobody has found any evidence of market manipulation and profiteering," Rob Doty, the chief financial officer of Dynegy Inc., told a reporter earlier this year.

California Inquiry
The agency has recently shown signs of wanting to apply pressure on generators. But its early efforts show how it is treading on new and uncertain turf.
When the California crisis grew severe last December, the commission issued a refund order, a shot across the bow for generators charging high prices. It required them to submit detailed data any time they sold electricity in California for more than $150 per megawatt hour, considered at the time a fair estimate of the highest costs any of them faced.
It also told generators that for the next several months, they could be forced to give refunds if the agency found that they had charged excessive prices. The commission also said that it would examine bidding practices and strategies for withholding generating capacity to ferret out any efforts to artificially raise prices.
When the agency's own 60-day deadline for examining market data in January approached, however, it became clear that staff members had not made any detailed examination. Instead, staff members said, the agency scrambled to forge a last-minute compromise that would allow it to issue a statement opposing high prices in the state without a time-consuming investigation.
During this scramble, a senior staff member, Kevin Kelly, suggested focusing on bad hours instead of bad actors.
"Our attempts to find illegal behavior or legal 'misbehavior' by sellers ('bad actors') always seems to fail," his memorandum said. It said that the agency could more easily blame high prices on acute shortages during the most critical hours.
The suggestion won the day. The commission decided to limit its order to the hours when California declared a Stage 3 emergency, when supplies are critically low.
Mr. Stern of Southern California Edison and several private-sector economists have attacked the economic logic of that order. They said that the commission has focused on times when prices might be legitimately high. The bigger worry: Generators can and often do sustain artificially high prices when supplies are not as tight, they say.
Mr. Massey, the Democratic commissioner, dissented from the decision for those reasons. Because most high-priced transactions in January and February did not occur during bad hours, he argued, the commission effectively chose to bless as "just and reasonable" the hefty profits generators are making from the California crisis.
"The problem with my agency is that we're so carried away with the rhetoric of markets that we've gotten sloppy," Mr. Massey said. "We're talking about electricity. It's the juice of the economy, so it's got to be available and reasonably priced."

HEADLINE: Foreign Affairs; 
Markets Call the Tune

BYLINE:  By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN; Gail Collins is on vacation.

 BODY:
I was talking to a friend on Wall Street about what impact the plunging Dow and Nasdaq might have on U.S. foreign policy, when he stopped me and said, "Look, the Nasdaq is America's Viagra -- without it, we just don't feel quite so potent."
 I wouldn't exaggerate the impact of the declining markets on U.S. foreign policy -- we mounted the Persian Gulf War during an economic slowdown. Nevertheless, part of the expansiveness of U.S. foreign policy during the past decade -- whether it was our intensive diplomacy in Northern Ireland and the Middle East, or our expansion of NATO, or our aggressive exporting of American capitalism, or our interventions in Bosnia, Haiti and Kosovo -- was to some degree tied to the soaring U.S. Dow and Nasdaq and the sense they produced of boundless American power. 
 There were plenty of good reasons to intervene to halt mass killings in the Balkans, but the soaring markets made these and other interventions much easier. There wasn't great public support for many of these operations, but there also wasn't much opposition because the costs were not big enough to notice -- and that was partly a function of how rich we felt. With the Nasdaq at 5,000, the public's attitude was that we could afford guns and butter, Arabs and Israelis, Northern Ireland and Nafta -- whatever. 
But with the Nasdaq's having fallen from 5,000 to 1,900, I sense that the public's attitude has gone from "Whatever" to "What did you say?" The same thing happened in Japan. When the Nikkei soared a decade ago, Japan was demanding a seat on the U.N. Security Council and sending peacekeeping missions abroad. With the Nikkei now in the tank, you don't hear much of that talk any more. With 50 percent of Americans now invested in the stock market and the markets collapsing, the public's tolerance for solving other people's problems has surely diminished. A broker friend called me to say that his mother had called him to complain that Alan Greenspan had lowered interest rates only 50 basis points, instead of 75. "Ten years ago my mother had never heard of Greenspan," the broker said. "Now she has an opinion on monetary policy."
But the soaring Nasdaq was not the only reason for American expansiveness abroad in the past decade. It also had to do with the fact that there is no more military draft, so none of the idle rich, no dot-com-ers, had to give up their stock options to serve in Bosnia or Haiti, and even more important, those who did go went with the assumption, and almost the promise, that these would be "zero-casualty wars." Americans had the same attitude toward the Nasdaq in the past decade that they had toward foreign wars: they were both no-lose propositions. You couldn't get hurt in either the Nasdaq or Kosovo, it seemed, so why not do both?
But now the laws of economics have brought down bloated tech stocks, and the laws of geopolitics -- that nature abhors a vacuum and if NATO doesn't fill the vacuum in Kosovo the local Albanian nationalists will -- have raised the stakes in the Balkans. Staying in both the stock market and Kosovo now has real costs.
Not only do we look at the world differently with the Nasdaq at 1,900, but the world looks at us differently. There's already a tendency among critics of U.S.-style capitalism to read the bursting of the Nasdaq bubble as an indictment of the American system and the vitality of our society. This is wrong and will be demonstrated as such when this business cycle ends. Meantime, one must agree with Jeff Garten, dean of Yale's School of Management, when he argues: "In the post-cold-war world the currency of a country's credibility is the strength of its economy. And to the extent that America was seen as having the magic formula, the rest of the world was willing to follow our lead. Now you will hear America's critics declaring, 'Who are these Americans to throw their weight around and tell us what to do?' "
Again, public moods alone don't determine foreign policy and would never stand in the way of wars of no choice. But the point about the post-cold-war era is that we feel it gives us more choices to intervene or not. And the markets, which have become the background Muzak of our lives, will affect the public's choices, especially if they turn costly. Background Muzak matters. If it didn't, companies wouldn't pay to put it in elevators.

HEADLINE: The Census Shows Growth In Atlanta's Population 

BYLINE:  By DAVID FIRESTONE 

DATELINE: ATLANTA, March 22 

 BODY:
The unstoppable growth in northern Georgia has finally spilled into the city of Atlanta, reversing a population decline that began in the 1970's and shifting the city's demographics, the latest census figures show.
 Between 1990 and 2000, the city of Atlanta grew to 416,474 from 415,219 people, an increase of three-tenths of 1 percent. But just as surprising to demographers was the fact that much of the growth was the result of whites moving back to the city after years of flight. 
 There were 130,222 white, non-Hispanic residents of Atlanta last year, the census figures show, compared with 122,877 in 1990, an increase of 6 percent. At the same time, the number of black residents in the city declined to 254,062 from 279,987, a decrease of 9 percent. Blacks are no longer two-thirds of the city's population, slipping to 61 percent, while the percentage of whites increased to 31 percent from 29 percent. The number of Hispanics -- who can be of any race -- more than doubled in the city, increasing to 4.5 percent of the population from 2 percent. 
The region's enormous growth began around the same time as the city's population decline, in the late 1960's and early 1970's. As white residents began leaving the city for the suburbs in response to desegregation, they were joined there by millions of newcomers from the Northeast and Midwest, attracted to the region's improving economy.
The city never again reached its peak of 496,973 in 1970, but the 20-county region boomed to 4.1 million residents last year from 1.8 million residents in 1970, the census numbers show. By far the largest increase occurred in the last decade, when the region grew by 39 percent.
The comparison of census data uses an adjusted figure for 1990 that adds an estimate of undercounted residents, mostly members of minorities, believed to be missed in the original census. The 2000 figures have not been adjusted, but last year's census was considered more accurate in counting minorities.
Using the unadjusted figure for 1990 -- 393,929 -- the city's population increased by nearly 6 percent during the decade.
Analysts said the shifts in the city were a result of the region's growth.
"From what we're seeing, it looks like a migration back into the city, probably from people tired of all those commutes," said Robert Giacomini, research director for the state data center at the Georgia Institute of Technology. "These numbers are higher than expected for Atlanta, and I think they reflect the fact that traffic here is becoming national news."
Most of the growth in the city is within a few minutes drive of downtown, where new residents are renovating older houses and moving into a growing number of apartments and lofts. Officials have been trying to encourage new housing and office space around subway stations, hoping to reduce the traffic and air pollution that have become the region's new symbols. There has been little indication that the number of miles driven in the region has declined, but officials expressed hope today that the new numbers raised the possibility of a turnaround.
While whites are returning to the city, the increasing economic power of blacks has propelled many into the suburbs, particularly in the less-congested southern tier of the region that has proved less popular in previous years with white newcomers.
Clayton County, southeast of Atlanta, was 24 percent black in 1990 and is now 51 percent black. DeKalb County, to the east (and including a section of Atlanta), was 42 percent black, and is now 53 percent black.
But the numbers show that white residents are also moving to the southern tier of the metropolitan area, seeking the easier traffic and lower housing prices than they have found in the northern crescent that has been the engine of the region's suburban growth. Henry County, an 80 percent white county wedged between DeKalb and Clayton, has doubled in population in the last decade.
"A county like Henry is growing by selling to the entry-level housing market," said Bart Lewis, chief researcher for the Atlanta Regional Commission, a planning body. "You can buy a $150,000 house there and have a 40-minute commute, or a house for the same price on the north side and a 90-minute commute. Congestion is driving the patterns of growth."
Over all, Georgia's population grew by 23 percent in the last decade, to 8.2 million people, an increase that moved the state to 10th in population from 11th and gave it two new Congressional seats. The number of Hispanics increased sharply to 435,227 from 115,615, and in several counties, one in five residents is Hispanic.
Other cities around the South also grew in the last decade, census figures show. Memphis grew to 650,100 people from 640,033, an increase of 1.6 percent, while Nashville grew to 569,891 people from 532,471, an increase of 7 percent. In North Carolina, Charlotte grew to 540,828 from 412,486, a 31 percent increase, while Raleigh grew to 276,093 from 215,578, a 28 percent increase.
But New Orleans declined substantially, moving to 484,674 residents last year from 514,554 in 1990, a loss of nearly 6 percent. Louisiana's economy has not been as successful as that of Southern states farther east, and the state grew only 3 percent in the 1990's.

HEADLINE: Reporter's Notebook; 
The New State Budget, All Versions, Is Bigger

BYLINE:  By RICHARD PEREZ-PENA 

DATELINE: ALBANY, March 22 

 BODY:
Every day, newspapers tell of signs that the economy is slowing, of state and local governments having to trim their sails. The talk nearly everywhere is of caution and cuts.
 But not in Albany, and especially not in the Assembly. 
 Gov. George E. Pataki, a Republican, proposed a 5.4 percent spending increase in the next state budget, to $83.7 billion. The Republican-controlled Senate's plan is a bit larger and calls for more tax cuts. And on Tuesday, the Democrats who control the Assembly called for an 8.2 percent increase, to $86 billion. 
The governor says that the Legislature, particularly the Assembly, is acting as if New York were immune to what ails the nation. "There's no doubt in my mind or most people's minds that we're facing a very real national economic slowdown," he said.
Mr. Pataki has built the state's reserve funds to record levels, to protect against a downturn. The Citizens Budget Commission, an independent group, praised his proposed budget as the most prudent in 16 years (though what counts as prudence here would be a spending binge elsewhere).
The Assembly speaker, Sheldon Silver, points to the state's large surplus, its healthy tax revenues and its pressing needs in education and other areas, and concludes that now is no time for an excess of caution.
But the governor repeatedly cites what happened in 1990, when a recession hit, the state was unprepared and lawmakers had to make midyear budget cuts. Mr. Pataki, then a little-known assemblyman, has called that a watershed experience for him, one he vows not to repeat.

It Takes Awhile
Bet on the state budget being late this year. Very late.
The budget is supposed to be adopted by April 1, the start of the fiscal year. Nice theory. It hasn't happened since 1984. The only question is whether it will be manageably late, or infuriatingly late.
Recent history strongly suggests that this will be a bad year, and not because of mere substantive disagreements (though there are plenty of those). It's all about odd-numbered years.
In an even-numbered year, every member of the Legislature is up for re-election. No one likes to be stuck in Albany while an opponent traipses around the home district, blaming the incumbent for a late budget. Besides, election-year budgets usually contain enough pork to send everyone home happy without too much fighting.
Lawmakers finished the budget in April in 1998, and in May last year; in both years, the legislative session ended on time, in mid-June. In 1997 and 1999, budget negotiations, and the session, dragged into August.
"When we go into the summer, a lot of spouses call and say, 'I'm going to Cape Cod whether you do or not,' " said Assemblyman Herman D. Farrell Jr., chairman of the Ways and Means Committee. "But sometimes that doesn't have the same pull that a re-election drive does."

Aid to Schools
The three sides are far apart on aid to local schools. The governor wants to increase it by less than 3 percent, the Senate Republicans by 7 percent, and the Assembly Democrats by 13 percent, a spread of more than $1.3 billion.
But looked at another way, there is remarkable agreement. All three sides have proposed similar approaches to restructuring education spending. There are important differences in the details, but all three have called for collapsing the many different categories of aid into a few, giving districts more flexibility in spending that money, and funneling any increases in aid primarily to "high need" districts like New York City.
"We're all in the same ballpark," said Senator John R. Kuhl Jr., chairman of the Senate Education Committee. "Everyone understands the need for flexibility."
In a landmark ruling in January, Justice Leland DeGrasse of State Supreme Court in Manhattan ordered the state to increase aid to the city's schools and to simplify the tangled knot of aid formulas. Mr. Pataki has said he will appeal the decision, but the budget proposals here could be seen as a first, small step toward complying with it and unraveling a byzantine system.
Then there is the matter of that $1.3 billion.

A Statistical Anomaly
The Assembly Democrats call themselves the defenders of poor communities and public schools. So it was odd to find that their proposed budget would raise education aid to wealthy districts next year much faster than it would raise aid to poor districts.
That kind of disparity is an especially important issue in the wake of Justice DeGrasse's ruling, which has prompted a heated public debate over the adequacy and equity of school aid in New York. Urban Democrats who dominate the Assembly support the decision, while their Republican colleagues and some suburban Democrats oppose it.
Yet in the Assembly's own budget plan, Garden City and Scarsdale, two wealthy suburban districts, would receive state aid increases of 35 percent and 34 percent, respectively. Elmont and Yonkers, two nearby low-income districts, would get 15 percent and 17 percent, respectively.
What gives? It all stems from the Assembly Democrats' pet program to help districts provide prekindergarten classes for 4-year-olds, and smaller classes in kindergarten through third grade.
In the first years of the program, nearly all the money went to poorer districts, while the wealthier ones will catch up next year. Those wealthy districts receive relatively little state aid, so even a fairly small increase in dollars can be a huge increase in percentage.
In other words, the apparent generosity to high-income communities is a statistical anomaly, one that would disappear after a year.
Mr. Silver and his colleagues have proposed a two-year education budget, a departure from the usual practice. "We're doing this to lock the governor into an election-year commitment to education," he said.
But some Assembly Democrats say privately that the sole reason for doing so was to avoid the embarrassment of appearing to favor wealthy areas over poor ones.

HEADLINE: Metro Business Briefing; 
NEW YORK CITY RESISTS SLUMP

BYLINE:  By Leslie Eaton 

 BODY:
 Statistics released yesterday by the New York State Department of Labor show New York City with a jobless rate of 5.3 percent in February, up slightly from the 5.1 percent in January but still below the 5.6 percent in December, when economic jitters began to sweep the country. 
And the city continues to generate new jobs at a rapid pace. Employment at private-sector companies grew by 2.5 percent in the 12 months ended in February, while nationally, employment rose by just 1.4 percent. Manufacturing suffered its sharpest drop since January of 1996, according to Comptroller Alan G. Hevesi. But there has been a surge of demand for secretaries and administrative assistants. Leslie Eaton (NYT)

HEADLINE: In Leaving Seattle, Boeing Also Asserts It's Not Just a Plane Builder 

BYLINE:  By LAURENCE ZUCKERMAN 

 BODY:
The Boeing Company's surprising plan to move its headquarters out of Seattle 85 years after the company's founding there represents the boldest step yet in a quest it has been chasing nearly as long: escaping the economic ups and downs of aircraft manufacturing. 
 As early as 1918, two years after its founding, Boeing decided to make flat-bottom boats and furniture to counter the slump in airplane sales after World War I. After World War II ended, it began making gas-turbine engines. And in the late 1960's, when aircraft sales dried up for more than a year, Boeing started making hydrofoils, wind-powered turbines and police-radio scramblers. 
 None of these businesses caught on, and Boeing ultimately abandoned them when commercial plane sales rebounded. As a result, its share price has soared and plunged over the years, and it has laid off thousands of workers only to hire them back when jet sales picked up. 
Having made more than $20 billion worth of acquisitions over the last four years, Philip M. Condit, Boeing's chairman and chief executive, has done more than any of his predecessors to diversify the company. Now Mr. Condit thinks he must take a startling step -- moving Boeing's headquarters to sever both the physical and psychological ties to its long heritage as a plane builder.
In announcing the headquarters move on Wednesday, Mr. Condit said he hoped the relocation to Dallas, Denver or Chicago, which he said would be completed by the fall, would show Wall Street analysts and investors that Boeing was no longer just a maker of passenger jets.
But that is also a risk because while there are some promising signs, it is not at all clear that Mr. Condit's corporate strategy will be any more successful than the company's past efforts. 
"Even if you diversify, you still have the problem of not being able to move people from one business to another," said David C. Colander, a professor of economics at Middlebury College in Vermont. "When the airplane sales drop, you still have all those employees with nothing to do." 
There is nothing wrong with having a cyclical business, he added, if you are profitable on average. 
Since buying the McDonnell Douglas Corporation, the space operations of Rockwell International and the satellite manufacturing division of Hughes Electronics, Boeing has become the world's largest aerospace company. It is now organized into three independent divisions: commercial airplanes, space and communications, and military aircraft and missile systems. 
But the company relied on the airplane business for 61 percent of its operating revenue last year, down from 66 percent in 1999. That and its military business face the prospect of slow growth in the near future. And several of the businesses that Mr. Condit is hoping will deliver big profits are highly risky and may not bear fruit for many years. 
Last year, Boeing announced that it would enter the market to supply live Internet connections on passenger jets. That business seemed like an ideal opportunity to combine the expertise of Boeing's satellite and aircraft manufacturing divisions. 
But airlines' enthusiasm for the in-flight Internet has since cooled. The practical questions of how much the carriers are willing to pay to install the equipment on their jets and how much of the revenue they are willing to share with Boeing have proved more complicated than expected.
In addition, it is not clear that large numbers of passengers would be willing to pay a premium to surf the Net at 30,000 feet. The market is likely to take many years to develop. 
Mr. Condit is also excited about an initiative to develop a new air traffic control system, using satellite technology. That would both make Boeing a tidy sum and provide room in the skies for more Boeing jets. But like the military contracting business, air traffic control systems are expensive to develop and appeal to only a small number of customers. 
Boeing has had more immediate success expanding its aircraft services business. It won contracts to convert fleets of passenger jets to freighters and has entered the maintenance business, which has put it in competition with some of its big customers. 
The company is also taking a cue from its old rival McDonnell Douglas by moving into the finance business. Using the parent company's wealthy balance sheet, the Boeing Capital Corporation helps finance the sale of products across all Boeing divisions and is to be expanded. 
"If you look at Boeing, the picture that you have is of a company that is generating a flood of cash," said Wolfgang Demisch, an investment banker at Dresdner Kleinwort Wasserstein, who has followed Boeing for years. "The critical issue from a corporate perspective is how do you deploy that cash for the benefit of the shareholders."
Last year, Mr. Condit used some of the cash to buy the Hughes satellite business as well as Jeppesen Sanderson, a maker of digital navigation maps and other information, and a handful of other companies. Yesterday, he told analysts that Boeing might make other acquisitions, particularly in the finance arena. 
At the same time he announced the headquarters move, Mr. Condit gave each of the heads of the three main operating units the title of president and chief executive. Since all three are already in charge of their divisions, it is difficult to tell whether the new titles are simply cosmetic. 
But Mr. Condit said he planned to push much of the decision-making down to the operating units, leaving the new, leaner headquarters the job of focusing on the company's overall strategy. 
"The role of the headquarters is to make sure we are incubating new, dynamic businesses," he said. 
The move may accelerate Boeing's transformation into a truly global company. For while it has had a presence in scores of countries for decades, Boeing's top managers and its board remained more insular than many other American multinational corporations. 
It remains to be seen whether Boeing will be any more successful conquering new businesses as a company based outside Seattle than it has been in past attempts.

HEADLINE: Schwab Plans Up to 3,400 Job Cuts 

BYLINE:  By DANNY HAKIM 

 BODY:
The Charles Schwab Corporation, forecasting no rebound in investor sentiment this year, said yesterday that it would eliminate 11 percent to 13 percent of its work force and warned that its first-quarter earnings would fall short of already lowered expectations.
 Shares of Schwab, the nation's largest online brokerage firm, fell 4 percent, or 70 cents, to $15.20, the stock's lowest closing price in more than two years. 
 The job cuts, to come mostly through layoffs in the second quarter, will reduce Schwab's work force of 25,500 by 2,750 to 3,400. The company expects the job cuts, as well as planned reductions in office space and spending on technology, to save $40 million to $50 million a quarter, starting in the second half of the year. 
Schwab officials also said the company would earn 8 cents a share in the first quarter, 3 cents short of the consensus expectations of analysts, according to Thomson Financial/First Call. Schwab had warned in February that it would not meet the previous consensus estimate of 15 cents a share.
"We face a period where our clients are trading less, and trading less in a profound way," David S. Pottruck, co-chief executive of Schwab, said.
Schwab is responding to mounting pressures felt across the brokerage industry as the long boom has given way to a bear market. Merrill Lynch, Bear, Stearns and other securities firms have announced job cuts in recent months, but most Wall Street firms have avoided layoffs despite the steep slump in their businesses.
Schwab had tried to stave off layoffs, using voluntary Friday leaves and executive salary cuts but they provided only a temporary reprieve, an official said. 
The spending cuts that brokerage firms are making to appease shareholders could give an edge to privately held competitors, like Fidelity Investments, the Boston-based mutual fund and brokerage firm. "The biggest risk to Schwab is that private companies like Fidelity really pick up their investment spending," said Amy Butte, an analyst with Bear Stearns.
Schwab's existing account balances have shrunk and the appetite of customers for trading has fallen sharply. Schwab's average daily revenue from trades was $189,000 in February, down from $279,400 a year ago, a 32.4 percent decline. Margin loans, which allow customers to borrow money to buy more securities, have plummeted, further cutting into the firm's revenues. 
It is also harder to attract new accounts. Last February, the firm landed 150,700 new accounts, compared with 78,500 this February. 
As a result, Schwab is having to retrench from its expansion and spend more time digesting its recent purchases of U.S. Trust, a firm that helps wealthy clients manage their money, and CyBerCorp Inc., a broker for active do-it-yourself traders. The acquisition of both companies was completed last year. 
Henry McVey, an analyst at Morgan Stanley Dean Witter, said he supported both acquisitions in the long term, but believed that integrating them would prove costly in the short term, especially as Schwab faces a bleak market environment. He said Schwab's revenue had fallen 29 percent from a year ago but its earnings per share had declined far more, 65 percent. 
"You haven't gotten the payoff yet," Mr. McVey said. 
Charles R. Schwab, the founder and co-chief executive, said the firm had expanded to meet the surging demands of customers during the bull market.
"We've been through a highly speculative technology bubble," Mr. Schwab said. "Maybe I should have been more emphatic about understanding it was only a temporary phenomenon, but we weren't sure."
Now that stock trading is waning, Mr. Schwab and Mr. Pottruck said customers wanted more advice. That demand prompted the firm to shield U.S. Trust from the job cuts, as customers seek the firm's advisory services. 
"U.S. Trust will not be affected by these cutbacks because the business continues to grow and grow very nicely," Mr. Pottruck said.

HEADLINE: Clinton Critic Is Bush Choice To Run F.T.C. 

BYLINE:  By STEPHEN LABATON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 22 

 BODY:
Signaling a sharp shift in the enforcement of the nation's antitrust laws, the White House announced today its intention to nominate Timothy J. Muris, a leading critic of the Clinton administration's antitrust policies, to become the next chairman of the Federal Trade Commission.
 The nomination of Mr. Muris, a 51-year-old economist and law professor who was a top antitrust official during the Reagan administration and an economic adviser to both President Bush and his father, was widely expected. 
 Experts said today that it was certain to lead to a significant easing of reviews of corporate mergers and a far less aggressive policy toward prosecuting cases of monopoly. 
Mr. Muris has long maintained that the Clinton administration challenged too many mergers and filed too many antimonopoly cases without adequately exploring the potential benefits that large companies bring to consumers in the form of efficient production and distribution. Although liberals have in recent years become more sympathetic to efficiencies as a defense to mergers and monopolistic conduct, Mr. Muris has said antitrust regulators needed to go further.
"Efficiency defenses will undoubtedly be taken more seriously under a Muris regime," said Herbert Hovenkamp, an antitrust scholar at the University of Iowa College of Law. "His appointment is clearly a move to the right. He's more aligned with the Reagan era of antitrust, but I wouldn't regard him as far right."
Mr. Muris's views of the Clinton administration's handling of monopoly cases is aptly summarized in an article he wrote on the subject last summer in the Antitrust Law Journal. The three main chapters in the article are titled "The F.T.C. is Wrong on the Law," "The F.T.C. is Wrong on Policy" and "The F.T.C. is Wrong on the Facts."
In the article, he criticized the agency's decision to sue Visx, a maker of laser vision correction equipment, and Intel, the chip maker, for antitrust violations in two important monopoly cases. (Visx won its case; Intel settled its case on the eve of trial.)
In an article two years ago on antitrust reviews of corporate mergers, he criticized the Clinton administration's handling of mergers. While he praised officials for accepting the arguments of merging companies that such deals produced important economic efficiencies that could benefit consumers, he said the administration had not gone far enough.
"The government antitrust agencies -- the antitrust division of the Department of Justice and the Federal Trade Commission -- have refused to recognize fully the efficiency-creating potential of mergers," Mr. Muris wrote in the George Mason Law Review's spring 1999 issue. "Although the government's treatment of efficiencies has varied, one theme dominates: a reluctance to accept efficiency as a justification for a transaction."
In particular, Mr. Muris has criticized a series of cases that have been the hallmark of the tenure of the current chairman, Robert Pitofsky. Mr. Muris has criticized the agency's decision to challenge two mergers among the nation's four largest wholesale drug distributors, and another deal that would leave two companies controlling 98 percent of the United States market for prepared baby foods. 
Antitrust experts predicted that the F.T.C. under Mr. Muris would not bring many cases of the kind that Mr. Pitofsky had brought. 
"In merger reviews, the bread and butter of antitrust, many people say Muris will only make a difference at the margins," said Steven C. Salop, a professor of law and economics at the Georgetown University Law Center. "I think those margins could be quite big."
At the same time, Mr. Salop and Mr. Hovenkamp said, Mr. Muris has shown that he supports cases against trade associations and other affiliations involving rivals that collaborate in ways that can discourage competition.
"I think you will see him becoming more active in those instances where there is rule-making by professional associations," Mr. Hovenkamp said, "particularly where the rule-making has an impact on price or restraint on advertising."
Mr. Pitofsky, who has been chairman for the last six years, said today that he would step aside as soon as the Senate confirmed Mr. Muris. Mr. Pitofsky, who is widely credited by his supporters with reinvigorating antitrust enforcement, said he would return to teaching at the Georgetown University Law Center, where he had been the dean. 

CORRECTION-DATE: March 28, 2001

 CORRECTION:
An article in Business Day on Friday about the nomination of Timothy J. Muris as chairman of the Federal Trade Commission misstated the timing. The announcement was made late Wednesday, not Thursday.
