HEADLINE: U.S.-Business Effort Urged on Cyberterror 

BYLINE:  AP 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 22 

 BODY:
The government must work more closely with private companies to prevent cyberterrorist attacks that threaten to disrupt the nation's economy, Condoleezza Rice, the national security adviser, said today. 
 "Today, the cybereconomy is the economy," Ms. Rice said, referring to the nation's dependence on computers for vital services, including electricity, transportation, banking and communications. 
 "Corrupt those networks, and you disrupt this nation," she said here at a forum on Internet security. 
Financial losses from cyberattacks reached nearly $400 million last year, a 40 percent increase over the year before, industry figures show.
To discourage attacks in cyberspace, the nation must take additional steps to increase security and must be prepared if deterrents fail, Ms. Rice said.

HEADLINE: First Meeting: China Testing Firmer Way Of Bush Team 

BYLINE:  By MARC LACEY and DAVID E. SANGER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 22 

 BODY:
President Bush met today with the Chinese deputy prime minister, Qian Qichen, in an Oval Office session that highlighted the sharp discord between the United States and China on security issues and human rights, but appeared to do little to resolve it.
 The 55-minute meeting was Mr. Bush's first contact as president with a high-level emissary from Beijing and it came at a key time in the evolving relationship between the two countries. Mr. Qian, a senior Chinese diplomat who has seen American presidents come and go, approached the session as an opportunity to sound out a new administration that has from the start signaled a firmer approach toward China. 
 With Qian Qichen (pronounced chee-en chee-chun) sitting at his side, Mr. Bush told reporters before the meeting that he intended to foster good relations with China but also to speak out bluntly on disagreements. In private, the president urged the Chinese to respect human rights and religious freedom, and encouraged Beijing to release Gao Zhan, a Chinese scholar based in the United States who has been held in China in isolation for more than five weeks, officials said.
"Nothing we do is a threat to you and I want you to tell that to your leadership," Mr. Bush told Mr. Qian, according to an administration official who briefed reporters. 
During his visit here, Mr. Qian pressed China's opposition to the United States' sale to Taiwan of destroyers equipped with the Aegis radar system, but Mr. Bush indicated that he would move forward with assistance for Taiwan. Bush administration officials said the White House would make a decision on the exact package of arms sales to the Taiwanese next month and that the Chinese could best affect shipments by working to reduce tensions along the Taiwan Strait.
The Chinese have placed hundreds of short-range missiles near the island, American officials say, and Mr. Qian made comments before his arrival here indicating that the chance of military conflict would increase if the Bush administration proceeded with the Aegis sale. Mr. Qian's language in the Oval Office was more restrained, officials said. 
Mr. Bush's proposed national missile defense system was another point of contention, as Mr. Qian reiterated China's opposition. Mr. Bush offered a pitch in favor of a missile shield, telling Mr. Qian that it ought to reduce tensions. 
While Bush aides focused largely on the strategic challenges posed by China, the president was facing several economic hurdles as well. 
Last year Congress passed legislation giving China permanent normal trade relations with the United States, ending more than a decade of efforts to link a yearly renewal of its trade status to its human rights record. Mr. Bush supported the legislation, which was tied to China's entry into the World Trade Organization, long a goal of Beijing's leaders.
But now that the Chinese have won the battle in Congress, they are delaying the final negotiations with the W.T.O. The reason is clear: China's obligation to open its markets to foreign competition, putting more Chinese out of work and increasing political pressure on the Communist Party, does not begin until it formally becomes a member of the trade group, which sets the rules for global commerce.
"Our relationship, of course, will be a complex relationship," said Mr. Bush, who will visit China in October. "There will be areas where we can find agreement, such as trade. There will be some areas where we have some disagreements."
Earlier, Mr. Qian met separately with Secretary of State Colin L. Powell, Defense Secretary Donald H. Rumsfeld and a bipartisan group of lawmakers that included Senator Craig Thomas, Republican of Wyoming, and Senator Dianne Feinstein, Democrat of California.
"He came here to take the temperature of the new president and report back to his bosses on the new team," said a Senate foreign policy aide. Senator Jesse Helms, chairman of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee and one of the most vociferous critics of China, stayed away from Mr. Qian's breakfast meeting on Capitol Hill.
At dinner on Wednesday night, General Powell raised the issue of human rights violations in China during a wide-ranging conversation with Mr. Qian. The Chinese leader, as expected, disputed General Powell's view that the Chinese have restricted press freedom in Hong Kong and clamped down on the Falun Gong religious sect, a senior State Department official said.
Likewise, when Mr. Bush urged the release of Gao Zhan, whose husband and 5-year-old son were also held separately for 26 days, Mr. Qian said without going into detail that she may not have been aware she was violating the law, the administration official said.

HEADLINE: Repercussions of a Spy Case 

 BODY:
As the United States and Russia embark on a series of retaliatory diplomatic expulsions initiated by the Robert Hanssen spy affair, the two nations should not let the skirmishing escalate into a diplomatic donnybrook. American and Russian leaders face a host of important security, political and economic issues. An espionage case, however serious, ought not to shape relations between Washington and Moscow. 
 Expelling foreign diplomats in retaliation for espionage cases is a well-established international ritual. So it was no surprise that the Bush administration responded to last month's arrest of Mr. Hanssen, an F.B.I. spy hunter charged with selling American secrets to Moscow, by ejecting a number of Russian diplomats. What was unusual was the scope of the American retaliation. In all, 50 Russians have been told to leave, the largest number since Ronald Reagan expelled 80 Soviet diplomats in 1986. Moscow has already signaled that it will respond with expulsions of American diplomats from Russia. 
 Expulsions on this scale could put an early chill into relations with Moscow. Mr. Reagan's 1986 expulsions temporarily complicated diplomacy with the Soviet Union. But that episode was overtaken by the arms control initiatives of Mikhail Gorbachev and Mr. Reagan's positive responses. It was encouraging to hear President Bush declare yesterday that he still sought "good relations" with Russia. 
There is a clear rationale for narrowly targeted diplomatic expulsions. Americans suspected of spying, like Mr. Hanssen, can be arrested. But their foreign controllers are usually intelligence agents working under diplomatic cover. The standard recourse is to declare these individuals persona non grata and demand their departure. 
These 50 expulsions send a strong message. Given the damage alleged to have been done by Mr. Hanssen, including the betrayal of Russians who were spying for the United States, a vigorous response was justified. He is accused of compromising some of Washington's most sensitive spy operations. But after Moscow inevitably responds with its own expulsions, it will be time to move on. 
Before Mr. Bush meets Vladimir Putin in July, the two need to turn their attention to other pressing issues. These include America's missile defense plans, the need for both sides to make additional cuts in their nuclear arsenals and the cooperative programs the two countries have developed to dismantle decommissioned Russian nuclear weapons left over from the cold war. New measures should be taken to help Moscow safeguard its nuclear materials from theft. Russia's plans to sell conventional arms to Iran must also be addressed, as must be its cooperation with Tehran in the construction of nuclear reactors in ways that could speed the Iranian development of nuclear weapons. 
With Mr. Putin giving Russian foreign policy a more nationalist edge, there is already a growing possibility that relations between Moscow and Washington will become more quarrelsome. But it would be unfortunate if the Hanssen case set the tone for Mr. Bush's dealings with Mr. Putin.

HEADLINE: Piety at Kyoto Didn't Cool the Planet 

BYLINE:  By David G. Victor; David G. Victor is senior fellow for science and technology at the Council on Foreign Relations and author of the forthcoming "The Collapse of the Kyoto Protocol and the Struggle to Slow Global Warming."

 BODY:
President Bush met a barrage of criticism last week when he backed away from regulating carbon dioxide emissions, but he was only hastening the inevitable. A major shift in American policy on global warming had to come -- not chiefly because of the new administration's debts to campaign donors, but because of the sheer impracticality of the policy in place when George Bush took office. In the long run, Mr. Bush may actually have improved chances for slowing manmade changes in the world's climate.
 Until last week, global warming policy was synonymous with the Kyoto Protocol, which requires industrialized countries to control emissions of greenhouse gases according to strict targets and timetables. Environment ministers dominated the negotiations that led to the 1997 protocol, and they sought targets that were symbolically tough but hopelessly unrealistic. 
 Caught in this fervor, the United States agreed in Kyoto to cut its emissions of greenhouse gases to 7 percent below 1990 levels, on average, from 2008 to 2012. Yet on the eve of the Kyoto negotiations America's emissions were already up nearly 10 percent from 1990 levels, and they have risen about 1.2 percent a year since then. Most of the facilities that will be burning fossil fuels from 2008 to 2012 are already in place today. For that reason alone, the Kyoto Protocol was never likely to be approved and implemented by Congress. Other industrialized countries, too, have recorded rising, not falling, emissions.
Even as it became clear that most governments could not deliver on their Kyoto promises, powerful environmental groups and influential Green parties redoubled their support for the treaty rather than admit the need for adjustment. Under this pressure, every government in every industrialized nation has officially pretended the protocol was workable.
Kyoto's unachievable targets have forced governments into bizarre diplomatic contortions. Some, especially in Europe, approached the Kyoto talks and subsequent negotiations in The Hague with no serious plan for how they would comply with the targets. Others, including the United States, Canada, Australia and Japan, are pushing for an international emissions trading system whose main effect would be to let them buy vast quantities of bogus emission credits from Russia and Ukraine. At Kyoto, Russia and Ukraine agreed to freeze their emissions at 1990 levels, but because of the collapse of the Soviet economy, they were already emitting greenhouse gases at 40 percent below those levels. So the emissions "reductions" they have available to sell are not real.
By making it clear that the United States won't pretend to meet the Kyoto limits, the Bush administration has, for all intents and purposes, killed the Kyoto Protocol. Now it has a responsibility to build an alternative.
America is ready for a sound policy. The Kyoto Protocol's demise is erasing unrealistic ambitions on the left, and a swelling majority of centrists now recognizes the need for precaution on burning carbon-based fuels. Conservative voices that oppose any control on carbon are fading as more Americans accept the scientific consensus on global warming.
The administration and Congress could assemble a sensible package from legislation already in the works. We should sharply increase funding for research and development on affordable ways to move the economy entirely away from fossil fuels over the next several decades and raise efficiency of fossil-fuel burning in the interim. We should also create an incentive for companies to limit emissions by letting them trade carbon emission permits. Unlike the sulphur dioxide trading system created in 1990 to control acid rain, this one should let the government issue new permits, allowing more emissions, if prices for the credits ever rise above a certain level. That provision would reassure business that the cost of compliance would not skyrocket if cheaper carbon-saving technologies did not become available.
This sort of program would embody the principle around which an effective global emissions reduction regime could also be built -- economic incentives that, over time, will slow the buildup of carbon dioxide in the atmosphere without the imposition of binding targets for a far-off future.
The rest of the world is ready to pin the blame for the Kyoto Protocol's demise on the United States, though all nations that crafted the compact really share the blame. The sooner America takes the lead in devising effective new policies, the better it can lead the world beyond Kyoto.

HEADLINE: Fox, on Tour, Stresses Mexico's Economic Importance for California 

BYLINE:  By GINGER THOMPSON 

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, March 22 

 BODY:
In his first trip to the United States since becoming president of Mexico, Vicente Fox has traveled across California proclaiming to state legislators, farm workers and high-tech executives the economic importance of the Mexican-Californian relationship.
 He also pledged to work as hard for the rights of Mexicans in the United States as for those at home. 
 In a speech to the state Legislature, Mr. Fox pressed the officials to reconsider legislation to offer educational help to Mexicans with established residency in California. The bill, which Mr. Fox's host, Gov. Gray Davis, vetoed on the ground that it would be too expensive, would have let the Mexicans with residency qualify for in-state tuition benefits to attend state-run universities. 
In a luncheon today with Los Angeles business and civic leaders, Mr. Fox pointed out that Mexico was the state's largest trading partner. Investments have risen by 43 percent in the last two years, officials said. 
The president praised the free trade agreement among Mexico, Canada and the United States. But he also acknowledged that for Mexico to become a fully equal partner with the United States and Canada, it would need to work to close the income gap that divides Mexico from its northern neighbor and forces hundreds of thousands of Mexicans each year to abandon their country.
To rousing applause from the corporate audience in Los Angeles, the president pledged to "open Mexico to greater flows of investment" and to use the new earnings to develop new jobs, to eradicate corruption and to improve education for the rich and poor.
Earlier President Fox visited a suburban elementary school in the company of Laura Bush, the first lady. 
Mr. Fox delivered his most passionate statements today in a meeting with 10,000 Mexican-American farm workers and community leaders in Fresno. 
Calling them "permanent cultural ambassadors," Mr. Fox told the audience that he would do all that he could to win the passage of laws in Mexico so that Mexicans abroad would have the right to vote in Mexican elections.
"You are important," he said. "Believe me, you are very important."
Speaking to business leaders, Mr. Fox restated his commitment to Mexicans living in the United States. "No more talking about migration as a problem," Mr. Fox said. "From now on, we will make migration an opportunity for the future. We are going to make sure that migration is an asset for both our countries."

HEADLINE: G.O.P. Chairman Under Republican Fire Back Home 

BYLINE:  By FRANCIS X. CLINES 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 22 

 BODY:
As he commutes here to his new second job as Republican national chairman, Gov. James S. Gilmore III of Virginia leaves behind a scathing example of how rough politics can get within his party: A group of Republicans in his own State Senate have joined Democrats in forming a fund-raising committee to oppose him in a running battle over the party's signature issue of cutting taxes.
 The unusual committee has incensed Mr. Gilmore by attracting fellow Statehouse Republicans at a time when he is supposed to be the national model of successful party unity and tax-cutting skills. 
 "The word is that it's an effort to undermine me," Mr. Gilmore said of the bipartisan alliance. But "I don't think I can be intimidated," he declared crisply in his office at the Republican National Committee. 
If nothing else, Governor Gilmore, a very successful 51-year-old politician long known for his tenacity, is showing intraparty steel in his new job as national chairman. That Republican flagship post was offered him by President Bush after Mr. Gilmore guided the Virginia Republican machine last year to an overwhelming Bush primary victory that finally stopped the presidential campaign of Senator John McCain. 
But as he serves out his last year as governor, an escalating budget struggle with some of his own party's leaders in the Republican-controlled State Senate is casting a shadow on his efforts to take firm hold of the national party machinery. 
The governor, noting that the struggle is over his keystone 1997 election pledge to eliminate the state's automobile tax, is far from ducking the fight; he is depicting the battle with his foes as a crucial test of voters' expectations that Republicans can be trusted to deliver on their promise to cut taxes.
"If they're going to be pouring hundreds of thousands of dollars into trying to tear me down nationally or locally in order to get me to go back on my promise to the people, that's just not going to happen," Mr. Gilmore said. "They should remember we Republicans have prevailed on the tax issue nationally. Keeping faith with the people is our No. 1 goal."
But his Senate critics insist that with state revenue now slowing with the economy, Virginia can no longer fully afford Mr. Gilmore's pledge to eliminate the tax on personal cars and trucks, a step that would save each vehicle owner some $200 or more a year but would impose an annual cost of about $1.2 billion on the state. Further, they say they were driven to organize against the governor because he was already using a political action committee of his own to undermine them unfairly with voters.
"We were being beaten about the head and shoulders by the governor's political machine and his PAC," said Senator Thomas K. Norment Jr., the Republican floor leader who helped organize the bipartisan effort. "I don't think this is in the spirit of leading the R.N.C. as a peacemaker," said Mr. Norment, who contended that the governor was breaking a campaign pledge to hold off on the car tax repeal if budgetary conditions worsened. 
The anti-Gilmore group has 17 Republicans and 17 Democrats from the 40-member Senate. It has hired Golin/Harris, a Chicago public relations firm, to stir protests by editorial writers and leaders from colleges, the arts and other areas suffering in the budget dispute. Senator Norment estimated that it had raised about $40,000 initially, mostly from the senators' own campaign funds, to serve not as a formal PAC but as a nonprofit issue education group. 
That portrayal was challenged by one of the governor's Republican supporters, H. Morgan Griffith, majority leader of the House of Delegates, who maintained that the group behaved like a PAC and was a "smoke screen" for "fat-cat donors." But Senator Norment said it was the governor who was in the "anomalous" position of having perhaps $500,000 from Republican donors in a PAC that he has been tapping to fight Senate leaders of his own party. 
Such an intraparty fracas was hardly anticipated when, in November 1999, the Republicans won control of both legislative houses for the first time in history. But Governor Gilmore, who retains the support of the House Republican majority, fell out with leading Senate Republicans over budget priorities when he insisted that the budget could be balanced even with a two-step elimination of the car tax, cutting it by 70 percent this year and 100 percent in 2002.
The Senate countered with 55 percent this year and 70 percent next year, which would find Mr. Gilmore, barred by term limits from a run for re-election, leaving office without fully delivering on his pledge. Lacking a two-house agreement, the governor acted under state law to issue a controversial two-year budget of $48 billion that included the 70 percent car tax cut but also a raft of state aid cuts for localities and college construction in order to close a $421 million shortfall. 
With this, the rift only widened, leaving Virginians with a public relations face-off between the Republican governor's No Car Tax PAC and the Republican Senate's Virginians for Fiscal Responsibility.
"Constituents are already hammering this guy," said one Democratic senator, Richard L. Saslaw, who maintained that the Senate effort was working and added, "I just hope he does for the R.N.C. finances what he's done for Virginia's." 
Mr. Gilmore contends that he "made the tough choices" while the Senate was trying to keep state finances and aid at the recent high levels so popular with voters. "When the economy begins to slow," he said, "why is it that the promise to the people has to be the one thing that goes out the window?" 
But Senator Norment insisted that the governor's budget tactic was putting their own party at political risk. "There's something inherently contradictory," he said, "about a family feud among Republicans that's being led by a high-profile Republican."

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST 

 BODY:
Republican Senators Agree To a $60 Billion Tax Cut
Republican senators agreed to give Americans a $60 billion tax cut this year to stimulate the economy, and Democratic leaders said they were inclined to go along.
 The cut would be in addition to the 10-year, $1.6 trillion tax cut package that President Bush has proposed and that most Republicans in Congress support. Page A1. 

Energy Agency Faces Skepticism
California regulators estimated that power generators charged $6.2 billion above competitive levels over 10 months. They urged the Federal Energy Regulatory Commission to investigate further, hoping it would demand refunds or other remedies. But the agency's record leaves state regulators skeptical that Washington will confront the producers. A1.

Argentine Official Outlines Plans
Argentina's economy minister, Domingo Cavallo, outlined his plans and asked Congress for extraordinary powers to revive the stalled economy. Mr. Cavallo promised to make Argentina more competitive without devaluing the peso or ending the decade-old currency board system that pegs its value to the United States dollar. He called for tax cuts, tariff changes and rapid easing of business and labor regulations. World Business, Section W.

Brazil's stock markets plummeted, rattled by a surprise half-point increase in interest rates and by further developments in neighboring Argentina. World Business, Section W.

Ad Sales Go to Wire for Oscar Show
In another sign of the effect of the struggling economy on Madison Avenue, ABC completed the sale of commercial time during the 73rd annual Academy Awards three days before showtime instead of the usual month or two beforehand. Stuart Elliott: Advertising. C6.

White House Picks F.T.C. Nominee
Signaling a sharp shift in the enforcement of antitrust laws, the White House announced its intention to nominate Timothy J. Muris, a leading critic of the Clinton administration's antitrust policies, to become the next chairman of the Federal Trade Commission. C4.

Assets of 3 Bond Funds Are Frozen
Securities regulators obtained a court order to freeze the assets of three municipal bond funds run by Heartland Advisors of Milwaukee, leaving the funds' more than 1,000 investors unable to withdraw their money and uncertain about the value of their investments. C2.

Schwab Plans to Cut Work Force
Charles Schwab, forecasting no rebound in investor sentiment this year, announced that it would eliminate 11 percent to 13 percent of its work force and warned that its first-quarter earnings would fall short of already lowered expectations. Shares of Schwab, the nation's largest online brokerage firm, fell 4 percent, or 70 cents, to $15.20, the stock's lowest closing price in more than two years. C4.

Fake Microsoft Documents Obtained
Microsoft warned computer users that someone posing electronically as a company executive had fooled VeriSign, a provider of digital signatures, into issuing fraudulent electronic certificates in Microsoft's name. The false documents could potentially be used by software virus writers or other vandals. C6.

Clinical Trials of Immunex Drug Fail
Immunex said that clinical trials of treatments to treat chronic heart failure and asthma had failed, dealing a blow to the company's effort to expand its product line beyond its treatment for rheumatoid arthritis. C4.

Leading Indicators Drop 0.2%
The index of leading economic indicators dropped 0.2 percent in February after a revised 0.5 percent gain in January. The drop matched Wall Street expectations. C4.

Lucent Cuts Price of Agere Offering
Lucent cut the offering price of its Agere Systems unit by 40 percent, saying it will sell 600 million shares for $6 to $7 each. C6.

HEADLINE: After 53 Years, Fresh Kills Gets Its Final Load of Trash 

BYLINE:  By KIRK JOHNSON 

 BODY:
Never has a pile of smelly trash had it so good: When New York City Department of Sanitation scow No. 123 passed by the home of Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani early yesterday morning on the East River, his honor stepped out on his porch to salute it. When it passed by the Statue of Liberty, Fire Department water cannons fired into the air. Tugboat whistles screamed. News photographers angled for a close-up.
 The final load of garbage bound for Fresh Kills landfill in Staten Island after 53 years of rage and rhetoric was en route, and so what was nothing more than ordinary rubbish from Queens had become invested with meaning. 
 "We waved to it and they signaled to us and it was really absolutely terrific," Mr. Giuliani said later about his encounter with D.S. 123.
Sure, there have been other famous loads of floating New York garbage. A barge named Mobro 4000 with rubbish from a New York City suburb made headlines in the 1980's as the trash that no port would take. Scow D.S. 123, by contrast, was the barge that everyone wanted to welcome home because its 600 tons of household castoffs -- a tattered Christmas wreath, a basketball, a gray sock, a few broom handles -- represented two short but profound words: the end. One of the most notorious garbage dumps in America had taken in its last.
The final barge's final voyage began at the Sanitation Department's North Shore Marine Transfer Station in Flushing, Queens, about 7:45 a.m. in a cold drizzle, under the roar of jets taking from La Guardia Airport. It ended five hours later in a downpour at a landfill loading dock, which, like the barge itself, had been wrapped in red-white-and-blue bunting, and was swarming with damp dignitaries. 
Not everyone was impressed. In the workaday world of the harbor tugboat crews who over the decades hauled an estimated 400,000 garbage barges through the currents and high-volume traffic of the waterfront, the final ride of D.S. 123 was a trip down the river like so many before, except for the load of reporters and camera crews. And the ride also symbolized, for the crews, the end, or at least temporary discontinuation, of an economic mainstay.
"I'd rather not see it close -- for the jobs," said Tommy Napoleone, the 21-year-old mate of the tug Justine McAllister, which was one of four escort boats taking D.S. 123 to its berth. Mr. Napoleone lives in Staten Island, but far enough away, he said, that the landfill never bothered him. As rain beat against the tug's windows, Mr. Napoleone said that with the growth in the port there seemed to be enough work, and that he would continue on the tugs escorting ocean vessels. "But I have a few friends who work down there," he said of the landfill. "Lord knows what's going to happen to them."
Although the long-term plan for the city's residential waste disposal calls for garbage to again travel by barge -- from a system of transfer stations to a terminal in Linden, N.J., where it is to be repackaged for shipment by rail -- that system is not expected to be in operation for four years or more. In the meantime, trucks will handle most of the garbage, hauling it to landfills and incinerators in some cases hundreds of miles away.
What comes next for Fresh Kills is, in its own way, another journey. The so-called capping of the landfill, which involves placing a moisture barrier over the garbage mounds and a layer of topsoil onto that, is but the first step toward what politicians and the Sanitation Department say is a long-term plan to bring at least parts of the 3,000-acre property into public use as parkland. But given the volume of waste that was disposed there, an estimated 108 million tons -- more than in any other landfill in the United States, according to Chartwell Information, a company in Alexandria, Va. that tracks waste industry data -- much of the land could be unusable for decades.
The ecology of the landfill and its surrounding lands, which include some wetlands that were never used for garbage disposal, is expected to begin evolving, as well. Birds that for generations fed on garbage could be stressed, for example. Unsanctioned uses by people are growing, too. As much of the landfill has closed, its hills have become a magnet for off-road bicyclists and motorcyclists.

HEADLINE: Residential Real Estate; 
Enclave Grows Green, Inside and Out

BYLINE:  By RACHELLE GARBARINE 

 BODY:
As tenants move into the 324 apartments at 22 River Terrace, the newest residential building at Battery Park City, plans were announced yesterday for the next two apartment towers that are to rise there, in the enclave alongside the Hudson River.
 The Battery Park City Authority announced that the Related Companies of Manhattan would develop a $113 million building with 330 apartments while the Albanese Development Corporation of Garden City, N.Y., would build a $95 million structure with 260 apartments. 
 Both buildings will be 24 stories and rise on the same block as 22 River Terrace in what the authority calls the north neighborhood of Battery Park City.
Despite jitters about the national economy, leasing has been steady at 22 River Terrace. In the five weeks since rentals began at the 28-story brick and glass building, leases have been signed for 140 of its studio to three-bedroom apartments, which have 556 to 1,374 square feet. 
In that time monthly rents have been raised an average of 7 percent, and now range from $2,225 to $5,915, said Kevin P. Singleton. He is vice president and general manager at Rockrose Development Corporation, which developed the $45 million building, its third rental in Battery Park City.
Rockrose's just-completed project also marks a shift at the waterside complex toward so-called green buildings, ones that are energy-efficient and environmentally sensitive. 
The authority's guidelines, which went into effect in January 2000 for future residential and commercial buildings, require that developers, among other things, install appliances that are 35 percent more energy-efficient than required by current state energy standards and use building materials that have recycled contents and reduced toxicity to soften the project's impact on the environment.
While the construction of 22 River Terrace began before the new guidelines were in place, Timothy S. Carey, the authority's president, said that Rockrose, "to its credit," had voluntarily added green elements in its building. They include the use of energy-saving glazing on the building's windows, as well as motion sensors and fluorescent lighting in public areas to increase energy efficiency. 
Mr. Singleton said that while installing such features added $400,000 or 1 percent to the building's cost, they would ultimately help reduce operating expenses. "Saving energy and being green these days is good business," he said.
That is the message the authority hopes will be driven home with a new apartment tower about to arise, the first so-called green building designed to meet the authority's environmental guidelines. Work is expected to begin next month on that 266-unit rental, which will rise at River Terrace and Murray Street and is being developed at an estimated cost of $110 million by the Albanese Corporation.
The two newly announced buildings will also be green.
Mr. Carey said the environmental features included in the authority's guidelines were expected to add 10 to 15 percent to the initial cost of those and future buildings, though the cost to the developers for leasing the land would not be decreased. The idea, he added, is that builders "will be paid back within the life of the buildings," not only by lower operating costs but higher rents, too. 
Mr. Carey said the authority's environmental guidelines mesh with those now being completed for a state environmental tax credit program that is expected to be announced soon.
There are six more sites left to be developed at Battery Park City. Meanwhile, Mr. Carey said the authority had discussed with property owners the benefits of retrofitting their existing buildings with environmental features. 
The Rockrose building will be flanked by two parks. To the west is the four-acre Rockefeller Park and to the east will be a new $12 million, two-acre park, now called Tear Drop Park. 
The vision for the new park, Mr. Carey said, is "of a glen in the Catskills," with a 13-foot high "weeping wall" made of bluestone with water trickling down its face. There will also be rock formations using stones from New York quarries, a children's play area and a brook. Michael VanValkenburgh Associates of Boston is the landscape architect. 
Since that vision will not begin until November and will take three years to complete, an $80,000 park of less than an acre will be created in the interim. Construction is to start by mid-April on that park, which will have rows of crimson clover, sunflowers and spring rye. The architect is Donald Shillingburg in collaboration with Signe Nielsen landscape architects of Manhattan. 
Mr. Singleton said 22 River Terrace had been designed by Gruzen Samton Architects of Manhattan "with two front doors," one on each side, to take advantage of its closeness to the parks and the river. Common amenities include a landscaped terrace on the 17th floor, where the building steps back.
Rents average $51 a square foot. "Basically that is what the market will bear and is on par with rents at other buildings downtown," said Elie Khen, a broker at Bellmarc Companies, a residential brokerage company in Manhattan. "Even with the jitters in the market there will always be people who will rent."

HEADLINE: Bush's Budget Would Cut 3 Programs to Aid Children 

BYLINE:  By ROBERT PEAR 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 22 

 BODY:
As part of his budget, President Bush intends next month to propose cuts in programs to provide child care, to prevent child abuse and to train doctors at children's hospitals, administration officials said today.
 State officials contend that stable child care for low-income families has been a major ingredient of successful programs to move people from welfare to work. Congress provided $2 billion last year for the Child Care and Development Block Grant. That included an increase of $817 million, or 69 percent, so that states could provide day care to 241,000 additional children. 
 Budget documents from the Department of Health and Human Services show that Mr. Bush plans to cut child care grants by $200 million, to $1.8 billion, as part of the budget he will send Congress early next month.
The documents also show that spending for programs dealing with child abuse would be reduced by $15.7 million, or 18 percent. That would leave $71.8 million for federal grants to the states to prevent and investigate child abuse and neglect.
About 900,000 children are victims of abuse or neglect each year, federal data show, based on reports of cases investigated and confirmed by the states.
Tommy G. Thompson, the secretary of health and human services, has often emphasized the need to invest in services for low-income people.
"For welfare reform to be successful, you have to make an investment up front," Mr. Thompson said at his confirmation hearing. "It cannot be done on the cheap."
Mr. Thompson acted on that philosophy in 14 years as governor of Wisconsin. Under his supervision, state spending on child care in Wisconsin increased to $250 million this year, from $12 million in 1987.
The 1996 welfare law imposed stringent work requirements on welfare recipients, and most states have long lists of people waiting for subsidized child care.
Dennis P. Williams, the top budget official at the Department of Health and Human Services, described the amounts of money for various programs in memorandums to agency officials. Copies of the documents were obtained from people in both parties who oppose the cuts.
Mr. Williams said that Mr. Thompson "personally negotiated the budget with the director" of the White House Office of Management and Budget, Mitchell E. Daniels Jr. The numbers for specific budget items reflect decisions by Mr. Thompson "within the overall constraints of O.M.B. guidance," Mr. Williams said.
Administration officials defending President Bush's proposals made two points. First, they said, many domestic programs received exceptionally large increases in the current fiscal year because Congress and the Clinton administration showed little restraint on spending.
In addition, administration officials said Mr. Bush's concern for children was displayed throughout the budget, most notably in his proposals to double the federal tax credit for children and to increase spending at the Department of Education by 11.5 percent next year.
Campbell Gardett, a spokesman for the Department of Health and Human Services, said, "People here do not want to comment on the budget" before its official release.
The budget documents show that Mr. Bush is planning to eliminate all the money, $20 million, that Congress provided for an "early learning fund" to improve the quality of child care and education for children younger than 5.
Mr. Bush's proposal could lead to a confrontation with Senator Ted Stevens, the Alaska Republican who is chairman of the Senate Appropriations Committee. Mr. Stevens and Senator Edward M. Kennedy, Democrat of Massachusetts, were the chief sponsors of the measure Congress passed last year to improve child care for preschoolers.
After President Bill Clinton signed the legislation in December, Mr. Stevens said, "I expect our new first lady, Laura Bush, a former librarian, to be a champion of early childhood education."
Administration officials said Mr. Bush was proposing a program to help older children after school.
But Helen Blank of the Children's Defense Fund, a liberal advocacy group, said, "It makes no sense to cut the Child Care and Development Block Grant to pay for a new initiative like after school vouchers."
In December, Congress also provided $235 million for a new program to train pediatricians and other doctors at children's hospitals across the country. Bush administration officials said the White House Office of Management and Budget had made a preliminary decision to seek large cuts in this program. Aides to Mr. Thompson said he was trying to get some of the money restored.
"We are still working on it," Mr. Thompson said. "We are still negotiating."
Representative Jennifer Dunn, Republican of Washington, expressed concern about the possibility of a cut.
"We really need the money for training of physicians who deal directly with children," Ms. Dunn said.
The president's budget for the Department of Health and Human Services, not counting benefit programs like Medicare and Medicaid, calls for $56.7 billion in 2002.

HEADLINE: SENATORS SEEKING A $60 BILLION CUT IN TAXES FOR 2001 

BYLINE:  By DAVID E. ROSENBAUM 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 22 

 BODY:
Republican senators agreed today to give Americans a $60 billion tax cut this year to stimulate the economy, and Democratic leaders said they were inclined to go along.
 The cut would be in addition to the tax reduction that President Bush has proposed and that most Republicans in Congress support. 
 The House, meanwhile, continued today to work on Mr. Bush's tax plan, which offers little immediate tax relief, but the chairman of the Ways and Means Committee, Representative Bill Thomas, said he was receptive to a measure that would lower taxes this year. 
"We can shift gears at any time," Mr. Thomas said.
A White House spokesman, Scott McClellan, said that while Mr. Bush was committed to the 10-year, $1.6 trillion tax-cut package he had outlined, "the President also believes we need to get more money into people's pockets quicker and he's committed to working with Congress to look at ways to make the tax cut retroactive so that we can give our economy a needed boost."
The lawmakers have not decided which taxpayers should get how much money or the mechanics of how they would get it. One possibility is a direct rebate -- a check from the government. Another is to change tax withholding tables so that take-home pay would immediately be greater.
If the $60 billion is divided evenly among about 200 million taxpaying adults, each would get $300.
The proposal was developed by Senator Pete V. Domenici of New Mexico, chairman of the Budget Committee. Mr. Domenici presented it this afternoon at a meeting of all Republican senators. Afterward, he said: "We all agreed here that we want to do this. This must be done quickly for the American economy."
Senator Trent Lott of Mississippi, the Republican leader, said he supported the proposal.
The money would come from the budget surplus for this fiscal year, which ends Sept. 30, after setting aside the money earmarked for Social Security and Medicare and about $30 billion in spending for other government programs.
Democrats said they wanted to see the details before they made any commitments, but they seemed enthusiastic.
"It makes sense to provide a stimulus and to do it in a timely way," said Senator Kent Conrad of North Dakota, the top Democrat on the Budget Committee.
Before the meeting of Republican senators, the House Ways and Means Committee approved two more parts of President Bush's tax-cut plan, but Mr. Thomas, a Republican from California, said after the vote that substantial changes might be needed to help the stock market and the economy.
The committee's bill would give a tax reduction to almost all married couples and would double the tax credit for most families with children to $1,000 per child. The committee made the measure somewhat more favorable to less affluent taxpayers than the president's plan.
But none of this money would get into people's pockets this year, and Democrats on the committee complained that Republicans were insensitive to current economic troubles.
In general, Democrats have objected to large tax cuts over many years, which they contend would drain government resources needed for social programs. But like Republicans, they feel the need to respond to what is seen as an economic emergency.
"We're not sure there's a tax cut that will stimulate the economy, but we're sure this one isn't it," said Representative Sander M. Levin, Democrat of Michigan, speaking of the president's plan.
The bill was approved by a party-line vote, 23 to 16, and is likely to go before the full House next week.
But the action in the House was overshadowed by the talk in the Senate about immediate tax relief.
Lawmakers from both parties have been struggling to find a way to address constituents' concerns about the sliding stock market and the possibility that the economy is faltering.
"There's a general perception that there's something Congress can do to overcome this economic slowdown," said Representative Lloyd Doggett, Democrat of Texas.
Senator Olympia J. Snowe, Republican of Maine, said, "There's a consensus that we need to do something that will have a stimulative effect."
Senator Max Baucus of Montana, the senior Democrat on the Finance Committee, said, "I think it makes sense to think in a shorter time horizon."
It will be up to the Senate Finance Committee to work out the details of how Mr. Domenici's proposal would be implemented, and the political consensus could well collapse over who should get the money.
For example, should people too poor to owe income taxes get money back? Should everyone get the same amount, or should people who pay more taxes get more returned? Should wealthy taxpayers unlikely to change their spending patterns because of a rebate check of a few hundred dollars tops get anything at all?
Senator Domenici said he hoped all this could be resolved in the next few weeks. "We're going to do this as fast as possible," he said. "It will send people a signal that we are responsive."
Mr. Domenici said he hoped Congress would approve the central element of the president's proposal, an across-the-board reduction in income-tax rates, within a matter of weeks to assure the public that long-term tax relief was on the way. The House passed its version of this measure two weeks ago.
The remainder of the president's plan like the lower taxes for married couples, expansion of the child-care credit and repeal of the estate tax could be considered at a more leisurely pace, Mr. Domenici said.

CORRECTION-DATE: March 24, 2001

HEADLINE: Procter to Cut 9,600 Jobs In Drive to Trim Its Overhead 

BYLINE:  By JULIAN E. BARNES 

DATELINE: CINCINNATI, March 22 

 BODY:
Procter & Gamble announced today that it would eliminate 9,600 jobs, or 9 percent of its work force, in the company's second substanial effort to reduce its payroll in two years. 
 About 40 percent of the job cuts will occur in the United States, and about 1,900 jobs will be lost in Cincinnati, where the company is based. Procter & Gamble said it would first offer early retirement and voluntary severance packages. Then, in about two months, it will begin laying off employees. 
 P.& G. is the second major consumer products company to announce large-scale layoffs. Gillette said in December that it would cut 2,700 jobs. Both companies have relatively high exposure to slowing overseas economies. 
Procter is the largest employer in the Cincinnati area, with 15,000 workers, and over the years it has developed a reputation as an insular and almost stodgy corporate giant. Of late, the company has been trying to change, entering into alliances and joint ventures with other companies. The cutbacks may be part of the company's effort to remake its culture and become more nimble.
Workers sitting in the corporate park outside the headquarters here slowly ate their lunches and mulled the company's announcement. Many were philosophical, viewing the cutbacks as further signs of economic slowdowns in America and overseas. Although they worried that colleagues, friends and neighbors could be forced out of jobs, several employees and other Cincinnati residents analyzed the cutbacks like investors.
"It's hard to find people who say bad things about Procter & Gamble here; we all own the stock," said Stephen C. Stricker, a Cincinnati resident and stockholder with friends at the company.
Procter announced in 1999 that it would eliminate 15,000 jobs by 2005 as part of a broad reorganization, but fewer people than expected took the voluntary retirement packages. So far, just 7,200 people have opted to leave. 
Alan G. Lafley, the chief executive, said yesterday that the new cutbacks were necessary to cut the company's overhead and restore its competitiveness. 
The layoffs and early retirement packages will cost the company about $1.4 billion, with most of the charges coming during the next fiscal year, starting in July. The company hopes the job cuts will save it $600 million to $700 million a year by fiscal year 2004.
Procter & Gamble's high costs are making it hard to compete on price, Mr. Lafley said. 
"The bottom line is we're not winning consistently with consumers," Mr. Lafley told analysts this morning. "They're often voting for competitors' brands, not P.& G. brands."
Sales growth at Procter has been flat and operating profit has declined for four quarters, Mr. Lafley said. Investments in new products and new markets have not generated the returns the company hoped for, but marketing expenses have grown to support those initiatives.
Although the cuts will be across the board, they will touch most lightly on the company's best-performing division, its fabric and home care brands, and fall most heavily on the lagging food and beverage division.
Mr. Lafley said he had told the managers of the global brand units to either fix stagnating businesses or get out of them.
"If we cannot get these brands or businesses profitable, then we will substantially restructure them, or shut them down," Mr. Lafley said.
Clayton C. Daley Jr., the chief financial officer, said the company could take an additional $400 million to $800 million charge if it got rid of underperforming brands. Analysts and some company employees say that Jif peanut butter and Crisco oil could be among the first products to be sold off.
Mr. Lafley said the goal was to return to double-digit sales growth and eventually double-digit earnings growth, but he said the restructuring could make it hard to increase earnings that much right away.
Analysts also expressed skepticism that the company could reach those targets in a slowing economy.
But Ajay Mehra, a portfolio manager at the Columbia Management Company, a unit of FleetBoston, said he recently bought Procter & Gamble for the funds he manages. The cuts, he said, were necessary for the company's earnings to grow. "It's not a good thing to have to lay off people, there is a human cost, but it is a much-needed remedy," Mr. Mehra said. "This is a faster pace of change than P.& G. is used to, this is a break with their culture. But I think that if I am Lafley, I am trying to send a message that change is necessary."
John J. Sweeney, the president of the A.F.L.-C.I.O., said the layoffs at Procter & Gamble were a sign of the softening economy and a reminder that the slowdown had an effect on families.
"It's not just Procter & Gamble; we are seeing layoffs all across the economy reflecting a sharp slowing of demand," said Mr. Sweeney, adding that Procter & Gamble and other companies should do more to retrain workers that are laid off. "We think there are going to be more layoffs."
Cincinnati did not seem to take the news as hard, however. The morning radio shows were almost as concerned with the fate of Rodger, the Kentucky resident competing on CBS's "Survivor," as they were with news of the layoffs.
John F. Shirey, Cincinnati's city manager, treated the layoffs almost as if they were good news.
"What is more important to us is the overall health of the company," he said. "If these cutbacks result in improving the company, that has a positive impact in the city."
Many in the local business community seemed to go out of their way to express support for Mr. Lafley's decisions.
"We respect the leadership," said Michael Fisher, the president of the Greater Cincinnati Chamber of Commerce, who predicted that many of the workers who lose their jobs would be snatched up by other companies. Procter management, he said, "will do the things that are necessary for the long term." 
Angela Schunk, 28, who has worked at Procter for seven years, was also trying to be upbeat. Ms. Schunk said the company was acting morally by making voluntary reductions first.
"I think it's the right thing for the company, this will make us a strong company," said Ms. Schunk, who works in the baby care division and has a newborn of her own. "While I hope I would not be one of the ones asked to leave, I hope I would be able to handle it with dignity and respect if I was."
Still, some newer employees expressed concerns. 
"The people who have been here a really long time, those are the ones who are really on edge," said Tanya Daniels, 26, who has worked in a sales division for about a month. "A lot of people thought they would be here forever and now they have to start over." 
Unlike many Procter employees, the owner of the Montgomery Inn Boathouse, a restaurant two blocks from the headquarters, did not put a positive spin on the layoffs. "We have people from Procter & Gamble here every day for lunch and dinner, we get quite a bit of business," Dean Gregory said. "When Procter & Gamble loses jobs, we lose customers."

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS; 
South American Trade Bloc Under Siege

BYLINE:  By LARRY ROHTER 

DATELINE: RIO DE JANEIRO, March 23 

 BODY:
In a more just world, the trade bloc known as Mercosur would be in a celebratory mood when its 10th birthday rolls around on Monday. Since its founding, trade among Mercosur's four members has tripled, to $15 billion a year; foreign investment has soared; inflation has been tamed; and the group has become the world's third-largest market, with more than 210 million people and combined production of more than $1 trillion a year.
 But "more than toasting the results of the past, Mercosur is going to mark this anniversary worrying about its future," said Gilberto Dupas, head of international studies at the University of Sao Paulo. The South American Common Market, as the group is also known, is now under siege from all sides, riven by disputes between Brazil and Argentina, its two main members, and facing mounting external pressures, mostly from the United States. 
 In its initial phase, Mercosur, which also includes Paraguay and Uruguay as full members and Bolivia and Chile as associate members, proved remarkably successful in stimulating economic and political integration. The original members had just recently shaken off military dictatorships that were as suspicious of each other as of competition and free markets, and the result was a quick burst of growth.
"Any time you talk about Mercosur, you have to recall its starting point," said Pablo Guidotti, professor of economics at Di Tella University in Buenos Aires and a former Argentine government official. "All of these countries were emerging from decades of total isolation from the rest of the world economy."
The last two years, however, have been a time of trial for Mercosur. In January 1999, Brazil's currency was devalued by more than 35 percent, putting an end to the exchange-rate stability that had spurred trade within the group. Suddenly, many Brazilian goods were much cheaper than those of other members.
Since then, Argentina and Brazil have been involved in a series of noisy trade disputes over products ranging from cars and shoes to chicken and sugar.
Trade within the group has also been hit hard, falling by nearly a quarter in 1999, to around $15 billion, before recovering somewhat last year, to $17.7 billion.
Mercosur suffered another blow in December, when Chile said it was beginning negotiations with the United States in hopes of signing a bilateral free trade agreement. Chile's president, Ricardo Lagos, took office a year ago vowing that full Mercosur membership was his top priority, but he changed his mind in the face of Brazilian reluctance to lower tariffs faster.
Chile, heavily dependent on foreign trade, has external tariffs of 9 percent and plans to drop them to 6 percent. But Brazil, which wants to give industry more time to prepare for competition from abroad and has a giant domestic market of 170 million people, was willing to consider only minor trims to Mercosur's common tariff of 14 percent.
And Argentina, long mired in a recession that contrasts sharply with robust growth in Brazil, has plunged deeper into a crisis that is now both economic and political. That has led some there to urge President Fernando de la Rua to follow the Chilean path and radically open its economy.
"Argentina must stop wasting its time with this absurd project called Mercosur," Adolfo Sturzenegger of the New Millennium Foundation in Buenos Aires said this month. "It must immediately seek a bilateral negotiation with the United States."
It has also become clear that the member countries have quite different objectives. Brazil has always envisioned the group as both a commercial and geo-strategic entity that could put up a common front in negotiations with the rest of the world, while the others seem interested mostly in gaining access to Brazil's huge market.
"Brazil especially wants Mercosur to be a counterweight to the deepening North American entity that emerged with Nafta," said Riordan Roett, director of the Western Hemisphere Program at the Johns Hopkins University School of Advanced International Studies. "But Mercosur is not moving as quickly and successfully as it was a couple of years ago, so the Brazilians don't have the Mercosur card to play the way they did then."
This week, in a move interpreted in Brazil as a blow to Mercosur, Argentina's new minister of the economy, Domingo Cavallo, announced a plan to eliminate tariffs on capital goods imported from outside the bloc and to impose new taxes on imported consumer goods. Both moves threaten Brazilian exports to Argentina, and on Thursday night Mr. Cavallo flew to Brasilia to reassure Brazilian officials that Argentina does not intend to bolt from Mercosur.
Still, Mercosur members are moving ahead with efforts to knit their economies closer together, somewhat the way members of the European Union have done. Common economic reporting standards are expected to go into place soon.
"We have begun to think as a unit and to draw up internal regulations, sanitary norms, and even dispute-resolution mechanisms," said Marcela Cristini of the Latin American Foundation for Economic Investigation in Buenos Aires. "Executives in Argentina and Brazil are investing in each other's countries, which is very important because in accords of this sort, if there are not opportunities for the private sector, the thing doesn't go anywhere."
Presidents of member countries also pledged last year to seek a common currency, without setting a timetable. That task, unthinkable until recently, is especially challenging because Argentina has linked its peso exactly to the American dollar, while the Brazilian real floats freely.
Mercosur has also established "a set of game rules that has been important in attracting long-term investment to the region," Dr. Guidotti said. Direct foreign investment, less than $5 billion a year a decade ago, has soared to more than $50 billion, most of it to Brazil, which now draws more investor dollars than any developing country except China.
But will Mercosur survive long enough to celebrate a 20th anniversary? The answer, trade analysts say, probably depends on the outcome of the American-led effort to create by 2005 a Free Trade Area of the Americas, which seems intended to swallow up Mercosur.
"If Brazil goes into the F.T.A.A., then Mercosur is finished," Dr. Dupas said.
But Fernando Henrique Cardoso, Brazil's president, said this month that "Mercosur is a destiny for us, while the F.T.A.A. is an option." That set the tone for the next round of trade talks, scheduled to be held in Quebec next month and expected to produce a new American initiative to move up the deadline to 2003.
"With their own economies slowing, both the United States and the European Union are making a major aggressive push toward the Latin American market," Dr. Cristini said. "Mercosur has to give an answer, but this is clearly not the best moment for it to reply."

HEADLINE: Supply and Demand Among the Faithful 

BYLINE:  By CHRIS SHEA

 BODY:
Drive down 16th Street in Washington, and you will see evidence of the religious diversity that has struck visitors to America since Toqueville. Church after church will flash by: Grace Lutheran, the National Church of the Nazarene, Trinity A.M.E. Zion, All Souls Unitarian. And on and on. To a small group of sociologists, the reason there are so many kinds of houses of worship is no different from the reason there are so many brands of detergent or toothpaste at the supermarket: economics. 
 Competition, and supply and demand, shape the earthly aspects of religion -- its popularity and how it is delivered -- they say. And people in pews are fickle consumers, ready to bolt to a competing brand if the current one seems stale or uninspired. 
 This economic approach has led them to conclude that competition, rather than undermining belief, actually spurs it. Not only does it make clergymen work harder, they say, but it also means there is a greater likelihood that any one person will find a church that suits his spiritual tendencies, whether New Age or biblical literalist. 
"It can be demonstrated that in any society there is a distribution of religious tastes and concerns," said Rodney Stark, a professor of sociology at the University of Washington and a leading proponent of what is known as the religious economies theory. "The basic point is that any society would be better served by many different religions focusing on -- if you want to use market language -- different market segments. I'm sure we drink more soda pop because there are 20 companies out there, rather than just Coke." Why wouldn't religion be the same, he asks?
Religious pluralism, Mr. Stark and others say, explains why the United States is so religiously vibrant, while much of Western Europe has seen a decline in interest in traditional churches.
But both the economic language and the pluralism argument have upset many in the field. Steve Bruce, a sociologist at the University of Aberdeen in Scotland, has written that the sociology of religion is suffering from "the malign influence of a small clique of U.S. sociologists" who are peddling daft ideas. And Mark Chaves, a sociologist at the University of Arizona, calls the pluralism theory a "house of cards," collapsing under close scrutiny.
The religious economies scholars, who focus on the variety of Christian denominations, are trying to tear down the view of pluralism that has reigned in the sociology of religion for a half-century. It was perhaps most famously articulated by Peter Berger in his 1969 book, "The Sacred Canopy." Mr. Berger, now director of the Institute on Religion and World Affairs at Boston University, wrote that faith was once like an awning that sheltered all of society, offering citizens a common certainty. But as tolerance opened the door to different varieties, the canopy tore: certainty could not help but decline, and faith followed. Mr. Berger made his case through broad historical and cultural analysis. 
But Mr. Stark and Roger Finke, a sociologist at Penn State and co-author of "Acts of Faith: Explaining the Human Side of Religion" (University of California, 2000), argue that this big-picture sociological view is often woolly and unscientific. They say, too, that a new theory is needed to make sense of America. In the United States today, some 40 percent of adults claim to attend church weekly, compared with 10 percent in Britain and 4 percent in Scandinavia. With some 1,350 denominations and sects, according to the Encyclopedia of American Religions, the United States is at once one of the most pluralistic and one of the most religious modern societies. Those facts have forced sociologists to rethink the idea that religion would die out when neighbors stopped believing in the same God. 
Adam Smith drew some links between competition and religious commitment in "The Wealth of Nations" 225 years ago, but most scholars ignored them. Mr. Stark and others started using economic language to describe religion in the mid-1980's. 
The new brand of thinking started making waves, however, in 1988, when he and Mr. Finke published an article in the American Sociological Review. Using data from an unusually thorough survey of religious behavior in 1906, conducted by the United States Census Bureau, they explored the link between religious diversity and commitment. (Such information is no longer gathered by the government.)
The secularization thesis held that religion would decline most rapidly in cities, because it would be impossible for urbanites not to notice that their neighbors headed off to different churches. But Mr. Stark and Mr. Finke found that rural areas had attendance rates of 50 percent, while some urban areas had rates as high as 60 percent. 
Their methods were as startling as their arguments. They used the same statistical formula that the Federal Trade Commission uses to measure the amount of competition in consumer markets (like software) to look at pluralism even more closely. They found that in towns of similar size, church attendance was highest when there was a choice of worship. 
"Contrary to the pleas of the clergy and the pronouncements of social scientists," they concluded, "pluralism is friend, not foe, to religious mobilization."
In 1991 Larry Iannaccone, an economics professor at Santa Clara University, went international with the theory. In an article in Rationality and Society, he argued that 90 percent of the variation in religious commitment among European states, the United States, New Zealand and Australia was attributable to differences in pluralism. Since then, there has been a flood of articles, often by these same three scholars, applying the thesis to various countries and periods. 
The real difference between religion in America and Europe, they propose, is on the supply side. Mr. Stark's European colleagues are baffled, he says, when he describes the raft of church solicitations he gets in the mail. They have never heard of such a thing. "I tell them: 'That's the point. You don't understand.' American churches work very hard at reaching out to people to bring them in." 
One of the most controversial of Mr. Stark and Mr. Finke's arguments is that Europe could wake up religiously if its churches started acting like their American counterparts. That strikes some scholars as absurd. Even those who think the theory works for America say it fails in Europe. For one thing, in Poland and Ireland (and also in Quebec) the Catholic church has few competitors, and yet faith and attendance at Mass are very high. 
Additionally, several sociologists who specialize in Europe's Protestant countries have said open competition and the decline of traditional religion have gone hand in hand. Mr. Bruce of the University of Aberdeen has said that was the case for Britain. "Dull as it may be to say so," he wrote in 1999, "the old orthodoxy was by and large right."
Other scholars question whether the pluralism theory is even applicable to the United States. A widely discussed paper in the American Sociological Review two years ago, by Daniel V. A. Olson of Indiana University at South Bend, attacked the statistical methods used by Mr. Finke and Mr. Stark. 
And an article in a forthcoming issue of the Annual Review of Sociology by Mr. Chaves and Philip S. Gorski of the University of Wisconsin at Madison, concludes that of 26 articles published in respected scholarly journals on religious pluralism in various countries, 16 found either no pattern in the relation between pluralism and religious commitment or found that pluralism hurt religious commitment. 
The pluralism argument is crucial for the religious economies scholars, Mr. Chaves said, because "it is the one place where they have a claim to an empirical 'discovery.' " But he added, "It is clear to me the weight of evidence is massively against this."
In some of the studies of America, Mr. Finke and Mr. Stark treated Catholics differently from followers of other faiths. Critics have called this statistical sleight of hand. But the pair said that as a tightly knit, often persecuted minority -- at least in the 19th century -- Catholics did not take part in the same economic market as Protestants. Mr. Finke and Mr. Stark often focus on 19th-century America because the important issue, they argue, is whether having one, two or three churches makes a difference. 
As far as Ireland and Poland are concerned, Mr. Stark and Mr. Finke counter that even monopoly churches can thrive when religion and political conflict get entwined. The Poles, for instance, long saw attending Mass as a way of thumbing their noses at the Soviets. To critics, however, that line of argument sounds self-justifying. 
Still, even the critics concede that America's staggering level of faith demands more study and more theorizing. Mr. Berger, author of "The Sacred Canopy," has modified his views on whether and how America is secularizing. In an interview he said he no longer thought pluralism dissolved faith entirely, although he maintained that it changed the character of belief, making it more tentative and malleable, even in America.
He declined, however, to give the religious economies thinkers credit for his own shift. Like many others, he thinks a market-based view of religion misses most of what's important -- for example, he said, history, meaning, symbolism and ritual. "To look at religion from a framework derived exclusively from economics," Mr. Berger said, "is not very helpful."

HEADLINE: SHELF LIFE; 
Witnesses to Revolution Wrote History's First Draft

BYLINE:  By Edward Rothstein

 BODY:
In 1777, during the American Revolution, a British Army officer recorded in his journal the aftermath of a brutal battle fought over terrain near Ticonderoga, N.Y. "The wolves," he wrote, "came down in numbers from the mountains to devour the dead, and even some that were in a kind of manner buried, they tore out of the earth; the great stench thro the country being the cause of their coming down."
 It is a stench that assaults the senses again and again in this powerful collection of original documents, the stench of rotting corpses from the forests of Brookland (later Brooklyn), from the swamps of Long Island, from the fields of Virginia. Here are letters, proclamations, chronicles of battles, newspaper articles, diaries and memoirs by British and American participants, by writers familiar and obscure. In their accounts the war takes on a detailed texture that is startling one moment, numbing the next. 
 There is almost no editorial intrusion by John Rhodehamel, the curator of American History at the Huntington Library in San Marino, Calif., who selected the contents and ended the volume with short biographical notes, a condensed history and a list of sources, many no longer available. More information might have been helpful along the way. But there is something compelling about a story being told with more than 120 different selections written in more than 70 different voices, unfolding with chronological urgency. 
The popular imagination, of course, has some sense of the travails of the American Revolution, portrayed in images of the starving, freezing troops led by Washington through Delaware or shown more recently in the movie "The Patriot," with its horrific re-creations of hand-to-hand combat. There are broader scholarly histories as well, but something changes when confronted with first-hand accounts by observers. 
First there is the minor, seemingly negligible detail, usually filtered out from formal histories, that allows the abstract to become concrete: how a British colonel could not keep up with his troops, "his being a heavy man," or how Continental soldiers in Pennsylvania appeared to a flirtatious young woman in a home where they were billeted, or how starving soldiers prepared food during the 1775 invasion of Canada ("a little water, stiffened with flour, in imitation of shoemakers' paste"). 
It is touching to read Abigail Adams's futile appeal to her husband John, in a 1775 letter, as affairs of the nascent state preoccupied him. "All the letters I receive from you seem to be wrote in so much haste, that they scarcely leave room for a social feeling," she wrote. "I want some sentimental Effusions of the Heart."
The bewilderment and anger of the British observers also come through with fresh intensity. Ambrose Serle, private secretary to Lord Howe, the British admiral, writing of the Declaration of Independence in 1776, thought it proved "the Villainy & the Madness of these deluded People." A year later John Burgoyne, the British general, wrote that the "present unnatural Rebellion," far from guaranteeing freedom, has ushered in "the compleatest System of Tyranny," including "Arbitrary Imprisonments, Confiscation of Property, Persecution and Torture." 
Tales of atrocity, by all combatants, abound: the colonists who laughingly shoot a 7- or 8-year-old child playing in a yard; the British soldiers who attack the wounded colonists, "beating their heads to pieces"; the Indian allies of the British who rape and scalp a colonist's wife. There is one account, after the end of the war, by the daughter of a Philadelphia Loyalist who feared the vengeful mob gathering around her house with pickaxes, iron bars and stones. 
There are also questions raised, again and again, about the status of the slaves. The British offer them freedom in exchange for taking up a musket; so do the colonists. But little is resolved. Washington writes home urging that economies be undertaken, "without making the poor Negros suffer too much."
Above all, though, is the sense of the immensity of the war. "I am surprized at the Suddenness, as well as Greatness of this Revolution," John Adams writes Abigail in 1776. There were times when even the goal of the Revolution might have seemed unclear. 
A doctor in the Continental Army is delirious during the march to Valley Forge: "Poor food -- hard lodging -- Cold Weather -- fatigue -- Nasty Cloaths -- nasty Cookery -- Vomit half my time -- smoak'd out of my senses -- the Devil in't -- I can't Endure it -- Why are we sent here to starve and Freeze -- What sweet Felicities have I left at home." 
This is, of course, the great weakness of war chronicles. The sacrifices rarely seem justified at the time. Why was so much put at stake when the British, offering negotiations, seemed to promise so much? How did the colonists succeed in creating an army that one observer called "the strangest that ever was collected: Old men of 60, Boys of 14, and Blacks of all ages, and ragged for the most part"? How was support galvanized from the gentry, intellectuals, poor laborers and farm workers? How did the colonists ever end up victorious?
That is where the historian must come in, confronting these varied documents and their many precedents, coordinating theoretical writings on liberty with actions on the battlefield, analyzing why some revolutions end with great possibility and others end in wholesale terror.
Here, though, there may be justification enough in the book's closing account, a 1783 letter from Washington's secretary, who describes the general's resignation from his successfully completed commission. In his farewell to Congress, Washington's hands shook, his voice faltered.
The letter writer, James McHenry, adds: "The events of the revolution just accomplished -- the new situation in which it had thrown the affairs of the world -- the great man who had borne so conspicuous a figure in it, in the act of relinquishing all public employments to return to private life -- the past -- the present -- the future -- the manner -- the occasion -- all conspired to render it a spectacle inexpressibly solemn and affecting."

THE AMERICAN REVOLUTION
Writing From the War of Independence
Edited by John Rhodehamel
The Library of America. 878 pages. $40.

HEADLINE: A Space Station's Long Goodbye 

BYLINE:  By Leon Aron; Leon Aron, director of Russian studies at the American Enterprise Institute, is the author of "Yeltsin: A Revolutionary Life."

DATELINE: WASHINGTON 

 BODY:
Much of the coverage of the demise of the Mir space station was misty-eyed and nostalgic. Commentators used Mir's fiery descent as a metaphor for Russia's fall.
 This lamentation is misguided. Instead, we should say "Good riddance!" The station's decommissioning is a sign not of Russia's decline, but of her liberation. 
 An offshoot -- like the entire Soviet space program -- of the Soviet ballistic missile project, Mir was designed exclusively to serve the military-industrial complex that for decades had looted and beggared Russia. In 1998, Yevgeny Primakov, then the foreign minister, revealed that the Soviet Union was spending 70 percent of its gross domestic product on "defense and defense-related projects." 
When Mir was launched in 1986, 35 percent of Soviet hospitals did not have hot water and 30 percent lacked indoor toilets. The country's infant mortality rate was higher than that of Barbados. Half of Soviet schools had no central heating or running water. People spent between 40 and 60 hours a month in lines, and ration coupons were needed to buy 400 grams of sausage a month. 
In Russian villages, World War II widows, many receiving a pension of four rubles a month, worth about 40 cents, dug up potatoes with wooden shovels. It has been famously said of Peter the Great that he had forged a rich state of the impoverished people. Mir was a symbol of such a state. 
In the last week, we have heard again and again that Russia could not "afford" Mir. Nonsense! National priorities are not set by accountants. 
Can Iraq afford its relentless pursuit of weapons of mass destruction? Can North Korea afford its missiles when its people starve? Can China afford to increase its defense budget by 8 percent annually? Can Vietnam afford the fourth-largest army in the world, or could Cuba afford an expeditionary force in Angola in the 1980's? 
It was not the absence of money that killed Mir but the transition to a political system in which the rulers must account for their spending to a democratically elected parliament, a free press, an opposition and, ultimately, the voting public. The national goals changed accordingly.
"A great power is not mountains of weapons and subjects with no rights," Boris Yeltsin declared in 1997. "A great power is a self-reliant and talented people with initiative. The sole measure of the greatness of our motherland is the extent to which each citizen of Russia is free, healthy, educated and happy." 
As president, Mr. Yeltsin cut defense spending to under 5 percent of the country's gross domestic product -- and Mir was doomed.
One hopes, fervently, that in a not-so-distant future a democratic Russia will be rich enough to restart its space program -- as an embodiment of prosperity and free will, not of militarized tyranny preying on a terrorized nation. Meanwhile, shed no tears for Mir.
