HEADLINE: New & Noteworthy Paperbacks 

BYLINE:  By Scott Veale

 BODY:
 The Missing World, by Margot Livesey. (Penguin, $13.) In this British novel, a young journalist awakens from a coma after a traffic accident to find she has no memory of the last three years; her creepy former boyfriend, seeing an opening, tries to marry her before she recovers her past. The result is "intelligent fiction, vigorous both in its observation of human foible and in its speculation on the role that memory plays in underwriting our sense of choice and direction in our lives," Michael Upchurch wrote in the Book Review last year.

The Other American: The Life of Michael Harrington, by Maurice Isserman. (PublicAffairs, $14.) Michael Harrington (1928-89) was a Socialist critic whose 1962 book, "The Other America," was a landmark study of the culture of poverty, and whose life work was to create a "left wing of the possible." In 2000 our reviewer, Victor Navasky, called this a "fair and fascinating account of a charismatic and appealing actor on the American political stage."

Sick Puppy, by Carl Hiaasen. (Warner Vision, $7.99.) This gleefully chaotic novel, in which a deranged eco-terrorist takes aim at a corrupt lobbyist (and litterbug), is populated by depraved and awful Floridians of all stripes, from crooked politicians to swamp-dwelling vigilantes. " 'Sick Puppy' begins with an absurd premise and then gets nuttier," Joe Queenan wrote here last year.

Shakespeare's Kings. The Great Plays and the History of England in the Middle Ages: 1337-1485, by John Julius Norwich. (Touchstone/Simon & Schuster, $16.) The British historian assesses the reliability of Shakespeare's plays about the later Plantagenets, setting the chronology straight and sorting out conflated or confused figures for the "enthusiastic but cheerfully nonexpert" Shakespeare lover. "Lord Norwich takes to his task with characteristic panache," R. N. Swanson wrote in these pages last year. "His style is easy and highly readable."

A Member of the Family, by Susan Merrell. (Perennial/ HarperCollins, $13.) In this first novel about the limits of familial love, an American couple who adopt an emotionally disturbed Romanian orphan are forced to contemplate some tough decisions when his disruptive behavior threatens to destroy their family. The result is "a heartbreaking story about an adoption gone very wrong," Betsy Groban said here last year.

The Nature of Economies, by Jane Jacobs. (Vintage, $12.) The social critic best known for her groundbreaking 1961 work, "The Death and Life of Great American Cities," maintains that economies mimic natural systems in the way they evolve, and that they need to be understood in ecological terms. "She draws upon a rich knowledge of diverse literatures . . . and has lost none of her astute wit," Robert Kuttner wrote here in 2000.

The Verificationist, by Donald Antrim. (Vintage Contemporaries, $12.) This slender novel features a bunch of squabbling psychoanalysts (none with medical degrees) who meet in an all-night pancake house to chew over their livelihood and their sexuality, among other things. The narrator observes most of the action while floating around the ceiling. The result is "a book that clatters and whirs like a Rube Goldberg device, spitting out, on every page, perfectly formed pellets of intellection, rude humor, grief and longing," Dwight Garner wrote here last year.

The Tulip, by Anna Pavord. (Bloomsbury, $14.95.) A British garden writer blends botany and history in charting the remarkable ascendancy of the tulip, a humble wildflower from Central Asia that captivated Europe in the 17th century and became a global craze. Her narrative, which has been reissued with fewer illustrations than in the hardcover edition, "will create many new devotees," Verlyn Klinkenborg wrote here in 1999. Tulipomania: The Story of the World's Most Coveted Flower and the Extraordinary Passions It Aroused, by Mike Dash (Three Rivers, $12), is a close-in study of the speculative buying and selling of tulips that gripped the Netherlands in the 1600's, creating the world's first futures market before ending in a spectacular crash. " 'Tulipomania' captures the frenzy of a fascinating phenomenon," Carol Peace Robins wrote here last year.

Acts of Mutiny, by Derek Beaven. (Picador USA, $13.) The narrator of this ambitious novel sets out from England to Australia in 1959 with his mother and her lover aboard a liner filled with disaffected emigres, and discovers that the military has stashed a deadly weapon in the hold. Last year in these pages, Mark Schone praised the book's "exciting, geopolitical plot." Scott Veale

HEADLINE: Books in Brief: Nonfiction 

BYLINE:  By Sarah Milstein 

 BODY:
 No Small Courage
A History of Women
in the United States.
Edited by Nancy F. Cott.
Oxford University, $35.
 "In much of the Western world's written history, women's presence is minimal," Nancy F. Cott writes in the preface to "No Small Courage." This ambitious book examines women's experiences in the New World since Columbus landed, and attempts to demonstrate that newly found perspectives will "change the historical record altogether." Its 10 chapters, written by nine historians under Cott's editorship, look at "work and leisure, family patterns, political activities, forms of organization and outstanding accomplishments." The writers also examine the effect of race and economic class on women's lives. For example, in a section on the colonial Chesapeake region, Jane Kamensky, a historian at Brandeis University, writes, "Planters' wives were increasingly able to restrict themselves to duties befitting proper English matrons because they enslaved Africans to do the rest of their work." In its coverage of the 20th century, "No Small Courage" becomes more a history of feminism than of the female experience. The final chapter, for instance, provides details on the divergent views of feminist factions in the 1960's and 70's, and even on countermovements, but offers scant information on the patterns of women's lives during that time. There is little new scholarship, but illuminating and lively personal narratives are interwoven throughout the book. These individual stories help shape this multilayered record, which falls short of painting a complete picture of women in the United States but succeeds in giving a sense of how women have been "active agents" in American history, in the words of Cott, who teaches history and American studies at Yale. Sarah Milstein

HEADLINE: ART/ARCHITECTURE; 
Racing for Dollars, Photography Pulls Abreast of Painting

BYLINE:  By RICHARD B. WOODWARD; Richard B. Woodward is an editor-at-large for DoubleTake magazine.

 BODY:
FOR better or worse, photography is the New New Thing in the art market. Over the last two years, with fortunes being won and lost on bets about our digital future, the most searching visual invention of the 19th century has been charting upward like a 1999 Internet stock.
 Record prices have become the norm for every period. A few contemporary photographers, at auction last year for the first time, outsold their peers in other mediums. No booth at New York's recent Armory Show, a showcase for international art trends, seemed up-to-date without a photographer or two; while the exposure photography received in the city's museums amid the millennial hoo-hah last year was unprecedented. Even if the new financial respect and visibility for photographs in 2000 is seen in decades to come as a blip, one of many tech bubbles that popped, a dizzying sense that milestones had been passed and barriers leaped was hard to ignore. 
 ARTnewsletter reported in September that a print of Man Ray's "Glass Tears" from 1932-33 had sold privately in 1999 to the collector John Pritzker for "substantially more than a million dollars." (Only three years earlier another "Glass Tears" set the record for a photograph at Sotheby's at a mere $266,500.) If nothing else, the sale indicated to many people, as the dealer Howard Greenberg said, that the "price gap between great photos and great works in other media is closing."
Nowhere was this phenomenon on more egregious display than at New York's contemporary art auctions last year. Enormous, digitized, color prints by young Germans ruled the block. "Pantheon, Rome" by Thomas Struth, hammered down for $270,000 at Christie's in May, measures 8 by 6 feet; while Andreas Gursky's "Prada II," which fetched the same price in Christie's November sale, is nearly 10 feet across -- wider than most of Pollock's canvases. Even photographs that aren't king-size, at least if by Cindy Sherman, were bid up to unheard of heights. "Untitled No. 209," a color self-portrait from 1989, went for $269,000 at Sotheby's in the spring while "Untitled No. 92" from 1982 fetched $259,000 in the fall at Christie's, making her among the most prized American artists of her generation in any medium. No photographer in history has achieved the monetary parity with painters and sculptors that Ms. Sherman, Mr. Struth and Mr. Gursky now enjoy.
That none of the photographs mentioned above are unique works -- all the images have existing variants or were printed in editions -- may mean that the upper end of the contemporary-art market has at last accepted the replicant nature of photography (previously a deterrent to high prices); or that buyers are willing to overlook this uncomfortable fact in exceptional cases.
The tide of money has rolled into the calmer bays of 19th-century photography as well. Sotheby's London sale in October 1999 of the Andre and Marie-Therese Jammes collection was billed as an event. The Parisian couple pioneered an appreciation for French calotypists like Gustave Le Gray, Henri Le Secq, Edouard Baldus and others. Still, few collectors predicted the bidding frenzy that ensued. An 1855 albumen print by Le Gray went to an anonymous phone bidder for $840,370 -- a world record for a photograph at auction. Another Le Gray went for $694,650.
The total of $12.3 million for 265 lots prompted The International Herald Tribune to call it "one of those historic days when an extraordinary sale brings home the fact that a major change in cultural perception has taken place."
The centrality of photographs for the millennial celebrations reinforced this impression of a cultural earthquake. Many surveys of American art, even one as recent as Robert Hughes's "American Visions," have played down the contributions of photographers to the country's artistic heritage. 
But last year there was no getting away from them. The Whitney Museum's two-part extravaganza, "The American Century," highlighted photographers from beginning to end.
At the Museum of Modern Art, the space given to photography was still more striking. In a year devoted to re-examining its mission and its collections, 30 of the 50 shows had photographs on the walls with paintings, drawings, posters, sculptures and videos. In this new, provisional, uncompartmentalized MOMA, photography stood for the first time on equal footing with every other art. Its prominence within the museum was further emphasized by the announcement in December that MOMA would buy 1,000 photographs by Lee Friedlander -- 868 prints from the 1950's to the present, and another 132 prints "representing current and future work." Not only is this the largest purchase of works by a living artist in the history of the museum, it is the first time the Modern has committed itself to buying art not yet made.
Some of the pressure to change photography's status has come from contemporary practice. Young artists everywhere have accepted the camera as simply one among many picture-making tools and photographs as just another kind of image. The awarding of the 2000 Turner Prize in England to Wolfgang Tillmans, the first time a full-fledged photographer has won this glamorous award, completes a dramatic shift that began in the 80's when photographers first appeared routinely in painting and sculpture galleries. It is no longer unusual to find, say, prints by Robert Mapplethorpe or Sherrie Levine hanging in the collection of someone who also owns a David Salle painting or a Damien Hirst vitrine.
But a noticeable change in the Chelsea scene over the last year or so has been the appearance of photographers who were never stars during the 80's art boom. Robert Adams, associated with the New Topographics movement of the 70's and among the most unassuming artists alive, had two large shows last year at Matthew Marks, a premier space for contemporary work. The color landscape photographer Stephen Shore, another relative old-timer, turned up at 303, a gallery better known for showing young painters and installation artists.
Perhaps the older New Topographic focus of Mr. Adams and Mr. Shore will help to establish an American lineage for the newer New Topographics of Mr. Struth and Mr. Gursky; or maybe photography of any style, even small-scale documentary, is now welcome in art's marketplace. The Andrea Rosen Gallery, which represents artists in many mediums but mostly with a conceptual bent, will have a show by Mr. Friedlander this spring. 
Some of the older antagonistic critical rubrics -- between modern and postmodern, "straight" and "staged" -- seem increasingly empty or pointless as money begins to change everything.
Whether this is altogether good for photographers is another matter.
Will people start to view exhibitions, like Mr. Gursky's current show at the Modern, with dollar signs in their eyes? What will happen to the photography market and to people's expectations when, as some conservators and dealers predict, the color in some of these high-priced prints starts to fade? The layer of serious photography collectors in the world remains dangerously thin.
The market may be surging ahead of what photography can truly deliver as an owned thing with an aura that offers solace or proves one's financial savviness and self-worth.
Throughout its history photography struggled to be respected as an art on equal grounds with painting and sculpture. It existed on the margins, with scant attention from the art magazines or general news media. Those days are probably over. But what seemed to be a disadvantage may in fact have been a relative blessing. Commenting from the sidelines on the follies of human vanity has been one of its most constructive roles. Then again, it may turn out that 2000 was the year that photographers finally joined -- or led -- the passing parade.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Wolfgang Tillmans's inkjet print "I Don't Want to Get Over You," 2000. (Associated Press)

HEADLINE: TRAVEL ADVISORY; 
West Coast Hotels Dim Lights, Raise Rates

BYLINE:  By EDWIN McDOWELL

 BODY:
The power problems on the West Coast have prompted a number of hotels to add surcharges, usually from $1.50 to $2.50 a night. In addition, some chains and individual properties are taking energy conservation measures, which range from installing dimmer light bulbs in guest rooms to shutting down the hotel laundry. 
 Marriott, for example, which manages or owns more than 150 hotels in California, has added a $2.50 surcharge to daily room rates in its full-service hotels and $1.50 a night at others, such as those carrying its Courtyard brand. While Marriott cannot mandate the surcharge for its franchisees, it said that it expects most of them to go along. 
 "When the energy situation is resolved the surcharge will be removed," said Lucy Bossert, a Marriott spokeswoman. Meanwhile, to conserve energy, which many hotel operators say accounts for about 10 percent of their costs, Marriott recently appointed an energy manager for its Western region.
Starwood Hotels and Resorts, which includes the Sheraton, Westin and W brands, has added a $2.50 nightly surcharge to its 60 or so hotels in California, Oregon and Washington. It also plans to keep the surcharge until energy costs start coming down.
Hilton Hotels has a $3 per night surcharge at the 49 properties it owns and manages in California. In addition to the Hilton brand, they include some Doubletree, Embassy Suites and Red Lion hotels.
The upscale 667-room Argent Hotel in San Francisco has begun assigning guests to certain floors when it isn't filled, then shutting off lights and turning down heating on the unoccupied floors. The Argent has also installed 27-watt halogen bulbs in its guest rooms, providing as much light as 100-watt bulbs while using less energy.
 EDWIN McDOWELL

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: ART; 
Three Shows and Each Has Its Charm

BYLINE:  By WILLIAM ZIMMER 

 BODY:
IT has become something of a trend at the Yale University Art Gallery in New Haven to emphasize presentation. 
 Three exhibitions currently at Yale illustrate this in different ways. (Two of them are here only through today; the third one closes in a week.) They are interesting in their details, but the way they look as totalities gives a clue to what might be expected in future shows. 
 The first show, "Objective Color," is the most radical of the three, discarding some of the traditional rules governing a museum exhibition. The show is an assembly of 20th-century art, almost all abstract paintings and sculptures from Yale's collection, with each piece included because color is its main reason for being.
The focus on color means the viewer is supposed to disregard chronology, even the title and artist's name, and give himself over to a pure retinal experience. 
Jennifer Gross, the gallery's curator of European and contemporary art, has concocted an alluring environment. All the intense color gives the proceedings a garish "swinging 60's" look. Viewers can't help being dazzled -- and then frustrated -- because Ms. Gross has done away with putting identification labels next to the objects. Instead, posted at various points in the gallery are laminated sheets containing information that is usually provided by wall labels. The experience of trying to find information about a work one is interested in is more distracting than any wall label could ever be. Perhaps Ms. Gross should have banished written information altogether.
But it is writing that emerges as the most engrossing part of the show. Near the exit is a book for visitors to write their comments. A civil war is being waged in those pages, and it is amazing that such a range of attitudes could be elicited by a display of art that is 99 percent abstract. 
Around the corner, by contrast, is an exhibition drained of color: "From Caligula to Constantine: Tyranny and Transformation in Roman Portraiture." The portrait sculptures are in various earth colors and the walls are gray. The gallery's decor is intended to recreate a Roman house with a pool, a household shrine and an atrium in which images of the ruling emperor and ancestors would be displayed. It is an august atmosphere, just right for the display of objects set in stone.
But when viewers begin to examine the carved portraits, or likenesses on coins, they realize they are looking at something that is the opposite of static; rather, it is fluid and chameleonlike. Most of these portraits have been reworked in order to erase the familiar physiognomies of tyrants. The features of a successor, or even an ancestor, supplant the original ones. The practice was not a matter of economy when it came to portraits of emperors. The reworking, the replacing of the bad with the good, was akin to redemption.
The exhibition also contains a number of portraits of private citizens, and their reworking was related to economy. Yale's curator of ancient art, Susan B. Matheson, contends the materials were costly and that warehouses of sculptures may have been available for reuse.
A major issue in the exhibition is the treatment of likenesses of women, who may or may not have been innocent bystanders. A marble portrait of Plautilla, the wife of Caracalla who was executed on her husband's orders a decade after their marriage, retains extensively damaged eyes nose and mouth.
Professor Eric Varner of Emory University, who organized the exhibition, comments that Plautilla's defacement deprived her "of any metaphorical ability to 'see' or 'speak' to the inhabitants of the Roman Empire."
In the Asian Galleries is "Ancients and Moderns: Tradition and Transformation in the Arts of Asia." There will be a Part II beginning April 17. The word "transformation" in the title is a clue that the show's intent is something like the Roman portraiture show. The objects are not to be regarded as static; rather the exhibition is an animated experience.
Standing at the entrance to the show a viewer is impressed by the vista, a long stretch of display cases containing a diversity of Japanese or Chinese household objects. There is also two-dimensional work on the walls. In the middle of the show, the viewer assumes the role of amateur connoisseur. Several centuries might separate the similar objects in a given display case and the viewer can't resist trying to determine the historical order.
A group of Japanese ceramics is especially rough hewn, evincing a kind of expressionism that is easily associated with the contemporary era. But basic, historically refined forms remain under the surfaces, and the experience of the exhibition becomes one of appreciating how much inspiration contemporary artisans have taken from the past.
"Objective Color" and "From Caligula to Constantine" close today. Part I of "Ancients and Moderns" closes April 1. Information: (203) 432-0600.

HEADLINE: MIDSTREAM; 
Knowing What You Owe

BYLINE:  By JAMES SCHEMBARI 

 BODY:
THERE is little that I can be smug about, but when it comes to debt, I can be obnoxious. Except for my mortgage, I have no debt: no car loans, no credit card balances, no margin loans. Even my mortgage is laughable: 15 years at 5.625 percent; I hope to have it paid off by the time my daughter starts college in four years.
 A few years ago, when I was thinking about moving to a different home, the loan officer who was handling my mortgage application was in awe, saying she had rarely met anyone who was so debt-free. 
 Is that obnoxious enough?
Many of my friends live on debt. They ask me, "Why should I spend my money when I can spend the bank's?" But I find debt troubling -- especially when the economy is slowing.
My generation is no stranger to debt. According to a Federal Reserve Board report on consumer finances in 1998, the latest agency numbers available, 87 percent of families headed by people 35 to 54 years old had some kind of debt. Almost 60 percent had mortgages, while about half had installment loans, like those for cars. About half had balances on their credit cards.
What the heck are we doing? That is easy to explain. "The American dream requires more than a turkey in every pot," said Robert E. Veasey, a certified financial planner in East Providence, R.I. "It needs filet mignon on every grill. When I grew up, going out to eat was a treat. No one stays home to cook anymore. We drive cars that are expensive. It isn't enough to have basic cable. Now I need digital cable."
Kathleen Meunier of Warwick, R.I., 37, said she and her husband, Richard, who have a combined annual income of $60,000, had accumulated about $45,000 in debt a few years ago. Using credit, they had bought two cars and a big-screen television and had a swimming pool installed at their home. "We were really living the idea that money grew on trees," she said. "We went out to eat three, four times a week. We went away on vacations twice a year and to bed-and-breakfasts once a month."
The odd thing about debt is that many people don't know how much they have. Ms. Meunier said she didn't realize the extent of her indebtedness until a financial counsel pointed it out to her about two years ago.
Credit counselors say debt problems don't hit some people until they are over the limit on their credit cards and cannot use them anymore.
"They almost don't want to know what their situation is," Mr. Veasey said. "They finally get to a point when they see the situation and then are embarrassed about it."
Ms. Meunier sought help from the Consumer Credit Counseling Services of Southern New England, a nonprofit group that put her on a budget and helped her pay off the debts.
Cynthia Becker, regional coordinator of education and new business development for the group, said many people use credit to pay for everyday expenses, which, of course, can snowball. A rule of thumb, she said, is that debt payments should not exceed 40 percent of income.
That is where some baby boomers are getting into trouble. The Fed report said that in 1998, some 11.6 percent of families in which the head of household was 35 to 44 had debt payments that were more than 40 percent of their incomes. That is up from 7.8 percent of such families in 1989.
For households headed by 45- to 54-year-olds, a category comprising mostly boomers, the figure was also 11.6 percent in 1998, up from 10.9 percent in 1989. And all of this was before the economy began turning sour.
Usually, Mr. Veasey and Ms. Becker said, the only way out is to cut expenses. But to do that, you have to know what they are. Mr. Veasey suggested carrying a little notebook and entering everything you spend money on. "I don't care if it's a pack of gum," he said.
Then start cutting back. Don't go out to eat as often. Put off buying that television. Visit Grandpa for vacation, not Mickey Mouse. Over time, the savings add up, and before you know it, the bills are not only paid, but you actually have money left over. 
Ms. Becker said the slowing economy and the pending change in bankruptcy laws would spell trouble for more people. She said her organization, which covers Massachusetts, Connecticut and Rhode Island, had 17,551 families enrolled in debt management plans at the end of last year, up from 16,223 in 1999. She said she expected the numbers to rise this year.
"It will get worse before it gets better," she said.

HEADLINE: Suffolk's Budget: Quick Change in Direction 

BYLINE:  By JOHN RATHER 

 BODY:
A CHILL passed through Suffolk County government earlier this year when state figures for December sales tax receipts arrived. They showed a 16.6 percent drop from a year earlier, a startling plunge in the revenues that finance more than half of county government but fluctuate, sometimes wildly, with the regional economy and with the strength of retail sales.
 The growth of sales tax revenues had been so strong from the 1990's through the first three quarters of last year -- frequently increasing by double digits over the previous year -- that last March Suffolk confidently joined a handful of other New York counties and cities in rescinding the sales tax on clothing costing less than $110, forgoing an estimated $29 million in revenue from March through December. 
 But with a weak fourth quarter last year, highlighted by the December plunge in receipts, county estimates of $789.6 million in sales tax revenues for 2000, estimates made before the slowdown, turned out to be almost $28 million higher than the $761.7 the county actually collected. And that's after the estimates had been adjusted to take the clothing exemption into account. 
Now a projected increase in sales tax receipts for 2001, based on what was in retrospect the overly optimistic 2000 estimate of an increase of more than 8 percent, looks impossibly high as the economy sputters.
In his state-of-the-county address last week, Robert J. Gaffney, the county executive, warned of a $35 million budget deficit by the end of 2001, a deficit that could grow to $140 million by the end of 2002 unless swift action is taken.
The action Mr. Gaffney prescribed includes a hiring freeze, a call for spending cuts and most significantly, an increase in the county sales tax of a quarter of 1 percent. That would bring the rate to 8.5 percent, a level matched in New York only by neighboring Nassau. In 1995, Suffolk voluntarily cut the sales tax by that same quarter of 1 percent. If the increase is enacted, the county's share of sales taxes will increase to 4.25 percent. 
In his address last week, Mr. Gaffney insisted that the county economy remained strong and called neither for higher property taxes nor for rescinding the sales tax exemption on clothing. He said the sales tax increase was the only short-term way to prevent deficits but should remain in effect only as long as it was needed. 
But in what may signify a change in the way the county finances its spending, Mr. Gaffney also broached the politically touchy question of whether an imbalance between sales taxes and property taxes needs correcting. The underlying problem, Mr. Gaffney told members of the County Legislature, is that by using sales-tax-driven budget surpluses of $330 million over the last eight years to reduce property taxes, Suffolk had grown too reliant on a source of revenue over which the county had no control.
"The fact is that property taxes are a more stable source of revenue than the sales tax," Mr. Gaffney said in his address. "And slashing the tax warrant has left the county more dependent on sales tax revenues -- and more vulnerable to a slowdown in the national economy."
Mr. Gaffney proposed changes in the county charter that would allow up to two-thirds of budget surpluses to be set aside for leaner times. Sales tax receipts created the surpluses in recent years, but current charter provisions, reflecting powerful anti-tax movements of the late 1970's and 1980's, require that surpluses be passed on to county taxpayers in the form of lower taxes, and not held by the government. 
A result of those laws, Mr. Gaffney said, has been an unprecedented 70 percent reduction -- from $161 million to $49 million -- in property taxes paid into the county general fund over the last eight years. "No other level of government anywhere can say as much," he noted.
The sales tax bonanza has also allowed the county to hold down the property taxes that still largely finance the police district that covers the five western Suffolk towns. The five East End towns have their own local police departments. 
But an arbitration award, which will increase the police district costs by more than $100 million over the next four years, coupled with flatsales tax revenues, spells trouble, Mr. Gaffney said. "To put it bluntly, binding arbitration may be the single largest threat to our long-term financial stability, and something has to be done about it," he said. 
Health-care and social-service costs, also dramatically down over the last eight years, are now beginning to rise again, other county officials said.
Yet raising property taxes could boomerang on elected officials. Mr. Gaffney said that making up the $27 million shortfall in the general fund would trigger a 56 percent increase in property taxes, although the increase would still leave taxes at half of what they were eight years ago.
Such an increase would probably be highly unpalatable for county legislators, who face election every two years, and could also harm Mr. Gaffney politically.
Support appears to be stronger for the sales tax increase. Paul Tonna, a Republican from Deer Park who is the presiding officer of the County Legislature, called the increase "an excellent proposal." He said he would join Mr. Gaffney in asking legislators in Albany to authorize the increase, which will also need approval from the County Legislature.
The clothing exemption, which budget officials estimated would result in the loss of more than $30 million a year, will remain in effect until at least next March, the earliest date at which the county could end it. Mr. Gaffney pledged to "keep sales-tax-free clothing in place, both for our residents and as a long-term economic boon for clothing retailers," but that decision will rest with the legislators.
Suffolk retailers lobbied for the exemption and say it has increased their business. Janine H. Nebons, the general manager of the Tanger Outlet Center in Riverhead, said that since the exemption began last March, there had been a 23 percent increase in shoppers from Nassau, which has no such exemption. She said the Nassau shoppers were "acutely aware" of the Suffolk exemption.
She said that holiday shopping volume rose 8 percent last year over the same period in 1999. The outlet center, which opened in 1994, is one of the largest such centers in the country, with 165 stores and 10 to 12 million shoppers a year, she said. 
Frederick B. Pollert, the director of the County Legislature's budget review office, said that budgets last year and this year took into account the lost clothing tax revenues and that the exemption was not a cause of the shortfall.
Mr. Pollert said the county would know more about sales tax revenues when a report on receipts for this year arrives in April. "That will give us a better idea of whether that last quarter in 2000 was an outlier or indicative of a trend," he said.
Dr. Pearl Kamer, the chief economist for the Long Island Association, the Island's largest business group, said with the downturn in the stock market the region was entering uncharted waters in which county governments' reliance on sales taxes became especially risky.
"You have a situation where half our residents and possibly more own stocks, values have declined considerably, and we still don't know where the bottom is," Dr. Kamer said. "So you are going to have a much more drastic effect on consumer spending than we have had in any previous business cycle."
Dr. Kamer said the surge in consumer spending in the last several years had been fueled by "the wealth effect" among consumers whose portfolios were growing by leaps and bounds. But after recent market declines, she said, consumers are "buying what they need and probably not much more than that." 
"That is why it is so dicey to project sales tax revenues at this time," she said. "We just don't know how powerful the reverse wealth effect is going to be and how long it will last." 
Nevertheless, the county still has the confidence of Wall Street. Fitch Inc., a credit rating service, recently upgraded its rating for Suffolk's general obligation bonds from A to A-plus. The service's highest rating, currently held by Westchester County, is AAA. Nassau has a BBB rating.
The agency said the upgrade reflected "the county's improved fiscal environment, highlighted by institutionalized cooperation between the executive and legislative branches on matters related to the budget, an established commitment to grow reserves as a means to offset future economic disruptions and an increased focus on longer-term financial considerations." 
The agency also noted the county's "broad and deep economic base" and moderate debt levels. 
Joseph D. Mason, the director of public finance at Fitch, said the service was aware of Suffolk's lower-than-predicted sales tax revenues. "The final numbers did not come in quite as hoped," he said. "We are not overly concerned about it."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Casey Bartholomew and Diane Flynn at a Stony Brook shop where most clothing is free of county sales tax. (Maxine Hicks for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: In the Region/New Jersey; 
As Market Pauses, Office Space for Sublease Grows

BYLINE:  By RACHELLE GARBARINE

 BODY:
A GROWING amount of the available office space in the state is not in the hands of landlords. It is on the sublease market, offering an exit for companies restructuring their space needs, good deals for tenants and a mixed blessing for the 11-county northern and central New Jersey office marketplace, national real estate services companies say. 
 There are 4.1 million square feet of space being offered for sublease, or 26 percent of the overall available space, according to Cushman & Wakefield. Figures from GVA Williams show there are 3.3 million feet of such space, or 20.7 percent of all available space. And Insignia/ESG says there are 2.31 million feet of sublease space, or 13 percent of all available space. 
 Because of the different ways brokerages calculate space availability, their statistics often seem to be at odds. In the case of subleasing, Cushman & Wakefield shows a doubling of such space from nine months ago and GVA Williams registers a similar increase but from last year, while ESG shows an increase of 10,000 square feet from the end of 1999 to the end of 2000. 
Despite the differences, there is an unaccustomed amount of sublease space available these days for the first time in recent years as the uncertain national economy affects the office market. Rental rate increases have started to diminish, cautious tenants have trimmed their space needs and the pace of leasing has slowed in some submarkets. 
Most industry professionals agree there is a pause in the market. But with the overall office vacancy rate around 10 percent, no one is predicting it will collapse. 
"There will be more turbulence in the next four to six months before the market rebounds," said Mark Yeager, president of Gale & Wentworth, a real estate company with headquarters in Florham Park.
Eric Witmondt, chief executive of the New Jersey office of GVA Williams, based in Parsippany, has a more tempered outlook. "It will be status quo at least through the summer," he said, "as everyone takes a wait-and-see approach to what happens to the New Jersey and national economies." 
The crop of subleases is the result of corporate mergers, acquisitions and even expansions. Rearrangements to the corporate house, including those of Lucent Technologies, Prudential, Merrill Lynch and AT&T, are expected to continue, at least for the near term, industry professionals said. 
Lucent has 155,000 square feet on the sublease market in a 310,000-square-foot building on Woodhollow Road in Parsippany. The sublease is part of the company's restructuring, which will result in 10,000 people being laid off, 1,500 of them in New Jersey.
That "will create vacant space," said John J. Skalko, a Lucent spokesman. He declined to speculate on future sublease plans but said the company had 8.5 million square feet of space in 36 buildings in the state.
As part of AT&T's efforts to reshuffle its space needs to cut costs, the company has put some 1.8 million square feet of space on the market, said Gary Morgenstern, a spokesman. As those efforts continue, the company's 12 million square feet in 35 buildings "could further tighten," by 2 million feet in the next year, he said.
The sublet space is filtering onto a market where rents have stabilized after rising an average of 35 percent in the last two years. Subleases generally are priced at 25 to 50 percent below market.
Subleases are a concern because they bring "another pricing dynamic" to the market, said Daniel J. Loughlin, a managing principal at the Staubach Company, a commercial real estate service firm with offices in Murray Hill. But he said, and most other commercial brokers agreed, that barring a full-blown recession the market should be able to absorb the sublease space.
Among the reasons are that such space represents just 2 percent of New Jersey's 152-million-square-foot market, said Patrick Murphy, executive director of Insignia/ ESG of New Jersey, which is based in Saddle Brook. In addition, he said there has been limited new construction, keeping demand ahead of supply. That is expected to continue because financing from lenders to construct buildings on speculation remains tight, he added.
Mr. Witmondt added that the state had also not been as negatively affected as other regions by sharp cutbacks at dot-com companies, which could have meant more sublease space. Additionally, the state has a diverse tenant base, he said, adding that while some industries like telecommunications are shedding space, others, including pharmaceuticals, are expanding.
Mr. Murphy added that his firm knew of at least seven companies looking in the state for large blocks of office space, ranging from 150,000 to 600,000 square feet.
In today's market, brokers said the conventional thinking about sublets as small unmarketable space with short leases and bargain rents did not always hold true. Indeed, a sizable amount of the available sublet space is in blocks of 50,000 square feet or more, reports Cushman & Wakefield, which lists 13 such blocks totaling 2.5 million square feet. 
Mr. Witmondt said that with large blocks of quality space still in demand, such subleases actually "could help loosen up submarkets where there has been no new construction."
An example is the 150,000 square feet of space that Prudential, the insurer, has made available as a sublease at a 325,000-square-foot building it leases on Wood Avenue in Metro Park. That space, resulting from the insurer's consolidation of its operations, has 10 years left on its lease and is an option for tenants, "because there is nothing else available in that submarket," said Michael A. Cohen, managing director at GVA Williams, which is marketing the space for Prudential. Asking rents of $33 a square foot a year are competitive, he said.
The same is true for sublet space that has become or will become available on the Hudson River waterfront, where the vacancy rate is low. There, EDS, a computer services concern, recently shed 45,000 square feet in a building in Weehawken. 
In submarkets where new construction is brisk and sublease space is abundant, it could drag down the market. In Morris and Somerset Counties, which have the largest amounts of subleases, such space accounted for 44 percent and 47 percent respectively of the overall available space in those markets, Cushman & Wakefield said. 
In Somerset County the biggest block of space is the 400,000-square-foot building on Davidson Road in Franklin Township that Merrill Lynch will be making available for lease or sale. The building is part of the company's consolidation to its new 1.25-million-square-foot campus on 450 acres off Interstate 95 in Hopewell, Selena Morris, a spokesperson, said. That is slightly more than the 1.1 million square feet the company will ultimately be leaving, she said, noting that it will have 3 million square feet of space in the state. 
Mr. Murphy of Insignia ESG, which is marketing the building, said, "It will draw tenants in this kind of market because there is a flight to quality." 
That is also what Mr. Loughlin of Staubach is hoping for in marketing the largest sublease in Morris County -- the 340,000-square-foot building in Parsippany that Aventis Pharmaceuticals is vacating. The company no longer needs the building, which was considered a temporary location, because it is moving to its larger permanent headquarters in Bridgewater. 
"The lease has eight and half years to go, making it more marketable" than short-term subleases and "competitive with new construction," Mr. Loughlin said. "We will be aggressive, but rents will not be below market."
Meanwhile, developers continue to build in the county. Gale & Wentworth is building a 175,000-square-foot speculative building as part of the Center of Morris County in Parsippany, which ultimately will have 850,000 square feet in four buildings.
"The market still has enough depth," Mr. Yeagar, the company's president, said, noting that in Morris County as elsewhere his company "plans to continue to develop because the basics are solid." But reflecting a more cautious market, it is adjusting its strategy on speculative building. Mr. Yeager said his company would now want to have an existing speculative building at least half leased before starting another one

HEADLINE: Incumbent's Loss Stuns Port Chester Democrats 

BYLINE:  By COREY KILGANNON 

DATELINE: PORT CHESTER 

 BODY:
OF all the local elections last Tuesday, one that may spell the biggest change is the upset of Port Chester's mayor, Christine Korff, by Gerald L. Logan, a 63-year-old securities broker and a political neophyte.
 The margin was slim -- Mr. Logan won by 16 votes of 3,415 cast (there were no dimpled chads). But the election caused a huge power shift in a village known for its bitter partisan rivalry. 
 As mayor, Ms. Korff, a Democrat, gave her party the majority on the village's board of trustees, which has three Republicans and three Democrats. But Mr. Logan's victory now gives the Republicans the majority.
Moments after his victory, Mr. Logan said he would reassess many of the Democrats' initiatives, most important the $100 million downtown redevelopment project that began last year. The developers, G & S Investors, of Long Island, were selected for the project by local Democrats.
Mr. Logan does not take office until April 3, but he was already talking like the new sheriff in town at a celebration at a local restaurant, Pasta Per Voi, stressing the need to reassess G & S's role in the project.
"I've been looking at projects like this all across the country," he said, "and we need to sit down and make sure they have the proper financing to deliver what they've laid out."
Ms. Korff's tenure was marked by lawsuits charging she blocked civil service jobs and promotions for several men related to prominent village Republicans. Republicans have also accused the Democrats of hiring a corrupt company to settle overdue parking tickets. 
Mr. Logan said, "We've been hearing all kinds of things, and we want to clean things up and bring some honesty and ethics to this village."
Ms. Korff, a mortgage broker who served three terms as mayor, lost one lawsuit over her hiring practices and is appealing the decision. She dismissed the charges as political attacks. 
A ruby pinky ring sparkled as Mr. Logan clasped his long fingers around a glass of white wine. Many supporters wore fine suits and smoked Cohiba cigars. The vote tallies, projected onto the wall next to pastel murals of Italy, were intermittently obscured by shadows of hands slapping high-fives and shouts of, "Kick the bums out."
Meanwhile, in the rear room of the Village Inn, a no-frills restaurant in town, Ms. Korff, 39, watched her vote lead dwindle. Several victory balloons popped as her aides reached for cigarettes and shouted into cell phones.
Angelo Rubino, chairman of the village's Democratic Party, stood in front of a droopy American flag and repeated into a microphone, "I am just shocked." A young boy was wearing a Yankees jacket and a say-it-ain't-so face.
High up on a landing, surveying the room and its lonely platters of salami heros, Sam Terenzi, Mrs. Korff's political mentor and a powerful Democratic supporter, cradled his drink, shook his head and slipped out of the room.

HEADLINE: Commercial Property/Montclair, N.J.; 
Town Steps In on Development of Long-Vacant Store

BYLINE:  By JOHN HOLUSHA 

DATELINE: MONTCLAIR N.J. 

 BODY:
THE building has sat there, empty and brooding, for more than 11 years, 110,000 square feet of void at the edge of one of this suburban town's most lively areas of small shops, restaurants and movie theaters.
 The two-story building was once a Hahne's department store, and many residents of Montclair and neighboring towns in western Essex County remember going there to shop and then browsing the smaller businesses nearby along South Park and Church Streets a block west of Bloomfield Avenue. 
 "Montclair residents have memories of a really vibrant, active corner," said Helen Mazarakis, executive director of the Montclair Economic Development Corporation. "They remember how people spilled out of Hahne's to the other stores, and they are disappointed that the place has been vacant for so long."
Since Hahne's closed, several plans have been advanced for the empty building, all without success. In the mid-1990's, there was a plan to convert it into a medical mall, with a mixture of medical care, health and fitness and retail tenants. As many as 72 physicians were to be affiliated with the center, with 24 of them in the building full time. 
Like so many other proposals for the site, nothing came of the plan.
Now, frustrated with the lack of progress, township officials have taken action. Unlike more typical instances when the aim of local officials is to stop unwanted development, the township council has declared that the Hahne's site needs to be redeveloped.
That is, the current owners must develop the site or sell it to a developer with an acceptable plan, or the town could seize the property through condemnation.
"The current council is fed up with the lack of progress," said Ed Remsen, a council member. "This current market won't last, and we don't want to wait through another real estate cycle before something happens." He said that town officials had "lost faith" with the owners of the property.
According to people with knowledge of the situation, the property is owned by a group of investors known as Center Montclair Associates. The group includes executives of York Hunter, a construction management company in New York. Kenneth M. Colao, a principal of York Hunter, did not return repeated calls seeking comment.
Planners have identified other sites that might need to be redeveloped, said Terence Reidy, the township manager, but the long delay at the Hahne's property put it at the top of the list.
"The council decided to pull the trigger on this one and said, 'We will do a redevelopment plan,' " Mr. Reidy said. "We are hoping that this will move things forward. But if it does not, it is critical that the town have a way to step in and make it happen."
It is not surprising that Montclair officials are taking steps to force the development of the vacant property, said James W. Hughes, dean of the Edward J. Blaustein School of Planning and Public Policy at Rutgers University.
"An empty building has negative implications on nearby properties, and the site has significant potential," he said. "In general, towns are becoming more proactive in guiding their destiny." Mr. Hughes said a township in the New Brunswick area was working to gain control of a tract of land to preserve open space in opposition to a developer who wants to build. In the Montclair case, town officials are seeking the opposite result, he said, but both are similar actions.
The long delay in development at the Hahne's site has deprived the township of money, Mr. Remsen said. Fully developed, the property would be taxed at about 10 times its current level, which over 11 years has amounted to a substantial amount of lost tax revenue, he said.
Other developers have found the Montclair property attractive and have approached town officials with plans, Mr. Reidy said, including projects that would include retailers on the ground floor with upscale apartments on upper floors. "Over the last three or four years, we have been approached by six or seven developers," he said. He said town officials had referred the prospective developers to Center Montclair Associates, with no results so far.
Several real estate executives close to the situation said the makeup of Central Montclair Associates had made decisionmaking difficult. The investors, they said, are mostly doctors, lawyers and builders, not professional developers, and each has ideas about how to develop the property.
"We have met with them over the years and developed marketing packages for the Hahne's property," said Ms. Mazarakis of the development corporation. Since the township's redevelopment designation, she said, "we have been backing away" because the marketing plans have not worked and the group does not want to get in the way of government action.
Adding to the attraction of the Hahne's site are zoning rules that would allow four floors to be added to the building.
"There is a six-story limit, as long as it stays within density maximums," said Karen Kadus, Montclair's director of planning. 
She said zoning rules required retailers on the first floor, to avoid having a break in the shopping strips to the north and south. "We don't want to have an interruption," she said. "We want people to keep on walking."
Mr. Reidy said there was great demand for apartments in Montclair, which is largely filled with single-family homes. He said a former bowling alley nearby on Bloomfield Avenue, a major thoroughfare in the area, was being developed with retail space on the street level with apartments above.
Although some business people in the area, which is chronically short of parking, have suggested tearing the building down and replacing it with a multilevel parking garage, Ms. Kadus said there was a better solution.
She said the town was interested in developing an existing surface parking lot into a deck as part of the redevelopment of the Hahne's property. "We now require the provision of additional parking as part of the development of the building," she said.
Mr. Remsen, the council member, said the designation of areas in need of redevelopment had been used before in housing, forcing owners to either repair or sell houses that had deteriorated into eyesores. "We must have done 15 to 17 rundown or abandoned houses," he said. "It had a good effect; they were either fixed up or sold."
Mr. Reidy said, "When I came to town in 1994, we had a lot of houses owned by absentee landlords that had been left to go to seed." But the properties were highly attractive to buyers looking to improve them, he said, and the redevelopment designation helped speed up the transactions.
The current redevelopment law has been modified from the days when parts of a city had to be designated "blighted" before urban renewal actions could be taken, Mr. Reidy said.
"In the past, you would condemn a property, pay the owner its fair market value and then try to figure out what to do with it," he said. "Now by the time you finish the planning, you know what to do and have a developer ready to do it."
He said he hoped that the owners of the Hahne's property would work with town officials and said he understood that Center Montclair Associates was meeting with potential buyers and developers.
He said the redevelopment could begin within a year unless the owners resist and go to court. Having stores operating once again in the Hahne's building and people living in the upper floors would provide a lift to retailers in the entire area, he said.
"Church Street is healthy, but not up to its potential," Mr. Reidy said. "Once the Hahne's site is developed, Church Street will explode and spill over to Bloomfield Avenue."

GRAPHIC: Photos: Former Hahne's department store has been sitting empty for more than 11 years in heart of a shopping area. (Keith Meyers/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Streetscapes/75th Street Between Fifth and Madison Avenue; 
Stately Limestone Mansions With a Sense of History

BYLINE:  By CHRISTOPHER GRAY 

 BODY:
THE old limestone mansions of 75th Street between Fifth and Madison Avenue seem a bit less august these days -- some were broken up into apartments decades ago. But the stately mansions' history involves several famous players from New York's past. They include Thomas J. Watson, the chairman of I.B.M. from 1915 to 1956, and Irving Berlin, perhaps the most renowned songwriter in American history.
 The first buildings on the block, put up as developers tested the viability of the area next to Central Park, were row houses built in the 1870's. The neo-Grec-style row house at 19 East 75th, built in 1876, was first occupied by the Rev. R. Heber Newton, a liberal Episcopalian clergyman who endorsed Darwin's theory of evolution. 
 In the 1880's, the street's architecture became richer and more vibrant. Queen Anne-style row houses were built at 13 and 15 East 75th, designed by William E. Mowbray for his father, Anthony Mowbray, a developer.
 The real mansions came in the 1890's, among them the 50-foot-wide 1896 limestone in French Renaissance style at 4 East 75th, designed by Trowbridge, Colt & Livingston for Nathaniel McCready, the president of a shipping firm. McCready hunted boar using dogs from his own kennel in France in the forests near Orleans. 
The 1900 census shows McCready there with his family and seven servants, including three coachmen. The house's current entry hall was originally an open driveway leading to a five-stall stable in the back. The driveway was filled in when Stanley Mortimer, an expert rider and polo player, bought the house in 1919; the bronze gate that appears to be original was designed for him by Carrere & Hastings, who also designed the New York Public Library. 
 In 1904 Stuart Duncan built a large house across the street, at 3 East 75th Street. Duncan's father, John P. Duncan, had made his fortune by importing Lea & Perrin's Worcestershire sauce. After his father's death in 1901, the son concentrated on the family's real estate portfolio -- and had C. P. H. Gilbert, the architect of what is now the Ukrainian Institute of America at 79th and Fifth, design this 50-foot-wide house. 
 Duncan initially took the address 1 East 75th, assuming that whoever ultimately built next door at the Fifth Avenue corner would favor a more prestigious Fifth Avenue address; early photographs of Duncan's house clearly show the "1" above the entrance.
But Duncan didn't reckon with the very reserved Stephen V. Harkness, son of Edward S. Harkness, one of John D. Rockefeller's oil partners. Stephen V. Harkness built a mansion on the corner in 1909 and demanded the less ostentatious 1 East 75th Street address, causing Duncan to get a bronze numeral 3 for his doorway.
 DUNCAN sold 3 East 75th in 1920 to Clarence H. Mackay, head of the Postal Telegraph Cable Company (later ITT), which handled trans-Atlantic communications. Mackay's daughter Ellin was living there in 1924 when she met Irving Berlin and fell in love. 
The Mackay family was Roman Catholic; Berlin was Jewish, and the elder Mackay was concerned about his daughter marrying out of her religion. He tried to delay things by sending her on a European trip. 
But on Jan. 4, 1926, Berlin, whose songs include "God Bless America" and "White Christmas," telephoned Ellin Mackay and proposed immediate marriage. She walked out of 3 East 75th in the clothes she was wearing, took her first subway ride and married Berlin at the Municipal Building.
Their daughter, Mary Ellin Barrett, tells the story of her parents' courtship in "Irving Berlin: A Daughter's Memoir" (Simon & Schuster, 1994). Ms. Barrett mentions that her mother called the 75th Street house from a phone booth immediately after the ceremony. The new Mrs. Berlin first reached the Mackay family nurse, Mary Finnerty; "Finny," Ms. Barrett wrote, simply fainted.
 In 1939, the head of I.B.M., Thomas J. Watson, bought the McCready/Mortimer residence across the street at 4 East 75th Street. 
 In 1954 Watson was interviewed by The New York Times and recalled the 1930's, when, he said, it seemed as if no one else had faith in the country's economic future. "We kept on, found new markets and were ready when business did improve," he said. His obituary in The Times in 1956 noted that he was "often called 'the world's greatest salesman.' " 
Eventually, some of the old houses were cut up into apartments. In 1951, the old row house at 9 East 75th Street was remodeled into apartments with a facade that looks typically plain. But on closer inspection the front door is from the 1840's or earlier, with an equally old brass plaque reading "No. 9." The managing agent, Martin Hollander of Marin Management, said that the 1951 owner had been extremely frugal and apparently often reused old materials, perhaps from other buildings.
Work is under way at two big houses on the block. The old Harkness house at the corner, now occupied by the Commonwealth Fund, is wrapped in netting for facade repairs, and Jean Doumanian, the film producer, is involved in a long, on-again, off-again renovation of the old Watson house.
THE wide Doumanian house is apparently empty except for occasional workers. "They've apparently gutted the interior, but lately they're in, they're out, you see trucks there, and then they're gone, and you don't see anyone again for weeks," said Vito Tricarico, an architect who lives in an apartment in the old Duncan/Mackay house across the street, which was broken up in 1941. Ms. Doumanian, who bought her house in 1987, declined to discuss the project.
 There are other buildings on the block that are empty, among them the partly renovated 10 East 75th Street, which is for sale, and others that merely appear empty. One that other residents on the block point to is the Queen Anne-style house at 15 East 75th Street. 
"No, it's occupied," said Ramon Garcia, who added that he had been the architect for a top-to-bottom restoration there that was finished last summer. The building's original yellowish stone and deep red brick, cleaned of paint, now shine amid the other buildings' more sober coloring. 
 Richard Steinberg, a managing director at Ashforth-Warburg, is the exclusive broker for 10 East 75th Street, which is for sale for $10.5 million. Mr. Steinberg estimated that it would take $3 million more to complete the renovation, which was left unfinished because of the owners' divorce.
He said he thinks that 75th and 73rd Streets are the two prettiest blocks on the Upper East Side, in part because they have so much limestone.
Mr. Steinberg noted that most of the houses on 75th are more than 20 feet wide. "In real estate terms," he said, "20 feet is the dividing line between houses and mansions."

CORRECTION-DATE: April 8, 2001

 CORRECTION:
The Streetscapes column on March 25, about 75th Street between Fifth and Madison Avenues, misidentified the man who built the mansion at 1 East 75th in 1909. It was Edward S. Harkness, not Stephen V. Harkness. The article also misstated the relationship between the two men and misstated which of them was a partner of John D. Rockefeller. The Rockefeller partner was Stephen Harkness, who was Edward's father, not his son.

HEADLINE: THE CENSUS; 
Fast-Growing, Fast-Changing

BYLINE:  By DAVID W. CHEN 

 BODY:
WHEN the 2000 census figures for New York State were released two weeks ago, the numerical snapshot of Westchester County was not, at first glance, all that surprising to anyone who has lived or worked in the area: while the county's population grew at only a modest rate, it has become more ethnically diverse.
 What was surprising, though, was that the number of Hispanics exceeded the estimate anticipated by demographers for the 2010 census. 
 That statistical revelation captured the essence of what one could glean from the county's first batch of census data. While most projections were fairly accurate, and major themes were readily identifiable, there were enough surprises and details to provide a crisper portrait of a county that has changed markedly in 10 years. 
Among the inferences drawn by sociologists, for instance, is the notion that Interstate 287 has become, with some exceptions, even more of a Mason-Dixon line between an increasingly diverse and densely populated south and a whiter, sparser north.
But the most noteworthy change, demographers and planners say, is that Westchester has become more heterogenous, and the pace of change seems to be accelerating. 
And spearheading that change, demographers say, are Hispanic immigrants who are turning many neighborhoods into ethnic enclaves, as evidenced by the 56 percent increase in the Hispanic population in the 1990's. That figure easily outpaced the state average of 26 percent.
Such influxes "used to take much more time, whether it was Russian Jews or Poles or Italians," said Gregory Holtz, research director at the Michaelian Institute for Public Policy and Management at Pace University in White Plains. "But the change has gone into turbo process, and the new immigrants get to Westchester and the suburbs much faster than they did before."
Overall, Westchester grew to 923,459 residents, from 890,635, an increase of 3.7 percent. The total was above the estimate of 906,000, said Michael Lipkin, associate planner with the County Department of Planning. But the pace was slower than that registered by New York City (6 percent) and some of the outer-ring suburbs, like Putnam (13.1 percent), Orange (10.2 percent) and Dutchess (7.2 percent) Counties.
In fact, Westchester would have recorded a net loss had it not been for the influx of immigrants, Mr. Lipkin said. In the last decade, 58,000 more people left the county than settled from other areas of the country. But that deficit was erased largely by new immigrants, and, to a lesser degree, a slight gap between the birth and death rates.
Meanwhile, Westchester's non-Hispanic white population continued to dwindle compared with other racial groups. In 1990, whites made up 72 percent of the county's population; this time, with whites declining by 50,000, the figure was 64 percent.
The black population climbed 4.5 percent, while the proportion of blacks in Westchester inched up to 13.8 from 13.6 percent. Westchester's Asian population increased 37 percent; that proportion now stands at 4.8 percent, up from 3.6 percent 10 years ago.
The figures used by The New York Times reflect a comparison between the 2000 census and data from the 1990 census that had been adjusted to reflect the undercount in that census. Others, including New York State officials, have compared the 2000 figures with unadjusted data from 1990.
But regardless of whether one uses adjusted or unadjusted figures, it is clear from the 2000 census that Hispanics are now the biggest minority group in Westchester, outnumbering blacks for the first time.
As a share of the population, Westchester's population of Hispanics increased to 15.6 from 10.4 percent. In raw numbers, the number of Hispanics increased to 144,124 from 92,150 -- surpassing the county's estimate of 110,000 for 2000, as well as the 2010 estimate of 140,000, Mr. Lipkin said.
And the places with the highest proportion of Hispanics, according to the census, were Port Chester (46 percent), Sleepy Hollow (45 percent) and Ossining (28 percent). All registered gains in the 1990's.
But for sheer explosive growth in the lower Hudson Valley, nothing in Westchester could approach the gains notched by the village of Brewster in Putnam County: while the overall population grew by 36 percent, the Hispanic population jumped 345 percent, resulting in an increase to 32 from 9.8 percent in the proportion of Hispanics.
On the other end of the spectrum, the least diverse places in Westchester included Bedford, which was 95 percent white, and Buchanan, which was 94 percent white.
One trend that appeared to emerge in Westchester, as well as in other parts of the metropolitan New York area, was that the Hispanic population became more segregated between 1990 and 2000, said John R. Logan, a sociologist at the State University of New York at Albany.
He found that the average Hispanic in Westchester was likely to live in a census tract that was 22 percent Hispanic in 1990. But in 2000, that figure jumped to 35 percent -- suggesting that Hispanics, particularly new immigrants, often settle in existing ethnic enclaves, Professor Logan said.
Geographic segregation between northern and southern Westchester was another theme, several analysts said. While the south became more culturally diverse and urban, the north, with its anti-sprawl attitude and zoning restrictions, did not change as much, said John Howard, a professor at Purchase College.
In fact, 10.3 percent of Westchester's population occupied 41 percent of the county's area in Pound Ridge, North Salem, Lewisboro, Yorktown, Somers and Bedford, said George Raymond, chairman of the Westchester Housing Opportunity Commission.
In the south, meanwhile, Westchester's cities more than held their own as New York City's population climbed and those of upstate cities like Buffalo and Syracuse dropped. Yonkers, the state's fourth largest city, grew 2 percent and now trails Rochester, No. 3, by only 25,000 residents.
With Rochester losing 8.4 percent of its population in the 2000 census, and the upstate economy still in a major slump, the possibility exists that by the next census, Yonkers may overtake Rochester.
