HEADLINE: A Downtown Flagship Strikes Its Colors 

BYLINE:  By DAVID W. DUNLAP 

 BODY:
BY way of settling into his new apartment at 45 Wall Street a month ago, Fu-Shing Wu, a financial analyst from Washington, introduced himself to the woman next door as her new neighbor.
 "Not for very long," she replied. "Haven't you heard? The building has been sold." As Mr. Wu put it, "She was like, hello and goodbye." 
 Although the Web site for 45 Wall Street still said last week that it is "destined to become the new standard for 21st century living," reality suggests that its destiny may be as the shortest-lived large-scale apartment development in New York history, with only four years elapsed from conversion to condemnation. 
In January, the Rockrose Development Corporation, which converted the 28-story office tower into 435 rental apartments in 1997, reached an agreement with city and state officials to sell the building.
The Rockrose property, bounded by Wall Street, William Street and Exchange Place, was the first piece nailed down in the assemblage of the full block across Broad Street from the New York Stock Exchange.
On this site, the city and state plan a 50,000-square-foot trading floor for the stock exchange, topped by a 1.3 million-square-foot office tower.
One of the things that makes the story of 45 Wall Street noteworthy is that the building was so recently a keystone of the Giuliani administration's plan to repopulate Lower Manhattan. And it is already scheduled for demolition.
Rockrose has told tenants that impending condemnation of the building by the Empire State Development Corporation "will necessitate that you vacate your apartment." The city has offered relocation assistance from $8,000 to $17,000 an apartment, depending on the size of the unit and number of occupants.
While the notice was not an outright eviction, it said that expiring leases would not be renewed except for rent-stabilized tenants and that even these would no longer be protected once the property was formally condemned by the state. Moreover, Rockrose said, some financial assistance "might not be available if you do not act promptly to relocate prior to June 30, 2001."
"You may, therefore, find it worthwhile to move now," the notice said.
That has left tenants perplexed, edgy and angry. "What's the rush to empty the building?" asked Ray Fleischhacker, vice president of the 45 Wall Street Tenants' Association, which represents about 100 families. "People are moving and giving up rights they don't know they have for a paltry amount of money that's fully taxable." He and his companion Alexandra Fisher, the co-president of the association, have petitioned the Appellate Division of State Supreme Court to annul the Empire State Development Corporation's determination that a public purpose would be served by condemning 45 Wall Street. They note that the full block has not been assembled, that no developer has been designated and that there is ample space nearby in existing office towers. They also question the commitment of the stock exchange to the project.
Several related motions are pending before the court now, Ms. Fisher said.
Whatever happens, the 900 or so residents of 45 Wall Street are not going to end up homeless. It is probably safe to say that many, if not most, would have moved on in a few years anyway. But it is also true that they are likely to pay more rent for less space and fewer amenities.
The Alliance for Downtown New York is torn between unalloyed support for the stock exchange project and its longstanding goal of attracting residents downtown. "This is a tough situation for us," said its president, Carl Weisbrod. "In the final analysis, though, the New York Stock Exchange is a unique institution that defines 'Wall Street' to the city, the nation and the world."
Michael G. Carey, president of the city Economic Development Corporation, acknowledged that 45 Wall Street played a role in the Lower Manhattan plan. "But now we're at a different stage," he said, and the stock exchange is a "very significant financial engine for the city and state."
HAVING agreed to buy 45 Wall Street from Rockrose, reportedly for $160 million, officials next reached an agreement to buy 23 Wall Street and 15 Broad Street from J. P. Morgan Chase & Company. The middle of the block, 37 Wall Street, is controlled by the Wilf family. Mr. Carey said it would be condemned.
Except for the facade of the landmark J. P. Morgan & Company Building at 23 Wall Street, everything on the block -- 45 Wall Street included -- is to be razed. Demolition is to begin late this year or early next year.
No developer has been designated yet for the project, which is expected to involve more than $1 billion in government subsidies, including land acquisition, but Mr. Carey said it was still early in the process.
It is not too early to begin emptying 45 Wall Street, however. "The program we're undertaking now is a voluntary program," Mr. Carey said. "What we've tried to do in anticipation of condemnation is assist with the relocation of as many tenants as possible. People don't have to get out by June 30."
About 100 tenants have already taken advantage of the relocation program, Mr. Carey said. "That goes to the fact that it is a very fair -- indeed, generous -- offer."
Not in the eyes of Doug Sheinberg, one of the original tenants. He deals in computer software. His wife, Lesley, is a commercial real estate broker. They have a 21-month-old daughter, Carson. They pay $1,850 a month for a rent-stabilized 900-square-foot apartment. "For me to get the same apartment is going to cost $800 to $1,000 more a month," Mr. Sheinberg said. "I'm not sure I can afford to live in the city."
"We're not looking to make money," he said. "We're just looking to ease out without taking a hit." That, he said, would mean relocation assistance of at least $30,000.
One of Carson's playmates, 34-month-old Caleb Berger, was probably the first newborn to arrive at Wall and William Streets in 160 years. His parents, Linda and Robert Berger, imagined they would leave 45 Wall Street eventually. "But we wouldn't have chosen this moment," Ms. Berger said.
The Bergers moved in 1998 from Murray Hill into a 2,000-square-foot apartment for which they paid $3,600 a month. "We decided to come downtown because we thought we could get more apartment for the money," Ms. Berger said. With a child on the way, they were also attracted to the riverfront parks at Battery Park City.
"It's very unsettling not to know what you're going to be doing three months from now," said Ms. Berger, who works for the federal government and walks to her office.
"We carpeted the whole apartment, painted it, put in floor moldings," Ms. Berger said. "And, lo and behold, we get a notice that we can't live here anymore."
Although Rockrose gets little sympathy from tenants, the transaction was not easy for the company, run by the Elghanayan family, which is known for holding its properties over the long run.
"We're not contesting it; it's by agreement, but it is a condemnation," said Sofia Estevez, vice president of residential marketing. "We don't ever sell a building."
"It's heartbreaking for us," she said, "because 45 Wall Street is our flagship building downtown. This is the most extravagant amenity package we've ever done."
Rockrose bought 45 Wall Street in 1996 from the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company, which developed it in 1959 as the Atlantic Building. Designed by Voorhees, Walker, Smith, Smith & Haines, it was one of the last wedding-cake-shaped towers.
Met Life had to persuade the U.S. Trust Corporation at 45 Wall Street and the Atlantic Mutual Companies at No. 49 to merge their headquarters under one roof, said Cornelius E. Golding, senior vice president of the Atlantic. To satisfy corporate egos, the new building was given the Atlantic name but the U.S. Trust street number. (This was a day when addresses were often commonly understood shorthand for businesses.)
U.S. Trust remained in the Atlantic Building until 1989. The Atlantic moved employees out in the 1970's and 80's but kept one floor as its executive office until 1995.
In July 1996, a year after Atlantic vacated entirely, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani took a sledgehammer to the limestone facade of 45 Wall Street to signal its conversion into an apartment building, a $75 million undertaking by Rockrose and the Whitehall Street Fund of Goldman Sachs & Company.
Zoning rules ordinarily require that an apartment be no more than four times deeper than it is wide, said David Mandl of Meltzer/Mandl, which designed the renovation. By designating the deep interior spaces as home offices, however, and ventilating those spaces mechanically, the builders created some units 12 by 70 feet.
The architects removed panels of limestone between the small windows, yielding wider bays. Rockrose built a fitness center and wood-paneled club room at the top of the building, added an underground parking garage and installed a distinctive marquee.
To qualify for real estate tax incentives under the 421-g program, Rockrose developed the building subject to rent stabilization, although individual apartments were removed from regulation as rents exceeded $2,000. Ms. Estevez said 34 percent of the units are still stabilized.
Leasing began in early 1997 and half the units were snapped up in six weeks.
But the pendulum downtown was moving again. Cater-corner from the Rockrose building, Swig Burris Equities bought 48 Wall Street in 1998 to convert it into apartments. The interest from commercial brokers was so great, however, that it is being renovated as an office building, said Kent M. Swig, a principal in Swig Burris.
In late 1998, the block with 45 Wall Street was publicly identified as a possible stock exchange site. Ms. Estevez said Rockrose was prevented from telling tenants about negotiations under a confidentiality agreement. But the company began adding a rider to leases noting generally that there was a proposal to acquire 45 Wall Street.
News of the stock exchange plans had in any case not reached Paris. So Yasmine Rossi Zoughbi and her husband, Djamal, believed they had found an ideal spot when they arrived at 45 Wall Street in 1999 from the 10th Arrondissement. It was close to the subway, which takes Ms. Zoughbi to her modeling agency in SoHo in 10 minutes, door to door, and was quiet at night.
They pay $2,700 a month for a penthouse unit. "If I could stay here, I would," Ms. Zoughbi said. Though her lease runs until November, she could not afford the intervening months of uncertainty. She looked at 22 River Terrace, a Rockrose building in Battery Park City, but it was too expensive. "Why don't they do an exchange?" Ms. Zoughbi asked. "For the same kind of apartment, we are obliged to pay $500 more."
The Zoughbis will move to a $3,000-a-month apartment on Greenwich Street.
Tamara Beudec despairs of ever again finding 800 square feet for $1,915 a month. She had an architectural practice when she moved into 45 Wall Street and designed custom furniture that could be wheeled around to create a variety of domestic or business layouts. "Some pieces of my furniture are unsellable because they're too big," said Ms. Beudec, who is now embarked on a second career in financial services. "They're meant for that space."
But she said she is even more troubled by how the city encouraged the redevelopment of a building that would be so quickly abandoned. "Why call it planning?" she asked.
WHEN the broker for Mr. Wu, who moved in last month, told him the building might be sold, it sounded to Mr. Wu as if the deal were remote. And when he was given a tour of the building, Mr. Wu said, the Rockrose representative never mentioned the possible sale.
Having dreamed of working on Wall Street, Mr. Wu was delighted to live there, too. It was, he said, icing on the cake.
His may have been one of the last leases executed. Ms. Estevez said that as soon as Rockrose reached agreement to sell the building, renting stopped.
"How could they continue to take tenants?" asked Mr. Fleischhacker, the tenant leader. "What was the purpose, to get every last penny out?" Now, he said, Rockrose is receiving a payment of $1,000 an apartment as an incentive to vacate the building. Ms. Estevez said she could not reply because of the confidentiality agreement.
She did say that next week Rockrose would open a leasing office for its newest project, 200 West 26th Street, exclusively for 45 Wall Street tenants. Meanwhile, residents coming home have seen a pitchman handing out fliers for 88 Greenwich Street, Ms. Fisher said, and have also found fliers and business cards in the lobby for moving companies and relocation specialists.
As of last week, a ticker screen on the www.45wall.com Web site was still saying: "Studio, one, two and three bedrooms available." Elsewhere on the site, visitors were told that "45 Wall Street is geared not just for today but for tomorrow." There was, however, no word about the day after.

HEADLINE: POSTINGS: Among 19 Stores at Crotona Park East; 
Work to Start On Bronx Supermarket

 BODY:
Almost a decade ago residents of the Crotona Park East section of the Bronx had high hopes for a supermarket and retail stores on a 10-acre site that had been an industrial park. Yet because the project involved City Hall, community groups and the private sector, there was no way to get it done quickly. But finally, one week from tomorrow, April 2, groundbreaking is scheduled for a $30.7 million, 134,000-square-foot shopping center at the site, 174th Street and Vyse Avenue. 
 The anchor tenant -- which has signed a 20-year lease and is investing $1 million in construction -- is Pathmark, which is building a 48,500-square-foot supermarket that will also house a bank and pharmacy. The 19 retailers that have committed to the project include Athlete's Foot, Petland Discounts, Blockbuster and Rockaway Bedding. 
 "Close to 80 percent of our space is already leased," said Ralph Porter, president of the Mid-Bronx Desperadoes, a community coalition that has sponsored and developed more than 2,300 housing units in its 25-year existence. The leasing agent for the shopping center is the Hutensky Group of Hartford. The contractor is GR2D, a partnership of R2D, a division of Hutensky, and Gabriel Associates, a local minority-owned real estate developer and general contractor.
The Desperadoes bought the site from New York City's Economic Development Corporation, together with Neighborhood Enhancement and Training Services, a Bronx-based nonprofit group, and the Retail Initiative, a commercial real estate equity fund affiliated with the Local Initiatives Support Corporation, which provides funds to help revitalize inner cities. Besides Pathmark's investment, the financing to cover the $30.7 million consists of an $18.8 million construction loan from the European American Bank and the Bank of New York and grants and loans from community groups, corporations and the federal and city governments. 
Mr. Porter said the new Pathmark would be the first supermarket in Crotona Park East in years, adding that it would be especially welcomed by elderly residents and those who do not own cars or do not drive. As to whether his organization had ever despaired of seeing the supermarket and shopping center materialize, Mr. Porter said no, adding, "We were encouraged by what Frederick Douglass said, 'The struggle continues.' "

CORRECTION-DATE: April 22, 2001

 CORRECTION:
A report in the Postings column on March 25, about the building of a shopping center in the Crotona Park East section of the Bronx, misidentified the general contractor. It is the Discover General Contracting Corporation; GR2D serves as the project manager and adviser for the owners.

HEADLINE: POLITICS AND GOVERNMENT; 
In Jersey City, Girding for a New Era

BYLINE:  By STEVE STRUNSKY 

DATELINE: JERSEY CITY 

 BODY:
When the clock struck 4 p.m., it marked the beginning of the end of the Schundler Era, nearly a decade of unprecedented economic growth and political controversy under Mayor Bret D. Schundler, a conservative Republican in this ethnically diverse and heavily Democratic city.
 It was at that time on March 15 that the deadline had arrived for mayoral candidates in the May 8 municipal election to submit nominating petitions. And by 4:01 p.m. it was apparent that Mayor Schundler -- elected to three consecutive terms -- was officially out of the race. The 43-year-old mayor is seeking the Republican nomination for governor. 
 The passing deadline put to rest speculation that as the underdog in the Republican primary against Acting Governor DiFrancesco, Mr. Schundler would hedge his gubernatorial bet by keeping his mayoral option open. "I guess we're really in it now," said Joe Pascoe, Mr. Schundler's campaign manager."
It was second of two big questions hanging over the mayoral race to be answered in three days. On March 13, State Superior Court Judge Arthur DiIalia ruled that Gerald McCann could seek his former job despite his conviction on federal bank fraud and tax evasion charges that resulted in his removal from office in 1992.
The charges against Mr. McCann, first elected in 1981, involved a failed real estate deal that took place after he lost a re-election bid and left office in 1985, but before he won a second term in 1989. Judge D'Italia ruled that he could run this year because his crimes were unrelated to his public duties. Coincidentally, it was Judge D'Italia who had barred Mr. McCann from running in 1997 because he was still serving the federal equivalent of parole. 
With Mr. McCann definitely in and Mr. Schundler unquestionably out, the race to lead Jersey City's 240,000 residents can begin in earnest. Voters now have six candidates from which to choose: Councilman Robert Cavanaugh; Glenn Cunningham, a former council president and United States marshal; Tom DeGise, the City Council president; Louis Manzo, a former Hudson County freeholder; Mr. McCann; and Kevin Sluka, the city's director of public works. 
All of the candidates are Democrats, although Jersey City holds nonpartisan elections in which candidates run under a campaign slogan but no party banner, and there is no primary. Candidates must receive at least 50 percent of the vote to win; otherwise, a runoff is held.
But even a final list of candidates does not necessarily give the city's 101,000 registered voters a clear choice. Each mayoral hopeful heads his own slate of candidates for the nine-member city council -- six seats for wards A through F, plus three at-large seats -- and 10 people are seeking council seats, for a total of 70 candidates.
It was fitting that the Schundler and McCann questions figured prominently in how the field shook out, since the two were closely associated with the main campaign issue: tax abatements, particularly for projects along the city's waterfront.
Abatements are deals granted by the city that excuse developers from having to pay standard property tax assessments on a particular project for a proscribed period, typically 5, 15, 20 or 30 years. Instead, the developer makes significantly lower payments in lieu of taxes directly to the city. 
Critics of the abatements point out that homeowners do not receive abatements, and therefore big business is essentially being subsidized by the average homeowner. Proponents dismiss such notions, insisting that the city collects more from the abatements than it would from standard property tax assessments. Furthermore, they contend, projects would not be developed without the abatements, and the city would be left collecting paltry sums on the undeveloped property.
The latest city figures show that 89 properties are receiving tax abatements in fiscal 2001, with payments in lieu of taxes totaling $48 million, up from just $17 million in 1992.
But as shrinking space and ballooning rents in Manhattan have made the Jersey City waterfront increasingly attractive, even people who support abatements in principle have criticized city officials as being unnecessarily generous.
"It's definitely a campaign issue," said Mia Scanga, who helped collect more than 3,000 signatures in an unsuccessful attempt to block an abatement for a proposed 43-story apartment project, Millennium Towers.
The candidates' views on abatements range from unapologetic supporters like Mr. DeGise, who led the city council in approving dozens of them, to critics like Mr. Manzo.
"The No. 1 issue related to Jersey City is the continual giving away of tax abatements to wealthy developers," said Mr. Manzo, a 46-year-old insurance salesman, who ran unsuccessfully in two previous mayoral races. "It's been going on since 1980, and what really ticks me off is that they turn around and roll over abatements."
Mr. Manzo criticized Mr. DeGise's close relationship with Brian Doherty, a lawyer and DeGise fund-raiser who has represented some of the city's biggest developers, including the Lefrak Organization, which developed the 600-acre Newport complex with the help of abatements, the Applied Companies of Hoboken, which just received an abatement for the huge HarborSpire project -- two waterfront apartment towers of 55 and 50 stories each -- and Mack-Cali Realty Corporation of Cranford, which owns the Harborside waterfront office complex, an abatement recipient that houses more than 5,000 jobs. 
No one disputes that developers have long been political contributors. But Mr. DeGise, who makes no secret of his fund-raising appeals to the development community, said he supported abatements because they were good for the city, not to fill his campaign coffers.
"A good deal of the business community is supporting me, and I'm not appologizing for that," Mr. DeGise said.
Other candidates fall somewhere in between. Mr. Cunningham, for example, voted for several waterfront abatements as a councilman in the 80's. But he said the waterfront and the city's economy were much more bleak then. While he still might approve some abatements now, he added, "I think much of our development can take place without those incentives."
Mr. Doherty said the abatement was an emotional issue and easy to exploit, though he said most criticism of the practice was unfounded. The businesses at Newport -- which operate in a mall and other buildings constructed with the help of abatements -- have generated $9 million in special sales tax revenue that go directly to the city, not the state, as part of an Urban Enterprise Zone. 
That money has financed business improvement districts around Central Avenue, Journal Square and Martin Luther King Drive, Mr. Doherty said.
"It's easy to be a demagogue," Mr. Doherty said, attacking what he called Mr. Manzo's hollow criticism of abatements. "The development community is fully vested in Jersey City, and therefore they want to contribute to those candidates who want to continue the development that is beneficial to Jersey City."

CORRECTION-DATE: April 1, 2001

 CORRECTION:
An article last Sunday about the mayoral campaign in Jersey City misspelled the surname of a State Superior Court judge who ruled that former Mayor Gerald McCann could seek re-election despite his conviction on charges of fraud and tax evasion. The judge is Arthur D'Italia, not DiIalia.

HEADLINE: BRIEFING: BUSINESS AND ECONOMY; 
FEBRUARY UNEMPLOYMENT

BYLINE:  AP 

 BODY:
 New Jersey's unemployment rate for February was 3.6 percent, unchanged from the previous month, state labor officials said last week. Last month marked the 14th consecutive month in which the state's rate was below the national rate; nationally, the unemployment rate for February was 4.2 percent. State labor officials also said 4,000 more people were employed last month, leading to a record high seasonally adjusted employment level of 4,033,100.

HEADLINE: Yonkers Should Renew Waterfront Industry 

 BODY:
To the Editor:
 The attempt by Yonkers to revive its waterfront and downtown with luxury housing is an expensive folly ("On the Waterfront, Yonkers Hopes Apartments Along the Hudson Will Start a Revival" March 18). 
 The area where Hudson Park will be built has few amenities and many social problems, but the developers intend to charge Manhattan-level rents for apartments abutting busy train tracks. 
What Yonkers really needs is a commitment to bring back industry. With lower costs and convenient transport, Yonkers could again be a commercial and industrial center providing jobs for its many impoverished residents. 
As a former resident, I just hope that it does not take another 20 years for Yonkers leaders to start making real progress.

GUTHRIE ALBERTS
Brooklyn

HEADLINE: Market Wisdom 

 BODY:
To the Editor:
 The falling economy is presenting great losses in the stock market (Business Day, March 22), but even though I am heavily invested through my retirement plan (as are many Americans), I haven't lost a penny. 
 Why? Because I haven't sold. Proof? I can't claim any loss on my income tax return. 
Buy low, sell high. Have people forgotten this, the only sensible thing ever said about the market? 

LEONARD MALKIN
Detroit, March 22, 2001

HEADLINE: BEHIND THE WHEEL/2001.5 Volkswagen Passat; 
German Engineers Refuse To Leave Well Enough Alone

BYLINE:  By CHERYL JENSEN 

DATELINE: ATLANTA 

 BODY:
WE are passing Bubba's Mountain Road, traveling through a kudzu-draped landscape with 750 miles to go on the kind of marathon journey that can sour your disposition, unless you have the right travel companion. Fortunately, I do -- the 2001.5 Volkswagen Passat. It is even enough to offset driving with my husband.
 We are headed for the Great Smoky Mountains on a trip through the land of "boiled p'nuts," pork barbecue and Dollywood -- all bits of regional Americana on the way home to Cleveland, where we should be able to deliver a trial-by-mileage verdict on the latest Passat. 
 As suggested by its in-between model designation, the Passat has not been completely redesigned. The size, interior space and cargo capacity are all about the same, but there are significant changes: VW made the styling a bit flashier, improved the way the car drives by making the structure stiffer, and gave the base engine, a 1.8-liter turbocharged four cylinder, more power. Depending on model, prices are up $200 to $540.
The base price of the four-cylinder GLS sedan -- the model I drove home from Georgia -- increased by $300, to $22,300 including shipping charges. The GLS wagon with the same engine went up $300, to $23,100. The top-of-the-line GLX sedan with a V-6 engine and 4Motion all-wheel drive is now $32,125, up $540, and the similarly equipped GLX wagon is $32,925. The GLX's now have standard 16-inch tires.
Why does VW call this a 2001.5 model? The answer is complicated, involving dwindling supplies of 2001's, the arrival dates of the new cars and an attempt to take advantage of emissions and economy rules.
The Passat has been an important car for VW. It paved the way for the company's strong re-emergence in the American market in recent years, and it is crucial to VW's plans to reach a more luxury-minded customer. The new Passat is also intended to create a buzz for the W8, an eight-cylinder Passat that is likely to arrive in the second quarter of 2002.
The Passat is also a family sedan with a semi-sporty European feel. Again this year, Consumer Reports ranked it first among family cars.
We left Atlanta on a Thursday afternoon in a front-drive sedan with the 1.8 turbo engine and a five-speed manual transmission. Soon we were on a two-lane road passing a sign that read "Baby Goat Quilts" and abandoned, weathered cabins.
While the steering of the old Passat was quick to respond, this one was even more eager to change direction, especially for a front-drive car. If you want to turn, you don't need to place an order in advance.
The suspension was only tweaked, not redesigned. Already a solid car, the Passat now feels even stiffer, and the driver feels even better connected to the road. That is largely because the body is 10 percent more rigid, said Stefan Krebsfanger, manager of product strategy for VW in North America. Engineers reinforced the body in strategic areas by using thicker sheet metal and adding welds to improve rigidity.
The steering, which used to feel a little too light and busy for a car that would like to be called a European sport sedan, seems improved. It is heavier now, although Mr. Krebsfanger said the basic steering setup wasn't changed. He attributed the difference to the car's 150-pound increase in weight, its wider track and a different tire-rubber formula.
After a night in Bryson City, N.C., and breakfast at Ma Barker's restaurant, we filled the tank with premium 91-octane fuel. (The turbocharger requires it.) Soon we approached Newfound Gap Road, which bisects the Great Smoky Mountains National Park, and a sign that warned: "Steep winding mountain road next 35 miles. Be prepared for severe weather, ice and snow."
Perfect.
While the Passat's V-6 is unchanged, the turbo 4 now has 170 horsepower, up from 150. Maximum torque, or pulling power, which has been increased to 166 foot-pounds, from 155, is available when the engine is turning at any speed from 1,950 to 5,000 r.p.m.
As a result, the engine is wonderfully accommodating. Crossing the park, even in fourth gear on an uphill grade, the engine pulled eagerly as we accelerated after slowing down for a sharp curve.
Side-curtain air bags, designed for head protection, were new for 2001; the only additional safety equipment is a third height-adjustable head restraint for a rear-center passenger.
Leaving the Smokies, we passed through Gatlinburg, Tenn., past Dinosaur Golf, listening to a country-and-western interpretation of how Moses led the Jews out of Egypt, and then through Pigeon Forge. We bypassed Dollywood and a Las Vegas-style entertainment strip offering everything from laser tag to Hill-Billy Village, whose attractions were not immediately clear.
On Interstate 75, we found the Passat to be a comfortable highway cruiser, and even at 80 the rather small turbo engine felt unstressed.
We didn't have to wait for Cleveland to test VW's claims that the improved tires made potholes and tar strips less jarring. As we left Kentucky and entered Cincinnati, Interstate 71 offered a bonanza of potholes. The Passat did a competent job of cushioning us against the harsh reality of Ohio's highways.
But after seven hours on the road the seats were beginning to wear on us. The bottom cushions could definitely be longer; both the 5-foot-6 driver and the 6-foot-4 passenger wanted more thigh support.
VW has improved the cup holders, which are now part of the center console, but not the rachet knob that tilts the seatbacks and that forces you to contort your arm like a chicken wing. It is a nuisance, but a small thing on a vehicle that satisfies on so many more important levels.
The verdict? The new Passat just shows that VW employs a bunch of overachievers who didn't know enough to be content with a first-rate sedan. Danke, y'all.

INSIDE TRACK: A marvelous multitasker.

GRAPHIC: Photos: Volkswagen has freshened its Passat with updated styling, a stiffer body and a more powerful base engine.

HEADLINE: Plasma TV: That New Object Of Desire 

BYLINE:  By RICK MARIN

 BODY:
SOME people's favorite "Hannibal" moment is Anthony Hopkins performing brain salad surgery on Ray Liotta. But the scene I can't get out of my mind is Gary Oldman's invalid Hannibal survivor lying in bed, staring up at a bank of televisions. 
 It wasn't what he was watching -- Bloomberg or CNNfn -- that grabbed me, but how: on half-a-dozen wafer-thin TV screens. I have become obsessed with flat, tube-free TV's, in particular those big, wide plasma screens that until recently cost at least $10,000. Before the movie even started, I confessed my dire case of plasma envy to one of my seat mates, Megan Martin, a 23-year-old aspiring filmmaker. She had no trouble relating. 
 "When I sell my first screenplay, I'm not getting a car," she said. "I want one of those flat screens." 
In the 80's, it would have been a Porsche; in the 90's a BMW -- before they became "Beemers" and schoolteachers started driving them. Now, there's a new status symbol, a new envy object in town. It doesn't have wheels, but it's equally cool, and elusive, for mortal consumers. 
You used to have to sneak into a high-end audiophile boutique to check out a plasma unit. Flat as a stack of pancakes, its two panes of glass are separated by just a few millimeters and filled with hundreds of thousands of tiny neon and xenon gas cells -- they produce the crisp digital image.
But the main attraction is the movie-screen width -- its 16:9 aspect ratio makes the 4:3 proportions of a regular TV set look so, like, square. You see gawping, suspicious browsers walking all the way around these machines looking for the tube or hamster wheels or whatever makes that space-sucking bulge in the back of ordinary TV's. Are the "wall screens" Ray Bradbury promised in "Fahrenheit 451" finally here? Do we start burning books now?
A year or so ago, the plasmas started materializing everywhere -- in gyms, clubs, malls. In a student lounge at New York University. Hanging from the ceiling of the Gap on Fifth Avenue in Midtown. In a show of video art at the Whitney Museum of American Art. There was a Philips ad with a hip couple watching one on their bedroom ceiling. Dangling before us in all these public spaces, plasma technology becomes even more tantalizing. The screens become what the ad people like to call "aspirational" objects of consumer desire. 
"It's the 'wow' factor," said Scott Schurman, who had a Sony plasma installed in the bedroom of his Upper East Side apartment two weeks ago. "Anybody who walks into your apartment and sees one of those TV's is going to say: 'You are cool. You are a better person.' "
Mr. Schurman, 44, is the national accounts manager for Recoton, a high-end audio component company. For professional reasons, he is something of an "early adopter" of consumer electronics. "I bought a Sony DVD player for $1,000 two years ago," he said. "Now, it's $179." He convened a meeting of his co-op board just to show off his plasma TV.
Pioneer, Marantz, Panasonic and NEC, among others, have all gotten into the plasma game. The screens come in two sizes: 42 inches and 50 inches (measured diagonally -- some things never change), and range from three to seven inches deep. Why have prices taken so long to come down? 
Mike Gleason, the national sales manager for Fujitsu General America, blames the technology. "Regular TV's have about a 2 to 3 percent failure rate at the factory," he said. "On plasmas, it's about 60 percent." Fujitsu was able to cut its sticker price in half, he said, partly because of a lower failure rate and weaker yen against the dollar. 
Liquid crystal display flat screens -- the same technology used in some computer screens -- are marginally more affordable. Sharp's 10-inch flip-down TV, popular for mounting under kitchen cabinets, is still $1,299.
About 65 percent of flat-screen sales are to businesses. It has proved an eye-catching marketing device. "You put a regular TV in a mall or a movie theater, and people walk right by it," Mr. Gleason said. "With plasma, the message is secondary. People stop just to look at the monitor."
At the Wiz on Fifth Avenue, I saw a couple of ultra-trendy Japanese teenagers sitting rapt in front of "Gladiator" on a plasma screen. The Apartment, a mod home furnishings store on Crosby Street, has one suspended from the ceiling -- the first thing you notice when you walk in the door. The James Dean Lounge in the Iroquois Hotel on West 44th Street has one over the fireplace. Its general manager, Paul Celnik, "wanted to present people with things they don't have in their own homes," he said.
So, who does have them in their own homes?
"Madonna, Donatella Versace," said Greg Mykietyn, a salesman at the Harvey electronics store in ABC Carpet & Home. Of the 100 or so plasma screens his store has sold in the last year, most went to celebrities and "the very rich," Mr. Mykietyn said. "It has attracted a type that said: 'I want it. I don't really care how much it is.' " He said he recently sold one to Julianne Moore.
Another "Hannibal" connection! Does everyone involved with this movie have one?
Jeffrey Sachs, an investment banker, said he got his 50-inch Pioneer plasma screen for a media room he just built in his apartment in United Nations Plaza. One criticism of the plasma screens is that they don't render black tones. But Mr. Sachs's only complaint was that until the broadcast and cable channels start sending out programs in the 16:9 aspect ratio, the wide screen makes everyone look fat. 
"I don't want to see Jennifer Aniston fat," Mr. Sachs said.
HBO's "The Sopranos," however, is in the wide-screen format this season. That was just one of many reasons that I wanted -- no, needed -- to get a flat screen in my apartment. 
Last week, Fujitsu lowered the price of its 42-inch screen from $15,999 to $9,999. A bargain! Their prices are insane, as Crazy Eddie used to say.
I called Fujitsu and asked if I could "test" one. (A journalist's privilege.) Gravely, I signed an agreement promising to pay a fine of $1,000 a day if I didn't give it back after a week. 
Last Wednesday morning, two Fujitsu technicians showed up to install my loaner: a 42-inch Plasmavision SlimScreen PDS-4222. I had taken a big painting off the wall to make room. They put the screen on top of a long built-in cabinet. If I was buying one, I would have hung it. Fortunately, the Fujitsu comes with a stand. Not so fortunately, the stand has "Plasmavision" written on it in big letters. 
"That's a bit much," my neighbor said when he saw the logo. "We get the idea."
Steven Sclaroff, an interior designer, had told me that most of his clients still want to hide these screens, even though their existing TV cabinets are too deep and have to be reconfigured with false walls. "There's still a tendency to want to put the TV away," he said. 
Are they nuts? My first thought was how perfectly the brushed-metallic frame matched my Harman Kardon stereo and Pioneer turntable. My second thought was, "I should have got the 50-inch." That's how sick I am. 
My third thought, once the technicians turned it on, was, "I'm never giving it back."
The Fujitsu guys, Ryan Flaig and Ringo Serrano, made the necessary connections to my cable box and VCR. I didn't wire the monitor to my speakers because I have a fear of becoming a home-theater geek. I don't want "Emergency!" -- which happened to be on TV Land when the screen turned on -- coming at me at THX volume.
There was a fuzzy line wiggling down the left side of the screen. "Noise from the cable," Mr. Flaig said. He shifted the frame of the picture and made it disappear. "A lot of customers get the TV and complain the picture's bad. But it's the cable."
An audio cable was missing, so I went to the Wiz to buy one. I also loaded up on DVD's. "Ben-Hur" (just out). "Gladiator." "Scarface." Because I have no DVD player in my apartment, I hooked up the one in my laptop. Now I could not only write about this personal Jumbotron, I could write on it.
I've seen "Ben-Hur" a dozen times, but not since my parents got a color TV has my world been so changed. I kept the Fujitsu on all afternoon. New York 1's Pat Kiernan never looked so good. That night, I invited a friend over for a flat-screening of "Apocalypse Now" on DVD. We cooked up "a little rice and rat meat" (as Martin Sheen's Captain Willard says) and hunkered down in front of a TV screen big enough for Marlon Brando.
"The horror, the horror," I croaked at the realization that I was soon going to have to go back to watching my 27-inch JVC, purchased in 1987. I needed my own plasma. But the cost -- how could I justify it?
Richard Mishaan, an interior designer, gave me an idea. He had put two Philips plasma screens in his section of the Kips Bay show house last year. (Philips sponsored the house.) He also has a Sony in his store, Homer, on Madison Avenue.
"A comparable television set was like four feet deep and costs $5,000," he said. "If you calculate the cost of real estate in New York and divide that by four feet . . . ."
Where's my calculator? My apartment is probably worth $500 a square foot. With a flat TV on the wall, I could get rid of my TV and reclaim enough space for another chair, another ottoman even. That's about 16 square feet.
That's $8,000 worth of real estate! The new Sony PFM-42B1 SuperTheater plasma lists for $7,999. 
I told another neighbor about my exciting calculations. If I got a Sony, I'd actually be saving $1.
"That's the kind of thinking that got us into this recession," he said.

HEADLINE: PORTFOLIOS, ETC.; 
Waiting for the Other Shoe to Drop on a Sagging Economy

BYLINE:  By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER 

 BODY:
CAN it get worse?
 That is the question for investors who have agonized through two of the toughest weeks in recent stock market history. The 10.7 percent decline in the Dow Jones industrial average since March 16, which pushed it briefly into bear-market territory on Thursday and Friday, was the worst two-week plunge since the 1987 crash. 
 Although the market rebounded on Friday, the answer is still yes, it can get worse. That is because corporate profits have borne the brunt of the economic downturn so far. But if the economy does not show signs of stabilizing or rebounding quickly, then the burden will shift to workers, who will be laid off as companies seek to cut costs. Incomes will fall, consumer spending will slow and the economy will sink further. That would leave stocks, at best, treading water. 
That is the prospect being described by economists who have predicted that this slump will become a recession. They are still in the minority and have not been looking prescient lately, with job growth stronger than expected in February and the housing sector holding up. But they warn that the other shoe has yet to drop.
As the economy slowed at the end of last year, many employers were reluctant to discharge workers who had been so difficult to find and keep in the first place. This is one reason that the unemployment rate, at 4.2 percent in February, is still so low.
Avoiding layoffs as production slowed cut into productivity, which grew at a 2.2 percent annual rate in the fourth quarter, down from 8 percent a year earlier. So the price of the downturn was reduced productivity growth, which raised costs and sent earnings into their own recession.
That decline has already devastated the stock market. Currently, earnings for the companies in the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index are forecast by Wall Street analysts to fall 7.2 percent in the first quarter of this year, compared with a year ago, and 5.2 percent in the second quarter, according to Thomson Financial/First Call. The outlook for the third quarter is still positive, at 2.7 percent, but slipping, while the fourth-quarter forecast of 13.8 percent seems to apply to another planet.
Only time will tell if the second shoe will fall. But the growing list of layoffs shows that companies are unwilling to live much longer with plunging earnings. Last week, Procter & Gamble said it would cut 9 percent of its work force. John T. Chambers, the chief executive of Cisco Systems, said a week and a half ago that his company was having a hard time reducing its production costs and warned investors to cut their estimates for the company's profit margins. And that was after announcing that Cisco was reducing its work force by 11 percent.
There are also signs that getting out of this mess will take more time and effort than expected.
While many economists still do not see a recession, they have given up on a quick recovery. And the Federal Reserve, which made its third half-percentage-point rate cut of the year last Tuesday, has not gone far enough yet, especially in the eyes of the stock market, which plunged after the announcement.
Bruce Steinberg, chief economist at Merrill Lynch, now says the Fed will cut its benchmark short-term interest rate, now 5 percent, to 4 percent, instead of the 4.5 percent he previously forecast.
Despite all the pessimism, the Fed does seem bent on turning around the economy, which is good for stocks in the long run.
But after the plunge into a bear market, it will be harder to convince investors that the future looks bright. They need to be confident that the Fed has cut interest rates enough to rescue the economy. And despite the fastest rate cuts ever under Alan Greenspan, the Fed chairman, we are not there yet.
Some important corporate executives, like Mr. Chambers, will also have to be able to announce that they are doing better than expected after months of acknowledging that sales and profits were falling short of expectations. 
But with the first-quarter confession season swinging into high gear in the next three weeks and earnings forecasts still declining, it's too soon to hope for that.

HEADLINE: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: KINGSBRIDGE HEIGHTS; 
Saying the Road Is Hard, Dominican 'Taxistas' Seek Unity

BYLINE:  By SETH KUGEL 

 BODY:
The organizers of the meeting had hoped for 50 livery-cab drivers, but only about a dozen showed up. One driver had an explanation.
 "Time is gold," said Francisco Taveras, using the Spanish version of the common saying, "and there's no group that saying applies to better than a taxista. When his car is empty, he wants it full, and when it's full, he wants it empty." 
 That comment brought a laugh from the drivers who gathered recently at the Bailey Radio Dispatcher base in Kingsbridge Heights to meet with organizers from the Coalition of Progressive Dominicans. The purpose was to discuss the problems faced by livery drivers, many of whom are Dominican. The coalition hopes to unite Dominicans from different sectors of the economy: teachers, lawyers, factory workers, cabdrivers. This was the first meeting dedicated to a single occupation.
Hilario Amparo, driver No. 102 at Bailey and a founding member of the coalition, started the meeting with a litany of complaints about high insurance rates, lack of Dominicans in government, and frequent summonses from the police and the Taxi and Limousine Commission.
"They never give us a break," Mr. Amparo said in Spanish, the language used during the meeting. "Not even if we're on a one-way street, picking up a call, and we double-park as we wait for the passenger. The police make us move, and if we don't, they give us a ticket. It's impossible." 
One driver, Julian Taveras, said lack of English was an obstacle. "We don't know how to express ourselves, so we get a ticket," he said. "Why? Because we didn't know how to defend ourselves, even if there's some silly reason for what you've done that you could have explained."
Rafael Pasian and Emiliano Perez, public school teachers and founding members of the coalition, told the drivers that the coalition would provide free English classes, perhaps at livery bases in Upper Manhattan and the Bronx.
Of 40,000 livery-cab drivers in New York, three-quarters are Latino, and three-quarters of those are Dominican, said Fernando Mateo, president of the New York State Federation of Taxi Drivers, a trade group.
In some ways, the goals of Mr. Mateo's organization, which was formed in 1998, overlap with those of the coalition. The taxi group has signed up thousands of members, lobbied public officials, secured discount health insurance and opened walk-in help centers for drivers.
But the coalition is focused on uniting Dominicans. After the meeting, Mr. Pasian said his group's top priority was to find a place to hold meetings. "The community center will be the unifying force that brings all the elements together," he said. SETH KUGEL

GRAPHIC: Photo: Hilario Amparo is part of a group trying to organize Dominican livery cab drivers. (Richard Perry/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: A Poet, Barred at the Gate 

BYLINE:  By TARA BAHRAMPOUR 

 BODY:
SHE is only 23 years old, although her passport says she is 26. She looks more like a tomboyish model than a national literary figure.
 But when the Eritrean poet Saba Kidane steps up to the microphone, she quiets the crowd with a flash of a smile and a single word. 
 Draped in a loose white robe, she doesn't read so much as sing.
Please fly my hello to the black and white Africans
Her English is heavily accented, but it flows like water.
Please float my hello to the African lake
Please fly my hello to those suffering from the unconscionable others.
The rest is in her native Tigrinya, laced with glottal stops and flattened vowels. Even those who don't know the language are drawn in; by the rise of her voice and the sway of her hips as the words dance from her mouth. But for those who understand her words, the effect is even more entrancing.
"She speaks about the condition of women in Eritrea, particularly women who are survivors of the war with Ethiopia," said Prof. Ngugi wa Thiong'o, a Kenyan novelist who teaches comparative literature and performance studies at New York University. He first saw Ms. Kidane perform last year at a pan-African literature conference in Eritrea. He doesn't speak Tigrinya, but he saw the effect she had. "There's humor there. I saw some women laughing. But I also saw some women crying."
Like many accomplished performers from distant lands, Ms. Kidane (pronounced ki-DAH-ne) is unknown to most Americans, but among her compatriots in the expat community here, she is a star. 
"She's very smart and interesting," said Amanuel Tekeste, a longtime New York resident who owns an Eritrean restaurant called Massawa in Morningside Heights. "My wife is very interested in her."
His sister, Freweini Tekeste, a waitress at the restaurant, speaks little English, but at the mention of Ms. Kidane's name, her face lit up and she began chattering in rapid Tigrinya. "I know her work," she said. "She is famous. I love her!"
Many in Eritrea have long known about Ms. Kidane, a single mother who was a program director for youth radio and is now working on starting a youth newspaper. But it was at the conference, in January 2000, that outsiders got their first glimpse of the limpid-eyed poet with the voice like a bell.
At the conference in Eritrea, after Professor wa Thiong'o, his wife and their grown daughter spent a few days with Ms. Kidane, he announced that he was informally adopting her, an honor that raised her recognition in the world of African literature. 
Bob Holman, a poet and professor of writing at Bard College in Annandale, N.Y., also attended the conference.
"Nobody had introduced her to me, she wasn't on any of the panels, and here she steps up to the stage and takes control like a diva," he recalled. "She blew the house down."
After Mr. Holman invited Ms. Kidane to perform in the United States at the People's Poetry Gathering, a five-day poetry festival in New York that begins Wednesday, Bard College and Yale University invited her to speak. The festival, sponsored by three New York organizations -- City Lore, an urban folklore center; Poets House, a poetry library; and Arts International, a nonprofit cultural exchange organization -- includes a segment on Eritrea in which Ms. Kidane would share the stage with Reesom Haile, her country's poet laureate, and Ararat Iyob, an Eritrean poet who lives in Washington. 
But last month, when she applied for a visitor's visa at the United States Embassy in Asmara, Eritrea's capital, Ms. Kidane found that not all Americans are so welcoming. As a young woman from a struggling third world country, she looked like a risky bet to the official who interviewed her. It didn't matter that she had invitations from five American institutions, that she was leaving behind her 3-year-old daughter, or that Mr. Haile had easily procured a visa for the festival. Rather than fitting the embassy's usual profile of a visiting artist, Ms. Kidane looked like someone who sought to enter the United States to stay.
"It's cynical and patronizing," Mr. Holman said. "They assume everyone in the world wants to live in the States. And they look at her being a child as being a reason for her wanting to get out rather than a reason for her wanting to go home."

Hard Times In the Horn of Africa
No one can deny that Eritrea is a poor country. A sliver of land on the Red Sea coast hugging the northern edge of Africa's horn, until the 1940's it was a colony of Italy, which bestowed it with palazzi and pasta but left it with a thirst for independence. That desire was severely challenged during a bloody, three-decade war to gain independence from neighboring Ethiopia that ended in 1991, only to start again in 1998. The violence ended last year. Ethiopian troops began withdrawing this year. 
Today Eritrea is a young democracy that tolerates more freedom than many of its neighbors. The government supports polyglot education, environmentalism and women's rights. But while Eritrea has a population of four million, more than a million fled the country during the long years of war and poverty. 
According to Kelit Alazar, an Eritrean-born engineer who moved to New York in 1972, most Eritreans in the United States never dreamed of emigrating here. But over the years, several thousand have settled in the New York area, many moving to Parkchester in the Bronx or to southwest Harlem. Some are doctors or engineers. Others drive taxis or work in hotels.
On a recent night, in a dimly lighted room in the headquarters of the Eritrean Community Center on West 125th Street near Broadway, rows of long tables were packed with people. Children scampered about chattering in English as adults used the spongy white bread known as injera to scoop mouthfuls of beef and lentils from large metal platters. Men gathered around the bar conversing in one or another of Eritrea's nine official languages, while an older woman wearing a gauzy white shawl bantered with friends in Italian, remembered from colonial days. 
Mr. Alazar helped start the center in 1985. Like other community centers aimed at certain groups of immigrants, it helps newcomers integrate and keeps younger generations connected with the old country. But the transition is often difficult. As years turn into decades, he said, "We're physically here, but mentally, everything is back home."
On this particular night, on a stage decorated with balloons and streamers, community leaders made speeches honoring Eritrea's National Women's Day and touted the participation of women in Eritrean public and professional life. Mr. Holman, wrapped in a white shawl, took the microphone and spoke of the coming festival and of the efforts to bring Ms. Kidane to the United States. Thanks to the Internet, Ms. Kidane's work is widely distributed among the Eritrean diaspora, and listeners cheered at the mention of her name.
"If she came, we'd have an event for her at the center," Mr. Alazar said. "It would be fantastic. We would have a full house." 
In the past, visiting musicians from Eritrea have been a hit among young people, many of whom have never seen their parents' country. "When they come live, people are dying to see them," Mr. Alazar said.
He added that Ms. Kidane would be popular with the new generation. "She's young," he said, "and young people like young people. It would be an incentive for some of them to go back home and take a look."
Ms. Tekeste, who was attending the festivities, rose from a chair and limped to a neighboring table. A recent arrival to the United States, she had fought for 16 years in an army in which women played an essential role. After artillery fire destroyed her hip, she came to this country to seek medical treatment, but doctors told her further surgery might result in paralysis. 
For Ms. Tekeste, Saba Kidane's poetry speaks directly to her experiences in the field. "I feel I'm part of the same front as Saba," said Ms. Tekeste, whose younger sister died in combat. "I feel very much connected to her."
If Ms. Kidane were older, she too might be hobbled by war injuries. In 1991, at 13, she dropped out of school, pushed her birth date back three years and joined the army. She trained to be a soldier and made it to the front. If the war had not halted that year, she would have seen combat.
According to Charles Cantalupo, a professor of English and comparative literature at Pennsylvania State University who specializes in African literatures, the idea of Ms. Kidane's trading in her Kalashnikov for a pen makes sense, because much of Eritrea's recent art originated in the trenches. 
"Many writers and artists attended the university of struggle and revolution," Dr. Cantalupo said. "The war was a cultural education, and many of the fighters were writers. Look for the brightest thinkers; they were on the field."
Well before the war, poetry played an integral role in Eritrea. The art form is even woven into the local currency. The five-nakfa bill, as common a denomination there as the $1 bill is in the United States, features an ancient sycamore tree whose branches spread like a wide umbrella over the ground. Like certain sycamore trees across Eritrea, this one, near the town of Segheneyti, has for centuries drawn local poets to perform there. 
"Ours is an oral society," said Kassahun Checole, publisher of Africa World Press, a publishing company in Lawrenceville, N.J. Although Eritrea has one of the world's oldest written languages, known as Geez, it is used mostly for liturgical purposes, he said. "By and large, most people record history, play songs and pass it down orally. And these people are very poetic. When they tell a story, they tell it in a very attractive and musical way."

A Young Medium With an Ancient Message
Saba Kidane's voice was quick and light as she discussed the poetry she began writing in 1995, upon returning to school after the war.
"It's about nature, social strife, spiritualism, love, silence, sadness, madness," she said in a recent telephone conversation from Asmara. "Always, the poetry just comes to me. I'm just a medium."
Women in Eritrea have long been bards. In one tradition, women gather around a newborn baby and compose poems for its mother. But their participation in the male-dominated worlds of government, the professions and public performance is a new phenomenon, a result of the war. 
"Traditionally, women sat in the background and didn't say much," said Mr. Checole, the publisher. "But in a 30-year war, everyone had to participate. Women made up over 30 percent of the fighting force."
Ms. Kidane, born well into the war, has inherited her country's new, more egalitarian mind-set. Through her radio work she has pushed for social change and has called for education to stem the AIDS epidemic that has seared the continent. "She has a very independent feminist perspective," Mr. Checole said. "In a male society, she stands up and speaks her mind on issues. 
"She is very hopeful for the country," he added. "Young people are very engaged in what is going on right now, and she represents that engagement."
The fact that most of her poems are in Tigrinya is seen as a sign of her commitment to her country. "There's no question of her wanting to write in English," Professor wa Thiong'o said. "A person of her age in a different country would aspire to become an English-language poet, but she is proud to write in her own language." 
Such national pride is common in Eritrea, Dr. Cantalupo said, adding that young Eritreans today are "profoundly committed to the national experiment." 
"It's a wonderful liberating moment for them to express themselves," he said. 
In that context, Ms. Kidane said, she would have no reason to leave Eritrea, where she is known and loved by so many. "Now that people have accepted me in their hearts," she said, "I'm not about to leave all that."

Back to Try Again, But the Embassy Is Adamant
Back in New York, Ms. Kidane's supporters felt confident that if the embassy officials who interviewed her could hear about her commitment to Eritrea and her place in its literary community, they would reconsider their decision to deny her a visa. So on March 13, after Representative Jerrold Nadler and the five groups who invited her had sent letters of support to the embassy, Ms. Kidane returned for a second try. She brought a letter of support from the Eritrean Ministry of Foreign Affairs, as well as proof that she had obtained a license to start her newspaper.
"We had so much compelling evidence," said Steve Zeitlin, City Lore's executive director. "We did not think it was humanly possible for them to deny this."
But Maureen Monetta, the consular officer who had heard the case the first time, had the same answer when Ms. Kidane made a return visit: no.
"She said, 'I'm surprised you came a second time,' " Ms. Kidane said later that day. "Even though I had brought these letters, she said, 'You don't fit the profile of the kind of person we want to let in.' " As Ms. Kidane recalled, Ms. Monetta simply handed back the thick packet of support letters and sent her home.
In an e-mail to Mr. Zeitlin sent the same day, Ms. Monetta encouraged him to replace Ms. Kidane on the roster. "If you would like to consider someone else from here," she wrote, "the requirements would be someone who has family, social and economical ties here. (Someone in the mid-40's, with business ties, a home and a family.)" 
Festival promoters say the stereotype of a poet as a middle-aged professional with a large family is exactly what they are trying to challenge. But embassy statistics do not help their case. "Our return rate for young people her age is about 5 percent," Ms. Monetta wrote in the e-mail to Mr. Zeitlin. "While I regret that this is a one-time shot for spotlighting Eritrea, I cannot help you with her application."
The following day, speaking by telephone to a reporter, Ms. Monetta repeated the statistic. "She is certainly very up and coming," she said of Ms. Kidane. "She is also very young, and frankly, her ties to Eritrea just aren't strong enough." 
Ms. Kidane said she had not planned to travel anywhere, and accepted the invitation only because it would give her an opportunity to do what she loved and would be a continuation of her work at home. "It would have been wonderful, I'm not able to articulate it," she said. "And the exposure would have helped me in Eritrea too." 
William Clarke, the United States ambassador in Eritrea, declined to be interviewed for this article, but the embassy press officer, Collette Christian, wrote in an e-mail that one reason for the strict visa policy was the responsibility of the United States to avoid causing "brain drain," the exodus of the brightest minds from developing countries that have seen political and economic instability. The embassy, she wrote, is trying "to protect Eritrea from developing a nation with a high rate of nonreturn, precisely by screening applicants to ensure that they meet the guidelines."
After Ms. Kidane's second rejection, the poet laureate of the United States, Stanley Kunitz, added a letter of support. And an impassioned petition posted on an Eritrean diaspora Web site has garnered more than 550 signatures from 22 countries, many from Eritreans living in the United States. "Depriving her is depriving all of us Eritreans," wrote one. Another wrote, "Don't they have an idea that some people love their country, family and culture?" A third added, "I'm 12 years of age, so I'd like to know about my home country." 
But as the festival approached, hopes dimmed. To attend, Ms. Kidane would have had to be on a plane out of Asmara by yesterday. 
Frustrated, Mr. Zeitlin wondered at the logic of Ms. Monetta's refusal. "Does she think this is all a giant ruse that Saba Kidane is using to get out of Eritrea?" he asked.. "She didn't find us. We found her."
In a country that struggled for so many years under the yoke of war, waiting is part of life. Saba Kidane will not fly her hello from New York this year, although she will add her voice to the festival via videotape. Back in Eritrea, she is throwing her energy into her newspaper, where she hopes to encourage a new generation to share its writing with the larger community.
Dr. Cantalupo surmised that her absence would be most sorely felt by listeners here. 
"Saba would have much to teach American audiences," he said. "Poets there are not separated or marginalized from mainstream society. It will be a loss not to see that example. 
"We'll be left in the dark a little longer," he added. "But hopefully not too much longer."

HEADLINE: After Earnhardt's Death, A Rebound for Nascar 

BYLINE:  By MICHELINE MAYNARD 

 BODY:
THE death of Dale Earnhardt, the fabled stock car driver, was a blow not only to his fans but also to companies tied to motor sports. Shares in the dominant racetrack companies, the International Speedway Corporation and Speedway Motorsports, plummeted just after Mr. Earnhardt's crash five weeks ago at Daytona International Speedway in Florida.
 Market analysts feared that fans would turn their backs on the sport, in attendance and television viewing, because racing's equivalent of Elvis was gone. 
 Instead, Mr. Earnhardt's accident appears to have evoked more awareness of Nascar racing. Nascar races on the Fox network have been the nation's top-rated sporting events on most recent Sundays, and track attendance has held up as fans take part in memorials for Mr. Earnhardt and cheer on his racing team.
Television revenue and attendance are the main sources of income for companies in the motor sports business. Shares in I.S.C., Speedway and a third company, Dover Downs, had recovered after Mr. Earnhardt's death. But I.S.C. and Dover have struggled in the recent market slide, while Speedway has held its own. "Definitely, there is momentum," said Breck Wheeler, an analyst at Legg Mason.
This year is the first of a six-year, $2.4 billion contract for Nascar and national television networks. Fox will show the first half of the Winston Cup racing season, through July; NBC is to pick up the broadcasts after that. In all, 27 races will be on the two networks, with an additional 10 shown on cable by Turner Sports.
The contract was a milestone for Nascar, which, despite a wide fan following, has never received the broadcast attention given other sports. As recently as 1985, Nascar collected just $3 million a year for 28 races on television. Track owners receive 65 percent of the television money, with 25 percent going to racing teams and 10 percent to Nascar.
The deal has been particularly lucrative for I.S.C., headed by members of the France family, which also controls Nascar, a closely held company. I.S.C. owns a dozen major tracks, including Daytona, the Michigan International Speedway and a new track in Kansas City, Kan. The company is also studying the feasibility of an auto racing complex in the New Jersey Meadowlands.
I.S.C. is the bellwether, said Joe Hovorka, an analyst with Raymond James and Associates. "They have the most tracks," he said, adding that they would have "the most benefit" from the television contract.
He has a "strong buy" rating on I.S.C. shares, which he said could reach $48 this year. They closed at $38.88 on Friday.
Scott Barry, an analyst at Credit Suisse First Boston, assigned the same rating. "I.S.C. trades at a significant premium, and a premium is deserved," he said.
Investors looking for cheaper shares generally head to Speedway, also rated a "strong buy" by Mr. Barry and Mr. Hovorka.
Mr. Hovorka said it could reach $30 within 12 months, compared with $24.28 on Friday.
Speedway is the industry's maverick. The owner of six tracks, it was first to see Nascar's upscale market potential. Its flamboyant managers outfitted its tracks with innovations like luxury boxes and lights for night racing.
CONCERN about attendance is a big reason that Jason Ader, an analyst at Bear Stearns, does not share the enthusiasm for these stocks, rating them "neutral." He said a weakening economy made it difficult for tracks to raise ticket prices above the typical $75 to $100 that a Winston Cup race commands.
He likened Mr. Earnhardt's death to Michael Jordan's retirement. "When Michael Jordan left basketball, it had an immediate impact," Mr. Ader said. "You make up some of the gap, but don't fully get it back."
Mr. Barry said Mr. Earnhardt's death might have shocked many fans into realizing how much racing meant to them. "The irony," he said, "is that the sport has never been better positioned to withstand this type of tragedy."

HEADLINE: INVESTING WITH/Edwin G. Vroom And Adele S. Weisman; 
Reserve Small-Cap Growth Fund

BYLINE:  By CAROLE GOULD 

 BODY:
THE volatile, tumbling stock market is making even long-term money managers queasy. "We take Dramamine before the market opens," joked Edwin G. Vroom, co-manager of the $76 million Reserve Small-Cap Growth fund.
 That said, he and the other co-manager, Adele S. Weisman, do not buy and sell stocks based on short-term market moves. "A major characteristic of our management style is that we make long-term strategic investments in growth stocks," Ms. Weisman said from their offices on Fifth Avenue, near 44th Street, in Midtown Manhattan. "We don't even think about market timing, nor do we view economic cycles as investable events." 
 Except, perhaps, for buying shares during market dips. "If we have companies with long-term growth prospects that are experiencing problems because of the overall economy, we continue to hold or even add to the position," Ms. Weisman said.
The managers' long horizons have paid off for investors. The fund returned 26 percent a year, on average, for the three years ended on Thursday, compared with 1.8 percent for its peer group of small-growth funds and 1.9 percent for the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index, according to Morningstar Inc. For the 12 months ended Thursday, it lost 44.8 percent, versus 38.1 percent for the group and 24.7 percent for the S.& P.
Mr. Vroom, 55, is president of Roanoke Asset Management, the fund's subadviser. Ms. Weisman, 54, is senior vice president of Roanoke, which also manages about $550 million in institutional and individual accounts. They have worked together for more than 20 years -- "longer than most marriages," Ms. Weisman said -- and have run the fund since its inception in November 1994.
The managers troll for growth among United States companies with market capitalizations of $2 billion or less. They look for annual earnings and revenue growth of at least 20 percent over five years -- actual results for the last two years and projections for the next three.
They split industry groups between them, with Mr. Vroom primarily following technology, health care and energy stocks and Ms. Weisman concentrating on telecommunications, retail, biotechnology and media. To choose the fund's 40 to 50 issues, they examine areas likely to grow rapidly. "We begin to look at niches or subsectors of our particular industries," Mr. Vroom said, "and then we look for different companies to fill those subsectors."
"Doing our research, we move up and down the food chain," Ms. Weisman said. "If we're working with service providers, we talk to management about the types of equipment in the network and who supplied them. When we work with equipment manufacturers, we talk to them about the companies that supply their components. That gives us a list of names to investigate."
Their financial-statement analysis helps them determine if a company's profitability is solid. They seek operating margins of 8 percent to 35 or 40 percent, depending on the industry.
Expenses are a key. "We want to make sure that what goes into the margins at every level -- marketing, sales, administration, R & D, taxes and other expenses -- are consistent with a company's long-term growth assumptions," Ms. Weisman said.
How much will they pay for shares? The answer is tied to a company's growth prospects; as a rule, however, they will not buy a company whose price-to-earnings multiple is more than twice its earnings growth rate.
Early last summer, the managers became convinced that the biotechnology sector was starting a period of prolonged growth. Because they viewed biotech stock prices as inflated, they began looking for related companies. Last June, they bought shares in Chronimed, a Minnetonka, Minn., company that distributes drugs and provides services for patients with chronic conditions.
"Many biotech companies have little or no distribution or marketing capabilities," Mr. Vroom said. "So when they develop new compounds, they're forced to go through large drug companies, which take a big share of their profits. A new industry has emerged that facilitates distribution for these drugs." 
The managers' positive view of broadband telecommunications led them to companies that supply components to that market. They bought shares of TranSwitch, a Shelton, Conn., company that makes high-speed semiconductors used in communications networks, at $61.58 in October and, convinced that growth prospects remained solid, added more when the price fell to $18.9375 this month. The shares are now at $19.56.
"There's been a slowdown in the telecommunications business," Mr. Vroom said. "We think it will correct in 12 months and people will look at the area much more favorably." He expects the company's earnings to grow 25 to 30 percent in the next 12 to 18 months, based on increasing demand for capacity in telecommunications systems.
In September, the managers bought shares of Genesco, a specialty retailer based in Nashville, at $17.0625. "Specialty retailers are exposed to unpredictable changes in style that put their earnings at risk," Ms. Weisman said. Genesco avoids this, she added, by distributing brands of many manufacturers. 
Ms. Weisman expects Genesco to have earnings of $1.70 a share in the fiscal year ending next Jan. 31, compared with $1.44 the previous year. The shares closed on Friday at $25.98.

HEADLINE: MARKET INSIGHT; 
Is Japan Digging Out, Or Falling Deeper?

BYLINE:  By KENNETH N. GILPIN 

 BODY:
THE 1980's were Latin America's lost decade. But in the 1990's, it was Japan that missed the boat. And after 10 years of no growth, slow growth or outright contraction, the wonder is that it remains the world's second-largest economy.
 The Japanese stock market hasn't exactly been a happening place, either. The Topix index is about 16 percent above a 1998 low but remains about 56 percent below the hyperinflated peak it hit in 1989. Many people say Japanese stocks are still expensive. 
 In their own incremental way, Japanese officials are trying to shake things up. Last week, the Bank of Japan started a new campaign to reinflate the economy.
Gary Motyl, chief investment officer for institutional equities at the Templeton Institutional Group, has been watching Japan for 20 years. He took time last week to talk about its prospects. Following are excerpts from the conversation:

Q. Are you impressed with the Bank of Japan's shift in policy?

A. Reducing an interest rate from 25 basis points to zero, which is one thing they intend to do, is effectively a nonevent. Also, it is not clear to us how committed they are to change. Will they do this in a piecemeal, short-term fashion, or will the effort get bogged down in politics?
The Japanese economy is in such a state that attacking one or two things just won't work. This has to be a concerted action that embraces monetary and fiscal policy, as well as restructuring everything. 

Q. Last week there were worries that coming accounting changes would rock the Japanese banking system and reverberate around the world. Can a further slide there really spread outside its borders?

A. We don't think Japan is going to implode and carry the rest of the world down with it. We don't see the deflationary problem spreading.
And the market has a pretty good idea how the stock holdings at Japanese banks are going to be valued come the end of this quarter. The numbers are going to be very ugly, but not orders of magnitude worse than people are anticipating.
The thing that is amazing to us is that the Japanese populace has been this docile in the face of a decade-long recession. I can't imagine that happening anywhere else, and certainly not in the United States.

Q. Templeton was a huge investor in Japan in the 1970's and into the 80's. But then the firm started to ease out, and by 1988 was effectively no longer a presence. Is your outlook more positive now?

A.In terms of the equity weightings in our portfolios, Japan has moved from the low single digits to the high single digits over the last couple of years.
The majority of stocks in Japan are still expensive on a price-to-earnings basis. We also think they are expensive on a price-to-adjusted book value basis, which is adjusted for things like pension liabilities and nonconsolidated debt.
There are some wonderful companies with very good managements. But there are a massive number of companies that have no interest in rewarding shareholders. To get corporate managements to really change will take a matter of years. We are still early in the game.

Q. What do you need to see to become more positive about investing there?

A. First, there has probably been more money lost trying to call the bottom of the Japanese market over the last 10 years than in the dot-com phenomenon over the last couple of years.
We would need to see some serious reforms and deregulation. In addition, individual companies need to get serious about enhancing returns on equity, about controlling their costs and positioning themselves to meet global competition.
When we visit these companies, for every one that says they are going to change and will be improving their return on equity, we meet 10 who want to stick to the same way they have been conducting business for the last 30 years. 

Q. Yet there are some companies that "get it." Which ones do you own a piece of?

A. One company we own is Komatsu, the world's second-largest producer of construction equipment. They are making the effort to truly globalize the company, watch their return on equity and manage themselves the way some of the better American and European companies are run.
The Toyota Motor Company is an extremely well-run operation, but the stock is too expensive. We own NTT. On a valuation basis, we think it is one of the most attractive telecommunications companies. They are also the eighth-largest holder of real estate in Japan, which is on their books at a nominal amount. And we still have some Sony that we have owned for many years. The stock is not cheap, but it is a world-class company with good management and good technology. It is a hold.
