HEADLINE: WAITING TO SLEEP: A special report.; 
For Family in Shelter System, Living From Bench to Bench

BYLINE:  By NINA BERNSTEIN

 BODY:
Jamall Roper fell silent as his younger brothers and sister talked about being homeless, stranded in a place where hundreds of families like theirs were trying to get into New York City's shelter system. 
 Day after day, and often halfway through the night, the four schoolchildren and their ailing grandmother had endured the city's Emergency Assistance Unit in the South Bronx, the waiting room for families seeking shelter, or, in the end, just somewhere to lie down until morning. 
 "I slept on a bench that was hard," Paris, 9, said softly. Tara, a second grader, blurted out: "The benches are too little and there are too many families. They didn't have no pillows and this lady had a hundred bags and they stole my brother's Game Boy." 
Homeless families have become all but invisible to many New Yorkers. The public image of homelessness is a grizzled derelict or a deranged bag lady. But this winter, when the nightly census in the shelter system rose above 25,000 -- more than at any time since the 1980's -- the people most likely to need shelter in New York City were, as always, children.
And what those children encounter in the system is often hard for them to understand.
For Paris, the security guards loomed large. "We don't get enough rest, so if there's an empty bench, I sleep on it, and the security guard wakes me up and says, 'Go,' " he said.
Their grandmother and sole guardian, Arlene Cruz, 55, who gathered them from New Jersey foster homes four years ago, now had to try to deliver them clean, fed and in uniforms to their Manhattan public school, starting from a different shelter each morning. Each afternoon they had to return to the din of the unit, to wait for the late-night bus to another bed.
Often the shelter assignment came way past bedtime, if at all. Asked where they slept when no beds or benches were available, even Ronald, the 6-year-old, could answer. "Floor," he said in an asthmatic growl.
But Jamall, 11, an honors student, could not speak. Tears filled his eyes, and he was trying too hard to hold them back.
"He has the best understanding of what's going on," Jamall's school counselor, Alana Reed, said later. "He has a sense of responsibility for his siblings and his nana." 
For families like Jamall's, the Emergency Assistance Unit is the mandatory first step. It is perennially in violation of court orders to enforce New York City's right to shelter, and the city's commissioner of homeless services recently acknowledged that it functions as a kind of gantlet.
"I can't screw the front door any tighter," said the commissioner, Martin Oesterreich, referring to tough screening procedures adopted in 1996 to discourage any parent with a housing alternative from using the shelters as a shortcut to a subsidized apartment.
What that means in practice is usually hidden from public view. Citing privacy, city officials have taped brown paper over the windows of the unit, at 151 East 151st Street, and barred reporters. But the experiences recounted by Jamall and his siblings, and corroborated by city, school and medical records and interviews with the adults in their lives, make the consequences for children hard to miss.
Despite Ms. Cruz's efforts, which were praised by school officials, the children began to miss school or arrive late, exhausted and unprepared. Their grades suffered. The whole family fell ill. And Ms. Cruz began to fear she could not carry on.
"I'm drained, but I've just got to keep going," Ms. Cruz said late last month, as tears slid silently down Jamall's cheeks. "I don't want them to take my grandkids and put them back in foster care."
On the day of that conversation, Feb. 23, the children were together in a temporary shelter apartment in the Bronx, a place with beds and blankets, a refrigerator, even closets where their grandmother had hung 16 crisply ironed school shirts for the week. But Jamall knew that the city had still not ruled them eligible to stay, and that only the last-minute intervention of a Legal Aid Society lawyer had kept them from having to apply for shelter all over again. 
"My biggest worry is that they find us ineligible and we have to leave," he said. "And that they're going to take us from our grandma because we don't have a place to live."

Becoming Homeless
Jamall and Paris vividly remember the day five years ago when New Jersey child welfare workers, citing parental neglect and drug use, took them from their mother, Maya, and stepfather, Ronald Jones, who is Tara and Ronald's father. "I tried to run back to my mom," said Paris, who was no more than 4 at the time, "but they caught me."
Jamall was placed in one foster home, Paris and Ronald in another, where, Paris said, the foster parents beat his baby brother. Tara went to a paternal aunt, then on to foster care, too, when the aunt was called to military duty.
It took their grandmother a year to extract all the children from the foster care bureaucracy. She was then living in rural South Carolina, after raising seven daughters in New York, where she had worked in factories, on switchboards, and for the Federal Bankruptcy Court as a clerk for 13 years. 
New Jersey was quick to end its financial support for the children. And South Carolina, Ms. Cruz discovered, would not grant her even a voucher for child care because she was not on welfare, but was working at a low-wage supermarket job. The total public assistance benefit she got for the children -- $286 a month -- barely covered Ronald's day care fees. 
For three years, Ms. Cruz made ends meet by adding a shift as a hospital aide to her supermarket job and by qualifying for food stamps. 
But when Ms. Cruz's health failed and the car broke down, Jamall realized that their home was about to fall apart.
"My grandma kept getting sick," he recalled. "She had to go to the hospital. She had problems paying the bills and stuff. She said she couldn't take it no more."
Ms. Cruz, who had discovered lumps in her neck requiring tests, hoped to get better medical care in New York, and help from relatives. A daughter, Cecily Pereira, sent her children's father to fetch them all at the end of May last year. But in mid-summer, he was jailed on a drug charge, and by fall, unable to afford the rent on the apartment, Ms. Pereira moved into a much smaller place with another working mother.
Ms. Cruz's efforts to find an affordable apartment failed, despite help from a social service agency in East Harlem, where the children were excelling in school. The children's own parents could not help. The father of Jamall and Paris had recently been released from prison and lives in one room; their mother is in residential drug treatment in Philadelphia. 
Reluctantly, in November, Ms. Cruz's sister Mary Campbell agreed to take in the family over her husband's objections, but only through Christmas.
On Dec. 29, when she insisted that they leave -- "It's too disruptive, too crowded, too expensive and has become overwhelming and a burden," she later wrote to city officials -- they turned to the shelters.

Branded Ineligible
The place where the Cruz family had to wait was full of children who could not freely play, eat or sleep. Some things that happened there are hard for Jamall, Paris, Tara and Ronald to forget.
There was the time in January when Tara and Ronald took ill. "The food had food poisoning inside of it," said Tara, who suffered two bouts of acute gastroenteritis and a case of dehydration, according to medical records. "We couldn't bring no food inside. There was no water fountain."
There was the time Jamall had strep throat and their grandmother caught pink eye. Forbidden to stand in line for meals with other families, they had to wait for city workers to bring them dinner. On the third night, no one came.
"We was quarantined in this little room, and we saw mice running all over the place," Paris remembered. "They forgot we were there. Ronald and Tara started crying because they were so hungry."
Finally, at 11 p.m., just before they were sent to a shelter for the night, Ms. Cruz dispatched Jamall to the deli across the street for $2 worth of ham and $1 worth of cheese. ("No bread," she said apologetically. "I didn't have enough for it.") The children devoured the rolled-up slices standing between the inner and outer doors of the unit, trying to stay out of the wind.
But the worst moment came early the next morning, when they had returned to the unit and a worker started screaming at their grandmother. He was angry that they had fallen asleep on the floor waiting for the quarantine room to be unlocked for them. 
"I just wanted to hit him so bad," Jamall said. Ms. Cruz, who had vowed to keep her dignity as she saw frustrated families fighting over the corner of a bench, was appalled to find herself shouting back.
"I just lost it," she said.
By then they had learned that if they left the unit without a pass, their application for shelter would be thrown out. They had to wait until they were called to board the bus to a shelter, usually so late that the unit's hallways were packed with sleeping families. By 6 a.m., they would be roused by a shelter worker's banging on the door and sent out to wait for the bus back again. 
Their grandmother, whose enlarged heart and hypertension had been duly noted on a medical screening form along with the children's asthma, had to line up for another pass so she could take them on to school, clutching hands and counting heads as they changed subways. 
They began to arrive weary and late to the brightly lighted classrooms of the East Harlem Block School, where each morning students recite the school mission: "to enable every student to achieve his/her personal best performance in all areas of their education and human development." 
In the fall, Tara, now 8, earned a 100 for her wishful account of a family Thanksgiving and a 90 on a report about "A Christmas Carol." By mid-January, when her penmanship became a sleep-deprived scrawl, her grade on an assignment was 70. The children could not enroll in the after-school program. The family's pass from the unit expired at 3 p.m., and they had to hurry back to keep waiting. 
"Last week, Jamall fell asleep several times during class and asked if he could sleep through recess," Ms. Reed, an intern who is the older boys' school counselor, wrote on Jan. 19. "Jamall, who normally shows a tough exterior, has cried through our last two sessions as he described his nights in the shelter and his fears that his family would never have a home."
That was one of several letters Ms. Cruz was given from the school, hospitals and doctors. They were all addressed "To Whom It May Concern," and they all pleaded that the family be given a steady place to sleep.
"If something is not done to help this family," Tara's second-grade teacher, Nyesha Patterson, wrote, "four young lives will be destroyed."
But after days of cycling the family through overnight beds, the city ruled that they were not truly homeless, as it typically does even in applications for shelter that are ultimately accepted. They were, in a word that came to be dreaded by the children, "ineligible."
"If they find us ineligible, we have to start all over again," Paris explained. "We already started over five times. They keep on saying we can go back to our aunt, but there's only three rooms and too much people and the landlord don't want so much noise."
Ms. Cruz tried to challenge the city's ruling on Jan. 22 at what is known as a "fair hearing," held in a Brooklyn office. It lasted five minutes and changed nothing. Directed to re-evaluate the family's application, the city ruled again a few days later that they were ineligible.
"The eligibility of this large family was initially in question," city officials said in a prepared statement last week, but they would not elaborate. 
The family had to start over. At 4 a.m. on Jan. 30, they were still waiting for a shelter assignment when a unit worker announced that the remaining families would get no beds that night. 
It was already morning -- the morning Paris took a citywide fourth-grade reading test, the day Ms. Cruz had a biopsy of the lumps in her neck at North General Hospital, the day before Jamall's 11th birthday.
"It's almost like getting punished for hitting bottom -- something you couldn't help," said Ms. Cruz, who has since been told she needs treatment for a thyroid disorder. "You see homeless people and you feel bad and then you turn around and you realize, 'I'm homeless. I am homeless with all these children.' "

A City's Unkept Promises
On Feb. 13, Ms. Cruz called the Legal Aid Society. She waited on hold for two hours, but it was worth it. After a lawyer called the city on her behalf, Ms. Cruz and the children were placed in a short-term shelter apartment on Valentine's Day, and two weeks later, the city acknowledged that the family was homeless. Under a 1995 court order, in fact, the Cruz family had even been entitled to expedited emergency housing because of their medical conditions. 
"This is a very typical case, and the impact on children is on the one hand appalling, on the other hand, all too common," said Steven Banks, director of Legal Aid's Homeless Rights Project. "There are 5,500 families in the shelter system, and five Legal Aid staff members to try to correct mistakes that the city makes on an individual case-by-case basis." 
That is the reason Legal Aid sues the city for overall relief, he added. 
But the longstanding battle to enforce court decrees seems to have reached a new impasse. Despite renewed promises of compliance made by the city last month, there were families left to sleep on the floors of the unit through 6 of the last 10 nights, including 113 children, city records show. That practice had stopped under pressure from a City Council ban in July 1999, only to begin again last summer. And now, like Ms. Cruz and her grandchildren, most of the applicants are shuttled back and forth to shelters each night -- a practice the city is under a new court order to end. 
Leonard Koerner, the city's chief assistant corporation counsel, said last week that the city was doing the best it could. He cited a recently announced program to add 517 rooms or shelter apartments for homeless families over nine months. But he acknowledged that officials had already fallen short on the first installment, and with the possibility of a recession looming, the prospect for reduced demand seems dim.
A confluence of factors is at work, current and former officials say. Housing costs rose sharply during the economic boom as the lowest incomes lagged, new welfare rules made it harder for poor families to rely on public assistance to help pay rent, and federal housing subsidy programs were cut.
Part of the problem, Mr. Koerner said, is that "doubled-up families living in harsh conditions" see the shelters as the only route to an apartment of their own. 
"There are some homeless people, certainly," he added, "but a lot of them are not truly homeless. You have to have a way of differentiating that or you don't have a functioning program." 
He added: "Over all, it works O.K. It's a very hard situation. I'm not going to say there aren't mistakes made."
Typically, the number of families seeking shelter declines in winter, when children are in school, and swells in summer. This winter, the numbers remained high. Last week, 10,385 children were in the system.
"It's all catching up to them," Mr. Banks said. "All the cuts in housing, the failure to address the gap between rents and incomes, the failure to have an appropriate program for survivors of domestic violence." 
Jamall, whose family is still waiting for an opening in a regular family shelter, has reached his own conclusions about why the system works the way it does. "I think they don't want us to have our education," he said. "Because they don't give us enough sleep to not fall asleep in class."

PERSON: William D. Brouse 

HEADLINE: Private Sector; 
In Proud Defense of the S.U.V.

BYLINE:  By KEITH BRADSHER

DATELINE: BROOKFIELD, Wis. 

 BODY:
WILLIAM D. BROUSE, the president of the Sport Utility Vehicle Owners Association of America, sits in a cramped office here amid the beautiful, cherry-wood furniture from his 31-year career as the top lobbyist for Wisconsin's savings and loan associations. In his new job, Mr. Brouse sometimes fields phone calls at least as difficult as those he received during the worst of the savings-and-loan crisis of the 1980's.
 Last fall, for example, he heard from a Long Island man whose son had been seriously injured while driving a car that was hit by an S.U.V. The caller demanded to know why people should be allowed to drive the big vehicles if they do not use them for what they were designed -- towing trailers and off-road driving. 
 Mr. Brouse drives a black 1998 Jeep Grand Cherokee with no trailer hitch, and he has never taken it off road. "I wouldn't want to scratch it," he explained. 
But he said he did not give an inch in the 20-minute conversation, asserting that Americans have a right to drive whatever kind of vehicle they want. 
"We've always had the freedom of choice in this country," he said. "Unlike some of the calls, the guy was easy to talk to and rational."
With his combative approach to issues involving sport utilities, Mr. Brouse quickly became a favorite of talk-radio programs after he established the association last April. Environmentalists suspect his group of being another front for the auto industry, which has a history of bankrolling "grass-roots" groups to campaign against government regulations. But auto executives say they are not financing Mr. Brouse's efforts, and he says the group is something more unusual: a for-profit trade association.
After decades representing savings and loans at the Wisconsin League of Financial Institutions, Mr. Brouse was pushed into a retirement for which he says he was not emotionally ready: in 1998, as its members disappeared, the league was absorbed by the Wisconsin Bankers Association.
Then 64, and convinced that no trade association would hire him because of his age, Mr. Brouse decided to establish his own. He chose to represent owners of sport utility vehicles because of the criticism the vehicles have faced over safety, fuel efficiency and air pollution, and because he loved Jeeps.
As a sergeant in the Air Force serving in South Korea for three years just after the Korean War, Mr. Brouse ran a telephone wire maintenance crew that used a truck with four-wheel drive. He loved the way that truck could chug up and down hills. But what he really longed to drive was a Jeep, which he was never allowed to use. "The Jeeps were reserved for people of rank," he said.
Four decades later, at the S.U.V. association, Mr. Brouse used some of his retirement savings to hire an Internet designer, who built a Web site, www.suvoa.com, to attract members. On the site, he began a defense of what he describes as a basic American right to drive any type of vehicle.
Over lunch at a Greek restaurant near the association's small headquarters in this Milwaukee suburb, he spoke even more strongly: "A tank would be all right if it didn't claw up the road with the tracks."
He also wants the police to pursue the handful of activists, mainly in San Francisco, who have surreptitiously put anti-S.U.V. bumper stickers on other people's sport utilities.
Mr. Brouse also defied convention in structuring the Sport Utility Vehicle Owners Association. George Constantine, the staff counsel at the American Society of Association Executives, said creating such a group as a for-profit venture, by setting an agenda and then trying to recruit members to support it, was an innovative and rare approach.
So far, the association is not making money. Mr. Brouse charges a membership fee of $50 a year, and in 11 months he has attracted 50 dues-paying members. He created associate memberships for people who fill out the group's survey and join its electronic mailing list but pay no dues; there are 3,200 associates. But there are 21 million sport utilities on the nation's roads.
Mr. Brouse says that his organization is still young and that he is confident it will grow. Other groups for owners of controversial products also represent minorities, but larger ones; the National Rifle Association was founded in 1873 but still represents only 4.3 million of the nation's 60 million to 65 million gun owners. Guns are like sport utilities, Mr. Brouse said, in that they pose no danger if used responsibly.
Like many executives of associations, he has been looking for ways to supplement dues with other income. He has installed a link to a Web site that sells auto accessories; members get a discount and the group a part of the profits from referrals. He also hopes to offer group insurance, automobile luggage carriers and clothing with the association's logo. And he may offer introductory memberships at a reduced rate.
And he acknowledges making two mistakes. One was in relying on the Web to recruit members. "We probably should have done more direct mail and that sort of thing," Mr. Brouse said.
The other, he said, was in not soliciting money early from automakers. He had hoped that once he attracted members, he would draw support from the industry's large lobbying budget.
The auto industry has long provided, for example, most of the money for the Coalition for Vehicle Choice, a lobbying group that opposes any tightening of fuel-economy regulations. The coalition publishes a newsletter and encourages its 32,000 members and 8,000 affiliated organizations, including the Farm Bureau, to send letters, faxes and e-mail messages when Congress considers issues relating to fuel-economy standards. 
The coalition is a taxable but not-for-profit group that occasionally asks members for contributions but does not charge dues, said Diane K. Steed, its president and a top traffic safety regulator in the Reagan administration.
Mr. Brouse does encourage sport utility owners to drive carefully, and he says automakers should make safer sport utilities if consumers will buy them. But environmental and safety groups describe his hostility to government regulations as extreme. "They're only going to be designed properly if there are safety, efficiency and pollution regulations, because these are the cash cows for the industry," said Joan B. Claybrook, who was the nation's top traffic safety regulator in the Carter administration and is now president of Public Citizen, an advocacy group.
Mr. Brouse extols the safety of sport utilities, saying their additional weight provides more protection. But government and insurance industry data shows that sport utility occupants have the same death rates as car occupants, mainly because sport utilities roll over more often.
With his aversion to off-road driving and pulling trailers, Mr. Brouse is not the kind of outdoorsman the auto industry cites in contending that sport utilities should continue to be regulated separately from cars. While Mr. Brouse enjoyed off-road driving in the Air Force, he frugally avoids it now for fear of costly damage.
Auto industry officials also express some wariness about backing an organization that they did not help to establish. Moreover, the automakers see little reason to help someone who is already helping them at no cost. As Brian Wallace, a spokesman for DaimlerChrysler, said, "To some extent, he's got more credibility if he's not supported by the auto industry."

GRAPHIC: Photo: William D. Brouse, president of the Sport Utility Vehicle Owners Association of America, started the group last year. (John Saller for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: PRACTICAL TRAVELER; 
Free 800 Calls? Not Exactly

BYLINE:  By BETSY WADE

 BODY:
A COLLEAGUE who spent seven nights at the Sheraton Chicago Hotel and Towers last month discovered at checkout that his bill included $107.06 in telephone charges, mostly in $1.44 bites for dialing "800" numbers on his modem. Mark Pruner, president of Web Counsel, a Stamford, Conn., marketing company, was charged $149.70 at the Westin on Michigan Avenue in Chicago for two calls to Connecticut, 50 minutes in all. "I practically fell over," he said.
 Because he was in a long checkout line at the hotel and was scheduled to lecture in 45 minutes, he paid, which my colleague did not. Mr. Pruner was using a new computer and had not incorporated a local Internet access number to get to his e-mail, so he just punched in his Connecticut access number. He had expected to pay perhaps 60 cents a minute, he said, but could not find an information sheet in his room saying how much. When he asked on checkout, it was $3 a minute. 
 Getting into the Internet on a computer, which involves using a phone line unless there is a high-speed network connection, has only exacerbated the issue of staying in touch, which has traditionally ranked high on travelers' list of concerns. A survey in 1999 of 1,207 randomly selected business travelers found that in rating hotels, respondents put phone service as fifth most important after cleanliness, efficient service, safety and express checkout. The survey, the National Business Travel Monitor, was made by Yesawich Pepperdine & Brown of Orlando with Yankelovich Partners of Norwalk, Conn.
Of the respondents, 75 percent said they wanted free local calls and 70 percent wanted no access charges for long-distance calls placed on a credit card.

Disclosing Rates in Advance
The Federal Communications Commission wants consumers to know the charges before placing calls. Last fall the agency's Enforcement Bureau investigated to see how well consumers were being served by a 1998 rule requiring that people away from home be told in advance what rate they would pay and how to reach a company they usually used. As Mr. Pruner might have predicted after his surprise bill, the answer was rather negative. 
F.C.C. agents across the country made calls from 1,700 hotel and motel telephones and coin phones to see if they got pricing information and access to the carriers they wanted. On Nov. 1, John Winston, head of the Enforcement Bureau, announced that three telephone operator services, USLD Communications, the AT&T Corporation and WorldCom, had signed consent decrees, meaning they agreed to changes without acknowledging wrongdoing. The decrees involved fines of $150,000, $105,000 and $56,000 respectively.
The bureau also issued 97 citations for noncompliance, but without fines. Many were to independent places, but familiar names of individual properties cropped up: Best Western, Econolodge, Holiday Inn, Marriott, Doubletree, Embassy Suites, Sheraton, Motel 6, Ramada, Radisson, Comfort, Super 8. The Sheraton in question was not the one my colleague stayed at; it was in Anchorage.
After the citations, the F.C.C. drew up a guide to its requirements, and the American Hotel Association is distributing it to members, according to Kevin Maher, who deals with telephone issues. 
In boldface, the flier says it is not enough for a hotel to put information about its phone service into the usual tabletop portfolio or even in a drawer; the information, including how to reach other telephone companies, must be posted "on or near the telephones used by guests or the public." The flier also says that guests must be able to dial all three types of access codes: 800 codes, 950 codes and 10-10 or 10-15 "dial around" codes that circumvent the hotels' preferred long distance companies. The government receives complaints about failures on these rules: F.C.C., Consumer Information Bureau, 445 12th Street SW, Washington, D.C. 20554.

Bypassing Regular Lines
It's a jungle of phone charges out there. The hotel industry is in the midst of another cycle of changes as many properties install high-speed Internet access, with a flat daily charge for use. These installations mean that regular phone lines are not used for 800-number calls for Web access of the sort Mr. Pruner made; to the hotels, it means that regular lines are not tied up by callers' computers for hours on end. 
Guests who want to use high-speed Internet links are usually asked to call the desk or sign up on registration to accept the daily charge. They must also have a network adapter, since the high-speed links are not regular telephone lines. A few of the latest high-speed links accept the USB connectors that are found on newer laptop computers; most require Ethernet adapters.
Here are some samples of what a few business chains are charging for 800 and similar calls.
Sheraton belongs to the Starwood group, which includes Westin, Four Points by Sheraton, St. Regis and the Luxury Collection and W Hotels. The Starwood policy applies to the 218 hotels with these names that are owned or managed by the corporation, according to Nadeen Ayala, a spokeswoman. Ms. Ayala said that Starwood policy permits hotels to look at the competition and charge guests either 85 cents, $1 or $1.25 for connecting to "800" numbers. The $1.44 a call that my associate was billed, according to the Sheraton Chicago, represented $1.25 plus a 14.5 percent communications tax levied by the city and Illinois. 
After an hour's duration, Ms. Ayala said, calls to "800" numbers incur an additional charge of 10 cents a minute. The Starwood policy for high speed dataports, where they are available, involves a $9.95 daily charge for use, with a charge of 10 cents a minute after the first hour. 
Hilton has high-speed computer lines in 150 of its 300 United States hotels and 56 of its 140 Embassy Suites. Daily charges for these range from $7.95 to $9.95. The regular phones also have two lines in Hilton rooms, so a modem can use one while the guest talks on the other. Calls to "800" numbers are free if the call is less than 60 minutes; after 60 minutes, the charge is 10 cents a minute. Jeanne K. Datz, director of communications for Hilton, said that Hiltons that wanted to deviate from these pricing policies had to get approval and "a few" had. 
All Marriott brands -- Marriott Hotels, Courtyards by Marriott and Residence Inns -- provide 800-number calls free, according to Roger Connor, a spokesman. High-speed Internet access is provided at 160 of 250 Marriott Hotels now, and should be installed in all by the end of the year. The price is $9.95 a day. Courtyards by Marriott, Residence and Fairfield Inns are scheduled to get these lines too, but no timetable has been set. 
At the hotel properties it manages, Hyatt Hotels charges $1 for 800-number calls that lead to a telephone company. Calls to 800 numbers that lead to something else, like a store or a catalog company or the Internet, are free, according to Angela Sikkema. In Florida, she said, charges for calls to 800 numbers are prohibited, and in Texas, the charge is 50 cents. At Hyatt resorts, guests are charged a flat fee of $10 for all telephone use during a stay.

CORRECTION-DATE: April 8, 2001

 CORRECTION:
The Practical Traveler column on March 25, about charges for 800-number phone calls from hotels, misstated the title for John Winston of the Federal Communications Commission. He is a spokesman for the Enforcement Bureau, not head of the bureau.

HEADLINE: BRIEFING: BUSINESS AND ECONOMY; 
VERIZON CONTRACT WITH LUCENT

BYLINE:  By Angela Starita 

 BODY:
Verizon Wireless, based in Bedminster, agreed last week to pay Lucent Technologies $5 billion to expand Verizon's mobile phone network. 
The upgrade will enable Verizon customers to reach the Internet through their mobile phones, hand-held devices and notebook computers almost 10 times faster than they currently can. The new technology, called 3G for third generation, will be available by the end of the year. After the announcement, Lucent, which is based in Murray Hill, saw a slight upturn in its stock price, which has dropped 85 percent this year.
 Angela Starita

HEADLINE: Group Urges City to Develop as Biotechnology Center 

BYLINE:  By TERRY PRISTIN 

 BODY:
Once a week, Dr. Jeffrey V. Ravetch, a professor of molecular genetics and immunology at Rockefeller University, hops the shuttle to visit MacroGenics, the new biotechnology company he helped to found in Rockville, Md.
 "I would have loved to have had a company up here," Dr. Ravetch said. But with lab space nearly impossible to find in New York, he said, he had to look elsewhere for a home for the company. 
 Scientists and entrepreneurs have long complained that state and city officials have been too slow to recognize the potential that the biotechnology industry holds for the city. Now the New York City Investment Fund, a private effort intended to stimulate job growth, is urging officials to provide at least $100 million in direct subsidies and tax incentives. With that level of public commitment, private industry would be willing to come up with another $400 million, the fund contends.
Gov. George E. Pataki has proposed spending hundreds of millions of dollars on biotech and biomedical research upstate. Legislative leaders have made similar pledges that would include projects in the city, like the science park that the New York University School of Medicine has proposed for city-owned land near Bellevue Hospital Center on the East Side of Manhattan.
But Kevin S. Corbett, the chief operating officer for the state's Empire State Development Corporation, said that academic institutions in the city had not made a persuasive case for public financing of biotech projects.
"If you look at this from an economic standpoint, the downstate economy is extremely hot," Mr. Corbett said. "In Buffalo, Albany and Rochester, the money can go a lot further."
According to the investment fund, about 30 new businesses a year emerge from the city's top nine research institutions, but nearly all of them migrate to other states. The biotech industry in the city consists of only about 35 companies, employing fewer than 2,000 people. And New York State has only 87 of the nation's 1,612 biotech companies.
"There is an opportunity for New York to become one of the the top three biotech centers if we move right now," said Kathryn S. Wylde, the investment fund's president.
What is needed in the next five years, the fund said in a report, is about a million square feet of space at rents fledgling companies can afford. Government aid is necessary, the fund says, because developers would have to charge an annual rent of up to $55 a square foot to make a reasonable profit, far higher than the $25 a square foot that it says start-ups can pay in their first year. 
The lab shortage is not the only reason New York has been left behind. Investors in fledgling companies contend that New York academics are less inclined to seize commercial opportunities than their peers elsewhere. "We have phenomenal hotbeds of expertise here," said Mark Leschly, the managing director of Rho Management, a venture capital company in New York. "But often the people doing it don't want to be part of a commercial setting."
Despite the drawbacks, some developers with experience in biotech are eyeing New York. Alexandria Real Estate Equities, of Pasadena, Calif., a landlord for many pharmaceutical and biotech companies around the country, is planning to open an office in New York and hopes to attract small biotech companies as well as larger pharmaceutical companies from Europe, said Joel Marcus, the chief executive. "There are some pretty big challenges," he said, such as recruiting workers to an expensive city. 
LCOR, a real-estate company that specializes in public-private partnerships and was chosen to develop the commercial portion of Queens West in Hunters Point, recently met with top officials of several medical institutions, including Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center and Rockefeller University, to discuss including a biotechnology center.
Officials at LCOR said that public support would be necessary for a biotech center at Queens West. "If the region wants a new industry, it needs to be induced," said Peter T. Gilpatric, a senior vice president.
Mr. Corbett of the Empire State Development Corporation, however, said the institutions seeking to build a biotech center at Queens West "have yet to present a coherent case for why they need a subsidy." He cited the Lennox Tech Enterprise Center, a high-tech incubator that opened outside Rochester in 1998. It received state funding, but only after the academic community there united behind it and the private sector showed that it was willing to make a substantial investment.
The only existing biotech incubator in the city is the Audubon Biomedical Science and Technology Center at Columbia University, which opened in 1995. Columbia is planning to build a second incubator building on a city-owned parking lot next to the center. Mount Sinai Hospital is also eager to put up a new research building that would contain incubator space, officials there said.
And New York University's School of Medicine is leading the effort to build the East River Science Park on city-owned land on First Avenue between 28th and 30th Streets, in partnership with the Veterans Administration, Bellevue, and Hunter College. Last summer, the city's Economic Development Corporation designated the site as a science park. 
State lawmakers say they are eager to help the biotech industry take hold in the city. The State Senate has proposed a $500 million fund to support biotech and is committed to providing $30 million for the East River Science Park, said Senator Roy M. Goodman, who represents the East Side. Last week the Assembly unveiled a plan that includes $125 million in capital funds. The Assembly speaker, Sheldon Silver, said he hoped that a peer review process, rather than politics, would determine how the money is allocated. 
This kind of help cannot come too soon for Dr. Samuel D. Waksal, the chief executive of ImClone, the city's largest biotech employer, with 120 people at its New York headquarters in Lower Manhattan. Dr. Waksal said his company, which makes anticancer drugs, expected to add 100 employees next year. 
"We're looking in the city," he said. "We don't want to move."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Samuel Waksal, head of ImClone, the city's largest biotech employer. (Chester Higgins Jr./The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Dennis Ross's Exit Interview 

BYLINE:  By Clyde Haberman; Clyde Haberman, The Times's Jerusalem bureau chief from 1991 to 1995, writes the NYC column for the paper.

 BODY:
There were moments this past year, Dennis Ross says, when breakthrough peace agreements between the Israelis and the Arabs were tantalizingly, almost maddeningly, close. This was especially true on the Israeli-Syrian front. A deal was just waiting to be sealed. With the Israelis and the Palestinians, well, that was always going to be a tough nut to crack. Ultimately, as everyone knows, peace negotiations broke down in an explosion of violence and a near-total exhaustion of mutual good will.
 Now, says Ross, whose job as "special Middle East coordinator" has been eliminated by the Bush administration, "it's going to take time" to put the shattered fragments back together. The new Bush White House seems to have stepped back from the Israeli-Arab conflict, choosing not to entangle itself in that web the way the Clinton administration did. That's probably wise, Ross says. But as a veteran at this business, he adds a cautionary note: "The Middle East has a way of imposing itself on any administration." 
 He should know. For 12 years, he was America's go-between with the Arabs and Israelis, through two presidents and three secretaries of state. This month, he joined the Washington Institute for Near East Policy, a research organization. It was time, he decided, to get a life, something he didn't have while shuttling constantly to and from the Middle East. 
Throughout the last decade, Ross stayed in close contact with all the key figures in the conflict. So he has a perspective that virtually no one else can claim. Not everyone may agree with his recollections or his assessments. But nobody sat through as many rounds of negotiations as he. And as he left the State Department at the end of the Clinton administration, he agreed to discuss the critical moments in the peace process as well as the personal traits of the leading figures he came to know so intimately. 
It was, if you will, kind of an exit interview, conducted in the sparely decorated house outside Washington where he lives with his wife and three children. It was also a change in procedure for Ross, who spent years keeping his thoughts largely to himself. This is no celebrity diplomat on the order of, say, Richard Holbrooke. "I prided myself on using a lot of words to not reveal anything," Ross says.
A cynic, or perhaps a realist, might say that years of American mediation in the Middle East produced very little. Washington's main achievement, arguably, was to get the ball rolling after the gulf war in 1991 with an Arab-Israeli peace conference in Madrid. But the blockbuster agreements of the last decade -- the Oslo accords between Israel and the Palestinians in 1993 and the Israel-Jordan peace treaty a year later -- were worked out by the parties themselves. 
In the final reckoning, there is no escaping the fact that the big ones got away: an Israeli treaty with Syria and a final settlement of the Israeli-Palestinian conflict. Some would call that failure, no?
"I don't feel I failed, and I'll tell you why," Ross says. "Because the United States is never going to impose an agreement. What we can do is make it easier for them to make really hard decisions. In the end, the failure can never be our failure. It may be their inability to get to where they want to go. But it's much more their doing than ours."
That was true on both the Syrian and Palestinian fronts, he says. Syria, under the despotic Hafez al-Assad, would never even have talked peace with Israel without Washington serving as a broker. And as time wore on, the Israelis and Palestinians, too, kept pulling in the Americans deeper and deeper. "My mere presence was kind of a security blanket for both sides."
On the Syrian track, Ross says, an agreement was achingly close last March. That was when Assad met in Geneva with Clinton, who was carrying peace proposals from Prime Minister Ehud Barak of Israel. It was clear to Ross that all Syria had to do was say the word and it would get back the Golan Heights, the strategic plateau that it lost to Israel in 1967.
"We were down to a couple of hundred meters, basically," he says. Disagreements remained on security arrangements and on a timetable for Israel's withdrawal from the Golan. But those were technical issues, and "there were different creative formulas we could have come up with."
There was only one sticking point. "We basically ran out of time with Assad," Ross says. The Syrian ruler simply wasn't prepared to close the deal. He was also in poor health and may have been more concerned at that point with the question of who would succeed him. Three months later, he was dead. Almost seamlessly, his son Bashar al-Assad took over.
"Assad approached negotiations like a man who was absolutely not in a hurry, as a way to show he wouldn't pay more than he had to pay -- and I think he genuinely wasn't in a hurry," Ross says. "Barak at that point was ready to go. But Barak himself got caught by moving too quickly, because he saw there was more resistance at home to doing this deal than he had anticipated.
"There's so much gamesmanship in negotiations, where if one side suddenly signals it's going to go slower, you have to show you don't need it more. Because if you show that somehow you need it more, they'll think you'll give away more. We got into that."
Why didn't they try again with Bashar? "With Bashar, there was only a limited effort made," Ross says. "His focus was understandably internal. We sensed an interest on his part, but the timing was not yet right."
It was maddening for the Americans to be so close and not succeed. "This is one," says Ross, "where there's a deal waiting to be had."
The Palestinian track is far more complex. But when all is said and done, Ross feels those negotiations failed mainly because they ran into a brick wall called Yasir Arafat.
Barak was prepared to give up a lot, including virtually the entire West Bank and sovereignty over the Temple Mount, the Jewish holy of holies in Jerusalem. He was willing to yield so much that it cost him his job in February, when he lost the election to the more hawkish Ariel Sharon. Some senior Palestinian officials were not blind to the opportunity for statehood that was within their grasp. "I had one Palestinian negotiator say to me, 'If we can't do an agreement under these circumstances, we ought to be fired,"' Ross says.
Those circumstances included the deep involvement of Clinton, who all but begged Arafat to make a deal when he summoned the Palestinian and Israeli leaders to Camp David last summer. Clinton could not keep himself from getting more and more immersed in the Israeli-Palestinian talks. Perhaps that was unwise. The Camp David talks ended up producing little more than a sense that the parties were not ready to deal.
Even before Camp David, Barak was in regular contact with the president.
"Clinton probably spoke on the phone with Barak more than any other leader in the world," Ross says. "Barak liked doing business this way. Whatever was important to him usually led to a phone call to the president, and Clinton made it clear that he was available any time to talk. At Camp David, they met every day that Clinton was there." But the Israeli resisted attempts to get him to talk substance directly with Arafat. "Barak feared that everything he would say would be committing himself, and Arafat would say nothing at all," Ross says.
Clinton's desire to make himself available to Barak may help explain the infamous Marc Rich pardon, Ross suspects. Rich was "never a factor" in the peace talks, he cautions. Nevertheless, a senior Israeli negotiator, Uri Savir, approached Ross in 1995 "to say that a man named Marc Rich was prepared to generate several billion dollars for development in the West Bank, but he had some problems with the United States government and needed some help for easing restrictions on travel."
When Ross learned that Rich was a fugitive, "I told Uri to forget it and that any other questions or requests should go through legal channels. Needless to say, none of the money was ever forthcoming for the West Bank, and after 1995 I never heard of Rich again."
That is, until the final days of the Clinton White House. "The president did not discuss Rich with me, and I thought nothing of it," Ross says. But Barak had begun to make several requests of Clinton, including new aid and pardons for the convicted spy Jonathan Pollard and for Rich. "I believe the president found it difficult to respond to many of Barak's requests," Ross says, "and I believe that he may have acted on Rich because he wanted to be responsive in at least some way to Barak."
Many feel that with the peace talks Clinton was desperate to build a legacy, something to counter the taint of impeachment and the Monica Lewinsky scandal. (Marc Rich had not yet become a household name.) That isn't how Ross sees it. "Whatever anyone says about legacy, I honestly think it misses the boat." Clinton came to believe fervently in the peace process, especially after Prime Minister Yitzhak Rabin was killed in 1995 by a right-wing Jewish fanatic. "That had a searing effect on Clinton," Ross says, "in terms of his own sense of obligation and responsibility."
But always there was Arafat, "an interesting complex of impulses and considerations and concerns -- and fears." In general with Arafat, Clinton did more talking than listening, according to Ross, because "Arafat would reveal little about what he could do and not do. Arafat was long on complaints but short on prescriptions.
"At Camp David, the president made impassioned attempts to move him, explaining what he stood to gain and lose. Arafat either would say he needed to think about it or, especially on Jerusalem, he would say he could not accept the idea, even when the idea was deferring Jerusalem and agreeing on everything else."
Ross is convinced, though he knows many will scoff, that "in his own heart of hearts" Arafat wants peace. "But I have come to the conclusion that he is not capable of negotiating an end to the conflict because what is required of him is something he is not able to do. It's simply not in him to go the extra yard." It isn't that Arafat made no concessions, Ross says, even if it may have looked that way to outsiders. But whatever he offered fell way short of Barak's minimum needs.
"Is it because Arafat is basically a revolutionary who can start the process and lay out a certain direction but can't be the one to end it? Is it because he has defined himself by struggle? I've often thought that maybe he wants to be the last revolutionary on the Palestinian side."
And there is no escaping the fact, Ross says, that Arafat hasn't prepared his people for peace. Israelis are not blameless, either. They have generally been indifferent to Palestinian economic suffering and to their frustration over indignities like checkpoint searches, property confiscations and settlement expansion.
But the failings of the Palestinian leadership loom larger for him. Arafat and his aides, Ross says, "constantly socialize hostility." By that he means that Palestinian newspapers stoke a limitless sense of grievance. Textbooks continue to teach hatred of Israelis. Arafat's soldiers run training camps where youngsters are taught to fight the enemy, Israel. Arafat himself has challenged core Jewish beliefs, even claiming there never were Jewish temples on the Temple Mount.
"I'll tell you," Ross says, "when that was first raised, I said to Arafat: 'Forget it. You're going to deny the essence of their faith? No one will accept it on our side. The president of the United States knows the temple was there, and if you proceed that way, what you will tell him is that you are not serious."'
Barak, for Ross, was a fine strategic thinker, and courageous. "But he alienated everybody around him, basically because he didn't trust anybody. He is someone who felt he knew best, that if he thought something was reasonable, ipso facto it was."
Interestingly, more hawkish Israeli leaders fare better. Take former Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu. He may not have been what anyone would call a flaming peacenik, but, Ross says, "he had ambitions that were grandiose. He compared himself to the great leaders who had come before. He would cite Ben-Gurion. But he never quite decided how he would proceed. On the one hand, he wanted to move ahead and achieve peace. On the other hand, he was very mindful of his right-wing base. It was kind of a constant struggle."
Bibi as a wannabe dove. Doesn't that fly in the face of accepted wisdom?
"Well," Ross replies, "I spent a lot of time with him."
As he has with Ariel Sharon, the new prime minister.
"He can be very practical," Ross says. Sharon understands Palestinian grievances. "He also understands that the Palestinian Authority is not going to go away. And he understands that he's not going to be able to coerce the Palestinians into submission. He's going to have to find a new way to deal with them."
Not surprisingly, Ross gives his heart to the old Labor Party lions who made the 1993 Oslo accords happen, Shimon Peres and Yitzhak Rabin. Never mind that many dismiss Peres as a hopeless utopian, with all his talk of "a new Middle East." To Ross, Peres is "a visionary."
And the martyred Rabin, the warrior turned peacemaker, is irreplaceable. "I found him larger than life," Ross says. "He was such the embodiment of Israel, and his experience so mirrored the experience of Israel that he had inherent credibility."
The "experience of Israel" looms large for Ross, so much so that it became an occasional factor in the peace talks.
He is Jewish, though his religious training was almost nonexistent when he was growing up in Marin County, Calif. His Hebrew is less than functional (and his Arabic is even worse). But with time, his sense of his Jewishness has deepened. When not on the road, he regularly attends Sabbath services at a local Conservative synagogue -- in addition to playing forward on its basketball team.
"My Jewishness has added to my sense of mission," he says. And he is an ardent supporter of Israel, where he has vacationed with his family. "I don't believe you'll ever produce peace in the Middle East," he says, "if Israel isn't strong and if there isn't a strong relationship between the United States and Israel."
But in his line of work, those feelings create complications. His land-for-peace formulas are anathema to Jews with absolutist views on Israel's right to disputed lands in the West Bank, Gaza and, of course, Jerusalem. When Ross started as a peace negotiator in 1989, Bush the elder was president and James Baker was secretary of state. In 1991, Bush and Baker unceremoniously shoved a recalcitrant Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir to a peace conference with the Arabs in Madrid. At Baker's side were three lieutenants: Ross, Aaron Miller and Daniel Kurtzer. All three were Jews. "Baker's Jew boys," they were called at one point by Shamir's chief of staff, Yossi Ben Aharon.
With the Palestinians, too, Ross's religion sometimes got in the way, though not often, he insists. Some hard-liners pegged him as hopelessly pro-Israel. Ross feels those attacks had more to do with his being an American than a Jew. It was business, not personal, except maybe when Arafat challenged Jewish history on the Temple Mount. That, Ross took personally. 
Jewish, not Jewish -- it's not nearly as important in negotiations as maintaining credibility, he says. "One thing a negotiator has to be is authentic. You have to be who you are."
He felt that he was always true to that rule, which came with this corollary: never bluff. "You can threaten, but you better be very prepared to carry out your threats." In early 1997, at a difficult moment in talks on an Israeli troop withdrawal from Hebron in the West Bank, he threatened to walk out. "After we closed it, I was asked if I really intended to leave," he says, "and I said, 'You bet."'
Most of all, any high-stakes negotiation requires a real deadline -- it has to be believed." Then why didn't that work with Arafat? He faced several real deadlines. Clinton's White House days were numbered, and Arafat knew that Barak would almost surely lose the election to Sharon. 
Ross shrugs. "Arafat is someone who will never make a decision before he has to," he says. "He always moves one minute to midnight. One of my great concerns was that he was misreading the clock."
So what lies ahead? Eventually, Ross says, Israelis and Palestinians will sit down once again to talk peace. Simple geography says that they have no alternative. And he believes that proposals set forth by Clinton -- the Israelis' compromising on sovereignty over Jerusalem and the Palestinians' giving up an absolute "right of return" for millions of refugees -- will inevitably form the basis for any settlement.
But the Bush administration's inclination to step back from the conflict is probably correct right now, he says. The recent swing through the Middle East by the new secretary of state, Colin Powell, suggests that a good deal more than an occasional American drop-in is needed to "transform the psychology of the region."
This is a time for soul-searching and truth-telling, Ross says. "Each side is not really seeing the needs of the other." The Israelis must "overcome this sense of indifference" to Palestinian suffering. "You can't stick your finger in their eye and expect that they're going to say, 'Fine,"' he says.
But the Palestinians, indeed the Arabs in general, may have the tougher climb. "One thing that has to happen in the Arab world is a good deal more truth-telling about what it takes to do an agreement," Ross says. "The concept of land for peace is always presented as a slogan. But where is the Arab side of the peace? It's not land for nothing. It's always talked about what the Israelis have to do, but it's never talked about what they have to do."

HEADLINE: The Way We Live Now: 3-25-01: The Ethicist; 
I Spy Inc.

BYLINE:  By Randy Cohen 

 BODY:
Is it ethical to call your competitors posing as a potential customer in order to get information? Most of the information is available to anyone who calls; we're simply not identifying ourselves as the competition. -- Joel O'neill, San Francisco
 The Society of Competitive Intelligence Professionals has a code of ethics that permits acquiring publicly accessible information through patent applications or annual reports, for example, but prohibits misrepresentation. So no false mustache, no fake French accent, no posing. Critics of such professional associations might charge that they are little more than public-relations operations whose purpose is to make spying palatable. But in this case, the group's guideline is a reasonable one. (Whether it is widely followed is another question.) 
 In addition, the Economic Espionage Act of 1996 made it a federal crime to steal an American company's trade secrets, like the formula for Coca-Cola or how Julia Roberts gets so many dozens of teeth into that fabulous smile. (Assuming the Roberts dental magic is a "trade secret," which it is not.) Thus, you may walk into any store and ask, "How much is that doggy in the window?" You may not break into a lab and rummage through the files to learn, "How did you bioengineer that doggy in the window?"
When my boyfriend and I rent a car, the way he follows the requirement to "return the car with a full tank of gas" makes me uncomfortable. He has me sit in the driver's seat and call out when the gas gauge just touches the "full line," hoping that this is gallons -- and dollars -- away from a full tank. He says he has no way of knowing that he received the car with a truly full tank. Is he right? -- Eric West, Washington
He is right on paranoia, wrong on ethics. The rental agreement he signed says fill the tank, not refuel until the semiaccurate gas gauge registers something vaguely fullish. His obligation is unambiguous.
It is true that he can't know if the car's previous renter topped off the tank, but that does not justify tailoring his own conduct to match that of the worst-behaved members of society. He also can't know if other drivers are carrying weapons, but he really ought not mount a machine gun on the roof of the rental car. (For one thing, he'd scratch the paint; that can be a pricey repair.) That there are petty scoundrels among us does not preclude the duty to behave honorably.
Every year my in-laws celebrate Christmas with my son a week early so that they can spend the real Christmas with their daughter's children in Atlanta. They spend the night and pretend it's Christmas Eve, and the next day we all get up early and pretend it's Christmas Day. I feel this is not fair to my son.
Am I wrong? -- M.B., New York
Lying to a child is always unfortunate, and in this case it is particularly ludicrous and unnecessary. Kids love celebrating early and often. Tell your in-laws that you welcome their festive visit but prefer that your son know the actual date (thus sparing you the tricky theological problem of explaining why Jesus' birthday comes twice a year but your son's just once). I suppose you should be grateful that they visit only a week early and not six months in advance -- it's so hard to get that artificial snow to stick to the ground in June. You may want to warn your in-laws that I will run this traditional holiday question in March (avoiding the Christmas ethics rush) and not pretend that this is a December issue of the magazine.

HEADLINE: Democrats' Full-Court Press Fails Again in Hempstead 

BYLINE:  By STEWART AIN 

 BODY:
In his toughest election contest to date, James Garner, a Republican, beat back a strong challenge from Hezekiah Brown, a Democrat, on Tuesday to win a fourth term as mayor of the Village of Hempstead.
 Senator Charles Schumer, former Gov. Mario Cuomo, and the state comptroller, H. Carl McCall, all campaigned with Mr. Brown, and Senator Hillary Clinton called in at a rally in Mr. Brown's behalf. 
 Mr. Garner said the Democrats "came after me like a ton of bricks." "It was like David versus Goliath," he said. "I ran against the State Democratic Committee. They put a ton of money into this race. But this was a campaign about people helping people, and as a result we came together for the good of the community."
Mr. Garner pointed out that he ran on a slate with three others, two seeking trustee seats and an incumbent trustee, Lance D. Clarke, seeking a judgeship. All three also won, and Mr. Clarke became the first African-American to win a judgeship in the village's 358-year history.
The day after the election, Mr. Brown said he was stunned by Mr. Garner's winning by 802 votes out of more than 5,400 cast.
"We can't figure out how it happened," said Mr. Brown, 62, a village trustee who pledged to cut taxes after what he said had been a 129 percent increase in village taxes during Mr. Garner's 12-year tenure.
Mr. Garner, 55, stressed the economic development that has taken place in the village, including a new Long Island Rail Road station in Hempstead, a new Home Depot and the development of the Times Square Commons, a shopping plaza.
Although Mr. Garner is a vice-chairman of the Nassau County Republican Committee, he ran on the Independence and Unity parties in a village that has a 2-to-1 Democratic registration. Lawrence Aaronson, chairman of the Nassau County Democratic Committee, said local issues and not the county's financial problems determined the election.
"In prosperous times, people don't have the same anger to throw out the incumbent unless there is an overriding local issue," Mr. Aaronson said. "There was no local issue that resonated with the residents."
In another contested mayoral race, James Nevile defeated John O. Maher by one vote in the Village of Baxter Estates. Mr. Nevile received 125 votes to Mr. Maher's 124. Mayor John H. Weaver, who withdrew from the election for personal reasons after the paper ballots were printed, received 10 votes.
The winners of some other contested village mayoral races were Peter T. Imbert in Amityville, Richard Goodwin in Brookville, James Altadonna in Massapequa Park, Claudia Moyne in Sea Cliff and Daniel P. Petruccio in New Hyde Park.

HEADLINE: FIVE QUESTIONS/for NANCY F. KOEHN; 
An Information Age Led by Business, So Far

BYLINE:  By JULIE FLAHERTY 

 BODY:
BUSINESS has scored a number of regulatory victories in recent weeks. Early this month, Congress voted to repeal ergonomics standards meant to protect workers from repetitive strain injuries. In an abrupt turnabout, President George W. Bush last week reversed a campaign pledge to limit power plants' emissions of carbon dioxide. And this week, the Environmental Protection Agency canceled a plan that would have reduced the allowable amount of arsenic in drinking water by 80 percent.
 Those moves, which coincide with other signs that the change in the White House will mean more business-friendly policies -- like the opening of the Alaskan wilderness to oil drilling -- appear to point to a new political climate for corporate America. Nancy F. Koehn, a business historian at Harvard University and the author of "Brand New: How Entrepreneurs Earned Consumers' Trust from Wedgwood to Dell" (Harvard Business School Press), takes a broader view. Last week, she talked about what comes next. JULIE FLAHERTY 

Q. Why are we seeing an expansion of the rights of businesses now? Is it more than just a friendlier government?

A. We've seen business become more prominent in the life of the country for some time. It is not brand-new to the Bush administration. An administration can accelerate that perception, but the fundamental drivers of what is going on transcend the White House.
What we're seeing is an inflection point in the history of capitalism as the information age takes hold. Business is leading that transformation. We're seeing businesses experiment with trying to exploit, trying to take advantage of and, over the next few years, make profits from the possibilities of the information age.
Those are Chapters 1 and 2. Coming chapters will be about other actors responding to business initiatives. It will be about workers, politicians and voters making the information age their own, regulating and trying to exert more control.

Q. Are there historical parallels that we should be examining for insight into what happens next?

A. The late 19th century is a perfect analogue. People perceived the country to be ruled by business and what business wanted. If we look back to the second industrial revolution, you think about someone like John Rockefeller and the birth of oil refining. That industry was not initially very regulated.
But as industrialization took hold, a whole lot of other people got in the game. The formation of what would become the A.F.L.-C.I.O. meant the acceleration of the unionization movement. The Sherman Antitrust Act, and others before it, initiated large-scale government regulation. A whole range of social and political movements was formed against what people saw as too much business power. 
I believe we will see extraordinarily vibrant responses on the part of workers and government to the new imperative of the information age over the coming three to six years. It could be a new form of collective action on the part of workers or new policies on intellectual property rights on the Web. It could be anything from sales taxes on electronic commerce to new standards in the workplace, because the workplace itself is changing so rapidly.

Q. Is there some opportunism at work here, with businesses seizing on signs of economic weakness to claim they need more flexibility, less regulation and so on?

A. Businesses, like workers, like politicians, will take advantage of any window of opportunity. That's the nature of the system we live in, economically and politically. Some business people perceive that window now.
But business is hardly monolithic. Almost all the executives I talk to say they have not lived in a more confusing moment. Some signals seem very robust and others seem to point toward a real economic downturn. They wonder: What does that mean for pursuing competitive advantage? For motivating and retaining your most valuable workers? Or, if you're a young enterprise, staying afloat? I do not think this is a moment when most business people are sitting back, rubbing their hands and saying, "Great, let's go for the gusto." 

Q. How much of a backlash will there be from voters, employees and consumer groups?

A. The importance of the stakes involved and people's perception of those stakes are critical determinants. How intensely do people care about the issues? When the economy is very good and people perceive that a rising tide is lifting their boat, a whole bunch of issues can be diluted in their importance. When the tide is no longer rising so fast, people take a different look.

Q. If the stock market continues its downturn, will people view business more critically? Will it affect whether business can keep winning in Washington?

A. The jury is out on that one. We've not been through a moment in history in which the economy was potentially turning downward and so many people were so involved in the stock market. The huge boom market of the 1990's drew in a lot of people. They are not only buying and selling stock, but thinking and talking about the market as part of their daily calculus. How will that affect people's actions in the workplace, in the polling booth? We don't really know that yet.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Nancy F. Koehn

HEADLINE: MARKET WATCH; 
Technology Tests the Strength of the Fed's Magic Wand

BYLINE:  By GRETCHEN MORGENSON 

 BODY:
EVEN though Alan Greenspan disappointed investors last week by cutting interest rates by only one-half of a percentage point, rather than three-quarters, most Americans still view him as the man who can save markets with a wave of his baton. 
 Mr. Greenspan first earned the maestro moniker by ensuring that the 1987 stock market crash did not cause a recession. He cemented it with forceful interest-rate cuts in 1998, after the Russian financial collapse. 
 Paradoxically, at least one economist says, as Mr. Greenspan's eminence grew in the 1990's, his ability to manage the economy with monetary policy diminished. That economist, James W. Paulsen, chief investment officer at Wells Capital Management in Minneapolis, thinks that investors may be even more disappointed in coming months when the Federal Reserve's actions do not produce a quick economic rebound. 
Some market strategists have fretted recently that Mr. Greenspan did not cut rates soon enough to remedy the slowing economy. But Mr. Paulsen's work suggests that the problem may lie with the monetary policy tools themselves and the nature of today's economy. 
Mr. Paulsen studied the impact that the Fed's two major policy tools -- changing the Federal funds rate and managing the growth in the money supply -- have had on economic growth over the last 40 years. 
For decades, both had demonstrable economic impacts. Growth in the money supply translated to growth in the economy. And changes in the Fed funds rate had an inverse effect on the economy, with a lag, of course. When rates were raised, economic growth subsequently fell, and when rates dropped, the economy did better.
All of that changed in 1990. Since then, the relationship between real economic growth and changes in the money supply and Fed funds rate has virtually disappeared. 
Mr. Paulsen thinks that the shift has much to do with the dominant role that technology plays in the economy today. While interest rates have huge impact on the fortunes of manufacturing companies, and on sales of cars and housing, the success of technology companies has everything to do with new product introductions, he said. Interest rates have less of an effect. 
"Although the Federal Reserve traditionally has had strong influence on the economic cycle, this suggests that coincident with the substantial growth in the technology sector, the Fed's ability to manage the economy has been greatly reduced," Mr. Paulsen said. "Greenspan gradualism has worked so well for him. You wonder now if gradualism is the appropriate policy."
Even though Mr. Greenspan has cut rates by one and a half percentage points recently, Mr. Paulsen points to another reason why more aggressive easing may be required. Banks' willingness to lend has plummeted, according to the most recent figures from the Fed. The percentage of large and medium-sized banks that are willing to make business loans has fallen below the level seen during the recession of 1990. 
This unwillingness has to do with the fact that long-term bond yields are not sufficiently higher than short-term yields. Banks, which charge rates based on long-term yields and borrow based on short-term yields, have lower profits than they would have if long-term yields were higher. "It used to be, when the Fed would ease, long yields would come down less," Mr. Paulsen said. "Now, long yields fall first."
A result? "They've lost a big piece of the ammunition that makes Fed policy work," he said. "They might have to be more aggressive than they're used to."

HEADLINE: Business; 
Advanced Online Banking, Born of Necessity

BYLINE:  By DAVID LIPSCHULTZ 

DATELINE: SAO PAULO, Brazil 

 BODY:
RODRIGO ABREU has not been inside a bank here in more than three years. He has not written a paper check for any regular expense in nearly that long. For almost half a decade, Mr. Abreu, now 30 and a technology executive, has made every kind of scheduled payment through the Internet arm of his bank, Banco Itau. 
 He is paying car insurance, buying stocks and conducting e-commerce through the bank's Web site. His 68-year-old mother and all his other family members are also doing most of their business transactions online. The same goes, he said, for "absolutely everyone I know here." 
 Advanced Internet technology is not generally associated with Brazil, where a vast majority of the population of 171.2 million has no online access. But when it comes to Internet banking, the country is a leader.
"I definitely would put the major Brazilian banks in the very elite in the world of online banking," says Virginia Philipp, an analyst at Tower Group, a research organization based in Needham, Mass., that covers financial services and technology. "Banks across the world look to them as models." 
It was Brazil's dire economic problems that helped pressure major banks -- Bradesco, Unibanco and Banco Itau -- to build advanced electronic payment systems that formed the backbone of the Internet services they offer today. 
In the early 1990's, Brazil's economy faced such inflationary pressures that the currency, the real, would sometimes lose 3 percent of its value in a day. In grocery stores, shoppers heard announcements that the price of bread had just gone up. To combat the hyperinflation, banks built communications systems to clear checks and allow their customers to pay bills as soon as possible. That helped the customers avoid losing money during processing. 
"We were able to cash checks within 24 hours when the U.S. banks were still taking nearly a week," said Milton Monteiro, who is vice president and is in charge of Internet banking at Banco Itau. "We had to be very efficient." 
By 1993, each major Brazilian bank had built a complex private network so that when a customer's paycheck came in, it was cleared overnight and moved into an account that was hedged against inflation. Home banking was coming into vogue and people were already dialing directly into the banks' networks to move money and pay bills instantly. In the United States, meanwhile, manual check processing and human bank tellers were still the norm. 
BY 1996, as the Internet began to take hold, the Brazilian banks not only had their own networks in place but also had the back-office support to advance quickly into online banking.
"In 1998, when U.S. banks were just trying to figure out the Internet, Brazilian banks were well ahead with a huge range of offerings," Ms. Philipp said. 
While many United States banks, like Wells Fargo and Bank of America, are certainly catching up with the range of their online offerings, Bradesco, Banco Itau and Unibanco still have a wider array of Internet services. Brazilians can complete basically any type of financial transaction through the banks' Web sites. Banks offer e-commerce portals, advanced business-to-business services, brokerage services, direct deposit and bill-paying, all integrated into their Web sites.
In fact, under a bill-paying standard now used in Brazil, bank customers can simply type in the bar code number of any bill; the bank immediately knows its amount and pays it upon request.
"When I lived in the U.S., I definitely found myself doing things I had almost forgotten about, like writing paper checks and going to a physical bank branch," said Mr. Abreu, who lived alternately in Palo Alto, Calif., and Brazil from 1998 until last year. 
Brazil's advances in Internet banking, however, do not necessarily reflect technological backwardness among American banks, which for many years operated under far more stringent restrictions about the breadth of their operations. Brazilian banks have long been free to offer both commercial banking and brokerage services, unfettered by regulations that only recently were relaxed in the United States with the end of the Depression-era Glass-Steagall Act. 
"Because of Glass-Steagall, we've definitely had to go slower," said Dan Hilken, senior vice president for investments at Wells Fargo. 
But the economic crisis was a big factor in prompting Brazil's banks to act faster than their counterparts in Europe and the United States. 
"We built up Internet banking not because it was fashionable like in the U.S., but because it created serious value to the customers and thus the bank," said Candido Leonelli, who is in charge of Internet banking at Bradesco, Brazil's largest private bank.
The relatively long history of online banking in Brazil is seen in its acceptance by customers. Bradesco says that 22 percent of its customers bank online, while Banco Itau says its figure is 25 percent. That compares with 15 percent at Wells Fargo, a leader in United States online banking. 
Those numbers alone, however, do not tell the whole story, because only about 4 percent of people in Brazil even have Internet access, compared with about 50 percent of people in the United States. That means that among Internet users, vastly higher percentages of Brazilians are banking online. 
ACCESS, however, could be the biggest obstacle in expanding the country's Internet banking culture. After figuring in the cost of a computer, its accessories and an Internet service provider, online access can cost more than $1,500 in Brazil -- more than one-third of the $4,200 annual income of the average Brazilian, the World Bank estimates. So even though analysts estimate that Internet access in Brazil will triple over the next three years, the banks will soon encounter a firm ceiling.
Banks are starting to offer financing for computers and sponsoring free Internet access in an effort to put more people online. Even so, with 17 percent of the population making less than $7 a day, it is likely that many Brazilians will not be able to take advantage of the country's banking technology. 
"Finding a way to get everyone access," Mr. Leonelli said, "is definitely one of our biggest challenges."
