HEADLINE: Despite Emboldened Critics, Jesse Jackson Isn't Yielding 

BYLINE:  By PAM BELLUCK 

DATELINE: CHICAGO, March 25 

 BODY:
The Rev. Jesse Jackson could not have picked a better place to make his point. 
 It was a high school basketball championship game at the United Center, the huge arena where the Chicago Bulls usually play, and it was packed to the rafters. 
 When Mr. Jackson arrived unannounced to take a courtside seat, the crowd's reaction was explosive. There was thunderous applause, scattered standing ovations, teenagers squealing and whooping. Throughout the game, people embraced him, slapped his back or asked for autographs. 
"Do you see people reacting to me adversely tonight?" Mr. Jackson asked. "Do you see how the people are responding?" 
Mr. Jackson's point was obvious: that despite his recent round of troubles -- from the disclosure in January that he had fathered a child during an extramarital affair to questions about the way he raises money for his nonprofit groups -- his popularity was as strong as ever.
But while Mr. Jackson's fans and allies here and elsewhere clearly remain committed, it is equally clear that he is enduring the rockiest episode of his four decades in public life. 
Longtime conservative opponents have been energized, filing complaints with the Internal Revenue Service and the Federal Election Commission over the financial practices of Mr. Jackson's organizations.
Ambitious members of the black clergy have begun suggesting publicly that Mr. Jackson's role as the nation's pre-eminent African-American figure is on the wane and that the time is right for a new generation of leadership. And a spate of newspaper articles and columns, concentrating mostly on the fact that Mr. Jackson's groups accept money from corporations he criticizes, have forced him to spend time defending his operation.
"He's going through, without a doubt, the deepest valley he has gone through," said Marshall Frady, the author of several biographies, including one of Mr. Jackson.
"Among the conventional power estate, I assume a number who have kind of accommodated him, indulged him and abided him will see this as a marvelous opportunity to get him out of their hair," Mr. Frady said.
The disclosures come at a time of great paradox for Mr. Jackson, 59. In some ways he is now a more respected member of the establishment than ever before. When Bill Clinton was president, he was a special envoy to Africa and persuaded Mr. Clinton and others to sign on to his antipoverty campaign. 
Mr. Jackson was also a high-profile counselor to Mr. Clinton when the president's affair with a White House intern became public and led to his impeachment. And for the last several years, Mr. Jackson has been holding conventions on Wall Street to persuade hundreds of business leaders to invest in minority businesses.
Yet at the same time, Mr. Jackson's political luster has dimmed considerably from 1984 and 1988, when he made bids for the presidency. At last summer's Democratic National Convention, he was sidelined during the prime-time events. 
Among blacks, the attitudes toward Mr. Jackson seem just as contradictory, if not more so. Some civil rights leaders, like the Rev. Al Sharpton, suggest he has become too caught up in the political mainstream, while some black ministers believe he is still too much of an outsider. 
Even before Mr. Jackson's recent troubles, a group of 20 lesser-known black ministers, veering away from Mr. Jackson's drumbeat of criticism of President Bush, wrote to Mr. Bush to congratulate him on his victory. Last week the same group embraced Mr. Bush's proposal to give religious organizations more access to federal money.
Here in his home base, where his every step reverberates loudly, Mr. Jackson has come under intense scrutiny. Some columnists and political consultants, typically those who have not been Jackson loyalists, are accusing him of hypocrisy, particularly over the affair and his acceptance of money from corporations that he criticizes for not having more minority involvement. Others are more upset that he has left himself open to attack. 
"What he did was put everything at risk by brazen, hypocritical and reckless behavior," said Delmarie Cobb, who was Mr. Jackson's national traveling press secretary in 1988 but has since had friction with his organizations. "Yes, they're out to get you," Ms. Cobb said of Mr. Jackson's critics. "What are you supposed to do -- help them? Give your enemies ammunition?" 
Further complicating matters for Mr. Jackson, other prominent blacks have begun to suggest that he is past his prime. In a recent interview with The New York Times Magazine, Mr. Sharpton compared him with an aging pugilist. "Muhammad Ali can't fight no more, but he's still a great champion," Mr. Sharpton said.
David Bositis, a specialist in black politics at the Joint Center for Political and Economic Studies, said: "You have white conservatives who would just as soon like Jesse to drop dead. You have black conservatives who would love Jesse to get out of the way. And for somebody like Al Sharpton, clearly if Jesse was out of the way it would give Sharpton more room to stretch his legs."
Mr. Jackson says there is more than enough room for other black leaders: "The fact that there is emerging more voices, that is a good thing. Who is the pre-eminent white leader? Is it Trent Lott? Is it George W. Bush? Dick Cheney?"
Mr. Jackson's troubles began in mid-January, when The National Enquirer reported that he had fathered a child with Karin L. Stanford, formerly the executive director of the Citizenship Education Fund, one of Mr. Jackson's four interconnected groups. When Ms. Stanford left the organization that year and moved to Los Angeles, Mr. Jackson's groups paid her $35,000 in relocation expenses and consulting fees. 
After that, a conservative watchdog group, the National Legal and Policy Center, filed a complaint with the Internal Revenue Service claiming that the Citizenship Education Fund violates its tax-exempt status by threatening to oppose corporate mergers and then accepting contributions from those corporations. 
The American Conservative Union has filed a complaint with the Federal Election Commission contending that Mr. Jackson's Rainbow/-PUSH Coalition had accepted money from the Democratic Party in violation of a nonprofit organization's obligation to be nonpartisan.
Mr. Jackson then released detailed information on his organizations' spending showing that the Citizenship Education Fund failed to list Ms. Stanford and other staff members on a tax form, an omission Mr. Jackson and his chief financial officer said was an oversight that they would correct by filing an amended return.
He also says his organizations have begun a search for a chief operating officer to make them more professional and accountable.
Many of the questions concern what has become the major way Mr. Jackson's groups now raise money: grants by corporations whose merger plans Mr. Jackson initially objected to by criticizing the corporations' records on minority contracting or serving low-income consumers. Companies like SBC and Ameritech contributed hundreds of thousands of dollars to his groups after Mr. Jackson objected to their mergers. 
Some of the companies ended up contracting with minority businesses run by Mr. Jackson's friends. Ameritech, for instance, sold some of its wireless communications business to Chester Davenport, a Jackson supporter. Mr. Davenport and other minority businesspeople who benefit from Mr. Jackson's efforts often contribute to his organizations, too, helping swell their coffers to about $17 million last year. 
Mr. Jackson says his organizations were doing nothing improper or even unusual. He argues that he is helping corporations by showing them how to find minority business partners and penetrate minority markets. And he says that while he is friendly with many of the minority businessmen he introduces to the corporations, he offers companies several names and does not expect them to choose from his list.
"The same people that you challenge one day, once they come around and honor the law, then we build relationships with them," Mr. Jackson. "Of course that's what we do. It is legal, appropriate and effective."
He added that "those who benefit, contribute" to the Rainbow/PUSH Coalition or his other groups. "Of course they do." 
Critics have also questioned why two of Mr. Jackson's sons, Jonathan and Yusef, both on the board of the Citizenship Education Fund, received a lucrative beer distributorship from Anheuser-Busch although they had no experience in the beer industry. Mr. Jackson, who organized a boycott of Anheuser-Busch in the early 1980's to protest its minority hiring practices, said his sons were qualified to run such a business.
Mary Mitchell, a columnist for The Chicago Sun-Times, said, "The point is that a group of people surrounding Mr. Jackson has profited from his civil justice involvement, and I think that's disturbing." Ms. Mitchell has also drawn attention to Mr. Jackson's income: $120,000 from Rainbow/PUSH, $260,000 for his CNN talk show and about $50,000 for speaking engagements.
Such criticism, though, has produced a backlash of its own. Laura Washington, editor and publisher of The Chicago Reporter, a journal about race and poverty, said that many people were "angry and disappointed" with Mr. Jackson but angrier at his black critics, because "that kind of criticism hurts the movement." Indeed, African-American radio shows here have been deluged by callers lambasting Mr. Jackson's critics.
Mr. Bositis of the Joint Center for Political and Economic Studies said many blacks saw the financial criticisms as harassment or a setup. And he said mainstream black political leaders were "entirely behind" Mr. Jackson "because many of them have events, demonstrations, marches, and have relied upon Jesse to come and speak, to get people enthused." 
Reactions to Mr. Jackson's current problems are so varied in part because he has long been seen as a man of contradictions. For example, his call-and-response cadences make him very effective at stirring people but can also obscure his detailed knowledge of complex issues. And boundless energy sometimes propels him into causes that some consider tangential or trivial. 
Mr. Jackson rebuffs suggestions that he might be weakened by the recent accusations. "In baseball, you cannot stay in the dugout just because you struck out," said Mr. Jackson, who is famously fond of sports metaphors. "In boxing you're measured by how well you can take a punch and not get punch-drunk."
Some observers say Mr. Jackson will rebound, partly because he has not tried to shirk responsibility for his out-of-wedlock child.
Ms. Washington of The Chicago Reporter said Mr. Jackson might be able to capitalize on the fact that Republicans are running Washington. "I think there's a certain segment of the community that believes this is a conspiracy to hurt him, and piling on by the media works to his advantage also," she said. 
Others think Mr. Jackson's sheer perseverance will keep him aloft. Before the basketball game two weeks ago, Jackson coached volunteers on a new campaign to get Chicago parents more involved in their children's education. 
"It's better to get ahead than to get even," he told the volunteers, as if reassuring them about his personal strategy. "Better to get there limping than to never make it out the door because you got even."

HEADLINE: Mr. Annan's Winning Record 

 BODY:
Kofi Annan's candidacy for a second five-year term as United Nations secretary general is welcome and deserves the strong endorsement President Bush gave it on Friday. Since taking office in 1997, Mr. Annan has strengthened the U.N.'s management and moral credibility and repaired its once-frayed ties with Washington. Further reforms are needed to enable the organization to live up to its founding ideals. A second term would allow Mr. Annan to make additional changes and cement a constructive relationship with the new Bush administration and Congress. 
 Mr. Annan's current term expires Dec. 31. To serve again he needs the support of the Security Council, including all five permanent members. Approval of the Council's choice by the General Assembly is usually a formality. 
 Mr. Annan's first four years have brought significant management reforms and leaner budgets. Without those achievements, and changes in the formula allocating international contributions, Richard Holbrooke, the former American representative, would not have been able to persuade Congress to begin repaying America's billion dollars in back U.N. dues. 
But Mr. Annan has been more than a competent administrator. He commissioned tough reviews of past U.N. peacekeeping failures in Rwanda and Bosnia, even though he led the peacekeeping department during those operations. For the past year he has pressed member nations to make peacekeeping more effective. He has also emerged as a voice of conscience on a variety of international issues, especially the problems of Africa and the fight against AIDS.
In other areas, for example Iraq, his effectiveness has been undermined by damaging divisions on the Security Council. It is difficult for any secretary general to uphold the authority of U.N. economic sanctions and weapons inspections if leading Council members like Russia and France are determined to weaken them. 
If given a second term, Mr. Annan must strengthen the understaffed peacekeeping department while continuing to curb patronage and wasteful spending elsewhere in the U.N. bureaucracy. At last year's Millennium Summit, Mr. Annan set ambitious goals for combatting poverty and disease. To this end, he has campaigned to make AIDS drugs available and affordable to those who need them. This work must continue as the epidemic spreads through Africa, Asia and Eastern Europe.
Mr. Annan's re-election bid has won strong endorsement from the Organization of African Unity. Asian nations seem prepared to defer their own claim to the secretary general's job under the U.N.'s informal regional rotation system. 
A successful secretary general must court Washington and the Security Council's other permanent members -- Britain, France, Russia and China. Those countries generally decide when to impose or lift international sanctions on misbehaving countries and where to send peacekeeping missions. The United States, Europe and Japan provide most of the organization's finances. But the secretary general must also be a voice for the needs of smaller countries and the 50 percent of the world's people who live on less than two dollars a day. Mr. Annan has managed both roles with competence and grace and should be kept on the job.

HEADLINE: Paid Notice: Deaths; 
EASLICK, DAVID K.

 BODY:
 EASLICK-David K. Longtime telephone company executive and civic and community leader, died Wednesday, March 14, in Naples, Fla., where he had wintered away from his Grosse Pointe Farms home for more than 20 years. He was 80. Mr. Easlick graduated from University High in Ann Arbor and then earned a B.A. degree from the University of Michigan in 1942. He was a Sloan Fellow at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology in 1954, was awarded an honorary doctor of law degree by Butler University in 1972, and was awarded an honorary degree of doctor of business administration by Eastern Michigan University in 1981. His fraternity was Phi Kappa Psi. Easlick's career at Michigan Bell began in Ann Arbor in 1948. He rose through the ranks to become vice president of personnel by 1960 and three years later took a post at AT&T, at the time Michigan Bell's parent company, to be the AT&T representative on President Kennedy's national task force on integration and equal rights. He was with Indiana Bell Telephone Company from 1963 to 1972, leaving as President of the company. In 1972 he returned to AT&T as vice president human resources and negotiated the historic national agreement on behalf of the Bell System with the U.S. Department of Labor and the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission to facilitate the movement of minorities and women into better jobs. After this assignment, Easlick served as Michigan Bell president from July 1973 until September 1983 when he was named chairman and retired. 
His concern for social justice was recognized by the Detroit NAACP when he was appointed co-chairman of its annual Fight for Freedom dinner in 1978 and when he was named Humanitarian of the Year in 1976 by the International B'nai B'rith. In World War II he served in the army as an infantry officer and spent three years in the European Theater where he took part in the D-day landing and in the Battle of the Bulge. He was awarded the Bronze Star with Oak Leaf cluster and the Silver Star as well as the Croix de Guerre by the French government. He was discharged as a major in 1945. Mr. Easlick was a director of a host of companies and community organizations, including American United Life Insurance Co., National Bank of Detroit, NBD Bancorp, Inc., Economic Club of Detroit, United Foundation of Southeastern Michigan and International Freedom Fund. His community involvement including serving as a trustee of the Boys and Girls Clubs of Metropolitan Detroit, Interlochen Center for the Arts, HarperGrace Hospital, New Detroit, Inc., Citizens Research Council of Michigan, Diocese of Michigan, Grosse Point Farms Foundation, and the Rose Hill Center in Holly, Michigan. Survivors include his wife Lucy; son David K. Easlick, Jr., daughters Susan Easlick Heinen and Anne Easlick, and six grandchildren, Christoph, Alexander, Max and Marta Heinen and Sarah and David Easlick. His parents were Dr. Kenneth Easlick and Mercie VanAken Easlick. Dr. Easlick was founding chairman of Pediatric Dentistry of the School of Dentistry at the University of Michigan. A memorial service will be held at Christ Church, Grosse Pointe Farms on August 11. Contributions may be sent to the David K. Easlick Memorial Fund, c/o Goodman & Breen, Attorneys at Law, 3838 Tamiami Trail North, Suite 300, Naples, FL 34103.

HEADLINE: THEATER REVIEW; 
On Evil and the Citizen, No Answers Are Easy

BYLINE:  By BRUCE WEBER 

 BODY:
It's rare to walk out of a play and wish it had been longer. But Abby Mann's post-Holocaust drama, "Judgment at Nuremberg," which opened on Broadway yesterday at the Longacre Theater, is a bit too brisk and trim for its own good. This is not to say that the show's two and a half hours fly by but rather that Mr. Mann's famous story about Nazi judges on trial before an American tribunal doesn't shrink comfortably to stage time and space. The play feels edited, nipped and tucked, in short, adapted.
 That's hardly surprising. The material was drawn, of course, from the last round of the Nuremberg war-crimes trials, and Mr. Mann first rendered it in a 1959 teleplay and subsequently as a movie script and a novel. But the constraints of the stage -- no cameras, no intercutting between scenes, no close-ups -- and perhaps a fear of the theater audience's diminished attention span seem to have foisted a need to economize on Mr. Mann and the director, John Tillinger. 
 And for those who remember Stanley Kramer's 1961 film version, the play may be particularly attenuated by the comparison it will inevitably stir. Chiefly what has been excised is the centrality of the lead American jurist, Dan Haywood, an obscure district court judge whose fundamental open-mindedness -- "I'm a rock-ribbed Republican who thinks Roosevelt was a great man," he says at one point -- isn't quite masked by a backwoods affect.
One of the strengths of the three-hour film is that it is painstaking in illustrating Haywood's German education. Mr. Mann's Oscar-winning screenplay told its story largely through Haywood's experience, and in Spencer Tracy's somber and steely performance his delving into the lives of ordinary Germans who submitted to Hitler becomes a powerful narrative all by itself, the story of a fair man bending over backward to see the world from a perspective that baffles and horrifies him.
Here Haywood walks a shortened path; his travels around Nuremberg and his interactions with Germans have been cut way back. He is played by George Grizzard, whose silvery white hair is reminiscent of Tracy's but whose characterization is not. A North Carolinian in the play (in the film, Haywood was from Maine), Grizzard's Haywood comes equipped with a cheery Southern drawl (at first, anyway; he eventually loses the accent) and a hickness that give him an Andy of Mayberry aspect. It's unwisely diminishing, but it is supported by the script, which makes Haywood far more naive than he needs -- or ought -- to be.
At one point Haywood asks his aide, a black military officer, "Hard to believe it really happened, isn't it?" and then is completely dumbfounded when the aide responds: "Not for me. I grew up in Texas." And an intimate conversation between Haywood and a general's widow (Marthe Keller, in a striking if abbreviated turn) is configured into a first-act finale that brings the lights down with cringe-inducing sappiness. "What the hell happened in this country?" Haywood asks shaking his fist at the air. "I've got to find out. I have to."
Still, if the play has sacrificed some narrative depth, it does maintain a fullness of legal and moral argument. The show's strength is in the courtroom scenes. They are of course written to raise provocative questions: What is the responsibility of individuals caught in a seemingly irresistible wave of evildoing? Were most Germans in the dark, as they claimed, about the purpose of Nazi camps? Would a conviction of the judges amount to a condemnation of all Germans? Politics is involved as well. During the trial the Russians invade Czechoslovakia, making conquered Germany a potentially pivotal American ally, perhaps not worth offending with a verdict based strictly on laws and moral imperatives.
So key questions apply to both the Germans on trial and Americans trying them. At what point does patriotism part company with virtue? What man is fit to judge another? On James Noone's set, three walls of dark, mirrored panels reinforce the idea that the issues can be viewed from many angles; at the same time the pure awfulness of mass murder hovers over the trials in photographs of unidentified victims projected across the mirrors like strips of celluloid. Against this backdrop the frantic rhetorical battle to define justice is staged by Mr. Tillinger at a tension-ratcheting gallop and skillfully performed by a company that includes Robert Foxworth as the American prosecutor; Joseph Wiseman and Michael Mastro as prosecution witnesses; Maximilian Schell as the leading defendant, Ernst Janning, a once unassailable jurist now tormented by his accession to Nazi edicts; and Michael Hayden as the German defense lawyer Oscar Rolfe, the role that 40 years ago made Mr. Schell a star.
This production may do the same for Mr. Hayden, whose square-shouldered, dark good looks recall the youthful Mr. Schell and whose poise and fervor as he mounts his increasingly persuasive defense are mesmerizing. His arguments -- that the judges merely acted according to existing law; that working within the system allowed them to help more people than they could have otherwise; and that placing blame on them is unfair when so many others are equally culpable -- take shape in a series of one-on-one confrontations.
Most notable are his cross-examinations of Mr. Wiseman, who plays Janning's former mentor, and of Mr. Mastro, as a twitchy, dimwitted laborer who was forcibly sterilized by the Nazis. His merciless bullying plays on the witnesses' most shameful secrets. And in Rolfe's face-offs with his personal icon, Janning, who disdains any defense because he's already found himself guilty, Mr. Hayden is facing off with an icon of his own. Neither the character nor the actor appears cowed.
The arrogance and surety of a young, gifted lawyer at a career-making threshold is so present in Mr. Hayden's performance that when he gives his summation, accusing the Vatican, Winston Churchill and American corporations that reaped war profits of complicity with the Nazis, the audience applauds as if he were the good guy. For his part Mr. Schell plays Janning as more openly pained, far less stoic than Burt Lancaster did so memorably in the film. 
That may be because stoicism plays well in close-up and is not so perceptible from the rear mezzanine, but in any case it changes the character of Janning, makes him more transparent in the way that melodrama is more transparent than drama.
Nonetheless, in the context of this production, that's not a bad thing. Mr. Schell is an imposing figure onstage, and as he makes Janning's inner crumbling outwardly visible, it gives the audience a visceral tug. When he and Mr. Hayden are nose to nose, the idea of his staring back at his own formidable youth yields a palpable tremor. These are representative moments in a play that gives oratory the muscle, sweat and high stakes of a last-man-standing prizefight. One only wishes it were more of a character-driven story and not merely a debate.

JUDGMENT AT NUREMBERG

By Abby Mann; directed by John Tillinger; set by James Noone; costumes by Jess Goldstein; lighting by Brian MacDevitt; original music and sound by David Van Tieghem; projections, Elaine J. McCarthy; production stage manager, Anita Ross; technical supervisor, Arthur Siccardi; production supervisor, Mitchell Erickson; general manager, Niko Associates Inc., Carl Pasbjerg; executive producer, Manny Kladitis; managing director, Fred Walker. Presented by the National Actors Theater, Tony Randall, founder and artistic director, in association with Earle I. Mack. At the Longacre Theater, 220 West 48th Street, Manhattan.

WITH: Maximilian Schell (Ernst Janning), George Grizzard (Judge Dan Haywood), Michael Hayden (Oscar Rolfe), Robert Foxworth (Colonel Parker), Marthe Keller (Mme. Bertholt), Joseph Wiseman (Dr. Wickert) and Michael Mastro (Rudolf Peterson).

HEADLINE: N.Y.U. Arts Scholarship Program Caps a Patron's Spending Spree 

BYLINE:  By DOREEN CARVAJAL 

 BODY:
Building on an extraordinary seven-month record of donations to the classical performing arts, Alberto W. Vilar, the Cuban-born high-tech investor and opera enthusiast, has pledged $20 million to New York University for an arts scholarship program that will draw students from around the world to New York City.
 The initiative, which is to be formally announced later this week, is to be modeled on the Rhodes scholarship program and will be headed by L. Jay Oliva, the outgoing president of N.Y.U., who promoted the concept to Mr. Vilar. 
 In an interview on Friday, Mr. Vilar recalled coming to Mr. Oliva's office for breakfast in September after reading his three-page proposal. "About six minutes into the meeting with breakfast rolls, I said, 'Let's just go to the terms; this works," ' he said. "We hadn't finished the eggs. I think the waiter was still cooking them in the kitchen." 
A patron of music, maestros and Verdi, Mr. Vilar has lavished money on favorite institutions and personalities for years, as well as on educational and health care organizations. But the last seven months have left many in the classical music world more than a little awestruck. 
In September he gave $14 million to the Kirov Opera and Ballet of St. Petersburg in Russia and $6 million for new productions at the Los Angeles Opera, with an additional $1 million a year for a young artists' program there. In December he gave $5 million to the Muiskverien Opera House in Vienna.
In January at Carnegie Hall Mr. Vilar and the conductor Lorin Maazel unveiled a $5 million competition and training program for young conductors. In February Mr. Vilar announced a gift of $50 million to the Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts in Washington for a training program for arts managers and annual visits there by the Kirov companies. In the same month the Washington Opera received $8 million for a training program for new artists and the production of an opera. 
Records at the Center on Philanthropy at Indiana University in Indianapolis, which has tracked high-level donors and their favorite charities since 1966, show that Mr. Vilar has no apparent rival for patronage of opera and performing arts.
"It's gloriously wonderful because he recognizes his obligations in terms of giving back to what he has an interest in, which is what philanthropists do," said Dwight F. Burlingame, associate executive director of the center.
In less than a decade Mr. Vilar has had a significant impact on institutions like the Metropolitan Opera, to which he has pledged $36 million for its endowment and productions; Carnegie Hall, to which he has committed $5.6 million to restore its Seventh Avenue facade; and the Salzburg Festival in Austria, to which he has contributed $15 million. Even the current fluctuations in the stock market have not slowed him.
Marc A. Scorcathe chief executive of Opera America, a Washington-based service organization for opera companies, said Mr. Vilar's largesse in the opera world is without peer.
"The benefits will accrue over time," he said, because Mr. Vilar has invested so heavily in programs for young artists. But just as important, he said, Mr. Vilar has raised the profile of charity to the arts.
The N.Y.U. program, which will be called the Alberto Vilar Global Fellows in the Performing Arts, will be open each year to as many as 20 incoming students studying voice, music, dance, composition, film and acting. 
Chosen by international panels, each of the the students will be eligible for $40,000 in annual stipends for the two-year program and will receive master's or other advanced degrees or certificates. They will receive an additional $10,000 each for room and board.
Mr. Oliva and his staff are looking for a site for the program near N.Y.U.'s new Helen and Martin Kimmel Center for University Life on Washington Square South. The headquarters will include space for performances, private practice rooms and student lounges. 
"This program is so uniquely, naturally brilliant," Mr. Vilar said in an interview in Mr. Oliva's campus office. "In a couple of years, when you say, 'I'm a Vilar scholar,' that means you came to the best school and the cultural center of the world. You've studied under a number of extraordinary specialists. You interacted with New York in this live laboratory."
Mr. Vilar, 60, a self-described billionaire and president and founder of Amerindo Investment Advisors, is not a graduate of N.Y.U. but took courses there in a doctoral program in mathematical economics that he never completed.
In his philanthropic career he has supported charities that reflect his passion for music and art education. He said that he had subsidized at least five programs to nurture the careers of young artists.
There is no particular force driving the recent spate of pledges except coincidence, Mr. Vilar insisted. In addition to the arts donations he has made in the last seven months, he has also contributed $10 million to the College of Physicians and Surgeons at Columbia University to create a neurological scholars' program.
When asked to explain his accelerated pace of giving, Mr. Vilar said: "I don't have a scientific answer. But I really worked for years, and I was really focused. Then maybe five, six, seven years ago, I began to say I'm in a position to do something in a large-scale way. And I have a very definitive agenda and of course my passion is music."
Mr. Vilar, who is divorced and has no children, said he had most of the perquisites he wanted in life -- homes in England and New York, a Colorado ski house -- and "it's nice to give the money away." He estimated that he had another decade ahead of adopting projects in his three favorite categories: performing arts, arts education and health care.
In the works, he added, are discussions about more gifts to create a department of philanthropy at his alma mater, Washington and Jefferson College in Washington, Pa., where he is underwriting a $15 million, 65,000-square-foot computer science center, the Vilar Center for Technology. He said he was also working on a donation to another "very large and very well-known academic institution" that would also finance an arts education program.
The charity donations have created a sideline at his financial offices in New York, where a staff of seven works on his philanthropy projects. Mr. Vilar said that he was dipping into his capital to finance his current charities, but that he had established a foundation through an offshore account in the Cayman Islands that he would allow to grow for the next 10 years. "It's got my name on it," he said.
Despite the downturn in technology stocks, Mr. Vilar does not intend to slacken his pace of gift-giving. His own flagship, Amerindo Technology D Fund, has fallen more than 80 percent since last March.
"I've been investing in technology for 30 years.," he said. "I've been investing in technology for 30 years. I was the first public investor in Microsoft, Cisco, AOL, you name it. Secondly, today you would say these stocks are down 50 percent, but in 1998-99 my firm was up 550 percent. The other thing that is important is that a philanthropist doesn't give away his last month's pay. He gives away part of his capital. So what you really say is, how much do I really want to give away? And that's a confidential answer." 
Early this year The Chronicle of Philanthropy and the online magazine Slate jointly published a list of the nation's top donors in 2000. Bill Gates and his wife, Melinda, topped the list with a $5 billion contribution to their foundation. 
But Mr. Vilar climbed his way to No. 19 with a total of more than $46 million, including his $14 million donation to the Kirov Opera and his gift to his alma mater.
More often than not, he has attached his name to his gifts. 
"With rare exceptions, there are very few large donations that are anonymous," he said. "They might have happened with the robber barons, but that was probably out of atonement." He noted bluntly that his aim was "to set an example for others."
"We all know a lot of people who could give and don't," he said.

HEADLINE: Analysts Give Fed Rate Cuts Mixed Review 

BYLINE:  Reuters 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 26 

 BODY:
Sizing up the Federal Reserve's policies over the last six months, a growing number of economists fear it has been too stingy in its interest rate cuts, a survey showed today.
 The survey by the National Association for Business Economics was taken in early March, before the Fed reduced interest rates by a half a percentage point last Tuesday. It was the third rate cut by the central bank this year. 
The poll of a panel of 267 members of the association indicated many were very concerned about the weakness in the economy and wanted the Fed to act aggressively.
"Goodbye Goldilocks," the association said in a summary of the survey results, referring to a shrinking number of economists who think Fed policy is not too hot nor too cold but "just right."
Even though the panelists would not have known with any certainty what the Fed was prepared to do last week, investors and many economists had widely predicted an interest rate cut.
"I think it's fair to say that one-third of our members would still view the Fed as being too tight," said David McClain, dean of the business school at the University of Hawaii and author of the survey.
At a news conference, Mr. McClain said the views represented a big change from other recent polls by the association.
In the latest survey, only 56 percent of the poll participants described the Fed's posture as "just right." That was the lowest percentage of economists agreeing with Fed policy in more than five years.
The last time the number was lower was in February 1996, when 51 percent of economists viewed policy as "about right." At the time, the economy was in a slowdown after a series of Fed rate increases in 1994-95.
As they did in 1996, most economists who disagreed with Fed policy felt it was "too restrictive." Thirty-four percent in the latest poll described it as such, compared with only 7 percent who said it was "too stimulative."
In 12 of the last 13 surveys, 74 percent to 86 percent of those polled viewed Fed policy as "about right," the association said.
In the latest survey, fully two-thirds of economists said they would prefer monetary policy over the next six months to be more stimulative.

HEADLINE: Foundation Grants Surged Last Year Despite Slowing Economy 

BYLINE:  By TAMAR LEWIN 

 BODY:
Despite year-end economic uncertainty, giving by foundations reached record levels last year, with ever-larger foundations changing both the scale and the scope of American philanthropy.
 According to an annual report to be released today by the Foundation Center, foundations gave out $27.6 billion last year, up more than 18 percent from 1999 -- the fifth straight annual double-digit increase. 
 "Foundations have grown so rapidly since the mid-1990's that not even a volatile stock market and slowing economy could keep them from posting record growth in grant dollars," said Sara Engelhardt, president of the Foundation Center, an independent clearinghouse on foundation data.
If stock prices continue to fall, shrinking the value of foundation holdings, a decline in grant-making will eventually follow. Still, Ms. Engelhardt said, the huge assets that foundations have amassed should help them weather a short-term downturn. From 1995 to 1999, foundation assets nearly doubled, to $449.6 billion from $226.7 billion, the report said. 
Without question, it has been an extraordinary era for philanthropy, with billions of dollars a year in new gifts flowing into existing foundations, some 10,000 new foundations formed, and vast gains in the value of the holdings of the largest independent foundations.
Whereas philanthropy tended to operate at the margins of policy throughout the 1970's, 80's and early 90's -- with most foundations dividing up grant money to support pilot studies, research reports or small community-based programs -- donors today increasingly practice "high impact" philanthropy, in which they look to transform an entire field. They have been led by George Soros, William H. Gates and Ted Turner, whose announcement in 1997 that he would donate $1 billion over 10 years to the United Nations gave philanthropy a new visibility. 
In the early 1990's, grants of $10 million were a rarity. And nationwide, most grants are still for $50,000 or less. Nevertheless, a big commitment is now one of more than $100 million. Last year the Lilly Endowment gave $105 million for genome research at Indiana University, double the size of any grant it had made in prior years. The Ford Foundation announced a $330 million global scholarship program, its largest grant ever. And the Bill and Melinda Gates Foundation started a $1 billion scholarship program for minority students.
"Traditionally, when foundations didn't have enough money to have a major impact on an issue, they tried to influence social policy," Ms. Engelhardt said. "Now people have been able to think bigger, and they tend to pick things where they can make a difference."
For the Gates Foundation, one such thing has been childhood vaccinations in the world's poorest countries, for which it pledged $750 million over five years. 
If an organization is new to philanthropy and needs to find a place where it can make a difference, "vaccinations are an obvious one," said Patricia Stonesipher, president of the Gates Foundation, the nation's largest, with an endowment of $20 billion. 
As with most of Gates's grants, the money will be funneled through existing organizations with experience in the field. But the scale of the money, $150 million a year, is enough to transform that field. At the United Nations Children's Fund, for example, the total budget for childhood vaccinations is only $100 million a year.
"The Gates contribution is a very significant sum of money, and coming after a decade of decline in foreign aid, it's very useful," said Carol Bellamy, executive director of Unicef. "But I hope people don't think it solves the whole problem, removing the need for further resources."
That is an understandable concern, said Dr. William Foege, chief medical adviser of the Gates Foundation, but what actually happens is that such significant sums only attract greater interest -- and resources -- from others.
"It just changes everything," Dr. Foege said.
That pattern has held true elsewhere. For example, the David and Lucile Packard Foundation's commitment to spend $175 million over five years to preserve open land in California has made a difference far beyond that sum alone. In November, halfway through the initiative, Packard reported that it had already protected 327,000 acres -- surpassing its goal of 250,000 -- and that the $96 million it had released had been supplemented by $245 million from other sources.
"Five years ago the total money, public and private, being spent on land conservation in California was on the order of magnitude of $50 million," said Steven J. McCormick, president of the Nature Conservancy. "It's changed so much so fast that it's hard to get adjusted." 
The new philanthropy is not without its critics.
"A lot of the new Gates-y foundations have become big so quickly that they have become wholesalers, spreading out big chunks of money through well-known organizations," said Pablo Eisenberg, who writes a column for the Chronicle of Philanthropy. "There's a tiny board, with no public accountability or understanding of the community."
Mr. Eisenberg questions whether the nation is getting good value for the tax exemption that philanthropists receive.
"Ten years ago the money given out through philanthropy was greater than the amount lost to taxes," he said, but that is no longer the case.
Others worry that the boom in private foundation spending may undercut government responsibility.
"What's happening now that's really interesting is that where foundations have as much money as the public sector, or more, there's starting to be an unhealthy role reversal, with public groups looking to foundations to take up the slack," said Catherine Cameron, executive director of the Wallace Global Fund. 
In a time of declining foreign aid, and increasing awareness of a global economy, foundations are taking on international roles.
At the Ford Foundation, where about 45 percent of the grant money goes to international work, Susan Berresford, the president, says she senses a far greater understanding that issues like the environment and health are global ones that cannot be addressed effectively in just one country. 
For the same reason, the Charles Stewart Mott Foundation, in Michigan, has opened offices in Johannesburg and Prague, and hired a program director in Ireland.
"We had always regarded ourselves as a Midwest local grant maker, but this is a logical extension of the work we were doing on the pursuit of peace," said William White, the foundation's president.
"Foundations are trying to figure out how to work together to spread the common values of democracy," Mr. White said. "In countries where they haven't had democracy before, there are great opportunities to go in and help them shape their not-for-profit sector."

HEADLINE: Brazil Flexes New Muscle In Another Trade Fight 

BYLINE:  By LARRY ROHTER 

DATELINE: BRASILIA 

 BODY:
First came a bitter trade dispute with Canada in which President Fernando Henrique Cardoso threatened, "If they want war, then war is war." Now Brazil's leaders are standing firm on another trade-related foreign policy issue, this time with the United States.
 The dispute with Washington has to do with patents on AIDS drugs. The one with Canada is over subsidies to aircraft makers and over mad cow disease. 
 What they have in common is the sight of Brazil as it sheds its image as eternally easygoing and cordial and suddenly flexes the muscles that naturally accrue to a regional power with 170 million people and a booming economy. 
"We're probably going to be seeing more of this assertiveness during the last 18 months of the Cardoso administration," said Riordan Roett, director of the Western Hemisphere Program at the Johns Hopkins School of Advanced International Studies. 
"The Brazilian government," he said, "feels that Brazil is entitled to much greater international recognition and more of a leadership role" because of the country's growing economic importance. 
In the dispute on AIDS drugs, the United States has filed a complaint with the World Trade Organization. It argues that a law here that would force foreign companies to provide their anti-AIDS drugs at lower prices, or license Brazilian companies to do so in the event of a health emergency, violates international trade rules. But Brazil shows no sign of backing down. 
"We will defend our case," Foreign Affairs Minister Celso Lafer said in an interview. "I think we are helped" not only by legal arguments based on Brazilian patent and intellectual property law but also by "what we believe is the moral dimension of our case."
Indeed, Brazil runs a highly successful program to fight AIDS, in part because it is able to provide drugs at prices below those charged by major pharmaceutical companies. The United Nations singled out the program for praise in early March. Many private groups have supported Brazil's stand, as have countries like South Africa and India, which have made similar challenges. 
In recent years, Brazil has been equally determined to defend Embraer, which builds commuter jets and military planes, against its main rival, Bombardier, the Canadian company. A new front in that conflict emerged in February when Canada suddenly announced a prohibition on imports of Brazilian beef, supposedly because of fears of mad cow disease. 
Brazilian officials argued that the beef ban was just an excuse to intimidate them in the aircraft dispute and gave Canada until March 1 to rescind the ban. 
When the Canadians finally gave Brazilian meat a clean bill of health on Feb. 27, the Cardoso administration was able to treat the event as a triumph and announced plans to file complaints of its own against Canada at the World Trade Organization. 
"This was a win-win situation for Cardoso, in that he got the attention of the Canadians and will probably get more attention at the upcoming summit than he would have otherwise," said Kenneth Maxwell, director of the Brazil project at the Council on Foreign Relations, referring to a gathering of Western Hemisphere leaders in April in Quebec. 
The agenda for that meeting focuses on liberalizing trade, in particular on an American proposal to create a Free Trade Area of the Americas as rapidly as possible, perhaps as early as 2003.
Brazil argues that a deadline of 2005 is more "adequate and appropriate," as Mr. Lafer put it, because of the complex issues involved. Brazil was almost alone in advocating a slower approach at first. But that position has now been endorsed by small Caribbean nations and by Ecuador, which becomes chairman of the trade talks in April.

HEADLINE: Congress Begins Planning for Increased Number of Uninsured as Economy Slows 

BYLINE:  By ADAM CLYMER and ROBERT PEAR 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 26 

 BODY:
A slowing economy and renewed double-digit inflation in health insurance costs are all but certain to cause an increase in the uninsured later this year and next, in the view of experts from foundations, business and consumer groups and the insurance industry.
 And while the issue is not now a major priority for the Bush administration or either party on Capitol Hill, Congress is beginning to consider tentative steps toward expanding coverage. 
 Republicans and a few Democrats are proposing tax credits to help people buy insurance, and Democrats and a few Republicans are seeking to expand participation in existing federally aided programs.
Still, Congressional action seems less certain than an increase in the number of uninsured, who totaled 42.5 million, or 14.2 percent of the population, in 1999, the last year for which statistics are available. Experts believe the numbers were stable in 2000. 
"You have to have grave concern about coverage," said Charles N. Kahn III, president of the Health Insurance Association of America. "We know from the past that when the economy slides and health care costs go up, that many employers find a need to reduce their benefits." 
Drew Altman, president of the Henry J. Kaiser Family Foundation, echoed his views and added that the situation "puts pressure on small employers." 
Those concerns are also reflected in the advice Congress is getting from its own experts. Kathryn G. Allen, a health policy expert in the General Accounting Office, said, "Any significant downturn in economic conditions would lead to resumption in the growth of the number of uninsured."
That growth, a steady pattern for more than a decade, came to a halt in 1999. The inflation of health care costs slowed in the late 1990's, and record-low unemployment led businesses, even at some low-wage companies, to offer health insurance and absorb premium increases to attract and keep workers.
From 1998 to 1999, the number of uninsured actually dropped by 1.7 million, while the number with private insurance, mostly through employers, climbed by 1.4 million. While authoritative statistics are not available for 2000, William S. Custer, associate professor of risk management and insurance research at Georgia State University, said he thought little had changed in 2000.
"It's really from now on that we would expect to see some changes," Mr. Custer said.
Another student of the uninsured, Larry Little, a vice president at Kaiser, said that in 2000 "the number of the uninsured either held steady or maybe went down a bit." 
In much of the country, labor is still tight. But Dan Danner, senior vice president for public policy at the National Federation of Independent Business, predicted that would change, saying, "As the market softens and there isn't fierce competition for employees in the marketplace, the result is that more small businesses will drop health care, and the uninsured will go up substantially." 
Many small employers were facing increased premiums of 15 percent this year, he said, and "there aren't very many small businesses whose sales are growing that fast." 
The economic fortunes of companies large and small are critical to trends in insurance coverage. Sixty-three percent of Americans get health insurance through an employer. Among the uninsured, more than 70 percent have an employed adult in the family but still have no coverage. Many work for small businesses that do not offer insurance or that require employees to pay more for coverage than they can afford. 
The uninsured are usually adults and are more likely than those with insurance to require hospitalization for conditions like diabetes and pneumonia, as well as more likely to have cancers diagnosed at a late stage. Surveys show that 40 percent of them skip recommended tests or treatments.
Mr. Altman said recognition of these differences was one important change in thinking about the uninsured since the 1993-94 effort by President Bill Clinton to insure all Americans. Now, he said, their problems are no longer dismissed with arguments like, " 'They are all kids. They are all healthy. They just go to emergency rooms.' "
Providing tax credits is one popular solution. President Bush has called for a $2,500 credit, though the administration has been working harder on other tax measures. Many proposals would apply only to more expensive individual policies. Others, like that of Senator James M. Jeffords, Republican of Vermont, seek to help the 7.3 million workers who decline employer-provided insurance.
There is sharp debate about whether tax credits would do much to reduce the number of uninsured. Senator Orrin G. Hatch, Republican of Utah, said a time lag of a year or so between buying insurance and getting the tax credit the next April 15 was a serious problem. Others contend credits would just provide subsidies to people who already buy insurance.
And some say the credits are too small. Iris J. Lav, deputy director of the Center on Budget and Policy Priorities, a liberal research and advocacy organization, said, "The proposed tax credits are typically of inadequate size to make insurance affordable for low- and moderate-income families." Proposed credits of $2,000 to $2,500 a year are for family policies that typically cost more than $6,000 a year, Ms. Lav said. Even with the credit, a family making $30,000 a year would have to spend 10 percent to 15 percent of its income to buy health insurance, she said.
The Congressional Budget Office, in a report last June, said that tax subsidies "would have to be fairly large -- approaching the full cost of the premium -- to induce a large proportion of the uninsured population to buy insurance." 
But Representative Nancy L. Johnson, the Connecticut Republican who heads the House Ways and Means Subcommittee on Health, argued that adequate family policies could be bought for only $3,000. Janet S. Trautwein, director of Federal Policy Analysis and State Government Affairs for the National Association of Health Underwriters, agreed, saying that in most states a plan covering a single mother and two children could be bought for less than $2,600. 
In Connecticut, Ms. Trautwein's data showed, such a plan would cost $2,536 and the family would have to pay the first $750 in bills as a deductible. In North Carolina it would cost $2,652, but with a $2,000 deductible. In New York, such a plan could not be found for less than $3,820, though with only a $250 deductible.
The preferred Democratic approach is to put more money into Medicaid and into the Children's Health Insurance Program, and to encourage states to open them up to uninsured adults, especially the easily located parents of already covered children. Three states -- New Jersey, Rhode Island and Wisconsin -- already do so.
But Mr. Hatch, for one, argued that with the children's insurance program -- which insures children not so poor as to qualify for Medicaid -- only reaching about a third of the nine million eligible children now, it does not need new burdens.
His frequent Democratic collaborator on health issues, Senator Edward M. Kennedy of Massachusetts, disagreed. He said that since insurance was often the first thing to go in a slowing economy, "We should move now to expand the Children's Health Insurance Program to cover low-income working parents and not just their children."
One solution is to put money into both tax credits and an expansion of the children's program, and both Representative Johnson and Senator Charles E. Grassley of Iowa, chairman of the Senate Finance Committee, said they favored that approach. But Mr. Grassley noted that his committee has many other priorities, and was uncertain when anything would be done. 
Mr. Hatch observed that even with health care, Congress faced other difficult issues, including a Medicare overhaul, prescription drugs, a patients' bill of rights and medical records privacy. He argued that long-range costs were a problem for the federal government and for the states, too, since they pay a share of the costs of Medicaid and the children's program. 
One unreconstructed advocate of universal health insurance, Senator John D. Rockefeller IV, Democrat of West Virginia, complained that in Congress, "You crush the present by invoking the future." 
"I'm willing to consider the future," he said, but "I want to do something now."

HEADLINE: Pension Fund Drop May Require New Government Contributions 

BYLINE:  By JAMES C. McKINLEY Jr. 

DATELINE: ALBANY, March 26 

 BODY:
With the stock market deflating, the state comptroller, H. Carl McCall, warned today that the state, county and municipal governments might have to resume contributing to pension benefits for their employees.
 The state suspended government contributions three years ago as the boom on Wall Street pushed state pension funds to unheard-of heights. But Mr. McCall said those giddy times were over. 
 "You've all seen what happened with the stock market," Mr. McCall said at a news conference. "And given the fact the stock market has performed way below everyone's expectations, and that every sector of our economy has been affected by that, it is quite possible there could be an increase" in payments by local governments.
New York City employees and teachers are covered by other retirement funds.
A year ago, the state pension fund totaled $127 billion, but at the end of December, it had fallen to $121 billion. The fund's investments in common stock lost more than $7 billion over the same period.
The market has continued to take a beating in the first three months of this year, though it will remain unclear how much damage has been done until the comptroller's office evaluates the fund again on March 31.
Mr. McCall, who oversees the pension fund, predicted that local governments might have to start paying 1 to 1.5 percent of their payroll to the retirement system. He said a decision would be made within a few weeks, based on a complex actuarial formula.
"What would happen," he said, "based on the performance of the pension fund: if there needs to be additional costs, those additional costs would come from employers, not the employees."
When Mr. McCall became comptroller in 1993, government employees paid 6 percent of their paychecks to the fund. But their contribution declined as the fund prospered.
At present, the most senior employees pay nothing to the retirement system. Only those with less than 10 years' experience contribute, at a rate of 3 percent.
The state constitution prohibits the state from rolling back retirement benefits, so employers would have to pick up the slack should the pension fund be underfunded at the end of the fiscal year, March 31, Mr. McCall's aides said.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST 

 BODY:
Baseball Fans to Be Charged For Internet Broadcasts
Major League Baseball said that it would begin charging fans to listen to broadcasts of its games over the Internet, a stark illustration of how content owners are trying to find business models that work in the online medium.
 The plan, which will cost $9.95 for a full season of games, signals an end to the ability of fans to get free radio feeds of baseball games online. Baseball fans, and sports fans in general, have used the Web to listen to play-by-play of their hometown teams in areas outside of the local radio station's range. Page C4. 

Groups Join Doctors in Insurer Suit
The state medical associations of California, Georgia and Texas joined individual doctors from seven states -- Alabama, California, Colorado, Florida, Georgia, Kentucky and Texas -- in a federal lawsuit that accused eight health insurers, including Aetna and Cigna, of engaging in "a pattern of racketeering activity" to deny necessary medical care. C13.

Two Chip Makers Announce Layoffs
Conexant Systems and PMC-Sierra said that they planned to dismiss hundreds of workers and also said that sales this quarter would lag behind already reduced forecasts because demand for communications chips is falling. Conexant said it was eliminating 1,500 jobs and 125 contract employees, about 20 percent of its work force. PMC-Sierra will dismiss 230 employees, or 13 percent of its staff. Shares of Conexant dropped 63 cents, to $10.50. PMC-Sierra fell $1.68 to $32.26. C4.

Higher Power Rates Are Proposed
California's chief power regulator proposed large increases in retail electric rates to help finance the state's spiraling energy costs and encourage conservation that could help avoid more blackouts during the summer. A12.

Blue Chips Rise, but Nasdaq Falls
Blue-chip stocks rose as investors snapped up big consumer and industrial names, but technology stocks slid. The Dow Jones industrial average gained 182.75 points, or 1.9 percent, to 9,687.53. The Nasdaq composite index lost 10.19 points, or 0.5 percent, to 1,918.49. The broader Standard & Poor's 500-stock index rose 12.86 points, or 1.1 percent, to 1,152.69. C14.

G.E. in Talks to Sell Satellite Unit
General Electric is close to selling its satellite services unit to Societe Europeenne des Satellites of Luxembourg for $5 billion in cash and stock, executives close to the talks said. C14.

MarchFirst to Eliminate 3,500 Jobs
MarchFirst is expected to announce layoffs of up to 50 percent of its work force, or about 3,500 employees, by the end of this week, executives close to the company said. C7.

New Campaign for Old Favorite
A $7 million multimedia campaign for Keds sneakers is appealing to women's memories of the shoes as it seeks to reconnect the brand with consumers and position the footwear as a fashion icon. At the same time, the sneakers have been updated to increase comfort for their now-older clientele and to align them with fashion trends. Advertising. C13.

Suit Against Amway Resurrected
A federal appeals court panel has resurrected a suit that Procter & Gamble had filed against Amway, accusing it of not doing enough to stop its distributors from spreading a rumor that P.& G. has ties to Satanism. C8.

Home Sales Decreased in February
Sales of new and previously owned homes fell in February, but the housing market remained one of the strongest areas in the nation's sluggish economy, two reports showed. C8.

HEADLINE: The Big City; 
In Education, Making More Out of Less

BYLINE:  By JOHN TIERNEY 

 BODY:
THESE days a casual observer might believe that New York is primed for education reform. Parents are voting on a radical plan to privatize five schools, and the candidates for mayor are declaring education to be their chief passion. One of them, Alan G. Hevesi, is already on television with an advertisement promising to "put education first."
 But if you listen to what the candidates are actually saying about schools, it's hard to imagine what is going to change. Most of their proposals could have been written 20 years ago by the teachers' union: more teachers, higher teacher salaries, smaller classes, higher taxes. Meanwhile, they're ignoring the evidence that something new is needed to fix New York City's schools. 
 The latest evidence is a study, released by New York University last week, comparing the local public and Roman Catholic schools. Because the two school system are so extensive -- nearly 300 Catholic schools below the high school level and more than 900 public schools -- New York offers probably the best chance in America to compare two large systems with different educational approaches operating in the same neighborhoods.
Compared with the city's public schools, Catholic schools have larger classes, lower-paid teachers and much smaller budgets. The Catholic system spends only half as much per student as the public system (and that total for the public schools doesn't even include all the money spent by the Board of Education on special education, administrative overhead, and extras like food and transportation.) 
Yet the Catholic school students scored consistently higher on tests, especially in poor neighborhoods, according to the N.Y.U. study. It was done by Raymond Domanico, an independent researcher who was formerly director of data analysis for the Board of Education. 
When comparing just low-income schools from both systems, where 90 percent of students qualify for a subsidized lunch, Mr. Domanico found that Catholic school students were more likely to pass both reading and math exams. The most dramatic difference was on the eighth-grade reading exam, which 35 percent of students in Catholic schools passed, versus 17 percent in public schools.
Mr. Domanico found a similar pattern when comparing schools where 90 percent of students were African-American or Hispanic. Those overwhelmingly black and Hispanic Catholic schools not only did significantly better than similar public schools, but they also scored slightly higher than the remaining, more integrated public schools (where 43 percent of students were white or Asian). 
THOSE results are remarkable -- and remember, they were achieved at half the cost of what the public schools spend. But the education establishment responded with the usual excuses, like the argument that Catholic schools attract families more dedicated to education.
It is an oddly self-effacing argument: if you really believe that higher paid public-school teachers are essential for children, why assume that the most dedicated parents are sending their kids to lower-paid teachers in Catholic schools? True, parents who send their kids to Catholic schools are sufficiently dedicated to pay tuition. But other studies have avoided this bias by tracking students awarded scholarships by lottery to attend Catholic schools, and the resulting test-score comparisons (between the lottery winners and the losers, who remained in public schools) have also been damning to public schools.
Public educators may not see what makes Catholic schools work, but the answer seems obvious to parents who choose them -- and to economists who analyze the behavior of monopolies. Catholic schools must please parents in order to survive. They can't tolerate lazy teachers, chaotic classrooms, restrictive work rules, bloated bureaucracies. They have to compete for students and money. 
New York City public schools do not. As long as the teachers unions remain powerful, as long as city politicians provide budget increases, it doesn't really matter how many students flee. Each departure means one less student and desk to worry about, and therefore more money for administrators' desks and teachers' raises. 
In other cities, politicians have concluded that competition is just as crucial in education as in any other industry. Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani has tried injecting competition here, most recently by inviting Edison Schools to take over five of the city's schools, but even that small experiment is too radical for the Democratic mayoral candidates to embrace. They prefer to promise more money.

HEADLINE: Contract Gains Ease Sting of Layoffs for Auto Workers 

BYLINE:  By KEITH BRADSHER 

DATELINE: KENOSHA, Wis. 

 BODY:
Joe Salazar, a machine repairman at the Chrysler engine factory here, has made one sacrifice as overtime has disappeared and layoffs have begun: he has postponed the purchase of a Dodge Ram pickup to replace his bright red Dodge Durango.
 But hold the pity. That Durango is just two years old, and his 20-foot powerboat is ready on Lake Michigan. "If I got laid off," he shrugged, "I'd go fishing." 
 Mr. Salazar's confidence appears justified. For most of the last century, auto workers have borne the brunt of economic slumps, laid off by the hundreds of thousands during recessions with limited compensation that ran out quickly. But this bout of hard times, while bringing swift layoffs with little severance pay in many industries, is proving far less harsh in auto factories. 
Not only are benefits vastly improved, but auto workers are older and wiser -- and have bigger nest eggs. While other unions struggled in the 1990's, the United Automobile Workers used its strength to win a long list of benefits. As a result, Chrysler's much-publicized layoffs are not likely to inflict nearly as much hardship as other dismissals.
Dismissed workers draw roughly two-thirds of straight-time pay for 42 weeks, through a mix of state and company payments. They then resume drawing full pay -- nearly $50,000 a year -- until the end of the current contract, in September 2003. They also stay in one of the nation's best private health plans.
Chrysler is insulated from the costs of its generous unemployment benefits because its labor contracts have forced it to set aside money for the last decade. 
The pay and benefits were much different at the end of the 1980's, when employment in auto factories here plunged from 12,000 to 2,000, making this city on Lake Michigan between Chicago and Milwaukee a symbol of the industry's woes. Chrysler laid off 5,500 when it closed an assembly plant in 1988, and many received just a few months of company payments to supplement unemployment checks. Their health insurance lapsed too, leaving many stuck in a town that offered few high-paying jobs.
"We went without insurance for a while, to the point that the kids couldn't go skiing because we didn't want them to break body parts," said Jeanie Kukawski, a loan officer at the union-affiliated credit union here. Her husband, Wally, was laid off by Chrysler for six years, helping her paint and sell folk art before being called back.
So generous are the provisions now that they have provoked envy in many blue-collar neighborhoods. The local daily newspaper, The Kenosha News, has published several letters bemoaning that laid-off auto workers earn more than many neighbors who are still working.
"It's really hard to feel sorry for them because you're thinking, 'They're living in a house I could never live in,' " said Glenn R. Woods, 45, a nonunion robot repairman.
Many of Mr. Woods's high school classmates did get union jobs, mainly through relatives. "You've got generations of factory people who don't know what it's like to be on the outside," he said.
To be sure, the cutbacks have frightened many workers, and caught others unprepared. Debbie Guzman, who machines engine cylinder heads, took a beauty-shop job when Chrysler laid her off from 1988 to 1997. She splurged after returning to a $23-an-hour job with lots of overtime, and is now struggling on a smaller paycheck.
"I bought a truck, I bought a van, I bought a house and I almost maxed out my credit cards," said Ms. Guzman, who proudly bore a black windbreaker with her union logo when she showed up for an afternoon shift. "I need the overtime."
Losing overtime hurts. "Compared with last year, when we made $100,000, this year we'll make $50,000 or $60,000," said Dave Laurich, 37, who makes precision tools.
But even $50,000 goes a long way in a community where a steak dinner for two, with wine, still runs less than $40 at the Marina Garden Restaurant. The median home -- typically a three-bedroom ranch -- sold for just $128,000 late last year.
The workers' plight this time is also eased by simple demographics -- the average age is about 50. Few have been hired since the 1980's, as the market share of General Motors, Ford and Chrysler has fallen, and as robots have replaced retirees.
Many workers are thus well along in preparing for retirement. Since workers here tend to start families young, many have also finished paying for their children's college education, often helped by generous U.A.W.-negotiated tuition subsidies.
"The kids are out of the house, many of them have the second home paid for," said Don Gillespie, president of the A.M. Credit Union, whose board is made up of auto union members. Although Chrysler began its layoffs in February, most of those dismissed are in excellent financial shape, and the credit union has had to make only one loan so far.
Many workers, scarred by past layoffs, have been squirreling money away. "I've been saving for a long time -- this doesn't bother me a bit," said Les Vincent, 53, a machine repairman, adding, "1982 was when I put my first check in an I.R.A."
Andy Palmen, the local Chrysler and Dodge dealer, said his sales to Chrysler workers had dropped, but no more than his other sales. The workers "have been able to work quite a bit in the last few years," he said. "They looked at this as an opportunity to get ahead."
John Drew, president of the local U.A.W. chapter, acknowledged that many workers were skeptical when told of the benefits now available, because they remember how bad it was last time.
In 1988, Chrysler had set aside little money for supplemental payments. But in each of the four contracts since, the U.A.W. has insisted that Chrysler put aside large sums. The various unemployment funds now total almost $1.3 billion.
That works out to roughly $100,000 for each of the 12,500 U.A.W. workers being laid off, including about 600 here. The money should be ample, barring additional broad layoffs, because 3,000 to 4,000 Chrysler workers are also retiring each year, and laid-off workers will replace them. Chrysler is offering $35,000 retirement bonuses to speed the process.
Chrysler is also laying off several thousand unionized workers in Canada, who receive similar benefits. It is dismissing 3,600 workers in Mexico and South America, who receive few jobless benefits, and has pushed 2,300 white-collar workers to take early retirement and laid off 2,700.
Factory workers with less than a year of seniority are not eligible for the many unemployment benefits. But the factory here has hired virtually no workers since the late 1970's except for a few skilled specialists, like robot repairmen, and they are not being laid off.
More senior workers whose full pay returns 42 weeks into a layoff can be asked to perform community service or other tasks. G.M.'s Saturn division already has nearly 150 laid-off workers in Wilmington, Del., who are using skills like carpentry and electrical repair to help local nonprofit groups.
Laid-off factory workers' chances of being called back to a job in their hometown someday are much higher than in the 1980's because Chrysler is not permanently closing any factories this time. The current contract specifies for the first time that DaimlerChrysler, Chrysler's parent, "will not close, nor partially or wholly sell, spin off, split off, consolidate, or otherwise dispose of in any form" any factory or unit represented by the autoworkers' union.
DaimlerChrysler agreed to the provision in September 1999, because it was extremely profitable then and because it set a precedent for the U.A.W. to insist on a similar provision at Ford, which was spinning off its parts subsidiary. But Ford negotiated the spin-off as part of its contract anyway.
A DaimlerChrysler executive who insisted on anonymity said the contract language received limited scrutiny in 1999 because no one anticipated that Chrysler's operations would develop serious problems so quickly. DaimlerChrysler now rues the commitment and fears the union outsmarted it, the executive said.
"It was a suicide pact, it was the most foolhardy thing imaginable, and it shows how out of touch people were with reality," he said.
But all these provisions have not reassured some workers, like Ms. Guzman, 45. She frets that if laid off, she might never find another job or be left with little when the current contract expires. Other local employers have also been laying off workers, notably Motorola, across the state line in northern Illinois.
Ms. Guzman has 27 years of seniority -- U.A.W. negotiators have made sure workers continue accumulating seniority and pension benefits even during yearslong layoffs -- and that could make other employers leery of hiring her.
That is because of a quirk in the contract that gives Chrysler the right to demand that workers show up within five business days when called back from layoffs, even if they haven't worked there for years. Workers who do not show up may lose their place. So employers here who hire Chrysler workers risk losing them on short notice.
Asked whether she would return to work if laid off, even if she had found another job, Ms. Guzman responded emphatically, "I would."
John Milisauskas, manager of the Kenosha County Job Center, said the average wage of available local jobs over the last eight months was $10.63 -- far less than Chrysler workers are used to. But while some employers have reservations about giving jobs to Chrysler workers, others do not, and the choice of jobs has become much more diverse since the 1980's, when this was still a fairly insular factory town.
The county now has 23,000 people who commute to jobs elsewhere, mainly in northern Illinois, while 36,000 live and work in the county, Mr. Milisauskas said.
High wages do not hurt American automakers as much as in the 1980's, because their main rivals now manufacture many cars here and pay the same wages. But foreign automakers provide less-generous benefits, notably for health care.
Mr. Salazar said that while a layoff might seem to some like a paid vacation, it could be stressful. "We want to be normal people, working and having fun," he said. "Nobody wants to be laid off, believe me."
The workers here are waiting for the overtime to return and fretting about who might be laid off next.
Raffaella Laurenzi, who installs engine blocks, continues to eat out, but has made one sacrifice -- her annual vacation in Italy to visit family. "They wanted me to go this year," she said, but I said, "I'm sorry, I can't go. I'm short of money."

But Debbie Guzman, who machines engine cylinder heads, said the loss of overtime had already made her a bit nervous about her financial future. (Photographs by John Saller for The New York Times)(pg.
