HEADLINE: Bush Team's Counsel Is Divided on Foreign Policy 

BYLINE:  By JANE PERLEZ 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 26 

 BODY:
Two competing foreign policy camps are emerging in the Bush administration -- an ideologically conservative Pentagon and a more moderate State Department -- which have already provided President Bush conflicting advice on central issues.
 At the Pentagon, Secretary of Defense Donald H. Rumsfeld is collecting a hard-line group of advisers who have supported arming the Iraqi opposition to overthrow President Saddam Hussein and who are deeply skeptical of the European effort to form a rapid deployment force alongside NATO. 
 On the other side of the river, at the State Department, Secretary of State Colin L. Powell stepped out in front on Iraq with ideas to modify sanctions, but found his policy belittled at the Pentagon. Although he is a product of the Pentagon, he has usually been a cautious warrior.
In a sign of the back-biting, European diplomats were told by Paul D. Wolfowitz, deputy secretary of defense and one of the most avid backers of the Iraqi opposition, not to consider the State Department's description of sanctions policy to be the last word, and to be wary of its more accommodating stance on the European force, officials said. 
On other issues, the State Department appears to be more open than the Pentagon to possible missile negotiations with North Korea. On Russia and China, too, General Powell is likely to place more emphasis on working with allies than is Mr. Rumsfeld, who has a history of supporting a unilateral approach.
"At some point the president is going to have to decide what foreign policy he wants, because he is not going to get consistent options on many issues," a senior administration official said.
In an ideal world, there is nothing wrong with the president's receiving clashing recommendations -- as long as the differences are discussed in private and the president's decisions, once made, are carried out, this official said. Indeed, all administrations endure policy debates, but try to prevent them from becoming public ideological cleavages. 
Although the administration is still in its relatively early days, there is evidence that the disputes are unlikely to be kept quiet, in part because of the strong ideological undercurrents.
Word has gone out to conservative writers and think tanks from administration hard-liners to "keep up the pressure," a think tank policy analyst said.
Mr. Bush, who is inexperienced in foreign affairs, has acknowledged that he will rely on his most senior policy advisers. So as the competition among them intensifies, Vice President Dick Cheney, who collected his own foreign policy specialists, more powerful than any gathered by previous vice presidents, is likely to be an important arbiter.
From the State Department, at least, Mr. Cheney is seen as leaning more toward the Pentagon, where he served as secretary of defense under President Bush's father.
The national security adviser, Condoleezza Rice, who has projected herself as a policy coordinator rather than a policy maker, also prides herself on having Mr. Bush's ear. So far, Ms. Rice's predilections in the interdepartmental rivalry are not clear.
As Mr. Rumsfeld selects a markedly conservative group of officials to serve under him and as General Powell chooses a more moderate lineup heavily dominated by career Foreign Service officers, the battle lines seem sharply drawn.
Mr. Rumsfeld, for example, has selected Douglas J. Feith for the chief policy job at the Pentagon, officials said. Mr. Feith, who served in the Reagan Pentagon, is close to Richard Perle, a neoconservative who served the Reagan administration and is on the board of the Center for Security Policy, a conservative defense analysis group. The position of assistant secretary for international security affairs has gone to Peter W. Rodman, a staff member at the Nixon Center who is viewed as a conservative on Russian and European issues.
In contrast, General Powell chose Richard Haass, an advocate of sanctions reform and an opponent of arming the Iraqi opposition, as the head of policy planning at the State Department. Mr. Haass is another veteran of the previous Bush White House and has served as director of foreign policy studies at the Brookings Institution.
For the most part, General Powell has turned aside suggestions of hiring ideologically driven Republican loyalists for the State Department.
"It is very clear that Rumsfeld wants a Pentagon populated with a conservative team who see themselves in a policy clash with Powell -- and they are gearing up for it," said Robert Kagan, a fellow at the Carnegie Endowment for International Peace and columnist at the conservative Weekly Standard.
"It's fair to say that this is shaping up into a Shultz-Weinberger battle royal of the Reagan administration," he said, referring to the policy and personal frictions between Secretary of State George P. Shultz and Secretary of Defense Caspar Weinberger.
In the current situation, though, the principal players -- General Powell, Mr. Rumsfeld and Ms. Rice -- have by all accounts maintained cordial personal relationships going back a long time. There is none of the personal animosity that permeated the Shultz-Weinberger relationship, colleagues say. The three players have been meeting once a week for lunch and check in with each other on the phone every morning at 7:15.
But on policy issues, in contrast to what was expected, the new group re-creates the ideological divisions within the Reagan foreign policy team rather than the more cohesive approach of those who served President Bush's father.
Tests of how the competing spheres are reconciled will come in several areas: Iraq, where a new sanctions policy is being formed; Taiwan, where the battle will be over selling advanced weapons; Russia, where the fight will be over how to deal with Moscow on missile defense; the Balkans, over how far to assist the Europeans in peacekeeping; and North Korea, where the question is whether to pursue missile talks begun under President Clinton.
Mr. Rumsfeld has said that the European deployment force makes him nervous because he sees it as possibly weakening NATO. 
General Powell said last month that the United States went into the Balkans with its NATO allies and would leave with them. So far Mr. Rumsfeld has not addressed this issue.
Administration officials say they have now started the policy review on Iraq even though many of the senior posts at the Pentagon and the State Department are yet to be filled. 
Mr. Cheney's shop is also playing a role. His national security adviser, I. Lewis Libby, has shown sympathy toward arming the Iraqi opposition against Mr. Hussein, while at the National Security Council itself, one assistant on the Middle East, Kenneth Pollack, who openly opposed arming the opposition, has left. 
At the State Department, much of the sanctions policy is based on assessments drawn up by Mr. Haass, who has said economic sanctions should be eased to stop punishing the Iraqi people, while financial and military sanctions should be tightened. 
To this end, the State Department has proposed to states neighboring Iraq that United Nations monitors be posted on their borders as well as at key foreign airports to prevent Mr. Hussein from importing materials that would help him manufacture weapons of mass destruction. 
At the Pentagon, however, Mr. Wolfowitz has made it fairly clear that he believes sharpening sanctions is probably not possible, and that trying to topple President Hussein is more desirable.

HEADLINE: J.& J. Deal For Alza Is Seen Close 

BYLINE:  By MELODY PETERSEN and ANDREW ROSS SORKIN 

 BODY:
Johnson & Johnson is expected to announce today that it will acquire the Alza Corporation, a fast-growing concern that creates alternative ways to deliver medicine to the human body, for $11.8 billion in stock, executives close to the deal said.
 The transaction, which the boards of both companies approved late yesterday, is intended to bolster Johnson & Johnson's prescription drug business amid increased competition. 
 Johnson & Johnson, the drug giant and maker of consumer health products, has struggled over the last year to overcome the loss of one of its best sellers, the heartburn drug Propulsid, which the company took off the market after it was linked to heart problems and dozens of deaths.
Two of Johnson & Johnson's other major drugs -- Procrit, a medication for anemia, and Risperdal, for schizophrenia -- face increasing competition from competitors. 
By acquiring Alza, which developed the technology behind the Nicoderm nicotine patches sold by GlaxoSmithKline, Johnson & Johnson, of New Brunswick, N.J., the sixth-largest seller of prescription drugs in the United States, will gain access to technology and a research-and-development team that has repeatedly succeeded in finding better ways to deliver medicine to the human body.
For example, Alza's newest drug, Concerta, is similar to Ritalin, the treatment for attention deficit disorder in children. Ritalin and similar drugs must generally be taken more than once a day. Concerta is a time-release product, which works for 12 hours. For children who take drugs for attention deficit disorder, Concerta eliminates the midday visit to the nurse's office for more medicine.
Under the terms of the transaction, Johnson & Johnson agreed to pay Alza 0.49 share for each share of Alza, or $41.83, the executives said. The stock ratio is fixed, they said, and there is no "collar" on the deal that would alter the transaction amount if the stock price of either company were to fluctuate.
The price represents a 39 percent premium to Alza's share price of $30.05 on Friday. Alza stock jumped $8.70 yesterday, or almost 29 percent, to $38.75, after The Wall Street Journal and The Financial Times reported that the two companies were in talks. Shares of Johnson & Johnson fell $2.83, or 3.4 percent, to $85.38.
Spokesmen for both companies declined to comment yesterday.
Alza, which is based in Mountain View, Calif., sold $432 million of prescription drugs in the United States last year, according to IMS Health, a company that tracks pharmaceutical sales -- an increase of more than 90 percent over such sales the previous year. Alza is the 42nd-largest prescription drug seller in the United States.
Alza introduced Concerta in August, at the start of the school year, and the drug already has 23 percent of revenue among attention-deficit-disorder treatments, IMS Health indicated. Analysts expect more than $200 million in Concerta sales this year. Ditropan XL, Alza's drug for patients with overactive bladders, is also expected to exceed $200 million in sales this year.
Wall Street analysts said yesterday that they were still trying to get more details on the deal, but they generally approved of it.
Neil B. Sweig, of Ryan, Beck & Company, said that the acquisition would hurt Johnson & Johnson's earnings in the short term, but that both companies could benefit. Alza would gain the help of Johnson & Johnson's much-larger sales force, he said, while Johnson & Johnson could add products to its pipeline.
"This could prove very beneficial over the next 10 years to J.& J.," Mr. Sweig said. 
One problem for Alza, he said, is determining how to manage the myriad of agreements it has with competitors of Johnson & Johnson. Alza has developed or is developing new delivery systems for many different prescription drugs. 
While Johnson & Johnson has made dozens of acquisitions over the last five years, a deal with Alza would be by far its largest. Until now, the company's biggest deal was in 1999, when it acquired Centocor Inc., a biotechnology concern that sells ReoPro, a popular anti-clotting drug used in angioplasty, for about $5 billion in stock.
Johnson & Johnson and Alza are not new to each other; J.& J helps Alza sell Concerta under a joint marketing agreement, and Alza receives royalties from Johnson & Johnson's sale of Duragesic, a skin patch for chronic pain.
Abbott Laboratories tried to acquire Alza in 1999, but the companies abandoned the deal after the Federal Trade Commission expressed concern about the potential monopoly they might have had in sales of drugs for prostate cancer.
Among a wide variety of consumer products, Johnson & Johnson makes Tylenol and Band-Aids. It also has a large medical-device business, but has been focusing more on sales of prescription drugs because of their higher profit margins.

CORRECTION-DATE: March 28, 2001

 CORRECTION:
A chart in Business Day yesterday comparing Johnson & Johnson with a company it plans to buy -- the Alza Corporation, a maker of alternative ways of delivering medicine to the body -- referred incorrectly to Procrit, a drug for anemia. It is made by Johnson & Johnson, not Alza.

HEADLINE: BOOKS OF THE TIMES; 
Giving Street Urchins A Ticket to a New Life

BYLINE:  By RICHARD BERNSTEIN 

 BODY:
ORPHAN TRAINS
The Story of Charles Loring Brace and the Children He Saved and Failed
By Stephen O'Connor
Illustrated. 362 pages. Houghton Mifflin. $27.
 For some 80 years the orphan trains described in Stephen O'Connor's book took stray and destitute children from New York's grim slums to the countryside, where they were chosen by farmers, artisans and merchants for employment or adoption. The scenes Mr. O'Connor evokes seem strange by today's standards: hundreds of newly transported children, most of them boys, being picked by strangers for what was intended to be redemptive labor, a new life-saving chance. 
 And yet, as Mr. O'Connor points out in "Orphan Trains," his insightful and fascinating piece of social history, that practice, which lasted until about 1930, was the immediate predecessor to today's foster care system.
In chronicling one of the first ambitious, privately sponsored social welfare programs in the United States, Mr. O'Connor provides an absorbing portrait of the nation at a moment of wrenching change, a moment that has in many ways not yet passed. Mr. O'Connor's last book, "Will My Name Be Shouted Out?," was also about children, ones he got to know while teaching creative writing in blighted areas of New York. In "Orphan Trains" Mr. O'Connor extends that interest backward, illustrating some of the special features of American life and history. 
He tells the stories of individual children who were on the orphan trains, from John Brady, who became governor of Alaska, to Charley Miller, who was hanged for the murder of two young men on a freight train. He writes a concise economic history of New York to account for the sudden emergence of homeless, destitute children during the first third of the 19th century. He explains the theological thinking that influenced the changing American perceptions of children, from congenitally corrupted creatures that needed to be set straight through sternness and discipline to innocent creatures corrupted by an evil world. And, while he shows what went wrong with the ambitious orphan train effort, Mr. O'Connor maintains a firm, non-utopian grasp of reality, avoiding the mistake of imposing today's judgments on yesterday's actors.
The book's main protagonist is the great, flawed visionary pioneer Charles Loring Brace, a complicated, contradictory minister and former journalist from Connecticut who wanted to be famous and to do good. "During the early 19th century, when, for better and for worse, one's moral character occupied a place in the public imagination akin to 'fitness' and 'success' today," Mr. O'Connor writes, "certain expansive natures" responded "to moral challenges the way contemporary joggers respond to marathons, or venture capitalists to promising start-ups." The author gives a keen sense of Brace as one of those expansive natures who found his life's work among New York's poor just before and in the decades after the Civil War.
"Orphan Trains" provides a gripping description of the urban disintegration that prevailed, especially in New York; family violence; infectious disease; unemployment; and alcoholism. "Throughout the 19th century," Mr. O'Connor writes, "between 20 and 30 percent of children became orphans before age 15, but only one-third of the children living in orphanages had lost both parents." In other words, poverty led many families, in Mr. O'Connor's words, "to park their children during family crises." It was against this background that Brace -- who at 25 was imprisoned on ridiculous charges for a month during a trip to Hungary -- became America's pioneer children's advocate.
His approach differed from that of later social welfare advocates in many of the ways that the 19th century differed from the 20th. In 1853 he became director of the newly created Children's Aid Society, and among his earliest and most successful programs was what came to be called the Newsboy Lodging House, created to help get New York's large squadrons of urchin newsboys off the streets.
The lodging was not free, nor was anything that Brace created later, because he seemed to anticipate the problem of welfare dependency and addressed it by treating the beneficiaries of his services as independent contractors, expected to work and to pay for what they got. This included children, because, as Mr. O'Connor points out, child labor, abhorred now as a crime akin to slavery, was accepted as natural and good in the 19th century.
"The assumption was that if children got into trouble, it was up to them either to contact the C.A.S. or to take care of the problem themselves -- often by running away," Mr. O'Connor writes. "That was what independence was all about." 
Mr. O'Connor spends a good deal of time examining the results of what became Brace's best-known program, the orphan trains, which Brace saw as a way of draining the cities of potential delinquents by putting them to work where they were needed, mostly on Midwestern farms. Mr. O'Connor makes the case that Brace and others in the aid society deluded themselves into thinking that the program worked well when, in fact, record-keeping was poor and there were many instances in which the children lived like indentured servants, or worse. Even at the time Brace had his detractors, including members of the Irish-American Catholic clergy who saw the orphan trains as a Protestant plot to destroy the faith of Catholic children. But in the end, Mr. O'Connor gives Brace the benefit of the doubt: 
"He knew that, especially given the limited funds available for helping the poor, it would be impossible to save every child, and so he considered failure (children suffering abuse in solitude and silence; children running away in fear or homesickness; children whose anger and pain turned inward, driving them to drink, violence and worse) to be an inevitable component of his humanitarian labors." 
"Orphan Trains" is a moving and instructive story, and as he tells it, Mr. O'Connor never loses sight of the real people and real lives at its center.

HEADLINE: Taking Back the City 

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Re "As New Economy Cools, San Francisco Quivers" (news article, March 26):
 It's unfortunate that the lavish Internet scene is lagging in San Francisco, but for many residents this is a long-awaited reprieve. 
The dot-com invasion has led to rampant citywide evictions, particularly among nonprofit cultural groups that can't afford the sky-high rents. 
 Gentrification has been a constant threat to San Francisco's diverse arts scene, sending many aspiring artists and musicians packing. Anyone on a fixed income, including students and the elderly, has felt the presence of the Internet profiteers.
It's a shame that the Internet economy is facing a downslide, but one hopes that the audacity and greed that seemed to accompany it are gone for good.

JEFF HIRSCH
Director
San Francisco Arts Council
San Francisco, March 26, 2001

HEADLINE: Now, Live From Alaska, It's King Crab 

BYLINE:  By FLORENCE FABRICANT 

 BODY:
THERE it was, a king crab from Alaska, an enormous, reddish-orange beast with a spiny round body and gangly legs. Not lying there frozen. Alive and fidgeting. It had arrived a few hours earlier, having taken a cross-country flight to New York, and it seemed a bit dazed. (Just as well: its future was decidedly bleak.)
 David Pasternack, the chef at Esca, served the snowy meat still warm, with a splash of lemon and a drizzle of fruity extra virgin olive oil. The texture was lush, almost creamy, the flavor sweet, barely hinting of the sea. It was not the stringy, salty king crab I remembered. 
 Until recently, live king crabs rarely made it to the East Coast. Crabbers went far out into Alaskan waters, kept their catch on board for a week or more and then brought the crabs to shore, where they were cooked and frozen. Dealers on the West Coast would get a few live crabs, but what turned up here, thousands of miles from where the crabs were hauled up, was just the huge frozen legs: cheap and abundant. Chain restaurants loved them for all-you-can-eat specials, but no serious chef would ever go near them. 
The Japanese have always been able to buy live king crabs. But with the Japanese market faltering, shippers see that they can make American dollars by keeping king crabs alive and flying them across the continent. And they are taking better care of the frozen legs as well.
"Live king crabs usually go to Asian communities on the West Coast, in Seattle, San Francisco, Los Angeles and Vancouver," said Ken Kachmarik, a salesman at Steve & Mike's Shellfish in San Francisco. "But in coming years you're going to see more and more live seafood in the market everywhere." It is partly a response to demands of top chefs for the freshest seafood.
Dan Kim, the owner of Alaskan Feast in the Fulton Fish Market, said that bringing live crabs to New York was new for him. "In the past, most of them went to Japan, but they're buying much less due to the economy," he said. 
That means more crabs for New York. 
Sushi Yasuda, a Japanese restaurant on East 43rd Street, boils the crabs and uses the meat for sushi, dressed with a little lemon, at $5.50 apiece. At Le Bernardin, Eric Ripert sometimes receives live king crabs, which he boils, serving the meat on lightly sauteed green cabbage dressed with truffle vinaigrette and scattered with black truffle as a special on his $77 prix-fixe menu. Browne Trading, his supplier, sent him two live king crabs on Monday, enough for 16 portions.
Those crabs, like the ones at Esca, are brown or golden king crab, Lithodes aequispinus, which averages five to eight pounds. It is related to the more abundant red king crab, Paralithodes camtschaticus, the largest, which can weigh 20 pounds and measure six feet across. 
Some East Coast companies ship crabs directly from Alaska, packed in plastic-foam boxes with frozen gel packs (the cold makes them dormant). Those are usually headed for restaurants, to be cooked within hours.
On the West Coast, where Asian markets are the primary buyers, the crabs are flown from Alaska to Seattle, where they are refreshed in seawater tanks before being repacked in plastic foam and catching a flight to their final destinations. These crabs, having spent a shorter time in the box, tend to be livelier and more appealing in the market tanks. They are also less likely to die en route. Crabs can survive about 24 hours in the box. 
The live crab operation is like day boat fishing: the vessels are smaller and go out for shorter lengths of time, to bring back a premium catch that sells for more money. 
The Alaskan king crab season is staggered throughout the fall, winter and spring, depending on the fishing ground and the type of crab (only mature males can be trapped). Last year's total catch was 12.7 million pounds. This year's is expected to be somewhat less.
"Our strategy is to maintain the stock and set quotas to sustain it," said Forrest Bowers, an Aleutians and Bering Sea biologist with the Alaska Fish and Game Department. "We only harvest 10 to 20 percent of the legal males. It is illegal to take females. The fishery could even rebound, with the right environmental conditions."
The golden crab season in Alaska started last month. The crabs are harvested under a strict quota. 
Most king crabs are from the icy Bering Sea, both in American and Russian waters. Golden crabs come from waters as deep as 1,600 feet, off the Aleutian Islands and southern Alaska. Red king crabs prefer the sandy bottom of shallower water. Laura Fleming, of the Alaska Seafood Marketing Institute, said that 99 percent of the crabs caught are processed by cooking and freezing.
There has also been an improvement in the way frozen crab legs are handled, Ms. Fleming said. The shippers maintain a subzero temperature from boat to truck to market. 
Live king crabs cost about $12 a pound wholesale. Retailers are few and charge up to $17.95 a pound for whole crabs and $24 to $30 for cooked legs.
The best meat is in the legs. Unlike most other crabs, king crabs have only six legs, not eight, and two claws, which are not so prized as the legs. The body of the crab has a little meat, but it usually goes to canners.
Mr. Pasternack has been getting five or six crabs once or twice a week. "This is the first season I've had them, and I can't get over how delicious the meat is," he said. He usually serves the crab simply cooked, dressed with olive oil and tossed with fresh pasta at $24 a portion. Last week, he said, a Japanese customer bought an entire crab to share with his dinner guests.
Rod Mitchell, the owner of Browne Trading, in Portland, Me., said that some of his other clients for live king crabs are Daniel in Manhattan and Emeril's in New Orleans. "The restaurants put them on as a special because they never know when they'll have them," he said.
Until the early 1980's, frozen king crab legs were everywhere and selling for less than $10 a pound. In 1980, crabbers in Alaska brought in 130 million pounds. Then there was a sudden shortage, caused by changes in water temperature and currents and other environmental conditions. Since then, the king crab harvest has remained at 20 million pounds a year, or less, and the price has more than doubled. 
Those frozen crabs may have been plentiful, but their quality was in no way up to freshly caught crab. Few fish markets sell them today. At Citarella, they are $19.99 a pound. A single leg weighs nearly a pound and provides nearly three-quarters of a pound of meat. 
In years past, when I had king crab, it was served cold in a salad or as a crab meat cocktail or hot with melted butter. Frozen crab legs that I bought last week and slowly thawed in the refrigerator were better than frozen king crab legs of the past. The shells were thin and easy to remove by cutting with kitchen shears. The meat was still wet and a little stringy. But it was a far cry from the sumptuous fresh meat. 
Then I tried steaming them gently for a few minutes in the shell, without thawing, just to warm them. The difference was astonishing. Though the steamed crab meat was a bit saltier and not so buttery as the fresh, it was good. But once it has been warmed, it must be served without delay. Refrigeration gives the texture that old stringiness. Mr. Ripert said that fresh cooked crab also tightens in the refrigerator. Like the crabbers, I learned that king crab requires careful handling. 
A few fish markets in the New York area sell live king crabs. One of them is Westfield Seafood, 220 South Avenue West, in Westfield, N.J., where whole crabs are $17.95 a pound. "We cook most of them here and sell the legs," said Vince Bruns, the owner. Last weekend, the legs were $24.95 a pound. "They've been a big hit, but the right price is probably $30 a pound, which is what we'll sell them for if we don't put them on as a weekend special," Mr. Bruns added. 
In Chinatown, A.E.G. Seafood, 206 Centre Street (Grand Street), expects to have live king crabs on Friday, $12.50 a pound whole. 
You will need a very large pot.
But if all you can find are frozen legs, just remember to steam them for a few minutes, remove the shell and serve them warm.

CORRECTION-DATE: April 4, 2001

 CORRECTION:
An article last Wednesday about Alaskan king crabs misidentified a store at 206 Centre Street in Manhattan that plans to sell them live. It is called Centre Seafood; A.E.G. Seafood is its telephone listing.

HEADLINE: An Overnight Sensation, 200 Years in the Making 

BYLINE:  By AMANDA HESSER 

DATELINE: SANLUCAR DE BARRAMEDA, Spain 

 BODY:
I TASTED more than I could count. Each time, a cool stream coursed through my mouth, leaving a trail of honey and melon, green apple and almonds. Sometimes even salt. Then I'd have a sliver of jamon, a fried anchovy or a shrimp fritter, and thirst for more of that chilly liquid. Back and forth, back and forth I'd go until it was time to amble on to the next tapas bar and start all over. 
 The drink was, of course, sherry. But not the usual fino. It was manzanilla, a sherry made only in this tiny seaside town, where the Atlantic and the Guadalquivir River join, wrapping the town and its bodegas with the humid, coastal air that nurtures this wine. 
 Many wines owe their flavor to the quality of the grapes or the skill of the winemaker. With manzanilla, it is really this ocean air that makes it what it is. It is light and dry like a fino, but with a cleaner, more delicate, almost tangy finish. It is a fine wine, and the antithesis of the stuffy old banker's drink many people associate with sherry. 
And after far too many years in obscurity, manzanilla is finally coming to the forefront of the sherry industry. The Spanish have long thought of it as simply an esoteric wine from Sanlucar, the traditional Andalusian drink, the drink for tapas.
But in recent years, Andalusia has revived its wine culture. While many mass-produced sherries fell out of favor, manzanilla has come into fashion. It is almost inescapable in restaurants in Seville and has even made inroads in New York, at places with a Spanish flavor, like Meigas and Pipa, but also at restaurants with American cuisine, like Gramercy Tavern. 
Fino, of course, is also a lovely drink. But after a glass, it sometimes weighs on your palate. Manzanilla is more like a fine Champagne. It is subtly flavored, cool on the tongue and leaves nothing behind but optimism about your next taste. Its faintly salty quality makes you thirsty and hungry.
In Andalusia it is drunk as an aperitif with tapas, but also as a wine through the meal. You almost cannot order the region's abundance of seafood -- langoustines grilled on a plancha, roasted fish, fried calamari and fried anchovies -- without being served a glass. But it goes perfectly with many other foods, from the Spanish tortilla to roasted chicken, roasted peppers and cured meats.
Taste it and see. It is no surprise that it has begun to stand out among sherries -- wines that have been plagued with a reputation as cheap and low grade.
International sherry sales have sunk by more than 30 percent over the last decade, producers say. In an attempt to cushion this economic blow, the Spanish government gave grape producers for the sherry industry incentives to cut their vineyard acreage. They did so by half: just 70 million liters are now produced annually. All the while, consumption of manzanilla in Spain and around the world has quietly grown. Now, of all the sherry consumed in Spain, almost 60 percent is manzanilla. Twenty years ago, it was just 15 percent.
There is still a lot of image mending to do. Finos like Osborne's Tio Pepe and Domecq live on as the musty drink of the elderly -- in Spain, in the United States, even in long-faithful Britain. "I was shocked to find, when in Britain last year," a friend recently wrote me, "that I was laughed at, first by friends and then in a pub, when I asked for sherry." 
Had he ordered manzanilla, he might have cut a better figure. Manzanillas like those produced by the bodegas Lustau, Barbadillo and Vinicola Hidalgo have turned their obscurity into cachet.
Traditionally, said Timothy Holt, the export manager for Vincola Hidalgo y Cia, "manzanilla producers were local family bodegas with no financial clout." And so, it was mostly drunk locally.
When you order sherry in Seville these days, though, the assumption is that you are ordering manzanilla. The waiter simply asks which brand. 
The word manzanilla showed up in the Spanish language about 200 years ago, about the same time the solera system of making sherry began in Sanlucar. But it is unclear exactly why the drink is called manzanilla. "Manzana," in Spanish, means apple, and "manzanilla" could be a diminutive of it, a reference to the apple's fruity aroma. But "manzanilla" also means chamomile, and if you order a manzanilla at an unusual time of day, you may actually get chamomile tea.
Manzanilla has a number of forms. 
Most common is regular aged, which is about three years old. Manzanilla fina is bottled slightly younger, with a lemon yellow color and a light, dry, green apple flavor. Manzanilla pasada is darker, and a few years older, with stronger notes of wood and nuts.
All of these -- and all sherries, for that matter -- are made with the palomino fino, a fragile, juicy white grape. "But the destiny is different," Mr. Holt said, standing small among high stacks of barrels in the dim, yeasty smelling bodega in Sanlucar, "and entirely because of the microclimate here they come out differently."
The palomino grapes are grown throughout the Jerez region, which sprawls across the southern tip of Andalusia. The best come from the lower altitudes on the chalky soil. Some manzanilla bodegas, like Hidalgo, own their own vineyards. Others buy grapes from growers.
The location and the design of the winery and the way the wine is aged are perhaps even more crucial to the wine's character than the grapes themselves. In Sanlucar, it is most desirable to be near the water, where the benefits of the microclimate are greatest. 
Then there is the physical structure of the winery. 
"It's not just the shape but the thickness of the walls and the orientation," Mr. Holt said. "It's so positioned that it catches the sea breezes, but also the sun's effect is reduced." Hidalgo's bodega, which has been around for 200 years, has thick stone walls and a cathedral roof made of conical Arab tiles. There are three layers of tiles and mortar sandwiching an air pocket that helps prevent the relentless heat of the summer sun from penetrating the interior. The structure is both solid and breezy.
Not all wineries are the same. The bodega where Lustau's manzanillas are kept is an old, more rudimentary building in the center of town. It is on a higher elevation, tucked among other structures. The windows are simply covered with straw mats, and the barrels are more cramped together. 
Once the palomino grapes are harvested, they are made into wine, then a few months later brought here and aged in oak barrels. Hidalgo's bodega is stacked high with these barrels, some of them 200 years old. Inside, it is dark and cool, and bats fly around during the day as if it were night.
During the sherry's time in wood, it develops a flor, or yeast cap, on its surface that looks much like cottage cheese. In most of the Jerez region, that flor thins out during the summer and winter, exposing some of the sherry to oxidation, which gives fino its typical pungent, nutty fragrance and body. 
In Sanlucar de Barrameda, however, the flor is thick and fluffy throughout the year, minimizing oxidation and giving the wine a fresher tang, often described as salty.
It's not salty exactly, but there is a kind of briny crispness that makes manzanilla distinguishable from fino. Manzanilla is light, dry and delicate, with a sweetness that's faint and fleeting like the sweetness in spring water. 
Like all sherry, manzanilla is aged by the solera system, a complex method of blending that ensures a consistent product. When a sherry is bottled, it is drawn in small amounts from barrels that have reached the end of the solera cycle. Sherries in younger stages of development are called criaderas. 
After bottling, the amount drawn out is replaced by the first criadera (which is also the oldest), the second by the third and so on until the youngest criadera is replenished with wine from the latest vintage. 
"The Spanish say that with the solera system, young wine is taught by the older wine," Mr. Holt said. "But also, the young wine provides the nutrients that allow the flor to live on and, in that, the solera system and manzanilla are inextricably linked."
Hidalgo's solera system is more than 100 years old. Lustau's is about 50. So, presumably, the latest manzanilla will contain a bit of every vintage, whether an atom or a drop.
Lustau's manzanilla solera has been managed by the same man, Pepe Espinar, for most of its existence. Mr. Espinar has worked in this bodega for more than 30 years, so he has experienced many of the vintages and has been witness to their every change in weather and flavor. 
Mr. Espinar, a small compact man dressed in a workman's indigo jumpsuit, took me through the bodega with sherry glasses in one hand and in the other a cana, the long slim ladle used for tasting sherry. Its end is a tall and narrow cylinder that can puncture the flor without causing too much damage and scoop up just a shotful of the liquid. His cana is fashioned from flexible bamboo, so that once he captures a shot of the manzanilla he can pour it at arm's length into a glass, using a whiplike movement. In Jerez de la Frontera, whale whiskers were supposedly once used for canas. 
As we tasted the young, unfiltered manzanillas, I could see the finished sherry evolving. All the flavors were there -- the apple, sometimes cherry, the yeast, the wood -- but fragmented. As they get closer to bottling, they lose their slightly sulphurous aroma and take on more of a uniform, whole flavor.
Hidalgo, which was founded in 1792 and is still owned by the same family, makes a number of manzanillas. There is La Gitana, the flagship; manzanilla Hidalgo, the lightest and driest; and manzanilla pasada, which has more wood, nuts and fruit in its aroma. 
Lustau makes a similar array of sherries, some of which are produced at its bodega in Jerez de la Frontera, others aged by almecenistas, or warehouses, which age sherries for producers to their specifications -- a common practice throughout the Jerez region.
Because manzanilla is produced in the same way as fino, it can also be made into other sherries like amontillado, an aged form of fino, or oloroso, a fortified, aged sherry, sometimes sweetened with Pedro Ximenez grapes (fortified to 17 percent alcohol; fino and manzanilla are fortified to only 15 percent). There is also palo cortado, a high-quality aged sherry with characteristics of both sweet oloroso and full, nutty amontillado. It has a gentle raisiny sweetness and an aroma of hazelnuts. 
What is perhaps most surprising with a great manzanilla is its price. 
Hidalgo and Lustau manzanillas are both around $12, which is about the same as most finos; aged sherries like amontillado and manzanilla pasada are more expensive, but rarely more than $30. Think of what $12 will get you in a Chianti.
These manzanillas are made from vineyards on the best soil in Jerez. They are produced in relatively small batches and aged in old barrels soaked with decades of character. 
You can drink chilled manzanilla throughout the meal. It easy to do. Each sip is ethereal. It is a small, finessed pleasure. It lacks the weight and pedigree of something like a Bordeaux, and does not ask you to revere it. It simply fills that brief pause between slices of jamon and olives in the most delicious way.

MUSHROOMS WITH MANZANILLA
Time: 15 minutes

2 tablespoons extra virgin olive oil
1 1/2 pounds mixed mushrooms (like shiitake, oyster and white button) trimmed and cleaned, thinly sliced
Sliver of peeled garlic
3 tablespoons manzanilla or fino sherry
Sea salt.

1. Place large saute pan over medium heat. Add olive oil. When oil is hot, add mushrooms and garlic. Season lightly with salt.
2. Saute until mushrooms soften and release their liquid. Continue to saute until most of the liquid evaporates. Add sherry, and saute for 1 more minute. Season with salt to taste. Serve, if desired, with crusty bread, thin slices of serrano ham and glasses of manzanilla sherry.

Yield: 4 tapas servings.

CORRECTION-DATE: April 4, 2001

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES 

 BODY:
 EURO FALLS. The dollar gained against the euro after a report showed United States consumer confidence unexpectedly rose this month. In New York, the euro settled at 89.36 cents, down from 89.64 cents on Monday.

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING; 
Asales pitch tries to connect with fans as baseball season starts.

BYLINE:  By Stuart Elliot 

 BODY:
REMEMBER the advertising for Nynex that tried to sell telephone services by proclaiming "We're all connected"? Major League Baseball is introducing a campaign that could well carry that theme as it seeks to strengthen ties with fans and build ties with nonfans who think the Tampa Bay Devil Rays and Florida Marlins might be menu items at Red Lobster.
 The campaign, "Connect with it," includes television, radio, print, outdoor and online advertising. It is meant to foster a closer, more emotional attachment between baseball and the general audience that Greta Garbo described in "Ninotchka" as "the messes." That is becoming increasingly important as ratings for most televised sports, including baseball, decline year to year amid a perceived glut in sports programming, while at the same time many marketers begin to rethink their ad budgets as the economy softens. 
 "We want to turn up the flame and remind people why they're connected, or should be connected, to the game," said a rhyme-minded Kathy Francis, vice president for marketing at Major League Baseball in New York.
"The game is all about bringing people together in many forms," Ms. Francis added, "through personal connections, through statistics, through stories, through purchasing apparel" and other licensed merchandise.
The campaign is the first work for Major League Baseball from the San Francisco office of FCB Worldwide, part of True North Communications, which agreed last week to be acquired by the Interpublic Group of Companies. In October, Major League Baseball consolidated various advertising assignments, with billings estimated at $20 million to $30 million, by naming FCB San Francisco to handle those tasks for the 2001 season.
Not surprisingly, the campaign is timed to begin with the new season, which starts on Sunday with a game in San Juan, P.R., between the Texas Rangers and Toronto Blue Jays.
"Our challenge is couplefold," said Patrick Kiss, executive vice president and managing partner at FCB San Francisco, perhaps coining a word. "It's getting people to go to the park more often and getting people to tune in to baseball on TV more often."
Mr. Kiss called that intended target of the campaign "latent fans, who go to one game instead of three" each season "and don't tune in as often as they should" to games televised in their local markets as well as nationally by ESPN, Fox Broadcasting and TBS.
Another target of the campaign, Mr. Kiss said, is "avid fans," the ones who get "goose bumps" watching footage of the home-run slugger Hank Aaron "when he was 25" or an "electric" feeling when they attend a World Series game.
Or electric goose bumps, perhaps, watching Hank Aaron play in the World Series, as he did with the Milwaukee Braves in 1957 and 1958.
So the initial commercial in the campaign tries to cover all the bases, so to speak, offering 60 seconds of baseball stars from yesterday as well as today, interspersed with shots of contemporary fans from all demographic groups.
The fast-paced spot cuts from vintage scenes of all-stars like Aaron, Joe DiMaggio, Babe Ruth, Jackie Robinson and Ted Williams to recent shots of outstanding players like Randy Johnson and Mark McGwire. The fans are glimpsed in ardent moments, holding signs, cheering, coming to the ballpark with their faces painted.
As those scenes appear, the word "Connect" is superimposed on screen, followed by phrases like "with a hanging curve," "with a kindred spirit," "with a hero," "with an era," "with your heritage" and "with heaven." The last pops up during glimpses of the World Series in Yankee Stadium.
"People mark time by baseball," said Tim Brosnan, executive vice president for business at Major League Baseball, offering as examples the World Series, known as the fall classic, and the remembrances of summers past through the quests to break home-run records in 1961 and 1998.
"We want to celebrate those deep connections," he added, "to get fans in seats, fans buying products, corporate sponsors and more viewing of our television programs."
To that end, Mr. Brosnan said, Major League Baseball is working with Fox, part of the News Corporation, "to understand the underlying reasons" for the "erosion in broadcast-television numbers" and find solutions.
Fox and its siblings, FX and the Fox Family Channel, will show the spot, along with ESPN, part of the Walt Disney Company, and TBS, owned by AOL Time Warner. There will be additional commercials in June, to promote the All-Star Game, and in September, to promote the postseason schedule leading up to the 2001 World Series.
"And everything we're doing this year will be about showing baseball's connections with its broad fan base," said Jacqueline Parkes, senior director for advertising at Major League Baseball. That would include campaigns for baseball's Web site (www.mlb.com) and licensed merchandise in addition to public service announcements.
Additionally, Major League Baseball is to provide its teams with a 30-second version of the initial commercial, Ms. Parkes said, which they can run in their local markets on local TV stations. Eighteen of the 30 clubs have asked for the spot.
Before FCB San Francisco was hired, the image campaign and public service announcements had been handled by Vigilante in New York, part of the Leo Burnett Worldwide unit of the Bcom3 Group. Duties for consumer products like licensed merchandise had been handled by the Lord Group in New York, a joint venture of Dentsu and the Young & Rubicam unit of the WPP Group.
"Our first assignment as an agency was 'Could you go to the World Series and shoot a couple days?' " Mr. Kiss recalled, adding with a laugh, "We said, 'We could do that.' "
"As a big New York Mets fan," he added, "I was thrilled."
Who has the heart to tell Mr. Kiss how the Series turned out?

PERSON: Sherwin Rosen 

HEADLINE: Sherwin Rosen, 62, Economist Who Focused on Labor Matters 

BYLINE:  By LAURENCE ZUCKERMAN 

 BODY:
Sherwin Rosen, the president of the American Economics Association and a pioneer in the study of why wages and incomes vary, died on March 17 at Bernard Mitchell Hospital at the University of Chicago. He was 62.
 The cause was lung cancer, said William Harms, a university spokesman. 
 Professor Rosen was a microeconomist who focused largely on the issues surrounding labor. One of his most influential papers, which was published in 1981, was "The Economics of Superstars." It explored why celebrities and sports stars make so much more money than others in the same field.
Professor Rosen concluded that someone with even a slight talent advantage over a competitor could command a much higher salary by dint of the fact that his or her work reached a broader audience. For example, two singers might sound nearly the same but the one who sells recordings and appears on television shows will receive a higher income than the one who appears only in nightclubs.
The paper attracted a lot of attention outside the field of economics as the salaries of actors, athletes and chief executives soared in the last 20 years. It also inspired related studies by other economists.
"The real test of whether you make a big contribution in economics is how much you affect the research in the field," said Gary S. Becker, the Nobel economist at the University of Chicago who was a longtime friend and colleague of Professor Rosen. "And on that one, there is no question he affected the research of quite a few people."
Professor Becker said that Professor Rosen also did groundbreaking work in the late 1960's by using statistics to show that physically risky occupations rewarded workers with premium wages.
"I think Rosen had a very good chance of winning the Nobel, if he had lived longer," he added. "In economics, 62 is a young age."
Professor Rosen was born in Chicago. He graduated from Purdue University in 1960 with a Bachelor of Science. He subsequently studied economics at the University of Chicago, where he received his doctorate in 1966.
He taught at the University of Rochester for more than a decade before joining the faculty at the University of Chicago in 1977. He was the chairman of the economics department from 1988 to 1994 and served as editor of the Journal of Political Economy from 1986 until his death.
Earlier this year, he assumed the presidency of the American Economics Association, one of the highest honors in the profession. A short time after, he was told he had cancer, Professor Becker said.
He is survived by his wife, Sharon, of Chicago, and two daughters, Jennifer Lynn Rosen, of Chicago, and Adria Jill Rosen Zurita, of El Cerrito, Calif.

HEADLINE: Political Peacekeeping in the Balkans 

 BODY:
The Bush administration has made clear its desire for an early withdrawal of American peacekeeping troops from the Balkans. That is an understandable goal. But it cannot be achieved until sufficient stability has been brought to the region to allow the removal of outside military forces without risking a rapid return to armed conflict. 
 Recent raids into Macedonia and southern Serbia by armed bands of ethnic Albanians show just how volatile the military situation remains. The guerrillas seek to exploit a variety of grievances that have been growing for the past decade during the breakup of the old Yugoslavia and the repressive dictatorship of Slobodan Milosevic. 
 The recent clashes between the guerrillas and the Macedonian army have subsided, with the Albanian forces pushed back into the mountains outside Tetovo, Macedonia's second-largest city. But if political, economic and social inequities in the territories of the former Yugoslavia are not effectively addressed, further ethnic bloodletting is likely. That is sure to increase the pressure on NATO to play a more forceful role in policing the region, precisely what the White House hopes to avoid.
The specific remedies needed in Macedonia, southern Serbia and Kosovo are different. But in all three areas, Western governments should work closely with moderate Albanian leaders who reject violence and promote the interests of their community by political means. NATO's secretary general, Lord Robertson, and Europe's top diplomat, Javier Solana, lent useful support to this approach during a visit to Macedonia earlier this week.
Macedonia's large Albanian minority was never subjected to the violent repression and political disfranchisement Mr. Milosevic inflicted on the Albanians of Kosovo and southern Serbia. Macedonia is a multiethnic democracy, but a fragile one. Although an Albanian party participates in the governing coalition, many Albanians feel unfairly treated. They want equal constitutional status for Slavs and Albanians, more decentralized government, official status for the Albanian language and international monitoring of the next census. Macedonia's government should support these proposals.
In Kosovo, the most urgent need is building new structures of self-government to replace the ousted Serbian administration. Last year successful local elections were held. Now the United Nation's administrator, Hans Haekkerup, needs to move on to a provincewide vote. Doing so would allow nonviolent Albanian parties to increase their power and prestige at the expense of the armed extremists.
In southern Serbia, Albanians were denied basic political rights during the Milosevic era. Serbia's new democratic government must regain their confidence by working cooperatively with elected Albanian local officials and by bringing more Albanians into the police and military forces. Belgrade must also see to it that Yugoslav army commanders involved in the Kosovo repression are not sent to areas inhabited primarily by Albanians. 
Improving political and economic conditions in the Balkans will take time, as the slow progress in Bosnia has shown. During the months ahead, NATO peacekeepers in Kosovo can help maintain stability by improving border security. More inclusive political arrangements in all three areas will reduce the potential for violence and speed the completion of NATO's mission.

HEADLINE: Publisher Named At Mercury News 

BYLINE:  AP 

DATELINE: SAN JOSE, Calif., March 27 

 BODY:
The president of The Miami Herald was named publisher of The Mercury News of San Jose today, replacing Jay T. Harris, who quit last week in a dispute over cost-cutting plans of the parent company, Knight Ridder.
 The Miami Herald executive, Joseph T. Natoli, 45, has spent his entire career with Knight Ridder, first as an accountant in the company's suburban division and then in management at The Miami Herald. 
 Mr. Natoli's appointment takes effect immediately.
Knight Ridder, based in San Jose, is the nation's second-largest newspaper publisher, with 32 papers in 28 markets. Gannett is the largest.
Mr. Harris left the Mercury News on March 19 after seven years as its publisher. He said he did so in hopes of forcing Knight Ridder to "closely examine the wisdom" of the profit targets it set for the paper.
Earlier in the month, Mr. Harris said the paper would have to lay off some employees because of significantly lower ad revenue during Silicon Valley's economic slump. But when he resigned, Mr. Harris said the paper had been unable to find a way to meet Knight Ridder's profit goals "without risking significant and lasting harm to The Mercury News."

HEADLINE: Computer Associates Considers Severance for Some It Fired 

BYLINE:  By ALEX BERENSON 

 BODY:
Computer Associates is considering offering severance payments to some of the employees it fired two months ago, the company said yesterday.
 In recent interviews, about two dozen former employees said that the company had dismissed several hundred of its 18,000 workers worldwide since November. The action, they said, was actually a mass layoff by Computer Associates, a software company based in Islandia, N.Y., that is struggling to rein in costs. 
 The company disguised the mass layoff as individual firings of nonperforming workers, they said, to avoid paying severance benefits. The firings have angered former employees, who accuse the company of acting in bad faith. The company's employee handbook says workers will receive two weeks of severance pay for each year they have worked for the company unless they are fired for poor performance. The firings may also have violated labor laws, employment lawyers said. 
Three former executives who fired employees stepped forward in the last week to offer accounts similar to those given by employees. The layoffs were directed by top management, they said, and were tightly scripted by the company's human resources department so the company could avoid paying severance packages to fired employees.
Computer Associates, which makes the software that many big companies use to manage their computer systems, said that it did not have a mass layoff and that the dismissals were a standard year-end pruning of unproductive employees. "C.A. is continuing to hire employees, as needs arise," said Bob Gordon, a company spokesman.
But the company has now decided that it may offer some employees severance pay after all, Mr. Gordon said yesterday.
"We are reviewing the terminations of folks who left in January to determine if anyone who was eligible for severance didn't receive it," Mr. Gordon said.
About 240 employees were terminated in January for performance reasons and did not receive severance pay, he said. In addition, 76 employees who were dismissed for other reasons did receive severance pay. Mr. Gordon declined to say how many people had lost their jobs since November, when former employees say the layoffs began, or whether the company's work force had shrunk in that time.
The company did not say how many employees might receive payments but said it would not need to take a one-time charge to earnings to cover the cost.
Since the dismissals were first reported, executives and employees involved in the firings have continued to come forward with their accounts. They say the company, whose revenues plunged 53 percent, to $783 million for the quarter ended Dec. 31, 2000, from $1.67 billion for the comparable period in 1999, is furiously trying to cut costs.
Henry Crouse, a former regional vice president at the company, said he got the call on Friday, Jan. 12.
Two weeks earlier, he met in Blue Bell, Pa., with three other executives. The managers, who oversaw about 15 salespeople in New Jersey and Pennsylvania, knew that their group, like others in the company, was far behind its sales quotas. With the economy slowing, customers were reluctant to sign new contracts.
Led by a senior vice president who would be fired a few days later, the executives at the Blue Bell meeting discussed which salespeople might be expendable, Mr. Crouse said. (Another person who was at the meeting but asked not to be identified confirmed Mr. Crouse's account. ) Because Mr. Crouse had just been promoted, and his salespeople were all behind on their quotas, he had little basis on which to decide, he said.
"I could have fired myself, and it would have made as much sense," Mr. Crouse said.
Nevertheless, the group agreed on six salespeople who would be fired if necessary, he said. Then they waited.
"On Jan. 12, the phone call came -- 'Fire them now,' " Mr. Crouse said. To ensure that employees would not receive severance pay, the managers followed the directions of Computer Associates' human resources department, he said.
"There were two people in each termination meeting, human resources and you," Mr. Crouse said. "Just tell them they're being terminated for poor performance. Get up and walk out and let H.R. handle it."
Employees call Jan. 12 "the day of blood," Mr. Crouse said. "The way these terminations were handled was embarrassing."
Mr. Crouse was fired last week, after kicking and breaking his office door when a $680,000 software sale he had negotiated fell through. He said the company told him it had fired him because he "had a pattern of being too intense," but he attributed his firing to the collapse of the sale.
Mr. Gordon said the company could not discuss the circumstances of Mr. Crouse's firing unless Mr. Crouse agreed to allow it to do so. Mr. Crouse declined.
Another former executive, a senior vice president who insisted on remaining anonymous, said that at the end of December, she and other executives were told to plan to dismiss 20 percent of their employees. "It was supposed to be for performance reasons," she said. "I was very bold, and argued and said, 'I don't think this is the right thing to do. I've been a good manager and I've been weeding out my pipeline every quarter.' "
A few days later, the orders came, she said. "We were told: 'Be careful. Do not say that this is a reduction in force. Do not say this is a layoff,' " she said. "We were told no severance, and the reason being, hey, you're not performing, you're going to get no severance."
Earlier this month, the senior vice president got another order.
"I had a sales rep in my office, and an H.R. person came in and said, 'Can I talk to you?' " she said. The senior vice president was led out of her office to a conference room. "I said, 'We're doing the doomsday walk, aren't we?' and she said, 'I have Chris on the line for you.' I knew the drill. I knew there's no severance. And that was that."

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: STOCKS & BONDS; 
Positive Consumer Confidence Report Gives Shares a Lift

BYLINE:  By MICHAEL BRICK 

 BODY:
Stock prices climbed again yesterday after investors were heartened by an unexpectedly strong report on consumer confidence, raising some hopes that personal spending will revive the weakened economy.
 Still, some market strategists said investors appeared to be rallying around a rally since stocks made a stunning reversal late Thursday from their recent steep losses. 
 "The market will use -- during a time of rebound -- any evidence it can find that things aren't going to be bad as a plus," said David A. Henwood, chief investment officer for Raymond James & Associates. 
The Dow Jones industrial average gained 260.01 points, or 2.7 percent, to 9,947.54. Since a late turnaround on Thursday from a steep intraday loss that would have put it in a bear market, the Dow has gained 558 points.
The broader Standard & Poor's 500-stock index gained 29.48 points, or 2.6 percent, to 1,182.17, putting it nearly 40 points below the point when it entered a bear market on March 12. And the technology-heavy Nasdaq composite index rose 53.77 points, or 2.8 percent, to 1,972.26.
The stock market began to pick up strength after the Conference Board, a New York research group, reported that its consumer confidence index jumped to 117 in March from a revised 109.2 in February. Economists had expected the index, which had fallen for five months, to drop again, to 105.
Some analysts questioned, though, whether yesterday's report signaled a turnaround in the economy's prospects. "Today's consumer confidence data does not register a brand new world," said Bryan Piskorowski, a market analyst at Prudential Securities. "Being so oversold, you will see supply rallies. The question is whether this is a trading market or an investing market."
Though they are unsure why this rally began or how long it will last, some investors are using the optimism to seek trading gains. And some money managers said it was hard not to get caught up in the excitement.
"There's a pressure that maybe I ought to be chasing this," said Brett Gallagher, vice president of Julius Baer Investment Management, who manages $400 million in stocks for foundations and wealthy individuals. Among the stocks leading the Dow higher, I.B.M. gained $4.10, to $99.50; United Technologies rose $2.70, to $74.46; and SBC Communications advanced $2.65, to $43.90.
But another Dow stock, Johnson & Johnson, fell $2.13, to $83.25, after the company said it would acquire Alza, a maker of drug delivery systems, for stock valued at $10.5 billion.
 --------------------

Treasury Prices Fall
 (By Reuters) -- Bond prices tumbled yesterday after a surprising jump in consumer confidence in March dashed hopes of an immediate interest rate cut and lifted stock prices.
The price of the 10-year Treasury note fell 14/32, to 99 31/32. Its yield, which moves in the opposite direction from the price, rose to 5.00 percent from 4.86 percent on Monday.
The 30-year bond fell 1 20/32, to 98 26/32. Its yield rose to 5.46 percent from 5.36 percent.

HEADLINE: Russia's Spy Riposte: Film Catches Americans in the Act 

BYLINE:  By PATRICK E. TYLER 

DATELINE: MOSCOW, March 27 

 BODY:
Indulging its own version of spy mania, Russia's intelligence services released television film on the main news channels tonight showing United States military attaches buying information from a Russian agent.
 The news programs also broadcast an audio tape of a Russian scholar, currently on trial for espionage, phoning Capt. Robert Brannon, a senior American naval attache here, and discussing what kind of armaments were aboard a Russian intelligence ship sent to the Balkans during the NATO military campaign in 1999. 
 In a day of Russian protest and bluster following the Bush administration's decision to expel 50 Russian diplomats for espionage, Moscow again summoned the ranking American diplomat here, John Ordway, and gave him the names of four diplomats who must leave the country within 10 days. Russian law enforcement officials promptly identified one of the diplomats as Paul A. Hollingsworth, a first secretary at the embassy. Embassy officials said they would not comment on the identities of those expelled. 
The Russians did not demand the expulsion of the C.I.A.'s Moscow station chief, a United States intelligence official said. The station chief, like his counterpart in the Russian S.V.R. in Washington, is known to the host government, and is the official liaison channel for contacts between the security services. The United States did not expel the Russian station chief in Washington, either. 
The Russian action was virtually identical to the American move. 
Moscow declared four American diplomats persona non grata, and demanded that 46 others leave by July, the official said. By this afternoon in Washington, none of the United States diplomats -- presumably C.I.A. officers under diplomatic cover -- had left Moscow. 
Though both President Bush and President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia have said they hope that the espionage crisis will not harm relations between the two countries, it seemed clear that Russian officials were seeking to discredit American arguments that it was Russia's overexuberance that brought on the crisis. 
The conflict has spilled over to the diplomatic field, with Russia's Foreign Ministry lashing the Bush administration over the meeting of senior American diplomats in Washington with Ilyas Akhmadov, a representative of the Chechen rebel leadership that the Russian Army has been trying to defeat. Moscow's protest carried a more indignant tone today after three car bomb attacks during the weekend attributed to Chechen militants killed 22 people. All the attacks were in the Stavropol region, which adjoins Chechnya.
"After the Stavropol events," said Aleksandr Yakovenko, a Russian Foreign Ministry official, "after all those bloody terrorist acts, this meeting in Washington looks immoral to say the least."
At the same time, Mr. Putin's government appeared to be going out of its way today to accentuate its initiatives in places where the Bush administration has either hesitated to become more deeply involved, as in Israel, or has resorted to military force, as in Iraq. 
In a message to the Arab summit conference in Jordan, Mr. Putin proposed suspending all economic sanctions against Iraq on the condition that it accept a "revival of international monitoring" that would prevent it from pursuing "banned military programs." 
As for Israel and the Palestinian territories, Mr. Putin said the "most burning issue" now was to normalize the situation by Israel's "lifting blockades, including economic ones, from the West Bank and Gaza and ending violence." 
On the spy front, a state television broadcast opened with a man standing at a telephone booth near the American Embassy in Moscow. He was placing a call to Captain Brannon, stationed here as a naval attache since 1998. The caller, Anatoly Popov, was identified as a Russian convicted of attempted hijacking in 1976.
The video documented how a meeting was arranged at a cafe near the embassy. While Captain Brannon paced the sidewalks near the restaurant, two unidentified American military attaches were shown meeting with Mr. Popov and paying him $400 for a maritime chart of the Yenisei River delta area in northern Siberian. Mr. Popov also promised to provide a map of "minefields." 
In the broadcast, Mr. Popov said he later turned himself in, fearing arrest. 
In a second episode involving Captain Brannon, the television broadcast played an audio tape of a telephone conversation between the naval officer and Igor Sutyagin, a researcher at Russia's U.S.A. and Canada Institute charged in 1999 with revealing state secrets after he helped compile a book on Russia's strategic nuclear arsenal. The book was based on unclassified literature and his own scientific analysis. 
Mr. Sutyagin's defense has rested on the assertion that he never had any access to classified materials. On the audio tape, he answered Captain Brannon's questions about what kind of armaments were aboard the Russian intelligence ship Liman. 
Captain Brannon was interested in whether the crew of the Liman was equipped with shoulder-fired antiaircraft missiles as it prepared to leave for the Balkans. Mr. Sutyagin said the ship did not have such weapons. Mr. Sutyagin wanted to know if Captain Brannon had received his fax, and the American replied that he had, adding that he had been much more pleased with the "envelope" Mr. Sutyagin had sent. 
The contents of the "envelope" were not disclosed, but a Russian commentator said that when Captain Brannon's name came up in the trial of Mr. Sutyagin, the American official left the country abruptly. He later returned.

CORRECTION-DATE: March 30, 2001

 CORRECTION:
An article on Wednesday describing a videotaped exchange between an American naval officer and a Russian scholar accused of espionage reversed the identity of the speakers at one point. It was the American who asked the Russian whether he had received a fax.

HEADLINE: LESSONS; 
The SAT Debate Ought to Be Broader

BYLINE:  By Richard Rothstein; E-mail: rrothstein@nytimes.com.

 BODY:
A MONTH ago, when Richard C. Atkinson, president of the University of California, proposed dropping the SAT requirement for applicants, he opened a vigorous national debate on whether College Board exams properly identify students who will do well in college.
 But by focusing on how to predict academic success, the discussion has mostly skipped over a deeper issue: How do we define broader goals for college graduates? Are scores on any high school test the best way to identify young people most likely to achieve those goals? "The Shape of the River," a 1998 book by William Bowen, former president of Princeton, and Derek Bok, former president of Harvard, argued against academic performance alone and for "contributions that individuals make throughout their lives" as the aim of college admissions. 
 Most people probably agree that universities should train students for economic, political, intellectual and moral leadership. These require academic skills, but also more. 
Dr. Atkinson noted that the SAT's test of mental agility had little to do with mastery of course work and that it distorted lives of adolescents who buy costly preparation packages and agonize over tiny score changes. Instead, he proposed to find tests more aligned with secondary-school curriculums. On these, students could excel from more conscientious high school study.
But small advantages in scores on any test may not be the way to predict college graduates' community service or business creativity.
White students have higher average SAT scores than blacks. Yet a Harvard School of Public Health team found that white college students were three times as likely to engage in binge drinking. In itself, propensity for alcoholism should not disqualify youths for college, but it is not entirely irrelevant. Higher SAT scores don't predict responsibility; tests aligned with high school curriculums may not do better.
A study at the University of California at Santa Barbara found that students who sacrificed to attend -- going into debt or taking part-time jobs -- were more engaged in academic, cultural and volunteer activities than affluent students with higher SAT scores. Dr. Bowen and Dr. Bok reached similar conclusions.
Surely college students need academic competence. But a qualifying level can be set by a passing score on standardized exams. Beyond that, score gradations are less important.
Little is known about forecasting college or lifetime success; research predicts only freshman grades. Students with higher SAT scores do slightly better in freshman year than those with lower, but the margin is small. Better high school grades also predict slightly higher freshman grades. Scores on College Board subject tests (called SAT II exams) do the same. The three do slightly better in combination.
But nobody knows if these can predict later college grades or completion, or character, creativity, civic engagement, religious leadership or business acumen.
The University of Texas now admits students in the top 10 percent of high school classes, without regard to SAT scores; Florida admits the top 20 percent. That approach tries to ensure that entering classes include at least some top students from mostly minority schools.
Opponents condemn such percentage plans, because one school's A may denote less knowledge than another's B. Yet this valid criticism fails to ask what qualities of ambition, discipline and sacrifice take youths to the top ranks of troubled schools. Might immigrant 10-percenters from El Paso be better bets for leadership than lower-ranked students from Dallas, though the latter do better on tests?
The University of California has a similar admissions policy, for the top 4 percent. With the university taking three times that many graduating high school seniors from within the state, the plan has barely affected admissions; SAT scores still play a big role. Instead of calling for a better standardized test, Dr. Atkinson might have urged including a larger percentage of top-ranked students. A gradual expansion could be monitored to be certain admitted students can do college work.
Of course, it would be wrong for colleges to drop the preparation of academic stars as their exclusive goal for the sake of adopting an equally extreme notion that they should produce only moral, political or economic leaders. Universities' multifaceted roles are what make admissions complex.
Dr. Atkinson stepped gingerly beyond a narrow goal of seeking better academic merit, saying campuses should also seek students who make great progress in troubled circumstances. But he did not say whether such students are desirable because they will get better grades or because they have other strengths.
The California proposal invites a broader discussion of universities' mission, and which traits predict high school applicants' contributions to it. That discussion should begin.

HEADLINE: School Management Company Faces Ouster in San Francisco 

BYLINE:  By EDWARD WYATT 

 BODY:
The private company trying to win approval to manage five low-performing public schools in New York City has moved a step closer to having a similar contract revoked in San Francisco.
 An investigation by the San Francisco Unified School District of complaints lodged against Edison Schools Inc. and the charter school it operates there concluded that the company violated several terms of its charter. According to a report issued by the district on Monday, the violations included inadequate financial reporting and Edison's failure to have an independent community board oversee the school. 
 But the investigation found no statistically significant evidence that the school tried to persuade academically deficient or special education students to leave, as critics have charged.
The San Francisco school board was expected to vote last night on a resolution to revoke the Edison school's charter. If the resolution passes, as is expected, the district is required to give the company 90 days to correct the violations. If adequate steps have not been taken by then, the district can revoke the contract, which runs through the end of the 2002-03 school year.
On Monday, the board's curriculum committee voted 2 to 1 to recommend that the full board vote in favor of the resolution, and board members who have stated their belief that the Edison contract should be revoked make up a majority of the board.
The San Francisco vote comes as Edison Schools is in engaged in an election, which ends on Friday, in New York City on a proposal to run five low-performing schools beginning next fall. The parents of a majority of the students in each of the New York schools must approve a measure to convert the schools to charters under Edison's management. 
Jill Wynns, the president of the San Francisco school board and a vocal opponent of Edison, said, "Although we recognize that a number of parents are satisfied with the education their children are receiving at Edison, the fact is that we've received a great many complaints indicating serious deficiencies that we are obligated to investigate."
Gaynor McCown, an Edison Schools executive, yesterday called the district's investigation "a sham." The company provided a detailed response to the report, presenting evidence that contradicts some of the district's conclusions about test scores and a changing student population. 
"Are there issues?" Ms. McCown said. "Yes, there may be one or two small issues. Does it rise to the level of revoking the charter? Absolutely not."
The district's report also faulted Edison for high teacher turnover after each of its first two years managing the school. In the spring of 1999, after Edison's first year operating the school, 21 of 26 teachers left in a dispute over Edison's longer working hours. Edison agreed to a pay increase for teachers, but 18 of 25 teachers left after the second year, according to the investigation.
The inquiry also found that a free after-school program managed by a community group moved out of the school after Edison asked the group to pay rent for its space in the school. The Edison school now runs an after-school program that charges parents about $200 a month, the report said.
The report states that after Edison took over, the school's population of students who are classified as "English language learners" and economically disadvantaged declined, but its population of Latino students and students classified as educationally disadvantaged increased.
