HEADLINE: Arizona Owes Growth Spurt Largely to an Influx of Hispanics 

BYLINE:  By MICHAEL JANOFSKY 

DATELINE: DENVER, March 27 

 BODY:
Population growth that is giving Arizona two additional Congressional seats came about largely because of a soaring Hispanic population in the state in the last 10 years, according to census figures released today.
 As the state population grew to 5.1 million in 2000, a 35.4 percent increase over the 1990 adjusted population of 3.7 million, the Hispanic population grew by nearly 80 percent, to 1.29 million from 733,153. Hispanics now make up a quarter of the Arizona population, compared with less than 20 percent a decade ago. 
 The 2000 census shows non-Hispanic whites being nearly 64 percent of the population, compared with 57 percent in 1990; American Indians, nearly 5 percent, a drop of 0.68 of a percentage point from 1990; and blacks, about 3 percent, a drop of 0.24 of a percentage point. 
The new census also showed that unlike in Florida and other states where the rising numbers are spread out fairly evenly around the state, the growth in Arizona was highly concentrated in metropolitan areas. The state's most populous county, Maricopa, which includes Phoenix, grew by 40.9 percent, to 3 million from 2.1 million in 1990.
Pima County, which borders Mexico and includes the state's second-largest city, Tucson, grew by nearly 23 percent, to 843,746.
Tom Rex, research manager for the Center for Business Research at Arizona State University, said the growing number of Hispanics in Arizona reflected a vacuum in the labor pool. With fewer native-born people to fill jobs as the country's economy was heating up in the early 1990's, he said, larger numbers of Hispanics were drawn to fill the jobs, which paid higher wages than were available in Mexico and other countries.
"We don't know yet how many of these people came from other countries or from California and Texas," Mr. Rex said. "But it's fair to conclude that the bulk of them entered the country illegally. In a sense that immigration bailed the country out. Otherwise, a labor shortage would have had a real effect on our economy."
To examine population trends in the last decade, The New York Times compared 2000 census figures to adjusted figures from the 1990 census to improve accuracy after the completion of the 1990 census.
The adjusted 1990 figures were based on a detailed survey of 170,000 households conducted several months after the original census was completed. The second survey found that the 1990 census missed 8 million people, many of them poor blacks and Hispanics, and that it double-counted about 4 million people.

HEADLINE: Florida Has More Hispanics Than Blacks, Census Shows 

BYLINE:  By DANA CANEDY 

DATELINE: MIAMI, March 27 

 BODY:
Leading a shift in the ethnic and racial makeup of the country, Florida now has more Hispanic residents than blacks, 2000 census data released today show.
 A million more Hispanics moved to Florida in the last decade, causing a surge in the statewide population that will enable the state to gain two Congressional seats. 
 "This is higher growth than we thought we'd be having," said Lance DeHaven-Smith, associate director of the Florida Institute of Government at Florida State University. Florida's overall population grew by three million residents, or 23.5 percent in the 1990's, census data show. 
Also surprising was the fact that the Hispanic population had spread throughout the state and was no longer concentrated in the south. Statewide, the Hispanic population grew by about 63 percent to 2.7 million people. Hispanics now account for 16.8 percent of Florida residents. 
The growth among Hispanics here is being driven not just by a surge in Cuban-Americans but also by people from Mexico, Puerto Rico, Colombia and other Latin American countries.
Considering plentiful service jobs, proximity to their countries of origin and government services that support immigrants, the growth of the Hispanic population in Florida is understandable.
"Because Spanish is spoken so often here, it draws individuals and investors from Latin American countries here," said Katherine Condon, demographer and research associate at Florida International University. "They feel comfortable coming to Florida because they can speak their own language."
In addition to giving Florida more political power in Washington, the growth in the Hispanic population also promises to affect politics, public education, the labor force and the economy.
"The diversity among Hispanics is certainly growing," Ms. Condon said.
And along with it, Hispanics' political influence should grow, too, and not just in Miami, which has a politically powerful, well-established Cuban-American population.
"Because Cubans have gotten into the political and economic structure, then other groups of Hispanics can use that to get their foot in the door," Ms. Condon said. 
The state's most populous county, Miami-Dade, grew by 16 percent, to 2.3 million people. The number of Hispanics there, meanwhile, grew by 338,330 people, or 35.5 percent.
Black Floridians, demographers said, risk being overshadowed as the third-largest segment of the state's population. The percentage of blacks in Florida increased to 14.4 percent, from 13.3 percent in the last decade. The new data show that 2.3 million blacks live in Florida.
The comparison of census data uses an adjusted figure for 1990 that was revised to include estimated undercounted residents. The 2000 census is considered more accurate and was not adjusted.
Though the data released yesterday did not include a breakdown by age of the state's residents, the growth among non-Hispanics can almost certainly be attributed to an increase in retirees, demographers said.
"They keep coming for the dream as much as anything else," said Mr. DeHaven-Smith of the Florida Institute of Government at Florida State. "That dream is warm weather, flowered shirts, outside life on the beach. And that has become part of our culture." 
He said growth in some counties in central and northern Florida reflected both the spreading out of the state's Hispanic population and retirement-age citizens looking to move farther from urban centers. The trend began in Miami and is continuing in places like Orlando and Tampa.
"We have watched this population move literally up the coast," Mr. DeHaven-Smith said. "In the 1970's, Miami was a Jewish retirement community. This is the exact same place that was little brown Jewish women laying in the sun. Today it is Hispanic women on Roller Blades."

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST 

 BODY:
Democrats Propose Giving $300 to Every Taxpayer
Democrats introduced legislation in the Senate that would give all taxpayers a $300 rebate check this year and give most of them $150 more by withholding less money from their paychecks in the second half of the year. Some Democrats said this would relieve the pressure on them to vote for the tax-rate reduction over 10 years that President Bush favors.
 At the same time, the president's plan to abolish the estate tax suffered a serious blow. The congressional staff that puts the price tag on tax measures calculated repealing the tax on large estates would cost two and a half times what had been projected. Page A16. 

Rate Rise Approved in California
California's power regulators approved the largest utility rate increases in state history to avert more blackouts and keep electricity producers from collapsing in bankruptcy. A1.

Abbott to Cut Price of H.I.V. Drugs
In the latest drug industry response to the growing global debate on the prices of AIDS drugs, Abbott Laboratories said it would sell two of its treatments for H.I.V. infection at "no profit" in Africa. The announcement comes after similar offers by Merck and Bristol-Myers Squibb. Shares of Abbott Laboratories rose 53 cents, to $44.78. C9.

Severance Pay Considered for Some
Computer Associates is considering offering severance payments to some of the employees it fired in what the workers described as a mass layoff that they said was disguised as individual firings of nonperforming workers so the company could avoid paying benefits. C5.

Stocks Gain on Confidence Report
Stocks climbed again after investors were heartened by an unexpectedly strong report on consumer confidence. The Dow Jones industrial average gained 260.01 points, or 2.7 percent, to 9,947.54. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index jumped 29.48 points, or 2.6 percent, to 1,182.17. And the Nasdaq composite index rose 53.77 points, or 2.8 percent, to 1,972.26. C15.

Nasdaq moved into Europe, announcing plans to take over and transform Easdaq, an ailing exchange that has been languishing for several years. World Business, Section W.

Nortel Says Its Loss Will Be Bigger
Nortel Networks, the maker of fiber optic equipment, forecast a wider first-quarter loss and lower sales than it had estimated. C4.

The Coffee Doctor in Italy
Andrea Illy, chief executive of illycaffe, an upscale coffee marketer in Trieste, Italy, said coffee had always been a part of his life, but as a child, he did not plan to join the family business. "I dreamed of being a sports car racer or a neurosurgeon," he said. After college, he added, he was all set to enter medical school when his family intervened. "I was the only scientific-minded sibling who could further the family mission of coffee-science research. So I returned to Italy and got my Ph.D. in biochemistry." The Boss. C10.

'Gone With the Wind' in Court Case
An Atlanta trust for the benefit of Margaret Mitchell's heirs has sued to block the publication of a novel that retells parts of "Gone With the Wind" from a slave's perspective. C7.

Napster Accused of 'Failure'
The Recording Industry Association of America asked a federal court to tighten controls on Napster, saying its filtering system for copyrighted files had been wholly ineffective. C4.

Argentina Moves Ahead on Economy
The lower house of Argentina's Congress moved slowly to approve the details of a new policy sought by the nation's economy minister, Domingo Cavallo. C8.

Chances Dim for Trade Settlement
With only days to go before an agreement limiting Canadian lumber exports to the United States expires, chances have dimmed for a quick resolution. World Business, Section W.

HEADLINE: WORLD BUSINESS BRIEFING: ASIA; 
STIMULUS FOR MALAYSIA

BYLINE:  By Wayne Arnold 

 BODY:
 Prime Minister Mahathir Mohamad of Malaysia announced a 3 billion ringgit ($789 million) fiscal stimulus package to offset the effects of a global slowdown on his country's export-driven economy. 
In addition to new spending to build schools and universities, Mr. Mahathir said his government would accelerate the construction of a controversial hydroelectric dam in the rain forests of Borneo, lower social security payments by workers and require banks to increase lending 8 percent a year. Stock-ownership regulations will be eased to encourage foreign investment, but the prime minister's decision in 1998 to peg the nation's currency to the United States dollar will stand. Wayne Arnold

HEADLINE: Business Travel; 
Competition among premium airline services intensifies.

BYLINE:  By Joe Sharkey; The Business Travel column appears each Wednesday. E-mail: jsharkey@nytimes.com.

 BODY:
AS the list of movies nominated for the Academy Awards indicated, people can sit through just about anything for two hours.
 Hence many frequent business travelers accept the discomfort of a cramped airline seat in steerage -- on a short flight. But even as businesses begin cutting back on travel expenses, many of the most frequent business travelers, who also tend to be among the most highly valued employees, are still demanding premium accommodations, especially on those all-night flights across the Atlantic or those 15-hour slogs to Asia. 
 "The way I see it, I'm working 24-7 when I'm traveling, which I do a couple of times a month, and I deserve a certain basic level of comfort," said a young investment banker who regularly flies from New York to London. She usually takes in Virgin Atlantic's new Upper Class service, started late last year to appeal to the well-heeled business traveler. It features sleeper-bed seats, lavish departure and arrival lounges, and amenities like massages. 
"Flying in comfort is nonnegotiable, from my point of view," she added. "The day somebody tells me to fly coach is the day I look for another job."
There's no doubt that corporate controls have suddenly tightened on air fares and hotels. In the last few weeks, several major domestic airlines have warned that their first-quarter profits will suffer, partly because companies cut travel spending this winter as the flagging technology industry sent the economy south.
On the other hand, business travel remains a long-term imperative in a global economy where, according to Business Travel Executive magazine, 80 percent of corporate travel departments will be booking international trips by the end of this decade. And according to a recent survey by Runzheimer International, nearly three-quarters of 182 North American travel managers questioned reported an increase in domestic business travel last year despite rising costs, and a 51 percent increase in international trips. 
Naturally, the recent cutbacks in business travel, the most profitable market segment for airlines, are worrisome for the carriers, given uncertainties about how long the situation will last. But even as cuts are made in some areas of travel, many airlines and company travel departments are also grappling with a separate question: How much of the corporate air fare dollar will continue going toward an increasing supply of first-class, business-class and premium economy-class seats that airlines have been rushing to add to attract weary business travelers? 
Last year, British Airways and Virgin Atlantic, the two major British carriers on the lucrative North Atlantic routes, led an audacious new push for the premium long-haul market, about 90 percent of which is business travel. British Air spent $300 million while the considerably smaller Virgin Atlantic spent $100 million to redesign cabins with more, and more luxurious, accommodations, including pod-like sleeper seats, high-quality food and in-seat entertainment systems.
Many other long-haul domestic and foreign airlines have also been rushing to refurbish their higher-end services.
Long-haul carriers laid down these high-stakes bets on the premium business-travel market just before the United States economy became shaky, however. While both British Air and Virgin Atlantic reported that their premium services continued growing last month, competition is intensifying in a tough market. As a result, corporate travel departments are probably going to be driving tougher deals when they spring for premium travel. 
"Companies are certainly exercising much tighter control over costs," said Ray Grainger, the general manager for sales at British Airways, which dispatches marketing teams to corporate travel departments to help tailor in-house travel policies to channel more customers into its Club World business class or its World Traveler Plus premium coach.
Some companies, he said, "just recognize that there is more to life than just the cheapest price, so therefore they'll pay a bit more money in order to realize a better quality of service for their employees when they travel around the world."
Airlines typically negotiate volume discounts with business clients, and neither British Air nor Virgin Atlantic officials would say how much a seat in their competing premium cabins really costs when purchased by a loyal corporate client. For round-trip travel between New York and London, Virgin lists Upper Class walk-up fares at $6,900; British Air's competing Club World fare is $6,800.
Whichever way the economy goes, one interesting note to the battle for the high-end market is that airlines are now openly promoting the services not as a way to get more work done, but as a way for executives to relax, sleep, dine well or have fun with a wide variety of in-seat entertainment options.
"This is the only time some of these people have to go to the cinema," said Paul Moore, the director of corporate affairs for Virgin Atlantic.

HEADLINE: Excerpts From Bush Speech Promoting His Tax Cuts 

 BODY:
Following are excerpts from a speech by President Bush yesterday in Kalamazoo, Mich., as recorded by The New York Times.
 Oftentimes what I try to say in Washington gets filtered and sometimes my words in Washington don't exactly translate directly to the people. So I've found it's best to travel the country. I'm coming in from Billings, Mont. We had about 12,000 people show up last night to hear -- gave me a chance to talk -- about what tax relief means and common-sense budgeting will do for our nation. 
 You see, it's the president's job to look for warnings of economic trouble ahead and to heed them, and to act. I got elected because the people want the president to act, and that's exactly what I'm going to do. My approach is based upon common sense, and here it is:
We must put more money in the hands of consumers in the short term and restore confidence and optimism for the long term. We need an immediate stimulus for our economy and a pro-growth environment for years to come. Some in Congress want America to choose between these goals, to think of the moment and not the future. But lasting prosperity requires long-term thinking, and if we face facts and act boldly, I'm confident we can build the long-term prosperity we seek. . . . 
In the short term, the American consumer needs a hand. About 25 million families are carrying more than $10,000 in credit-card debt. Many families have tried to reduce their debt by tapping into their home equity and, partly as a result, the average homeowner's equity share in his or her house declined in the 1990's. More than a few consumers counted on their earnings in the stock market to help them carry their obligations. They need tax relief fast. In fact, they need it yesterday. So I strongly support the idea of backdating tax relief to get cash into the consumers' hands as swiftly as possible. And I applaud the members of Congress, Republicans and Democrats, who have come forward to endorse quick action on tax relief. Yet our economy needs more than a pick-me-up, more than a one-time boost.
Our economic health depends on people feeling comfort and confidence about long-term decisions to start a new business, to invest in a new idea, to buy a new home. And the people who make those decisions don't care only about this year's tax rate; they care about next year's rate and the year after that. 
Immediate tax relief is good news, but tax relief that gets yanked away next year is not such good news. Lower rates do not stimulate much economic activity unless people can rely on them for years down the road. We must rebuild business confidence and market confidence and consumer confidence through a permanently improved business environment.
Lower tax rates mean a new home will be more affordable, not just the first year, but every year. Lower rates mean that a new investment will have a better chance of success, not just the first year, but every year. Lower rates mean that a start-up company will keep more of its earnings, and not just the first year, but in every year.
The long-term growth of our economy also depends not only on real, meaningful tax reductions, but also on increasing productivity. America has prospered more than any other major economies in recent years because our productivity has grown faster than that of other major economies, and faster than we ourselves once believed possible. Since 1995, in fact, productivity has grown nearly twice as fast as it did between 1975 and 1995.
And what makes productivity go up? Well, you know as well as anybody, it's education and investment. If our productivity is to continue to grow, our people must know more tomorrow than they know today. They must read better. They must calculate faster and more accurately. They must understand science more deeply. So our education policies must insist upon results. We must be bold enough to measure our children's progress. We must hold schools accountable. And we must give parents and children better options if our schools fail to teach and will not change. And if our productivity is to continue to grow, our tools and machinery and equipment must work better and faster.
Our present tax code discourages investment by small business and entrepreneurs. The vast majority of American businesses pay tax on the personal schedule, not the corporate schedule. It's important for Congress to hear this. The number of unincorporated businesses and sole proprietors are huge. But they're the backbone of economic vitality in America. Back in 1990, they faced a top rate of 28 percent. Today the unincorporated business can face a maximum federal rate of nearly 40 percent.
Those taxes come right out of cash flow, making it harder for small-business owners to make investments that raise productivity, boost incomes, provide benefits to their workers. High taxes discourage potential entrepreneurs from taking the risk of starting a new business in the first place. Small business generates approximately 75 percent of America's net new jobs. High tax rates are weighing those businesses down.
And so I've submitted a plan that not only reduces the rate at the bottom end of the economic spectrum, but raises the top rate as well, to give small businesses the lift they need to continue providing the job base that'll keep America strong.

LENGTH: 428 words

HEADLINE: The President on the Economy 

 BODY:
President Bush took to the road yesterday to assert his authority as the nation's economic helmsman and plug for Congressional passage of his unaffordable and regressive 10-year, $1.6 trillion tax cut proposal. "It's the president's job to look for warnings of economic trouble ahead and to heed them, and to act," he told Michigan businessmen. "I got elected because the people want the president to act, and that's exactly what I'm going to do." But of course he cannot award tax cuts unilaterally, and the political motivation for his foray into the hinterlands was to generate pressure on Congress to support a tax cut of the size, duration and distribution that he has proposed. 
 Mr. Bush was clearly concerned that his tax proposals may founder in the Senate, where they currently lack the votes for passage, and where Democrats are backing an immediate short-term tax cut as a way to erode support for the bigger Bush package. But his third and latest rationale for his plan is no more persuasive than the first two. 
 When the big tax cut was first proposed on the campaign trail, under far more exuberant economic conditions, Mr. Bush argued that because the government was stockpiling surpluses as the economy continued to grow, the people who pay most of Uncle Sam's bills deserved a large tax break. But once it became apparent late last year that a sudden slowdown was threatening to end the 10-year economic expansion, Mr. Bush slapped a new label on his plan. It suddenly became a necessary stimulus, never mind that only $5.5 billion of the $1.6 trillion went to taxpayers in the first year of the plan. 
On Capitol Hill, Republicans and Democrats began clamoring for more immediate tax breaks to encourage consumer spending, so yesterday the president sought to regain the initiative. He endorsed the idea of putting more money in the hands of consumers in the short term by making more of his tax cuts retroactive, and he put forth a third rationale for his overall plan. Long-term tax relief is needed, he said, to encourage investment by small businesses and entrepreneurs, thus giving a populist gloss to a cut that would mostly benefit the wealthy. 
What is most worrisome about the president's speech is that it shows an alarming lack of appreciation for the role that the prudent management of public finances played in the past decade's economic expansion. Mr. Bush's 10-year tax cut plan, with a price tag that seems increasingly as uncertain as the estimated surpluses used to justify it, is a threat to that very pillar of economic growth.

HEADLINE: Abbott to Sell Low-Cost AIDS Drugs in Africa 

BYLINE:  By MELODY PETERSEN 

 BODY:
In the latest drug industry response to the growing global debate on the prices of AIDS drugs, Abbott Laboratories said yesterday that it would sell two of its treatments for H.I.V. infection at "no profit" in Africa.
 The announcement by Abbott, based in Abbott Park, Ill., follows similar offers earlier this month by Merck and Bristol-Myers Squibb. All of the makers of AIDS drugs are under increasing pressure to reduce the prices of their medicines in African nations and other developing countries. Health officials estimate that in Africa alone, 25 million people may be infected with H.I.V. 
 And yesterday, it also became clear that the debate on the high prices of AIDS drugs is moving to the United States, where the typical cocktail of medicines that can keep the virus at bay costs $10,000 to $15,000 a year.
Members of the Consumer Project on Technology, a patient advocacy group in Washington, said yesterday that they had formed a nonprofit company that would soon ask the government to allow it to make and sell a low-cost version of d4T, an AIDS medicine that is sold by Bristol-Myers for $10 a day in the United States. The group said it believed it could sell d4T, which is sold under the brand name Zerit, for 10 percent or less of the Bristol-Myers price.
The group argues that under a 1980 law known as the Bayh-Dole Act, the government must grant the nonprofit company a license to sell a low-cost generic version of Zerit. A provision in the Bayh-Dole Act allows the government to require a company selling a drug developed with government-sponsored research to grant a license to another party if it is shown that the drug company is not making the invention available to the public on "reasonable terms." The advocates say they will show that Bristol-Myers' price for Zerit is excessive and that it is creating hardships for patients.
The consumer group says government grants covered most of the cost of discovering and developing Zerit, and the government holds certain patent rights on the drug. Yale University also holds a patent on Zerit, and in the early 1990's it granted Bristol-Myers an exclusive license to sell the drug, which was approved in 1994.
James Love, director of the Consumer Project, which was founded by Ralph Nader in 1995, said that he had researched how much Bristol-Myers paid for the clinical trials to have Zerit approved, and that he believed that the company paid less than $15 million for those trials, but has generated more than $2 billion in revenue from the drug.
A spokesman for Bristol-Myers said yesterday that Mr. Love's figures were "inaccurate." But he said he could not immediately provide the amount the company had invested to develop Zerit. Bristol-Myers earned $618 million from Zerit last year.
The government has never approved a petition under the Bayh-Dole Act. But a spokeswoman at the National Institute of Health said if the government received the petition, "it will be taken seriously."
"There is a clearly set-out process whereby a group can do this," she said.
Bristol-Myers said yesterday that it did not have an immediate comment. "This is the first that we're hearing of this, so it's impossible for us to say anything," said John Kouten, a company spokesman.
A spokesman for Yale said yesterday that officials could not comment without seeing the group's proposal.
Mr. Love said the group was in the process of appointing directors to the new company's board, which does not yet have a name. He said the group expected to file the petition with the Department of Health and Human Services in mid-April.
If the petition is successful, Mr. Love said, the group may also ask the government to let it sell cancer drugs and other medicines that the government discovered.
In the other development yesterday, Abbott Laboratories said that it was offering to sell its two antiretroviral medications, Norvir and Kaletra, in Africa at prices that would cover the company's costs of manufacturing, distribution and import duties. Rick Moser, a company spokesman, said that the price of each drug for a patient was likely to be less than $1,000 a year. The price would vary, he said, from country to country.
To receive the lower-priced drugs, Mr. Moser said, a government or group must apply to a consulting firm that Abbott has hired, Axios International, to help distribute the medicines. Those who want to buy the drugs must prove that they can properly and consistently treat patients, he said.
Patients taking AIDS medications must be monitored by health professionals to ensure that they are taking the drugs properly and are not having significant side effects.
"AIDS has taken an unprecedented toll on the health, economic and social structures of Africa," said Miles D. White, Abbott's chairman. "Abbott has taken this action to give people most affected by this disease a better opportunity to access care."
Some advocates for AIDS patients praised Abbott's move yesterday, but questioned whether the prices Abbott is offering would really provide no profit to the company.
Kate Krauss, a member of Act Up Philadelphia, said that it wanted Abbott and the other drug companies to offer voluntary licenses to their products so that generic manufacturers could make lower-priced versions of the drugs.

HEADLINE: Buffett Says Stocks Are Still Too Costly 

BYLINE:  AP 

DATELINE: LONDON, March 27 

 BODY:
Warren E. Buffett, one of America's most respected investors, said today that many United States stocks were still overvalued and their prices must decline further before he would consider them good investments.
 Mr. 
Buffett stopped short of calling the economic downturn in the United States a recession. 
 "We're in a slowdown, that's for sure," he said.
Mr. Buffett, chairman and chief executive of Berkshire Hathaway, spoke at a news conference to announce the delivery of 50 new aircraft to Executive Jet, a Berkshire Hathaway subsidiary. Executive Jet will use the Cessna aircraft for its NetJets fractional ownership program, in which several owners buy a plane on a time-share plan.
Mr. Buffett said he would start buying shares again "when businesses sell for less in the market than they're worth."
He reasserted his well-known aversion to shares in high-technology companies, saying he has not bought any, despite the plunge in share prices for dot-com businesses in the last year.

HEADLINE: Tremors in the Economy, Uncertainty in the Capital 

BYLINE:  By RICHARD W. STEVENSON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 27 

 BODY:
The politics of prosperity is giving way to the politics of uncertainty.
 Even before it becomes clear whether the nation is slipping into recession or just enduring a wrenching slowdown, Republicans and Democrats alike are scrambling to adjust to the abrupt change in the outlook from last year, when economic cockiness suffused policy and political considerations. 
 "It's like an earthquake," said Senator Max Baucus, Democrat of Montana.
After an election campaign that focused on how to apportion the spoils of affluence, President Bush now faces the possibility of governing in a period of diminished expectations. He could also confront the tricky task of dodging the blame that inevitably gets directed at the occupant of the White House when the economy turns down. 
Just today, Mr. Bush said his policies were intended to deal with "reality as we found it" upon taking office, months after the slowdown first became apparent. 
On his signature issue of tax cuts, Mr. Bush further de-emphasized his original argument: that getting the projected federal budget surplus out of Washington and into the hands of taxpayers was the only way to ensure it would not be spent on a bloated government. Instead, he called more forcefully than in the past for Congress to rework his $1.6 trillion proposal so that it gives the faltering economy an immediate kick.
For their part, Democrats have abandoned their traditional response to economic trouble: fiscal stimulus in the form of additional government spending. Determined to avoid being cast as impediments to a quick recovery, they are coalescing around a smaller tax cut that would give a sizable, one-time push to the economy in the short run and provide more of its benefits in the long run to the lower end of the income scale than would Mr. Bush's proposal.
But it is not just tax cuts that have been put in play by the changing economic landscape. The budget-surplus projections, the foundation for the agendas of both parties, will only become more suspect if the economy remains weak for an extended period. 
"I don't think there's any doubt, given what we now know about the economy, that this $5.7 trillion has already partially evaporated," the Senate Democratic leader, Tom Dachle of South Dakota, said of the projected surplus over the next decade.
With Wall Street having made the 50 percent of households that have invested in stocks feel like losers for the last few months, the drive to create personal investment accounts within Social Security could become harder to sustain. And free trade, a tough sell in Congress even during the boom of the 1990's, could face new resistance if the unemployment rate starts ticking up. 
Representative Rob Portman, Republican of Ohio, said members of Congress were already hearing about layoffs in their districts and were wondering how constituents would handle losses in the stock market and whether it would be possible to continue moving people off the welfare rolls. "Most members of this body have been here only for some pretty good times," Mr. Portman said, "and the politics of prosperity is what we've gotten used to." 
Because the economic outlook has remained so murky, members of both parties have had trouble determining how sweeping an overhaul in policy and strategy is necessary. 
Still, Republicans and Democrats too have moved with unusual speed to get out ahead of what might or might not be the end of the decade-long expansion, keenly aware that it is a cardinal sin in politics to appear detached when jobs, retirement plans and a general sense of security are on the line. 
"If you go back through the history of the postwar era, in many if not most cases the political establishment and the forecasters didn't even recognize the recession until we were well into it," said Bruce Bartlett, a senior fellow at the National Center for Policy Analysis, a conservative research group. "This time the recession was cited in advance, before it even happened. We've speeded up the whole process."
Mr. Bush has tried to pin the "downturn," as the White House has taken to calling it in the last two days, on the preceding administration. He could be lucky in getting the down phase of the business cycle out of the way early in his first term, assuming the bad news does not linger.
But a deep or prolonged economic problem would almost certainly undermine Mr. Bush's political standing. And with Republicans in control of both houses of Congress, it would not help his party, either.
In his speech in Michigan today, Mr. Bush said his policy goals after cutting taxes were to create private investment accounts within Social Security and to negotiate more free-trade deals around the world, steps he said would help maintain prosperity for the long run.
But opponents of the president's Social Security proposal have already stepped up their campaign against it, in the wake of the fall in share prices.
And even supporters of expanded trade say that winning authority from Congress this year to negotiate trade deals in Latin America and other regions could prove difficult for Mr. Bush if American workers and industries feel beleaguered by the economy.
"One of the things trade-expansion advocates have noted with dismay in recent years is that we were not getting widespread support even with low unemployment and high growth," said Daniel Tarullo, a Clinton administration official. "People fear that when those favorable economic circumstances turn, it may be even more difficult to move forward."

HEADLINE: Senate Democrats Ask $300 Rebate for Taxpayers, and Further $150 Cut for Most 

BYLINE:  By DAVID E. ROSENBAUM 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 27 

 BODY:
Seeking a political edge on the question of tax cuts, Democrats introduced legislation in the Senate today that would give all taxpayers a $300 rebate check this year and give most of them an additional $150 by withholding less money from their paychecks in the second half of the year.
 Some Democrats said this proposal, whose cost they put at $60 billion, would relieve the pressure on them to vote for the across-the-board tax-rate reduction over 10 years that President Bush favors. 
 At the same time, the president's proposal to abolish the estate tax suffered a serious blow. The Congressional staff that calculates the cost of tax legislation estimated that repealing the tax on large estates would cost $662 billion in the next 10 years, two and a half times what the White House projected when it submitted Mr. Bush's budget outline last month. 
The two developments put Republicans in Congress on the defensive.
On the question of rebates, they accused Democrats of distorting the idea Republicans first broached last week of allocating $60 billion from the budget surplus in the current fiscal year for an immediate tax cut. Republicans insist that the one-time stimulus be combined with long-term tax reduction.
Senator Don Nickles of Oklahoma, the assistant Republican leader, said of the Democrats: "What they're trying to do is give everyone $300 with no real tax cut. I don't think they want a tax cut."
Concerning estate tax repeal, Republicans threatened to twist the arms of the staff of the Joint Congressional Committee on Taxation, the nonpartisan experts who use computer models to determine what tax legislation would cost. "They need to review their methodology," Mr. Nickles said. "This is ridiculous."
Democrats, meanwhile, were upbeat after months of uncertainty about how to respond to the Bush tax plan.
"We're mystified as to why the Republicans will not take us up on their offer" to lower taxes by $60 billion this year, said Senator Tom Daschle of South Dakota, the Democratic leader. 
"Is it possible," Mr. Daschle said, "that the Republicans have just met the first tax cut they don't like, or is it that tax relief for everyone is being held hostage by their commitment to a massive tax cut for the very few?"
Republicans replied that such talk was nonsense. Asked about the Democrats' motive, Senator Pete V. Domenici of New Mexico, chairman of the Budget Committee, who first suggested the $60 billion cut for the current year, said: "Whatever they're trying to do, it isn't going to work -- from the standpoint of passing or from the standpoint of helping the economy. It's a nice gesture, but it's not what the economy needs."
Under the Democratic plan, the government would send a $300 check to everyone who paid income or payroll taxes in 2000. A couple would get $600.
In addition, the lowest income tax rate, 15 percent, would be reduced to 10 percent on the first $6,000 of taxable income for an individual and $12,000 for a couple filing jointly. That would mean a tax reduction in the second half of this year of $150 -- $300 for a couple -- which would be reflected in lower withholding from paychecks beginning July 1. 
Democrats maintained that the economy was now shaky, that Mr. Bush's plan would do nothing until next year and that their plan would give the economy a quick and needed lift. Republicans countered by saying the only way to help the economy in the long run was to give upper-income taxpayers a large tax cut that they would use to invest and create jobs.
In a speech today to the National Association of Business Economists, Treasury Secretary Paul H. O'Neill said: "Some suggest we send a rebate to taxpayers now and stop there. That's not good enough. If we want to change consumption patterns, we need to make a permanent change in people's tax burdens."
Much of this was just political jockeying, each side often seemingly more interested in making a case than in passing legislation. But at the day's end, it seemed possible that a compromise could be worked out.
Senator Charles E. Grassley of Iowa, chairman of the Finance Committee, suggested that Republicans might be willing to pass a stimulative tax cut for this year if Democrats would agree on a specific date later in the spring for a vote on Mr. Bush's long-term tax plan.
Democrats did not completely reject the idea. "That forms the basis of a discussion," said Senator Kent Conrad of North Dakota, the top Democrat on the Budget Committee.
The debate on taxes and the budget is centered in the Senate, evenly divided between Republicans and Democrats, because the House of Representatives now operates in so rigidly a partisan manner that the outcome is predictable and compromise is out of the question.
Three weeks ago, on a nearly straight party-line vote, the House approved the across-the-board tax-rate reduction that the president sought. 
On Wednesday, a vote is scheduled in the House on a budget blueprint that closely tracks the president's proposals. On Thursday, the House plans to vote on two other aspects of Mr. Bush's tax plan: a tax cut for married couples and an increase in the tax credit for families with children.
The House Ways and Means Committee is scheduled this week to consider the other big item in Mr. Bush's tax package, a gradual repeal of the gift and estate tax. But the prospects for such a measure were shaken by the cost projection from the staff of the joint tax committee.
In the budget outline it sent Congress last month, the White House estimated that the 10-year cost of the phased-in repeal would be $266.6 billion. But the committee staff built into its computer model various legal strategies wealthy taxpayers would use to avoid income taxes if there was no gift or estate tax, and concluded that the true cost over 10 years would be $662.2 billion.
Moreover, that figure assumed that people with large inheritances would be subject to capital gains tax on the inherited property, an additional tax that Mr. Bush did not include in his proposal. Without the capital gains element, the cost of the Bush plan would be even higher.

HEADLINE: Greenspan Calls for Better Data Collection 

BYLINE:  AP 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 27 

 BODY:
The biggest payoffs in efforts to improve economic forecasts are likely to come from raising the quality of the data collected, Alan Greenspan, the chairman of the Federal Reserve, said today.
 Mr. Greenspan said that economists needed to put more emphasis on ways to better analyze the output of an increasingly complex society. 
 He said this effort was likely to yield more benefits than building ever-more-complex computer models that try to predict where the economy is headed.
"I suspect greater payoffs will come from more data than from more technique," Mr. Greenspan said in remarks delivered to the National Association for Business Economics.
He said that in the 1960's, economists were "increasingly mesmerized by the possibilities of econometric models as a crystal ball for the future." 
But it became apparent, he said, that even the most sophisticated models had drawbacks.
"We soon learned that the economic structure did not hold still long enough to capture its key relationships," he said.
Mr. Greenspan told members of the association, which represents economists working for businesses and government agencies in the United States, that while the Federal Reserve had found economic models useful, he thought that greater benefits in forecasting would come from devoting resources to improving the data that was collected.
He said this effort was critical, given that the economy is now much more greatly influenced by fields like computer technology and medical services that are hard to measure in terms of the gross domestic product.
"Over time, and particularly during the last decade or two, an ever-increasing share of G.D.P.," Mr. Greenspan said, "has reflected the value of ideas more than material substance or manual labor input."
In an age of the microprocessor, fiber optics and the laser, he added, the problem of precisely measuring output has grown more complex.
He said the Fed and other agencies were devoting more resources to improving methods of measuring the economy, and adding, "I am encouraged by the progress that economists and economic statisticians have been making to date in tackling the daunting task of measuring real output and prices in a rapidly changing economy."

HEADLINE: Giuliani Calls for Tightening Controls on Electricity Rates 

BYLINE:  By ERIC LIPTON 

 BODY:
Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani called yesterday for the temporary imposition of more stringent price controls on wholesale electric power rates in New York State, saying that with last summer's surge in prices and the discomforting shortage of extra power supplies in the city, government intervention is needed.
 The proposal -- outlined yesterday in a speech to more than a hundred Wall Street, real estate and electric utility executives -- represents a subtle redirection of blame by the mayor for last summer's spike in electric prices and similar jumps he fears might result this year. 
 Last summer, after retail prices increased 43 percent in July, the mayor blasted power companies for gouging the public. Now he is turning his sights toward the state and the federal government's management of electric power deregulation, saying that with a limited supply of power in New York City and growing energy demand, it is too early to allow power generators to freely set their own prices. 
"The double-digit price increases that New Yorkers had to pay last summer are just unacceptable," the mayor said in a speech at the historic 23 Wall Street, former headquarters of J. P. Morgan & Company.
"Deregulation should not be abandoned, it should be completed," the mayor, a Republican, continued. "The problem is, unfortunately, when it was done we didn't think through all of the impacts it would have, how quickly it would have an effect on us, and it needs some adjustment right now."
New York City, Mr. Giuliani said, should be able to avoid the waves of power blackouts that have plagued California, another state that moved quickly and aggressively toward deregulation in the 1990's.
To prepare New York City for this summer -- when the city's peak power demand is expected to hit 10,535 megawatts -- a fleet of small electric generators is being installed to produce 404 megawatts, a small margin of surplus capacity, he said.
To speed the construction of the needed new permanent power plants -- four have been proposed in Queens and one each in Brooklyn, Manhattan and the Bronx -- the mayor also urged the state to accelerate environmental and regulatory reviews for the plants. And he asked civic leaders and judges not to try to block these projects and also urged more power conservation.
"This has ramifications beyond just the economy," the mayor said, referring to blackouts that could occur if the city's power supply is not increased. "It goes to whether people are going to live or die. Whether people are going to be safe."
The mayor's pleas did little yesterday to sway the power projects' critics. In a statement after his speech, opponents of several of the power plant projects disputed the need for so much new electricity capacity and questioned why most of the new or expanded plants would be built in lower income neighborhoods. 
The mayor "cannot scare New Yorkers into believing that we'll be sitting in the dark," said Eddie Bautista, a leader of Communities United for Responsible Energy. 
Mr. Giuliani anticipated such a response, saying after his speech, "I am good at teaching people reality."
The mayor's call for the Federal Energy Regulatory Commission to impose a lower price cap on wholesale electric rates in the state and perhaps the entire Northeast region put him somewhat at odds with the Pataki administration and the electric power industry. The cap is now $1,000 per megawatt hour, and the mayor's advisers said yesterday that he would like to see it set at $250.
The state's Public Service Commission and the independent organization that coordinates wholesale electricity prices are primarily backing a separate mechanism for preventing price surges this summer, a so-called circuit breaker. Unlike a fixed cap, their plan would limit the wholesale prices only when day-ahead prices surge at least $100 a megawatt hour.
The current average in New York over the last year is about $60 per megawatt hour, said Carol E. Murphy, a spokeswoman for New York Independent System Operator, which administers wholesale energy costs in the state. If a $250 cap is imposed, it could encourage electric power generators to raise their prices to this level, she said. "It would have a contradictory effect," she said.
John S. Dyson, a former deputy mayor who is advising the mayor on his energy policy, said the Giuliani administration would be open to other approaches to prevent price spikes this summer.
"As long as it works, the mayor is open to whatever everyone will agree on," Mr. Dyson said.

HEADLINE: BUSH SAYS REBATE ISN'T A SUBSTITUTE FOR HIS TAX PLAN 

BYLINE:  By FRANK BRUNI 

DATELINE: KALAMAZOO, Mich., March 27 

 BODY:
President Bush urged lawmakers today not to let the momentum in the Senate for a one-time tax rebate serve as a substitute for his 10-year tax-cutting plan that he values at $1.6 trillion, saying that the immediate measure would not do nearly enough to revive the economy.
 In a speech here that came as Mr. Bush's tax cut encountered growing trouble in the Senate, the president said that enacting a $60 billion quick-fix measure that many Senate Democrats and Republicans favor made sense only in concert with a broader, more permanent reduction in rates. 
 "Some in Congress want America to choose between these goals, to think of the moment and not the future," Mr. Bush said. "Our economy needs more than a pick-me-up, more than a one-time boost." Nonetheless, as Mr. Bush spoke, Senate Democrats introduced legislation that would give all taxpayers a $300 rebate check this year and reduce amounts withheld from their paychecks by $150 more. Such a plan, some said, would relieve the pressure on them to vote for the president's 10-year tax plan. Page A16. 
But Mr. Bush argued in his speech, which underscored an intensifying political battle over who gets credit for responding best to Americans' economic pain, that the Democrats' plan was shortsighted. 
"Our economic health depends on people feeling comfort and confidence about long-term decisions -- to start a new business, to invest in a new idea, to buy a new home," Mr. Bush said. "And the people who make those decisions don't care only about this year's tax rate; they care about next year's tax rate, and the year after that.
"Tax relief that gets yanked away next year is not such good news," the president continued. "Lower rates do not stimulate much economic activity, unless people can rely on them for years down the road."
Mr. Bush's speech, which at nearly 30 minutes ran much longer than his remarks on the stump usually do, represented one of his most forceful and wide-ranging attempts yet to make the case for his tax cut.
But it also sought to make clear to Americans that he was acutely conscious of some of the economy's troubles and that he was wholly prepared to find solutions.
Mr. Bush said, "It's the president's job to look for warnings of economic trouble ahead and heed them, and to act. I got elected because the people want the president to act, and that's exactly what I'm going to do."
Mr. Bush's comments clearly reflected his administration's concern that the enactment of a rebate, cast as the tonic the economy needed, would further jeopardize the prospects for his entire package being passed, because lawmakers would feel they had taken action and satisfied voters.
The president supports an immediate tax cut, as he made clear again today, but does not want it isolated from the rest of his plan.
The White House press secretary, Ari Fleischer, told reporters, "He will not support anything that does not permanently cut taxes, because that's an excuse for the politicians to spend more money." Mr. Fleischer meant that it would leave too much of the surplus in federal coffers for spending projects.
Mr. Bush said he wanted to take immediate and long-term steps at the same time.
"We need an immediate stimulus for our economy," Mr. Bush said, referring to some of the ideas gathering force in the Senate without throwing his explicit support behind any single measure. He later added that Americans "need tax relief fast. In fact, they need it yesterday."
White House aides billed Mr. Bush's speech to businesspeople in an enormous gymnasium at Western Michigan University as a major economic address.
He framed his proposals for energy exploration, improvements in public education, free trade and private investment accounts within the Social Security system as facets of an overall strategy that would encourage economic growth.
Mr. Bush also seemed to be responding to critics who had claimed that his administration's expressions of economic gloom, which they have used to build support for a tax cut, had only made matters worse.
The president tempered his stated worries about the economy with statements of faith in its essential sturdiness, describing it as a "great athlete" who is "somewhat winded but fundamentally strong."
"This is an economy that has done amazing things," Mr. Bush added, "and it's on the verge of even greater accomplishments and achievements." 
But Mr. Bush also pointed to an array of statistics that suggested that economic growth had begun slowing long before he took office.
"As many Americans know firsthand, U.S. stock markets have been declining steadily for more than a year," he said, ticking off the percentage declines over the last year in major stock indexes. "In the final quarter of 2000, the American economy grew at a sluggish 1.1 percent pace."
Mr. Bush said that he had chosen to deliver his speech in Michigan because unemployment here had risen more over the last year than in any other state. It was 4.5 percent in February, up from 3.3 percent a year earlier, according to state figures.
But the president also wanted to put pressure on Michigan's two Democratic senators, Carl Levin and Debbie Stabenow, to back his tax cut, which has yet to garner the support it needs in a Senate divided 50-50 along party lines.
The most expensive element of Mr. Bush's 10-year plan is an across-the-board reduction in tax rates, and many Senate Democrats and moderate Republicans have expressed particular concern about Mr. Bush's desire to lower the top rate to 33 percent from 39.6 percent.
As Mr. Bush explained his thinking today, he at one point bobbled his words, saying that his plan "not only reduces the rate at the bottom end of the economic spectrum, but raises the top rate as well."
He defended a top-rate reduction as a measure that would help the many businesses that essentially file taxes as individuals.
"Those taxes come right out of cash flow, making it harder for small-business owners to make investments that raise productivity, boost incomes, provide benefits to their workers," he said.
Mr. Bush portrayed himself as someone pursuing a solution driven by common sense, not party ideology, and invoked a former Democratic president for that purpose.
"John F. Kennedy supported tax cuts to jump-start a sluggish national economy, in the 1960's," Mr. Bush said, adding that a former Republican president, Ronald Reagan, had effectively used the same tool "to break us out of stagflation in the early 1980's."
A sweeping tax cut now, Mr. Bush added, would help the economy "come roaring out of its doldrums."

HEADLINE: SENATORS DEFEAT EFFORT TO DERAIL A SOFT-MONEY BAN 

BYLINE:  By ALISON MITCHELL 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 27 

 BODY:
The Senate handed a decisive victory today to the supporters of an overhaul of the campaign finance law, comfortably defeating a rival proposal that would have limited but not prohibited the unregulated large donations to the political parties that escalated to nearly $500 million in the last election.
 The 60-to-40 vote to kill the centerpiece of legislation sponsored by Senator Chuck Hagel, Republican of Nebraska, reflected strong Senate sentiment to enact a ban on the unrestricted donations, which are known as soft money. The ban is at the heart of legislation sponsored by Senators John McCain, Republican of Arizona, and Russell D. Feingold, Democrat of Wisconsin. Roll call and news analysis, Page A18. 
 Although Mr. Hagel had the backing of Republican leaders and tacit support from President Bush, Mr. McCain and Mr. Feingold picked up a handful of Republican supporters. 
"Our principal goal has been for a long time to get rid of soft money," Mr. Feingold said. "This was the vote that got rid of soft money."
Even Senator Mitch McConnell, the Kentucky Republican who has long been the chief opponent of the McCain-Feingold legislation, conceded that if any campaign finance bill makes it through the Senate this week, "it will not have a penny of soft money in it."
However, in a reminder that Senators McCain and Feingold still face perilous challenges as they try to shepherd their measure to passage, Mr. McConnell would not commit today to a final vote on the campaign finance legislation on Thursday. And he left open the possibility of using parliamentary maneuvers, like a filibuster, to block a final vote.
"We scripted the beginning," Mr. McConnell said in a pointed exchange with Mr. McCain about how the voting would proceed. "We did not script the end."
The McCain-Feingold bill has been killed repeatedly in the last five years by Republican-led filibusters. The Senate majority leader, Trent Lott, has said he will discourage such a tactic this time. Mr. McCain and some Democratic supporters warned today that they would tie up the Senate if they were denied a final vote. And the vote defeating Mr. Hagel's limit on soft money suggested for the first time that they might be able to break a filibuster. 
Other challenges loom this week for Mr. McCain and Mr. Feingold, including the question of whether quarter-century-old limits on regulated donations will be raised and by how much. The two are also trying to fend off a provision that would kill the whole bill if the Supreme Court found any part of it unconstitutional.
For more than a week, the Senate had been heading toward today's critical test of strength between Mr. McCain and his close friend Mr. Hagel, whose proposal was considered the most comprehensive and potent challenge to the McCain-Feingold legislation. Under the Hagel proposal, soft-money donations would have been limited to $60,000 annually to national political parties. The limit on individual contributions to federal candidates would have tripled to $3,000 an election, and the cumulative contributions by individuals to candidates and parties would have risen to $75,000 a year. The McCain-Feingold legislation, by contrast, would ban all soft money. It would not increase the individual contribution limits. It would increase the cumulative total for individuals to $30,000 a year from $25,000.
Mr. Hagel argued that Mr. McCain's bill would "weaken the parties and put more control in the hands of wealthy individuals and independent groups that are accountable to no one." Mr. Hagel presented his measure as a compromise, saying it was one that was "constitutional, does not weaken political parties and that President Bush will sign." 
Mr. Hagel's opponents said that if all the provisions of his measure were added up, couples could still donate $540,000 every two-year election cycle to candidates and parties, and it would do little to limit the influence of money in politics. 
"The Hagel bill is so watered down, has so many loopholes in it, it is like Swiss cheese," said Senator Charles E. Schumer, Democrat of New York.
In a sign that Mr. Hagel knew he lacked the votes to win, he moved unexpectedly in the last minutes of debate to split his bill into three parts and have a separate vote on each.
The Senate killed by a vote or 52 to 47 his proposal to triple the individual contribution limits to candidates and parties, an increase opposed by many but not all Democrats. By even greater numbers, it defeated his proposal to cap soft-money contributions to the national political parties at $60,000 a year. Two Democrats -- Senators John B. Breaux of Louisiana and Ben Nelson of Nebraska -- broke with their party to vote for Mr. Hagel's cap on soft money. Twelve Republicans broke with their party to vote against the cap. 
Mr. McCain and Mr. Feingold also tried to defeat Mr. Hagel's provisions for increased disclosure requirements for candidates, parties, groups and individuals. But when it became clear that the provisions would pass, senators began switching their votes to be on the side of disclosure, and the provisions were ultimately approved unanimously. Negotiations continued behind the scenes over proposals to raise the limits on regulated contributions that individuals can make to candidates and political parties. Even some supporters of the McCain-Feingold measure say that the 1974 contribution limits are now impractical because they were never adjusted for inflation. But the debate is over how much they should be increased.
Democrats lag behind Republicans at this kind of fund-raising and many of them fear large increases. Senator Tom Daschle of South Dakota, the minority leader, said today that he would "reluctantly" support an increase in the current individual limit of $1,000 a year to a candidate to $2,000. He said that could be coupled with an increase in the cumulative limit on donations to parties and candidates from the current $50,000 a campaign cycle to $65,000.
But he said: "That's as far as I can go. I want to serve notice." 
In a sign that the McCain-Feingold coalition could still fracture, the Senate began debate on a proposal by Senator Fred Thompson, Republican of Tennessee, to raise the individual donation limit to $2,500 and the cumulative two-year limit to $100,000. 
Supporters of the overhaul legislation also face a critical battle over whether it will be subject to an all-or-nothing review by the Supreme Court. Mr. Bush, many Republicans and some Democrats say that to ensure a balanced bill they want to include a provision calling for the entire bill to be struck down if any part of it is found unconstitutional.
The issue took on heightened significance after Republican opponents of the McCain-Feingold bill unexpectedly teamed up with liberal Democrats on Monday night to pass an amendment sponsored by Senator Paul Wellstone, Democrat of Minnesota, that broadly restricts political advertising by outside groups in the last days before an election.
Some Republicans who voted for it did not hide the fact that they thought the amendment was unconstitutional and could kill the bill in court. Mr. McConnell said of his support for Mr. Wellstone's provision, "I thought that something that was a little bit unconstitutional ought to be made a little bit more unconstitutional." 
Mr. Daschle said he was working hard to convince all 50 Democrats that it was important to keep the bill's component parts severable. Mr. Lott, however, said the bill had to have an all-or-nothing clause and "that is a nonnegotiable item." --------------------

HEADLINE: At Lunch, Talk of Lieberman For President Is the Appetizer 

BYLINE:  By RICHARD L. BERKE 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 27 

 BODY:
As recently as this morning, Senator Joseph I. Lieberman of Connecticut scoffed at the idea that he would seek the Democratic presidential nomination in 2004 if Al Gore decided to run again, saying it would be "very awkward."
 But just in case Mr. Gore backs away from another bid, Mr. Lieberman is moving energetically to lay the groundwork for a campaign of his own. 
 In the most telling example, he invited nearly two dozen political operatives, old friends and Democratic thinkers to a private luncheon on Capitol Hill last week to mull over his political future.
While the participants were assembled to discuss how Mr. Lieberman could capitalize on his attention from the campaign by positioning himself as a national spokesman for centrist Democrats, several said in interviews that the underlying purpose seemed to be an effort to begin thinking about how best to frame a possible presidential race.
Many said that they and Mr. Lieberman were concerned that he not appear too brazen, and eager, to run, and that the senator even made clear that he would defer to Mr. Gore. Still, Tom Nides, Mr. Lieberman's campaign manager last year, said some attendees urged him to stop insisting that Mr. Lieberman would wait for Mr. Gore to decide.
"People said: 'That's kind of silly. Why are you precluding yourself from that?' " Mr. Nides said. "But Lieberman said, 'Gore gave me an opportunity, and I respect that.' "
For all the public protestations, participants said that the two-hour session touched on fund-raising and other mechanics necessary should the senator decide to run. "I remember some discussion about how he had done well in the last campaign in helping raise money for the ticket," one participant said.
Many said that while the longest single discussion was about an economic policy speech that Mr. Lieberman gave on Monday, it was unavoidable that the session would be interpreted as the first step toward a presidential drive. "You're not naive," a friend of Mr. Lieberman said when asked about the meeting.
Even more striking is that several top lieutenants to Mr. Gore during the campaign last year attended the luncheon on Wednesday, at the Monocle restaurant.
Among them were Ronald Klain, who was Mr. Gore's vice-presidential chief of staff and who supervised his legal team during the postelection stalemate; Tina Flournoy, Mr. Gore's finance director who became Mr. Lieberman's political director, and Stuart E. Eizenstat, an official in the Clinton and Carter administrations who has worked closely with Mr. Gore.
Others included Mickey Kantor, a former commerce secretary; Robert Barnett, a prominent lawyer and literary agent; Jim Kennedy, Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton's press secretary; Al From, chief executive officer of the Democratic Leadership Council; Sherry L. Brown, Mr. Lieberman's Senate campaign manager; and Bill Andresen, his top aide on Capitol Hill.
The attendance of the Gore loyalists by no means signifies that they would defect to Mr. Lieberman. Several people who attended said they were far from making up their minds. "There was no blood oath," one participant said. "No one signed up to do anything."
Other attendees said Mr. Lieberman's political aspirations were an unmistakable theme -- and that many of the participants could eventually form the core of a Lieberman-for-president organization.
"Joe's a national leader of the party now and there's a lot of people interested in him running," said Simon Rosenberg, president of the New Democratic Network, a group that helps moderate Democrats. "But there's a long way to go between now and 2004."
Separate from the luncheon, Mr. Lieberman is forming a political action committee and taking other steps that could help him run for president.
Dan Gerstein, Mr. Lieberman's spokesman, said the gathering was something of a kitchen cabinet for the senator. He was careful to note, though, that it was not his boss who was promoting himself as a presidential prospect.
"Any discussions about the future," Mr. Gerstein said, "were more initiated by friends who were at the meeting."
Lanny Davis, an official in the Clinton White House who has known Mr. Lieberman since their days at Yale, said: "Were there people in the room that would love Joe Lieberman to be president of the United States because they're his friends and admirers? Yes. Count me in. 
"But it's too early for him to start planning a presidential campaign. It's not too early for him to start taking advice about speaking out on issues."

Britain Reluctantly Weighs Livestock Vaccinations

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: Market Place; 
The Lehman analyst who viewed Amazon.com through a no-nonsense microscope moves on.

BYLINE:  By Gretchen Morgenson 

 BODY:
RAVI SURIA, the convertible bond analyst at Lehman Brothers who shot to fame on his rigorous and skeptical research reports on Amazon.com and other stock market darlings, has left Lehman to join Duquesne Capital Management, a $4 billion hedge fund in New York City. 
 Mr. Suria, 30, joins Duquesne as a managing director. Stanley Druckenmiller, chairman of Duquesne, was George Soros's top lieutenant at the Soros Fund group until he resigned to open his own shop last June. 
 "The past couple of years have been extremely rewarding, and Lehman was a wonderful firm to work for," Mr. Suria said. "But I am excited about this new opportunity to put my research to work for investors in the fund."
Clients of Lehman Brothers who followed Mr. Suria's advice the last year have certainly done well. The analyst burst onto the scene last June with a scathing report on Amazon in which he questioned the retailer's long-term prospects for profitability. The report was unusual for the depth of its analysis and contrasted sharply with upbeat reports on Amazon by the great majority of Wall Street firms. The day before the report came out, the stock closed at $42. Yesterday, Amazon's shares closed at $11.64.
With many Internet retailers in bankruptcy or on the brink of failure, it is hard to believe that only nine months ago Mr. Suria was virtually alone on Wall Street in questioning that Internet retailers like Amazon could be more profitable than traditional merchants. Since then, other analysts have become much more dubious about the industry in general and about Amazon's prospects in particular. 
And Mr. Suria was also a leader in debunking the investment myth that gained great currency during the Internet mania, that Web companies should be held to a more forgiving set of analytical standards. Last month, for example, Mr. Suria wrote another report on Amazon in which he predicted that the company's creditors would grow fearful of Amazon's ability to pay its bills and would stop financing the company later this year. According to a report in The New York Observer, John Doerr, an Amazon director, called Lehman's chairman in an attempt to suppress publication of the report. When it came out a few days later, Amazon dismissed the report's conclusions. 
When asked about Mr. Suria's move to the hedge fund, Bill Curry, Amazon's spokesman, said, "We have nothing to add."
In addition to his work on Amazon, Mr. Suria won praise from investors for his extensive and cautionary report on the telecommunications sector last fall. In the report, dated Nov. 2, Mr. Suria examined the extremely high debt levels amassed in the industry and predicted a severe shrinkage in stock values for the big telecommunications companies and bankruptcies for the so-called new- economy telecoms. Since then, several small companies -- including Northpoint Communications -- have filed for bankruptcy protection and many stocks of the companies still in operation have plummeted. Market values of the large companies have fallen significantly as well.
Mr. Suria, who began his career on Wall Street in 1994 at PaineWebber and rose to head its convertible bond research, was not a perennial bear. Last April, for example, he wrote a positive report on the energy sector, a call that has also proved to be prescient for investors. He joined Lehman in April 1999.
A native of India, Mr. Suria has a background in engineering but became enthralled with finance when he was studying for his M.B.A. at Tulane University. On March 16, Mr. Suria returned to Tulane to accept the first Rising Tide Award from the A. B. Freeman School of Business. The award, which is to be presented annually, is given to an outstanding alumnus of the school.

HEADLINE: Disney Is Cutting 4,000 Jobs Worldwide 

BYLINE:  By BILL CARTER 

 BODY:
In a move executives described as the most significant job reduction in the company's history, the Walt Disney Company will eliminate 4,000 jobs, about 3 percent of its work force, through buyouts and possibly mandatory layoffs, the company announced yesterday.
 The order will affect every Disney division worldwide. In a letter to employees, Michael D. Eisner, the Disney chairman, and Robert A. Iger, the president, called the job cuts "the most difficult series of decisions the company has made in the last 20 years." 
 John Dreyer, a Disney spokesman, said it was the first time the company had ever announced a worldwide reduction of its work force. The only previous big job cut in the company's history came during the Arab oil embargo of the early 1970's, which curtailed the number of visitors to Walt Disney World in Orlando, Fla., and prompted Disney to eliminate1,700 jobs there. 
Yesterday, Disney executives cited the sputtering economy and, in particular, the recent slowdown in advertising sales, which has directly affected such big Disney divisions as the ABC television network and the ESPN cable network.
The plan announced yesterday will offer employees a voluntary buyout that will include unspecified severance incentives. If the buyout does not achieve the desired cuts by July, Disney will impose mandatory layoffs with what Mr. Eisner and Mr. Iger, in their letter, referred to as "lesser severance benefits."
Disney will take a one-time charge of $250 million, the majority of which will be spread over the next two quarters, to pay for the severance expenses. Mr. Dreyer said the company expected to save $350 million to $400 million with the cuts.
But the company is not otherwise changing its immediate financial forecast. "Excluding the charge," Mr. Dreyer said, "we do not believe this will alter our previously established growth targets."
The announcement came after the close of trading on the New York Stock Exchange, where Disney's shares ended the session at $29.20, up $1.28, or 4.6 percent, on the day. 
Wall Street analysts said that the Disney jobs announcement was not surprising and that the action might help the company financially.
"How do you say when people are losing their jobs it's a good thing?" said Jessica Reif Cohen, a media analyst with Merrill Lynch. "But it is a prudent move to do this in this economic environment." With earlier cost cuts announced by the company, Disney will have saved about $900 million by fiscal year 2003. "That's a sizable number," she said.
Previously announced cuts include the decision in January to scale back the Go.com Web portal. Disney has already cut more than 500 of the 2,000 employees in the company's Internet group and has taken a $790 million charge to write down the value of its Internet assets. 
In their letters to employees yesterday, Mr. Eisner and Mr. Iger said: "We need to face up to the increasingly pressing challenges of the softening economic environment. We must also uphold investors' confidence in our future while maintaining our core commitment to quality and creativity in all we do.'
Ed Hatch, a media analyst with SG Cowen, said one part of Disney's business certain to be affected by the softening economy and the devaluation of investors' stock portfolios would be the company's theme parks. "People will think twice about taking a trip to Disney World," he said.
Indeed, Disney had already announced a hiring freeze at its largest theme park, Walt Disney World, which alone employs nearly half of Disney's overall work force of 120,000.
But Mr. Dreyer, the spokesman, said the company had taken into account projections of lower bookings in the spring and summer at its parks and was nevertheless "on track to achieve growth in park attendance" this year.
Mr. Hatch, the analyst, also said that "the same shocks" from decreased advertising that are hitting other media outlets will hit Disney and ABC this year "and they'll face it with possibly weaker programming."
Other big media companies have announced layoffs recently, including NBC, which said in January it would cut 300 to 600 jobs, 5 percent to 10 percent of its work force. AOL Time Warner announced the same month that it would eliminate 2,000 jobs, about 2 percent of its work force.
Christopher Dixon, an analyst with UBS Warburg, said that while the slower economy and the slump in ad sales were real factors in the decision, the Disney move was also consistent with the company's overall goal of cutting costs sharply.
"We'll take it at face value at this point," Mr. Dixon said. "But I think Disney may be using this as an excuse to accelerate an ongoing cost-saving policy."
Mr. Dixon noted that the Disney film studios had more or less stopped active production for now because of the threat of strikes by writers and actors later this spring. "This may be an opportunity to clean house at the studio," he said, "which is not going to need six development executives at every level."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Citing a cooling economy, Disney's chairman, Michael D. Eisner, shown in February, announced big job cuts. (Agence France-Presse)
