HEADLINE: Lose-Lose Situation 

BYLINE:  By RICHARD L. BERKE 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 27 

 BODY:
Not only did the Senate defeat the campaign finance proposal that was most to President Bush's liking today, it also raised the prospect that he might be forced into an unenviable political bind:
 Does Mr. Bush sign a measure that he has repudiated, and one that was championed by a political foe? Or does he veto the bill and open himself to attacks that the candidate who amassed the largest campaign warchest ever to win the presidency opposes reform? 
 Mr. Bush could have stomached a proposal sponsored by Senator Chuck Hagel, Republican of Nebraska. 
His aides worked ardently behind the scenes to muster support. But the measure was a colossal failure, losing the votes even of many Republicans.
That has left the president to contend with the more ambitious proposal promoted by his persistent rival from the Republican primaries, Senator John McCain of Arizona.
When it comes to Mr. Bush's approach to Mr. McCain, it may be difficult to separate the political, personal and policy considerations.
"It's a no-win," said a Republican who is close to the president. "If he signs, he capitulates to his rival. And if he vetoes it, he gives McCain one teeney step toward heroism."
Others who have talked to Mr. Bush in recent days suggested tonight that he might go ahead and sign the legislation.
"He told me that he is not in the mood of vetoing a campaign finance bill right now," said Senator Conrad Burns, a Montana Republican who flew to the state with the president for a rally earlier this week. "I think his message to us was we have to pass a bill that satisfied us." 
The hope in the White House, of course, is that the bill, which is sponsored by Mr. McCain and Senator Russell D. Feingold, Democrat of Wisconsin, will be so larded with objectionable amendments that it never survives Congress. That way, the bill could die quietly, and no one could blame the new administration.
But the McCain-Feingold measure has picked up such potency, largely because many Republicans signed onto it, that Mr. Bush must brace for the possibility it will reach him in one piece.
"When you have one bill on your desk and it's labeled 'campaign finance reform,' it is hard to veto," said Trevor Potter, an expert on election law who was Mr. McCain's counsel during last year's campaign. "The public is not going to make the fine distinctions between the various plans that all of the political players have been arguing about in the Senate."
Mr. Bush has insisted that he favors reform, and earlier this month he called for a partial prohibition of soft money, the large, unregulated donations to political parties.
But his prescription differs sharply from that of Mr. McCain and Mr. Feingold, who favor a ban on soft money. Mr. Bush endorsed a ban on such donation by unions and corporations but not by individuals.
Mr. Bush's advisers have expressed concern that the McCain-Feingold proposal would endanger their party politically. Throughout his presidential campaign last year, Mr. Bush emphasized that donors should have unfettered rights to express themselves in political campaigns and that the parties themselves should not be threatened.
His advisers asserted that the McCain-Feingold legislation could enhance the power of independent advocacy groups at the expense of the parties.
Some advisers to Mr. Bush say that he could perhaps avoid a sign-or-veto climax by working with Congressional leaders to fashion a compromise. The president already has a meeting scheduled for Wednesday with Republican House and Senate leaders.
But it would be no easy trick accommodating both Mr. McCain and Republicans on the other side of the issue, like Senator Mitch McConnell of Kentucky, who are bent on smothering the legislation.
Representative Tom DeLay of Texas, the Republican whip, sought to embolden his party to defeat the bill by saying publicly last week that Mr. Bush told him "we could not count on a veto."
"He'd have to come up with the best of both worlds," said Mickey Edwards, a former Republican representative from Oklahoma who now teaches government at Harvard. "Look like an advocate of reform and do it without buying into the idea of completely cutting off soft money. After the votes this week, Bush has to understand that people want some change."
Mr. Potter said that Mr. Bush could save face by highlighting elements that may be in the final product that the White House advocated, like a possible increase in the limits for regulated contributions.
"His choice is: Does he in fact claim credit for the things he does like, or declare defeat?" said Mr. Potter, a former chairman of the Federal Election Commission. "But can he sustain saying, 'I didn't get what I wanted?' What does that say about his leadership qualities?"
People who are close to Mr. Bush and his top aides said that no one should underestimate the enmity toward Mr. McCain and how that could play into the White House's calculations.
"I don't think he wants to surrender," the friend said of Mr. Bush. Speaking of the president's aides, he added, "I don't think they want to give John McCain this victory. And that may be an unwise posture on their part. They have to weigh how salient this is against the main issue, which is the economy right now."
Indeed, the ultimate question may not be Mr. Bush's feelings about Mr. McCain, or even about the merits of changes in the campaign finance process. It may be a question of how deeply the public cares about whether a bill is passed.
"Nobody wants to be viewed as against campaign finance reform," said Al From, who heads the Democratic Leadership Council, a group of centrist Democrats. Asked if voters really would oust a politician who is seen as anti-reform, he replied: "It's more of a symbolic issue. Will people cast their votes on it? Probably not very many."
Veto or not, the overriding question for Mr. Bush is this: Does the politician who collected a record $100 million for his campaign want to give the Democrats ammunition to deride him as the man who blocked reform, no matter how flawed he feels that reform measure may be?

HEADLINE: March Survey Of Consumers Is Brighter 

BYLINE:  By KENNETH N. GILPIN 

 BODY:
A crucial measure of consumer confidence rebounded sharply in March after falling for five consecutive months. 
 Financial markets interpreted the data, which were much better than anticipated, optimistically. Stock prices jumped after the figures were released at 10 a.m. By the close, all three major market indexes had risen by more than 2.5 percent. Page C13. 
 But economists were reluctant to read much into one monthly figure from the Conference Board. They said the recent decline in consumer attitudes might be bottoming out, which should help put a floor under measures like retail sales. 
Alan Greenspan, chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, has said many times in recent months that he considers consumer sentiment an important economic barometer. 
Economists pointed out that the performance of one indicator over one three-week period said little about the overall health of the economy and practically nothing about whether the Fed would cut short-term interest rates before its next scheduled meeting in May. 
Additional economic data, including employment figures for March, are expected to be a factor in determining when, or if, the Fed will make a move. 
"No matter how much importance Mr. Greenspan puts on the confidence data, both the equity and the bond market are probably overreacting" to the new figures, said Bruce Steinberg, chief economist at Merrill Lynch & Company. 
In its monthly report, which covered the first three weeks of March, the Conference Board said its consumer confidence index rose to 117.0 from 109.2 in February. It was the first increase since September. 
The Conference Board's monthly survey is based on a representative sample of 5,000 households across the country and is considered an important indicator because consumer spending accounts for two-thirds of the nation's economic activity. 
The confidence index reached an all-time high of 144.7 in January 2000. It reached that level again in May last year. 
Given the generally gloomy news that has been released so far this month, most economists had expected the index to post a decline. Consumer attitudes about the present situation were little changed from a month ago, but expectations about what the economy would look like in six months were much brighter. 
"If confidence is stabilizing, all that says is that consumer spending won't take off," said Donald J. Fine, chief market analyst and managing director at J. P. Morgan Chase. "These numbers are strong historically, but well off the recent peaks." 
Mr. Fine and other economists said that despite the improvement, consumer confidence remained fragile. 
Indeed, since the list of companies announcing layoffs and lower earnings rose in the first three weeks of March and since stock prices have moved sharply lower, the surprise is that confidence rose at all. 
Lynn Franco, director of the consumer research center at the Conference Board, said that as bad as things seemed earlier in March, those surveyed considered things even worse in January and February. 
"Fuel bills have been a bit smaller," Ms. Franco said, "and the shock of the dramatic slowdown from the first half of last year to the second half has lessened a bit." 
"And there could also be a sense that the Fed is on the case," she added. "One would expect the effects of easier monetary policy to filter through the system relatively soon. That may alleviate concerns about conditions getting much worse." 
Should the March employment report show a spike in the unemployment rate, the sense of unease could quickly return, economists said. Those figures are expected to be released on April 6.
"We have had a pretty ugly trend in initial unemployment insurance claims for the last five or six weeks," said David Resler, chief economist at Nomura Securities International. 
"If that trend continues or the numbers rise," Mr. Resler said, "it will be something people will sit up and take note of. If there are many more layoffs, confidence will deteriorate." 
Confidence rose in every section of the country except in the Middle Atlantic states, a region that includes New York. The consumer confidence index for the Middle Atlantic region slipped to 98.9 in March, from 101.8 in February. Respondents in the Middle Atlantic states were markedly less optimistic about the future than they had been in February.

HEADLINE: Britain Reluctantly Considers Animal Vaccination 

BYLINE:  By ALAN COWELL 

DATELINE: CARLISLE, England, March 27 

 BODY:
As Britain prepared to slaughter hundreds of thousands more healthy sheep that may have been exposed to foot-and-mouth disease, the government indicated today that it might reverse policy and use vaccination against the outbreak.
 A switch to a fiercely debated vaccination program would fuel assertions by some government critics that, after more than five weeks of rampaging infections through hundreds of farms and the killing of 441,000 pigs, sheep and cows, Prime Minister Tony Blair's government was only now acknowledging that its policy of destroying animals had failed. 
 In Parliament, Agriculture Minister Nick Brown called the epidemic "an unprecedented outbreak that has not yet reached its peak." An additional 59 cases were confirmed today, bringing the total to 694.
While Mr. Brown did not commit the authorities to a switch to vaccination, he did say that the government "is considering whether to use vaccination." 
The government has resisted vaccination out of concern it would hurt Britain's livestock and meat exports. Current tests cannot distinguish between an infected animal and a vaccinated one, making it difficult to prove that animal products are not diseased.
The European Union outlawed vaccination against foot-and-mouth disease a decade ago in order to qualify member countries' livestock and meat as free of both foot-and-mouth disease and vaccine for export to countries that included the United States.
Britain banned all meat and livestock exports when the outbreak was first identified on Feb. 19. Now, Mr. Brown said today, Britain has asked the European Union for "a contingent decision permitting the use of vaccination during the present outbreak, so that it can be deployed immediately if we conclude that is the right approach."
Earlier today, Mr. Blair himself said that a switch to vaccination, which "may have seemed utterly unpalatable a short time ago," was now "on the agenda."
Tim Yeo, the Conservatives' agriculture spokesman, said that by adopting vaccination, the government would be "admitting that its other policies have failed."
But for all the debate about vaccination, there was no sign today that the government was slowing its mass cull. More than 700,000 animals have been marked for destruction.
By tonight, military and other authorities had readied mass animal graves on the Welsh island of Anglesey, at Birkshaw Forest in southern Scotland and at a disused airfield at Great Orton near this northwestern city, where some 16,000 infected animals have already been buried. The huge pits are to be used mainly to bury apparently healthy sheep brought from farms within a two-mile radius of infected animals. The slaughter began on Anglesey today and will begin at Great Orton airfield on Wednesday, the authorities said.
Mr. Brown, the agriculture minister, also said today that the likely source of the disease was a farm in northeastern England at Heddon-on-the-Wall, where there was speculation that pigs had been fed contaminated swill containing illegally imported meat. The highly contagious disease was then carried by air to nearby sheep. The account awoke memories of Britain's earlier battle with mad cow disease, which was also ascribed to cows being fed animal matter. Mr. Brown proposed a ban on the use of swill -- used to feed fewer than one percent of Britain's 7.2 million pigs and usually made up of leftovers from restaurant, hospital and school meals. He also urged the introduction of a 20-day "standstill" period during which animals would not be transported after arriving on farms.
The speed with which the disease has spread has been linked to the distances animals now travel between farm, market and slaughter.
By the time foot-and-mouth disease was identified at Heddon-on-the-Wall, four days after it had first been diagnosed at an abattoir in Essex, 200 miles to the south, "infected animals had already spread through markets and dealers to Cumbria, Dumfries and Galloway, Devon, Cheshire, Herefordshire and Northamptonshire" -- areas stretching from southwest England to Scotland.
Mr. Brown also said it had been difficult or impossible to track the movements of infected sheep because of unrecorded animal sales. The remark reinforced suspicions among some farmers that the government was seeking to shift part of the blame to questionable farming practices.
The most contentious issue facing the government, though, is whether it should resort to vaccination, a tactic some critics call unreliable.
"I don't think the basic scientific view has changed," said Chris Bostock, head of the Animal Health Institute, who has criticized vaccination. "What has changed is what's happening in the field, and whether the circumstances now match those in which you would choose to use emergency vaccine."
The discussion is laden with scientific disputes, and the bottom-line question of the long-term economic impact and even politics. The crisis has prompted heated debate over whether Prime Minister Blair should put off plans to seek re-election in May.
In a telephone interview, Professor Bostock said the debate involved two approaches to vaccine: whether it was to be used as an emergency measure, or as "long-term policy, which means you are accepting that you have endemic disease."
Since the foot-and-mouth disease outbreak started, Britain has rejected both approaches on the grounds that vaccination would damage the export business and not necessarily work. But, with the government itself acknowledging that the epidemic has yet to peak, it is now being considered to reinforce mass culling to build a "firebreak" around the worst infected areas in Cumbria, Devon, southern Scotland and parts of Wales.
Foot-and-mouth disease, which afflicts cloven-footed mammals, is not normally fatal in animals and rarely affects humans. However, the disease produces painful blisters in the mouths and feet of infected animals which, before they recover, become unfit for sale through weight loss. Even when they do recover, they must be slaughtered before countries or regions regain their coveted status as disease- and vaccine-free exporters -- a process that can take up to a year.
Prof. Julian Wimpenny, from the Cardiff School of Biosciences, said "the technology exists now that can distinguish between an animal that's infected and one that's immunized."
But Professor Bostock at the Animal Health Institute countered that, saying that while new forms of testing were being developed that might enable veterinarians to judge the health of a herd, "even the best test available is not reliable on an individual animal."
Moreover, he said, "vaccinated animals are not necessarily protected against infection. They can still be infected and they can still act as a potential source of infection."
Britain has identified the virus afflicting its livestock as one called Pan Asian Type O. But that is only one of seven main types, all of which respond to different vaccines, and there are up to 80 sub-types. The Animal Health Institute holds 500,000 cattle-size doses of the vaccine against the Pan Asian Type O virus, and 10 million more doses are thought to be available elsewhere in the European Union. But Britain has some 44 million sheep, 11.3 million cattle and 7.2 million pigs.
Within Europe, the Netherlands has treated a far smaller outbreak with vaccination surrounding an infected area, coupled with the slaughter of infected animals and healthy ones within a two-mile radius.
Such is the scale of the disease in Britain, however, that delays in removing culled animals from farms and even their incineration on pyres that draw smoke across the countryside have helped spread the disease. "You cannot guarantee that you are not putting virus particles into the atmosphere" from the pyres, Professor Wimpenny said.
The British authorities and some scientists have argued that vaccination, even as an emergency measure, is unreliable, costly and would divert personnel from destroying animals. Not only that, vaccination can take one or two days to take effect, meaning that animals could pass on the disease during that period.
But the counterargument, which the government now seems to be considering, is that, as an emergency measure, vaccination would act as a reinforcement to mass culling.
"You can use vaccine very quickly and still cull animals," said Peter Midmore, a professor of rural studies at the University of Wales.
"The role for vaccination is to achieve widespread protection and lower the risk of infection."

HEADLINE: Political Memo; 
Bush Shapes His Presidency With Sharp Eye on Father's

BYLINE:  By RICHARD L. BERKE 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 27 

 BODY:
When George W. Bush was elected governor of Texas in his first try at a statewide office, a close friend marveled at his rather glitch-free campaign. The friend recalled that Mr. Bush told him, "Never underestimate what you can learn from a failed presidency."
 While Mr. Bush does not consider his father to have been a failure as president, people who know him say he does view his father's tenure as a supreme disappointment, simply because the elder Mr. Bush could not persuade voters to re-elect him. They say the former governor blames the people around his father, as well as himself, for not working hard enough to ensure that re-election in 1992. 
 Now that George W. Bush has reached the White House, no one should underestimate how his approach to the presidency has been molded by the experiences of the elder President Bush, and his desire to avoid the mistakes that he believes cost his father a second term. 
That is why, his friends and associates say, the 43rd president has been far more inclined than the 41st to mix politics with governing, to show deference (some even say reverence) to conservatives, to demand loyalty from aides and to pursue an ambitious but more narrowly focused agenda.
"When you've got a functional family, doesn't everybody learn from their father and mother?" asked Gov. William J. Janklow of South Dakota, who is close to the president and his father.
The contrasts between father and son have much to do with personality. George W. Bush has been far more hospitable to Congress than his father, who actually served in Congress, perhaps because the younger Mr. Bush is, by nature, a more gregarious politician.
But the times and circumstances are different, too. As president, Mr. Bush's father had to contend with the fiercely partisan George J. Mitchell, the Senate leader, and a Democratic-led Congress in no mood to be courted.
"It's not Bush 41st's fault that there was a George Mitchell reign of terror in those days," said Richard N. Bond, whom the first President Bush installed as Republican Party chairman. "They wanted to destroy Bush's presidency."
The times may have changed, but here are some lessons that Bush II has gleaned from Bush I:

Politics Is Not a Dirty Word
Campaign-style trips, like the two-day, three-state tour Mr. Bush began on Monday, were not so common in the elder Mr. Bush's administration. Once he was in the White House, Bush No. 41 cringed at the thought of blatantly political activity; he seemed to view it as an ugly chore. He was slow, even, to start his re-election drive. The younger Mr. Bush has since expressed his concern that his father never made the most, politically, of his soaring popularity after the Persian Gulf war.
In reaction -- and in a nod to the political success enjoyed by President Bill Clinton -- the current president has not hesitated to venture onto the road to pitch his tax cut.
"Sometimes my words in Washington don't exactly translate directly to the people," Mr. Bush said today in Kalamazoo, Mich., "so I found it's best to travel the country."
Thus far, Mr. Bush has been on the road nearly a third of his time in office, far more than his father, Mr. Clinton, Ronald Reagan or Jimmy Carter in their first two months in office. In all, the president has traveled to 25 states and spent nearly 30 days away from the White House. (His father had spent about 17 days on the road by now; Mr. Clinton, roughly a dozen.)
"He talks about using his political capital wisely," said Karen P. Hughes, Mr. Bush's counselor. "I've heard him say his father had a great deal of political capital from Desert Storm that could have been spent more wisely."
Attention to politics has permeated the administration. Mr. Bush's address to Congress last month was one example of the way he has packaged his proposals in a disciplined and systematic way, focusing on a handful of big themes. His father's addresses to Congress reflected a much more scattershot approach. 
Mark McKinnon, who was Mr. Bush's campaign media adviser, said that by watching his father early on, "he learned that the crisis of the moment should be seen in the context of a much longer picture."

Don't Tolerate a Sununu
When President Bush's friends are asked about lessons learned from the father, they invariably cite former Gov. John H. Sununu of New Hampshire, the elder Mr. Bush's first chief of staff.
Mr. Sununu had no Washington seasoning and was widely viewed as a divisive figure in the White House, but the elder Mr. Bush felt indebted to him because Mr. Sununu had helped him win the New Hampshire primary. Mr. Sununu was pushed out of his job only after the younger Mr. Bush, in an unbridled conversation, let him know of the dissatisfaction. 
And for years the elder Mr. Bush stood by Nicholas F. Brady, his old friend and Treasury secretary, even as conservatives repeatedly called for his resignation.
"Loyal to a fault" was how one friend described the ex-president.
The son, on the other hand, expects loyalty from below and appears less tolerant of people who are not team players. Mr. Bush has had a closer and longer relationship with his top orbit of aides than his father did with Mr. Sununu.
His aides also say Mr. Bush knows not to let them linger on when they are not succeeding. It was no accident that Mr. Bush quickly dispatched Linda Chavez when her nomination for labor secretary ran into trouble.
And Mr. Bush is intent on keeping backstabbing to a minimum.
"He was the one who gave Sununu his marching orders," said Gregory Slayton, president of an e-mail marketing company who is a friend of Bush the father and son. "Loyalty is a big deal. He talked about that all the time. He felt that in the re-election campaign for his dad, some of the professional staff didn't fight it out at the end. They were more concerned about their next job than getting his dad re-elected."

Be Nice to Alan Greenspan
From the start, the first President Bush had a strained relationship with Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve chairman. In fact, he blamed Mr. Greenspan for costing him the election by not moving fast enough to speed the recovery from the recession of the early 1990's.
"I reappointed him and he disappointed me," the elder Mr. Bush once said.
Mindful, perhaps, that it did not help his father to be on Mr. Greenspan's bad side, the younger Mr. Bush has tried to seduce his father's foe. He sought him out for a meeting even before taking office, clapped a hand on his shoulder and said, "I talked with a good man right here."
The entreaties may reflect the determination of Mr. Bush not to let the economy tarnish his presidency, as happened with his father.
While the elder Mr. Bush suffered because the economy did not improve in time to help him get re-elected, his son may be paying the price for an economic picture that he inherited. Successful or not, the son seems more aggressive in promoting his economic policies.
"The lesson learned from the economic side of former President Bush's administration is you have to market the policy well," said Ron Kaufman, an adviser to the elder Mr. Bush. 

Protect Your Right
A most obvious lesson Mr. Bush has learned from his father is to stroke conservatives. While conservatives never trusted the elder Mr. Bush, his son has gone out of his way to win them over. He is filling jobs at all levels of his administration with conservatives, from Attorney General John Ashcroft to the White House staff. And he has embraced conservative positions on matters including abortion and the environment, with his opposition to regulating carbon dioxide emissions from power plants and to stricter standards on arsenic in drinking water.
"This fellow saw the right wing crush his father," said Robert S. Strauss, the former Democratic chairman who is an old Texas friend of the elder President Bush. "He's not going to let anyone get too far to the right of him. In fact, he's overreacting a bit right now, and it's going to come home to haunt him."
Rahm Emanuel, a senior aide to Mr. Clinton, argues that the public is not as tilted to the right as the new president. "He's done everything to assure that the base of the party is happy going into the midterms," Mr. Emanuel said, "but he's done nothing to expand the 49 percent of the vote he got. Name me a suburban district that supports more arsenic in water."

Vice President Does Matter
An obvious lesson is that Mr. Bush picked a vice president who has been tested. People close to Mr. Bush said he heeded his father's counsel in settling on Dick Cheney -- and was determined not to tarnish his presidency with a vice president like Dan Quayle, who was continually criticized as not being ready for the job.
"Clearly, Dick Cheney is no Dan Quayle," Mr. Slayton said.
